
2	306 Lunar Landing Plates Year Released: 1979 Piece Count: 2 Minifigs: 0 List Price: unknown As part of the Classic Space Collection, Lego offered two sets of moon plates.

2	One was a set of two crater plates, and the other, this very useful Landing Plate set.

2	Not much to review, but worth sharing a few images: The landing plate: And T-Plate: The two plates connect to form this very nice Classic Space landing platform: Set 497, Galaxy Explorer included the landing platform, but the one that I had was lighter in color than the one contained in this set (at least the yellow circle).

2	Future Lego space sets could benefit by having similar road plates.

2	Share your thoughts.

3	These are my only space base plates from Classic Space.

3	Actually, with only 2 plates, I could not do much serious expansion with it.

3	Instead, I merged it with my old city baseplates, and used it as a docking station for scientific purposes or restricted facilities that is guarded by the police.

3	These baseplates are very useful and is suited for creating a space command center, up in the space.

1	Year Released: 1976 Piece Count: 53 Minifigs: 2 LEGO brought out floating boats quite early, and in many ways the first were the best.

1	(I'll explain why later...) This set in particular is interesting as it came out in two versions; one that includes the first minifigs and another that included the non-armless type.

1	(Set 709.)

1	The police signs are stickers, and are in surprisingly good condition considering the age of the set.

1	(I am missing one sticker on the front though.)

1	Note the Technic Bush and Axel; they are the old type.

1	The position of the second figure is not a mistake; I think he's supposed to be sitting down....

1	The first boats out by LEGO needed a weighted keel to prevent them.... keeling over.

1	(I have tested this!)

1	I suspect this is because of the density of the old hulls and the flat bottom... but I could be wrong.

1	(It can't be just because of the flat bottom as the new cargo ship doesn't need one.)

1	The keel in detail.

1	The bottom extension is for a motor.

1	(Not included, nor made by LEGO at the time.)

1	The keel had longer studs.

1	Even now it holds extra firmly.

1	This is why I prefer the old design.

1	You can extend or shorten the hulls as you please, or even insert other LEGO in the middle.

1	You can easily add wheels or any other piece to the bottom of these hulls.

1	I wish they would go back to this idea; the 4+ hulls were of this concept but were too wide.

1	(Probably so the keel wasn't needed.)

1	The old minifigs aside from having odd feet and no arms had a normal stud as the neck.

1	Thus when you turn the head it tends to come off.

1	I love this set!

3	I own the later version, 709 released in 1977.

3	Mine no longer has decals though.

3	The variations were minimal.

3	It looks like your boat is in really good shape considering it's >30 years old.

3	Excellent review!

3	well what to say?

3	i got this boat late 70s, when we were on our way to Italy to spend the holidays there.

3	My parents always needed to keep my quiet during the 3-day trip, and the best way to do that was to buy me a lego set...

3	I got this one in a gas station in Germany.

3	As far as I remember Italy didn't have lego sets, so a gas station close to the Italian border but still in Germany or Austria was very often their last chance.

3	I often saw large quantities of lego sets in those gas stations though... i remember seeing yellow castle and... the galaxy explorer, standing on a shelf.

3	It would be my birthday 1-3 week(s) later so i always made sure they knew what to buy for me...

3	As you may have seen in my topic in general LEGO discussion, I received a bunch of old LEGO from my step-grandmother-in-law.

3	Among the bricks were instructions and pieces for an almost complete set 345 from 1969.

3	I was very excited to find this out, so I put it together.

3	I recently took it apart and re-assembled it, taking photographs along the way for the sake of Eurobricks.

3	So, without further ado, set 345: House With Car.

3	First off is the car.

3	This was still constructed in the bucket of bricks I received, so I never took it apart: Next I'll show you the instructions.

3	Lots of added bricks per step, which was fun.

3	However, the angle of the instructions sometimes made it difficult to find where things were supposed to go.

3	The in-build shots.

3	Finally, an all-around view of the finished set.

3	Sadly, I don't have much time to post more pictures or thoughts.

3	However, I'll try to come back and update the review later this week.

3	Until then, enjoy!

3	Nice review, 'Mariko'!

3	This set is way past my time.

3	The baseplate is okay (though I hate those dots).

3	The car is pretty cool too...

3	Great review.

3	I never had this set, but it looks nice.

3	I really like the checker pattern near the big window.

2	Way before my time, too--in fact, this set came out twenty years before I was born!

2	The baseplate doesn't actually have dots--I'm not sure if they were there once, and then rubbed off (a possibility, as the studs are rather smoother than I imagine they once were), or if this particular one didn't have the dots.

2	This set also shows that the difficulty LEGO has in doing vehicle scale isn't new.

2	The house is the perfect size for microfigures from the LEGO Games; however, the car is massive--over twice as tall as a microfig!

3	Great Review Mariko!

3	This set is way before my time too.

3	I like how LEGO used to create simple one story houses instead of the really tall house that we see in today's Town Theme, such as 8403 City House.

3	One story houses such as 345 just look more realistic to my eyes.

3	The simplistic, minimalism vibe that I get with this set is something that is hard to find in today's much more detailed sets (although, trust me, I love love love today's detailed sets).

3	- The Brick is Epic

3	Image Link from Brickset I thought I would do a pic review of the 1st Lego Castle, The Yellow Castle, #375- released in 1978.

3	First, let me say that this set was truly "ahead of it's time".

3	It introduced new building concepts (such as the hinge and new figs (most were still the armless, faceless mini-figs during this time).

3	This set introduced me to Castle which was my first real favorite theme.

3	I enjoyed breaking it out from the garage and building it again.

3	The majority of the pieces are 1x1, 1x2, 1x3, 1x4, 1x6, and 1x8 standard yellow bricks.

3	The set also includes yellow 1x4, 1x6x2, and 1x8x2 arches, yellow 2x2, 2x3, and 2x4 bricks, various grey plates, 1x2 black inverted slopes, red drawbridge pieces, two classic red castle doors, 8 hinges (2 for each corner), and a few other nifty pieces including six red 1x1 windows.

3	A complete inventory is available at Peeron: 375 Inventory.

3	A view from the front.

3	The drawbridge is 6x8.

3	The front tower stands 12 1/3 bricks high (plenty of room for horses).

3	The drawbridge does work.

3	The string (originally black) is attached to the opposite side between a plate and the arches.

3	The right side of the castle (identical to the left).

3	I've always loved the 2x2x3 sloped bricks (and corner pieces): The back.

3	I love these red doors.

3	A 1x4 brick attached to the other side of the baseplate keeps intruders out.

3	That banner was the original sticker piece.

3	Notice the wear.

3	The rear tower, largest of the towers: And backside: Two hinges at each of the corners allow the corners to open for playability: Before opening: Open: Lots of arches add to the detail of the inner walls: Inner front: This set included 14 figs (how about that for quantity).

3	Unfortunately, I peeled off worn stickers from the shields and the breast plates years ago.

3	The blue castle guards and knights are the keepers of the castle.

3	I still think that these helmets are the best Lego ever made.

3	They just look good.

3	The black and white knights: And the red knights: I've always prefered to use the black and red guards and flags from the knight's joust set(s): Conclusion The Yellow Castle is truly a classic set and I'm so glad I kept the pieces to this together after all these years.

3	If you have a chance to buy one or even obtain the set instructions, it's worth building and wouldn't be difficult to substitute grey or other colors.

3	I hope you enjoyed this review and feel free to share your comments.

3	nice review!

2	kimt, on Dec 29 2005, 06:40 AM, said: ImperialJohn, on Dec 29 2005, 02:06 PM, said: You might find the stickers here I've searched that page before - It doesn't have the stickers, but it has a lot of other useful ones :oD TheBrickster send me a link to a page that has remakes of the good old classic shields and more, You can find it here [Thanks Brickster *satis* ] KimT From www.Classic-Castle.com, I opened the shield images, then copied and pasted them into PowerPoint.

2	They do need to be re-sized.

2	In US, I converted them to .59 inch width.

2	You could do the same in cm by converting to 1.5 cm wide.

2	I did the same with the torso stickers - same ratio.

2	I ended up with a PowerPoint sheet of multiple shields and torso designs.

2	Printed on sticker pages from a good quality photo-printer gives you very nice stickers.

2	The hard part is cutting them.

2	The results are the four knights pictured above.

2	The web site also has Forestmen and custom torso and shield designs that are very nice.

3	Theme: Hobby Sets Set name: Harley-Davidson 1000cc Set Number: 394 Price (new): 260-280 $, 185-200 Euro Price (used): 14-175 $, 10-125 Euro Pieces: 143 Year of release: 1976 Links: Peeron, Bricklink and Brickset Looking at the release date of this set makes me remember the good old times when LEGO sets stayed in production and could be found in stores for long years.

3	Yes, I hear you younger FOLs say this meant we had less variety at the time, but at least we did not have to go on a frenzy to get them all in just 1 or 2 years before they disappeared (to re-appear on the secondary market at crazy prices).

3	Anyway, I also realise this set is older than me by 5 years (at least the first boxes of this set).

3	I think my parents bought it when I was something like 1/2 year old, or even before, as my Father really liked the Hobby Set line and took any chance to get one, you know, for the kids, when theyâ€™ll be old enough to play with themâ€¦ I am really happy my Father did it, too.

3	As a matter of fact, this has always been one of my favourite non-minifigure scale sets.

3	I know younger eyes will look on it and wonder how we could love and enjoy a model like this, so blocky and rough.

3	Just remember this was the best TLG designers could do with the bricks available at the time.

3	Enough about memories; letâ€™s start with the review!

3	The Box Front The front of the box (here cut and folded to save space) shows the Harley Davidson 1000cc in all its glory upon a nice town landscape.

3	I really appreciate how TLG box designers used a real life photo of the model in a real life environment to give this Hobby Set a better background.

3	Moreover, the landscape does not distract the eye, even with its lights, since the focus is strongly set on the motorbike itself.

3	Back (and sides) The back of the box shows the model on a more neutral background and from another angle.

3	We can see the stickers in place (take a good look at them here, because I did not apply them).

3	The right side we also see a pic of the set from the front, and one with a child playing with it.

3	In this latter shot, the model rests upon a nice black box with a Harley Davidson sign on it.

3	I frankly do not remember if this was some sort of tray or smaller box within the LEGO one or if it is meant for publicity only.

3	Another thing we can notice on the right-most side of the box is a white band, right below the LEGO logo, sporting the sign â€˜Designed for experienced LEGO buildersâ€™ in various languages.

3	All in all, a really well done and professional job.

3	Contents Inside This set includes a number of parts in mainly Black, White and Light Grey.

3	Some Blue and Yellow add nice touches of colour to the total.

3	The partsâ€™ selection is not mind-blowing, as most of the pieces had been in production, in these same colours for years.

3	Anyway, Iâ€™d like to focus on a couple of details: The Milky White Technic axles as well as the Red Technic Bush Old 2 are among my favourite parts.

3	The bushes, in particular, are quite useful to build more sturdy looking tubes than what can be achieved with the newer and slimmer ones.

3	It would seem that the tile pieces appeared in the â€˜without groveâ€™ version as a standard and in the â€˜with groveâ€™ version as alternates (see Bricklink inventory).

3	Notice, though that the box (above) and instructionsâ€™ (below) pictures all show the â€˜with groveâ€™ variety.

3	As said, there are no re-coloured parts in this set.

3	New pieces The few new molds used in this set are: Black and White Slope, Inverted 45 2 x 2 Old Type with Round Bottom Tube, Black Technic, Brick 1 x 2 with Hole Type II and Red Hinge Plate 2 x 4 with Articulated Joint â€“ Male and Female.

3	The most interesting piece from this lot, as many of you will have noticed is the Technic, Brick 1 x 2 with Hole Type II.

3	This kind of technic brick was use during 1976 and 1977 only.

3	It would seem TLG tried a new design variant, which did not meet success and was later replaced with the standard bricks again.

3	Nonetheless, Iâ€™m sure that people who own these bricks like them for the unusual design and the possibilities they offer into adding details to their creations.

3	Instructions Cover â€“ As usual, the instructions are not organised in the form of a booklet, but they consist of a folded double printed sheet.

3	The â€˜coverâ€™ shows again the same shot as the front of the box, with bigger LEGO logo and set number and without the other additional information.

3	â€˜Back coverâ€™ â€“ Here we see the full name of the set: Harley-Davidson FLH 1200.

3	This makes me wonder: why is this set known as 394 Harley Davidson 1000cc when it is indeed a 1200cc?

3	Anyway, what really makes me love this page is the list of stats below the photo, and in particular these two lines: H.P.

3	(?

3	)/(not given).

3	This calls for just one question: why did Harley-Davidson not release this info?

3	My opinion is that since this is a motorbike built for the Police, they did not have permission to share the specifications on the motor, which was probably customised either by Harley-Davidson upon request or by the Police themselves.

3	â€˜Random pageâ€™ â€“ As expected, no call-outs here, but the build is pretty straight forward and does not need them (apart for one passage weâ€™ll see later).

3	The colours are easy to tell apart (in the end there is no Dark Grey in this set that could be confused with Black).

3	Again, notice how the instructions include the â€˜with groveâ€™ tiles and not the older ones.

3	Maybe this was changed during the long time this set stayed in production?

3	The â€˜last pageâ€™ shows other four models included in the Hobby Set line.

3	Unfortunately, I own only one of them: the 396 Thatcher Perkins Locomotive.

3	Indeed, I would have liked to have them all!

3	Building Start The handle bars look a bit too squared to me, but itâ€™s just a minor feature, and the overall shape is still good in my opinion.

3	Notice the red hinge plate, which will be almost totally hidden in the finished model (see below), and the blue tiles which work as indicators.

3	The first steps, used to build the front wheel and windshield are really easy, until you get to the wheel.

3	In facts, the instructions do not show clearly all the pieces needed for it, and I found myself with a â€˜floatingâ€™ wheel for the absence of one of the Red Technic Bush Old 2 on one side (the one not visible on the instructions, of course).

3	Not a big deal, but something that could have been done better.

3	Motor and seat The second part of the build includes the motor, seat and â€˜saddle bagsâ€™.

3	The technique used for the motor, or better the radiator, is very clever.

3	To get the ridged feel, TLG designers used 4 Light Grey plates stuck one on the other but not completely in contact.

3	This way, the studs, while keeping the plates in position, keep them raised from one another at the same time.

3	The Yellow round bricks add some details and colour touches to this predominantly Light Grey parts of the vehicle.

3	The use of the Engine, Smooth Small, 1 x 2 Side Plates for the exhaust pipes, while quite clever, still looks a bit strange to me.

3	Iâ€™m mostly used to see them in airplanes, helicopters and spaceships.

3	â€˜Saddle-bagsâ€™, a simple build for one of the iconic parts of this motorcycle.

3	Here you see them in place, as well as get a look at the finished seat.

3	I like how LEGO designers managed to make its shape with just a few quite big bricks.

3	The â€˜saddle bagsâ€™ are a really nice touch, and they work perfectly when compared to the original.

3	This is the rear wheel.

3	As said before, only when you get to this passage in the instruction you get a real understanding of how the front wheel is supposed to be mounted as well.

3	Careful readers will notice how this is not one of the original wheels in this set.

3	The original ones were mounted using the Technic, Gear Expert Builder 9 Tooth.

3	Unfortunately, I could only find one of them in my collection, an itâ€™s used as the front wheel.

3	By adding the rear wheel (which is shown from a better angle in the instructions), we complete the model.

3	Notice how the two technic bricks supporting the wheel are held in position by two 2x1 plates.

3	I think this was a bad case of â€˜building by compartmentsâ€™ mentality: if TLG designers had considered this a bit more, they would have used 2 4x1 plates instead of 4 2x1.

3	On the other hand, this is not the worst case I have seen in a LEGO set, and they keep up the tradition nowadays too.

3	Finished set Front And here it is our fancy Police Harley-Davidson!

3	Indeed, the front looks blocky and quite horrible to our eyes, but again, it was almost the best that could be done at the time.

3	I only wish they had made it a little less bulky, even though this build is clearly thought to give better stability to the wheel.

3	The Blue tiles work nicely to emphasise the indicators, the slightly unsightly red plate is normally covered by the plate sticker and the windshield, albeit being hard to see through, is nicely shaped.

3	Back The back side is less detailed than the front, but shows the red light and antenna which are typical of the Police motorbikes from this period.

3	How many times have we seen this angle in the chase scenes from TV shows like â€œCHiPsâ€?

3	Side All in all, this model looks pretty sturdy (apart for the antenna, which falls off all too easily) and detailed, especially considering the limited variety of parts available and used at the time.

3	They even got so far to put a 2x2 tile as kick-stand to display it without fear of it falling on the sides!

3	Bonus images Size comparison?

3	What I never understood about this set is what scale it is meant to be.

3	I mean, it is clearly not minifig-scale, and it could not be technic-fig-scale (those came later).

3	But it is not even Miniland scale!

3	Moreover, the only other model with the same scale is the other Hobby Set motorbike, as the cars have a scale of their own and the Thatcher uses still another one!

3	Final comments Overall, this is a great set for collectors of old models and motorbike fans, or both.

3	It does not sport a huge variety of bricks, but was a good choice at the time, and even if the result is matter-of-fact blocky when compared to the original, it implements some good solutions to minimise the LEGO brick appearance and maximise the similarity as much as possible.

3	Design & Colour scheme â€“ 9/10 (The design is as accurate as possible, apart for the front mudguard maybe, and the colours are completely in line for a Police vehicle.

3	The solutions and details included in this set justify the â€˜Expert buildersâ€™ label and add to the appearance, and, why not, playability of the model.)

3	Parts - 8/10 (Not a huge selection, and very few new molds.

3	Nonetheless, a good source of Black and White standard parts for MOCs and one of the few sources for the extra rare Technic, Brick 1 x 2 with Hole Type II pieces.)

3	Playability - 9/10 (A sturdy model which can take some serious play and swoosh-ing without falling apart.

3	The easily detachable antenna and the lack of an appropriate scale interaction with most other models make it lose one point, though.)

3	Build - 7/10 (Pretty straight forward, with few nice solutions and an already mentioned slightly obscure passage in the instructions.)

3	Price - 5/10 (Like most older models, especially the Hobby Set and Model Team ones, this set can be found at reasonable prices only rarely.

3	Most of the times, people are asked shameful prices for such a smallish set.)

3	Overall: 8/10 Very good.

3	As always, questions, comments, and pic requests welcome!

3	Edited by WhiteFang, 17 April 2011 - 06:19 PM.

3	The various elements are instantly recognizable and it even has the unusual 'partly-stacked' plates technique for the motor.

3	Overall, I'd say this is an above average set that is a must-have for any hardcore LEGO collector.

3	Brick On Ride On Everyone !

3	Great review for a classic model.

3	I love it.

3	Theme: Hobby Sets Set name: Thatcher Perkins Locomotive Set Number: 396 Price (new): 369-450 $, 258-314 Euro Price (used): 100-355 $, 45-250 Euro Pieces: 434 Year of release: 1976 Links: Peeron, Bricklink and Brickset My Father assures me this is the very first LEGO set I ever got.

3	In facts, he gave it to me as a present for my first half year.

3	Of course, that is to say he bought it for himself and used me as the official excuse!

3	When I grew up, at first I found it to be quite boring: no minifigures, limited play features; in the end, it was just a locomotive!

3	It soon went to forgotten-land.

3	Then, when I was about 10 years old, I one day found again the instructionsâ€™ â€˜bookletâ€™ and saw this bright coloured big steam engine, and I suddenly wanted to build it again.

3	It would seem I finally got to the right age (at least for me) to appreciate the design of this great set.

3	But enough about memories; letâ€™s start with the review!

3	The Box Front The front of the box (here cut and folded to save space) shows the Thatcher Perkins Locomotive in all its glory upon a nice countryside landscape.

3	I really appreciate how TLG box designers used a real life environment made of sand, gravel and pebbles to give this Hobby Set a better background.

3	Moreover, the landscape does not distract the eye, since the focus is strongly set on the locomotive itself.

3	The box measures about 39.5 x 24.5 x 5.5 centimetres, or 15.56 x 9.65 x 2.17 inches.

3	This is more or less the size of the 4840 - The Burrow, or the Advent Calendars.

3	Back (and sides) The back of the box shows the model on a more neutral background and from another angle.

3	We can see the stickers in place (take a good look at them here, because I did not apply them).

3	The right side we also see a pic of the set from the (3/4) back, and one with a child playing with it.

3	In this latter shot, the model rests upon a nice black box with a Thatcher Perkins sign on it.

3	Unlike the Harley Davidson 1000cc set, the Thatcher Perkins does not have the sign â€˜Designed for experienced LEGO buildersâ€™ for some reason.

3	Contents Inside This set includes a large number of parts, mainly Black, Blue and Red, with some nice Yellow to lighten it up more.

3	Parts of interest The partsâ€™ selection is not exceptional, but weâ€™ll see this set includes some unique pieces which have not been in LEGO sets for long years since the 1980s, like the very nice Black Plate, Modified 1 x 2 with Steam Engine Cylinder, Flat Surfaces, Black Train Wheel Spoked for Motor and the Red Train Steam Drive Rod Holder - Train Steam Drive Rod group.

3	The Wheel Spoked Large, as beautiful as they were, saw the light from the production line for the last time in 1976!

3	The only new mold used in this set is the Black and Blue Slope, Inverted 45 2 x 2 Old Type with Round Bottom Tube.

3	As you can see in the above picture, this locomotive was designed to work (well, be played with) on all kind of surfaces, so the wheels sport tyres.

3	In this picture you can see how they look without the tyres.

3	Of course, builders can use the Thatcher Perkins on their brick-built tracks.

3	Another group of interesting parts are shown in this pic: Red Wheel Spoked 2 x 2 with Stud (and tyre), Black Brick, Modified 2 x 4 with Wheels Holder Old, Clear Bottom and Yellow Minifig, Head (Plain) - Stud Solid.

3	Many newer fans will not be familiar with the last two parts: they were standard fare in a number of sets between the 1960s and early 1990s, but then (unfortunately) they were taken out of production.

3	To be fair, the replacement of the Black Brick, Modified 2 x 4 with Wheels Holder Old, Clear Bottom with the standard technic parts was probably due to the fact that the metal pin used to connect the wheels to these bricks had a shameful tendency at getting off the wheel.

3	Too bad it could not be fixed and these parts kept in production.

3	For those interested, here is a picture of the DSS, courtesy of Peeron.

3	Instructions Cover â€“ As usual, the instructions are not organised in the form of a booklet, but they consist of a folded double printed sheet.

3	The â€˜coverâ€™ shows again the same shot as the front of the box.

3	â€˜Back coverâ€™ â€“ Here we see the name of the set and some additional information, like the year when the first Thatcher Perkins started working (1863) and the type (4-6-0) of this locomotive, which, as shown in the image, is related to the number and position of the wheels.

3	On a side note, the pencil signs on the sides of the sheet were made by my Father while counting the parts in the set.

3	â€˜Random pageâ€™ â€“ As expected, no call-outs here, but the build is pretty straight forward and does not need them.

3	The colours are easy to tell apart.

3	Full page â€“ As you may have noticed, all the building steps are drawn on one side of the â€˜bookletâ€™, making it more properly an instructionsâ€™ sheet.

3	What really makes this â€˜instruction bookletâ€™ stand out in my eyes is the fact that it is indeed a poster: the building steps are all on one side, while the other is a bigger image of the completed set with the name Thatcher Perkins in yellow enclosed in an old styled red tag.

3	Building Start The build starts with the base of the locomotive, putting the 10 wheels in place and strengthening the engine.

3	Notice the use of this â€˜illegalâ€™ technique to build the bumpers.

3	LEGO, as we all know can be a tricky medium to build with, and some details need special solutions to be completed.

3	We then start building the boiler and cabin.

3	Going up fast and steady!

3	In the penultimate step, we build the chimney and cow catcher.

3	Iâ€™d like to spend a few more words on the chimney and how it is attached to the main body.

3	As you can see in the left picture, the 3x3 base of the chimney is asymmetrical, with a 3x2 base on one side and a combination of a 1x2 and a 1x1 plates on the other.

3	In the right picture, you see the top of the main body where the chimney will be attached; it is made of a 1x2 base and 1 1x2 tile.

3	Using another â€˜illegalâ€™ technique (or at least one LEGO designers do not like much nowadays), the holes of the 3x2 plate of the chimney will connect with the studs of the 1x2 plate on the main body, giving a well centred and quite sturdy build.

3	Finished set Front The front of the model sports 3 big headlights, a nice cow catcher and the nicely detailed engine front.

3	I can almost hear it whistle!

3	Side And here it is our good old Thatcher Perkins Locomotive!

3	Indeed, it looks like a classic and powerful engine form one of those Spaghetti Western films, doesnâ€™t it?

3	What I found strange in the beginning is the choice of colours (I was convinced steam engines were all black, at the time).

3	Then I checked some pictures of the original, and I must admit the resemblance is almost perfect!

3	Back The back side is less detailed than the front, with cabin almost devoid of details.

3	I think LEGO could have done a better job on it.

3	3/4 Front and â€¦ Just see how good it looks from this angle, with all the tubing, moving parts and the lovely 3 headlights!

3	â€¦ 3/4 Back The back view is not as impressive, but grants us a good look at the big posterior wheels and the bumpers.

3	Bonus images Size comparison?

3	As I stated elsewhere, I never understood what scale these Hobby Sets are meant to be.

3	They are clearly not minifig-scale, and they are not technic-fig-scale either.

3	But they are not even Miniland scale!

3	Moreover, they use different scales between locomotives, cars and motorbikes amongst the Hobby Set line!

3	As I said before, the set comes with tyres on the wheels to allow a wider playing experience, not limiting this model to tracks.

3	Nonetheless, builders can assemble their own track (maybe using the vintage blue 4.5V tracks) and make the Thatcher Perkins run its proper environment.

3	Final comments Overall, this is a great set for collectors of old models and steam engines fans, or both.

3	It does not sport a huge variety of bricks, but was a good choice at the time, and even if the result is matter-of-fact a bit blocky when compared to the original, it implements some good solutions to minimise the LEGO brick appearance and maximise the similarity as much as possible.

3	Design & Colour scheme â€“ 8/10 (The design is as accurate as possible, and the colours are completely in line for the Thatcher Perkins Locomotive.

3	The solutions and details included in this set justify the â€˜Expert buildersâ€™ label and add to the appearance, and, why not, playability of the model.

3	Though, I still wish TLG had included more details in the cabin.)

3	Parts - 10/10 (Quite a big selection, but only one new mould.

3	Nonetheless, a good source of Black, Blue and Red standard parts for MOCs and one of the few sources for the extra rare Black Plate, Modified 1 x 2 with Steam Engine Cylinder, Flat Surfaces, Black Train Wheel Spoked for Motor, Red Train Steam Drive Rod Holder - Train Steam Drive Rod group and Wheel Spoked Large.)

3	Playability - 9/10 (A sturdy model which can take some serious play and swoosh-ing without falling apart.

3	The somewhat easily detachable chimney and the lack of an appropriate scale interaction with most other models make it lose one point, though.)

3	Build - 7/10 (Pretty straight forward, with few nice solutions.)

3	Price - 5/10 (Like most older models, especially the Hobby Set and Model Team ones, this set can only rarely be found at reasonable prices.

3	Most of the times, people are asked shameful prices for such a smallish set.)

3	Overall: 8/10 Very good.

3	More pictures can be found in this Brickshelf gallery.

3	As always, questions, comments, and pic requests welcome!

3	Edited by Rufus, 10 July 2011 - 07:05 PM.

3	Overall I think it's a really good set at that time, of course judging this one by modern standards won't be fair but at the time I'm pretty sure it was a 'cool' set to have (though less cooler than having the Harley Davidson set).

3	INDEXED 410 â€“ Payloader Theme: Legoland/Vehicle Piece Count: 28 Year Released: 1973 MSRP: ???

3	Links: Brickset, Lugnet, Peeron, Bricklink *Note: This set was released under the number 604 outside of the U.S.* Ah, classic Legoland.

3	A time before mini-figs ever existed, and cars and buildings could be made with just a few bricks.

3	The part selection was pretty basic: bricks, plates, slopes, windows and wheels were all you needed to construct an entire town.

3	Heavy machinery could be modeled in 4-wide and be just a few bricks tall.

3	For this review we will be taking a look at the 410 Payloader, one of LEGOâ€™s first sets of a bucket loader.

3	So grab a hard hat, we are heading to the construction yard!

3	Box image courtesy of Bricklink.

3	Box Contents Here we have our instructions which are obviously the older style of LEGO instructions.

3	The steps used much simpler imagery, but they get the job done.

3	They show how to build the Payloader in seven steps.

3	This small set has all of 28 parts in it.

3	The more interesting parts of note are the red digger arm, the bucket, the blue 1X2 brick with arm holes, and the blue 2X2 brick with the classic LEGO logo printed on it.

3	Construction In the first few steps we start building up the base.

3	Then add the arms and start building the cab.

3	Add the bucket, the trailer socket and finish the cab.

3	Throw on some wheels.

3	Completed Set And with that we are finished with our nice small model.

3	Here is the back right side.

3	Notice how the back of the cab was left with an empty spot.

3	Here is the left side.

3	Notice how on the top of the arm they made it so you could just push down on the tips it to make the arm lift instead of having to grab by the arm itself.

3	On the front we have the nice LEGO logo shown to remind the forgetful of what they were playing with.

3	You can also see how much space is in the bucket itself, which can't hold more than a few small plates.

3	Finally on the back we have the trailer socket.

3	This was a nice addition to make it able to tow trailers from other sets like 685.

3	Just donâ€™t try to bring it into your layout populated by mini-figs, they may have a problem trying to get in.

3	Other Thoughts Considering this set is nearly 37 years old, I myself am still surprised by how well the bricks have held up.

3	I purchased this set from a thrift store a year ago for a mere 25 cents.

3	Normally when used LEGO is purchased you can expect to see scratches, marks, wearing, discoloration, etc but boy was I surprised to see how all these parts are in mint condition.

3	Even the instructions still looked like they came from a new box and not all ripped up and tattered.

3	The pieces still connect to each other nice and tight and the metal pieces for the wheels haven't rusted.

3	This just shows that with proper care these things can last a lifetime.

3	I really would like to get a small display case to show it off.

3	Conclusion Playability: 8/10 In addition to the standard of having rolling wheels, you also get a fully movable bucket assembly.

3	With it you can pick up smaller pieces and unload them into a dump truck.

3	Design: 7/10 Like all other Legoland vehicles it has a very basic design, but you can still easily identify what it is.

3	Simple yet effective.

3	Parts: 7/10 Like most other older LEGO sets, all you really get are a few basic bricks and plates.

3	However, you do get a bucket assembly and the 2X2 brick with the classic LEGO logo on it is very cool.

3	It was also nice of LEGO to include the trailer socket so you could tow around your trailers.

3	Price: 8/10 Bricklink's history shows them to sell for around $10 USD used.

3	While that is a bit much for a set this size, it is pretty good considering this set is over 37 years old.

3	However, if you are looking for a new boxed set be prepared to fork over about $50 USD.

3	Overall: 8/10 This small machine would make a nice addition to your collection as a reminder of LEGO's past.

3	So what are your thoughts on this classic set?

2	Well, it's not exactly a large shuttle, but still a nice set: 442 Space Shuttle Year Released: 1979 Piece Count: 79 Minifigs: 1 Vehicles: 0 List Price: unknown This little classic was my smallest classic space set.

2	Believe it or not, I still have the box: Here's the back: The instructions are pretty tattered and missing a section.

2	I had to download some from the web: But the ship is again intact, missing only one grey 1x3 plate: I've always liked this computer piece: Here's the under side.

2	This set included the small classic jet engines: A close-up of the sloped printed space brick: And the complete set with minifig: This set was a great little space ship that made a nice addition to the Blue Space Theme.

2	As small as it was, it could hold two-three figs (one standing up).

2	I don't even think the Mars Mission Recon Drop Ship holds three figs.

2	In any case, it was a must-have for Blue Space Fans, and probably only a few bucks back in the day.

2	SWOOSH!

2	INDEXED Everyone remembers their first time.

2	For me, it was in 19*cough*somethingsomething*cough*.

2	We were at her house, and her mother was gone for at least an hour.

2	She slowly unzi... uhhh.

2	Sorry, wrong story.

2	Um, yeahh.

2	Anyway, I do remember my first time.

2	It was 1977, in late summer.

2	Our neighbor, who worked for a department store called Famous-Bahr, said that the main store had a travelling LEGO display.

2	So my family filed into the car and drove into downtown St Louis to see this display.

2	To tell you the truth, I don't remember much about the display itself, but I DO remember that my parents bought me my first LEGO set.

2	Set # 456, the Spirit of St Louis.

2	Set #: 456 (also sold as Set # 661) Name: Spirit of St Louis Theme: LEGOLAND / Large Vehicle Year: 1977 Pieces: 49 Minifigs: 0 Price: $5.00 USD?

2	(Bricklink MISB start @ $175.00 USD, Used Complete ~$35.00 USD) Links: Peeron, Bricklink, Brickset Packaging Box Front: The original box that my set came in was most likely trashed 5 minutes after returning home.

2	This image was lovingly stolen off of the Peeron page for this set.

2	I feel lucky that I even got this much.

2	Similarly, I have no pictures of the plastic baggies the set came in.

2	Truth be told, I can't be sure that there even WERE plastic baggies that the parts came in.

2	THE SET Side View: Well there she is.

2	My first set ever .

2	Actually, I seem to recall the real Spirit of St Louis was silver colored, not Black and Yellow.

2	If you need a history lesson, the Spirit of St Louis was Charles Lindbergh's plane when he made the first trans-Atlantic solo flight.

2	More details can be found on the Wikipedia page.

2	The overall shape is pretty close, at least.

2	The cockpit window could stand to be moved forward one stud, but everything seems to be relatively close.

2	The tail piece isn't the right shape, but it is likely the only tail piece LEGO produced at the time.

2	If you look closely, you can see the various bite marks that my brother and I inflicted over the years.

2	I know some people would be aghast that there are bite marks, but brick separators wouldn't come out for another 10 years.

2	Besides, we were young.

2	We didn't know any better.

2	I certainly had no idea that it would become my obsession.

2	There are some interesting part choices here.

2	Everything is brick and plate built, as you might expect.

2	The same set nowadays would have lots of slope, wedges and wedge plates to round things out.

2	But LEGO was all about the brick in '77, so bricks are what we got.

2	The black inverted slopes worked pretty well asthetically as the wing struts.

2	The wings are simple 4 x 10 plates, nice and square.

2	There were no minifigs in this set.

2	If I remember correctly, 1977 was just about the time when minifigs made their first appearance.

2	I know I have one other set from '77 that does include a minifg, at least.

2	I don't have a lot of comments for the following photos.

2	I'll let the pictures speak for themselves.

2	3/4 View Back Back 3/4 Top Front PARTS Interesting Pieces I have no idea if there were any extra pieces that came with this set.

2	I kind of doubt it.

2	Instead I took a photo of some of the interesting parts to the model.

2	That translucent white piece didn't photograph so well, but it is a Technic Axle 8.

2	That's right, sets from 1977 contained Technic elements.

2	The two black parts are the forerunners to the 1 x 2 Technic Brick, as well.

2	Everytime I hear someone on the forums complain about Technic elements in system sets, I think back to this set.

2	The round brick is special as well.

2	Here is a closer view of it, complete with bite marks .

2	Round Brick As you can see, the stud is closed.

2	It is only one of two closed stud 1 x 1 Round Bricks that I own.

2	They stopped appearing in sets in 1981, for those that are interested.

2	The DSS You thought you were going to escape this heading, didn't you?

2	Surprise!

2	Yes, even in 1977 LEGO sets had stickers.

2	The oldest printed elements I can remember were in the Classic Space sets that started in 1979.

2	Again, when people in the forums complain about DSS in sets, I can only help think of this set.

2	And chuckle to myself maniacally.

2	The sticker has held up really well considering it's been stuck on the brick for 32 years.

2	No discoloration, very little curling.

2	I think if all stickers held up this well over time, there would be less DSS complaints.

2	THE RATINGS Playability: 6/10 - The set is quite swooshable, and the propellor spins.

2	Outside of that, though... Minifigs: N/A Design: 6/10 - The overall shape is quite good, especially given the era.

2	The color choice leaves a lot to be desired.

2	Price: 1/10 - It's been retired for 30 years.

2	It's going to cost you to get your hands on it.

2	Overall: 13/30 - This set is for true collectors only.

2	I can't imagine anyone wanting one because they want to play with it.

2	It was a great set back in the day, but the design feels REALLY dated.

2	And if you're wondering, mine is NOT for sale.

2	Ever.

2	All the photos, plus more, can be found in the Gallery.

3	Very brave to give an impression about one of the oldest sets ever reviewed!

3	A lot members here are younger than the set itself.

3	I think you will have to have grown up with it to like it.

3	Nowadays we have seen quite a few better airplanes than that one, for example this years 7643 .

3	But thanks for letting us know.

3	Btw., the 1x1 round brick with the solid stud is no.

3	3062a instead of 3062b (with the hollow stud).

3	I really like the design, it has an aesthetic value lacking from most official Lego planes and follows closely to the real thing (minus the colours), something that can't really be claimed for more recent sets.

3	483 Alpha-1 Rocket Base Year Released: 1979 Piece Count: 170 Minifigs: 3 Vehicles: 1 (two sections) List Price: unknown Despite the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty of 1968, Lego dared design a Rocket Base complete with a rocket system that may have had nuclear capability in 1979.

3	Luckily, the rocket was defective having rather flimsy white bricks that did not stay together well during launch attempts.

3	Lego scrapped its WMD program and the result was this classic "blue era" space set known as the Alpha-1 Rocket Base.

3	Instructions: On the backside of the instructions, the set is featured with the Space Command Center, Space Cruiser, and a few vehicle sets: The set includes three figs: And this great rocket fuel tanker: Here's the front section complete with computer: And the rocket fuel section: The set has some interesting features including the Control Section, Fuel Control, and Launch Pad: On top of the Control Section is a nicely design radar/tracking system: Here's the open control room: The Launch Pad and Fuel Control: The Fuel Control includes two sink pieces and blue steering wheels: And Lego's WMD (Weapon of Mass Destruction), the Alpha-1 on the Launch Pad: Here's a shot of the launching mechanism: Unfortunately, I have lost one of the blue sink/faucet pieces as well as a black hose: A close-up of the Alpha-1 Rocket.

3	The white bricks never stayed together well often times coming apart within your hands: The arming and guidance system was nicely designed: A view of the complete set: And another: This is a great set.

3	The base, fuel vehicle, and launch platform offers a great amount of playability.

3	My only complaint is the rocket (as mentioned above).

3	I don't think I ever played with it a sa kid because it always fell apart.

3	Legocastlegirl, on Jun 20 2007, 05:20 PM, said: i also think that this is a replacement for some windows and i like this idea, because i often see houses with that kind of "windows" There was once "windowtaxes" in the Netherlands.

3	When rich people became poor, they placed bricks in their window, so they paid less taxes.

3	Some older houses still has walls were once were windows.

3	Well, here are mine: I´ll hang on the my extra Blackhole Stormie a while more !

3	If Morten doesn´t come here and break it that is !

3	Well, now that I have some money, a trip to ToysRUs was obviously in my future, especially since my local TRU has much of the summer 2007 lineup.

3	When I got there, almost all the smaller Castle sets had been sold out, but there was one left: the one I am now reviewing for both Eurobricks and BZPower.

3	;-) The Box: Well, for starters, the Castle theme boxes are beautiful!

3	The blended clear and stormy skies give a great ?clash of the titans?

3	effect, and the action poses help as well.

3	;-) The back is equally nice, featuring a photo showing kids how to use the crossbow, and the brave axe wielder taking a swipe at the skeleton (foolish soldier, that won?t work on skellies!

3	See later on in the review to find out why).

3	And of course, we have a small box with the link to the official Lego website, where TLC can advertise even more Lego sets!

3	:P The Contents: After opening the box, a single bag of pieces (with a couple loose ones), the instruction manual and necessary catalog ( :-P ), and a new wider rubber band holder spilt out.

3	The instruction manual is clear as a bell.

3	No color trouble here, folks!

3	Also, it?s worth mentioning the nice background with the mountain and King?s castle silhouettes.

3	:-) Sorry that there's no picture, but I'll take one if someone wants to see it.

3	;-) The Pieces: For being a 5 dollar set (well, seven in my case.

3	Darn your above average prices, TRU!

3	), Crossbow Attack features a lot of nice pieces (as does the entire Castle lineup).

3	Notable elements include two large brown spoked wheels, two brown modified 1x1?s, a pearl gold slope end, and SIX dark blue modified 1x1x2/3 slopes!

3	The bulk of the pieces, however, are nothing special.

3	I?ll let the picture do the talking for this.

3	The accessories are by far the best parts in this kit.

3	Two different helmets in a beautiful shiny silver are my favorite, but I also really like the scythe (looks good for MOCing) and the round shield ( *wub* ), which are both brand new parts.

3	And can anyone not love the classic axe and crossbows?

3	Oh, and there?s a black lightsaber too, but that?s rather boring compared to the other parts.

3	:-P The Minifigures: Can you say, FOUR figures (including the horse)?!

3	That has to be a record for a regular 5 dollar set, at least in the present age of limited figures per set.

3	We?ll start out with the two Crown militia: a regular soldier and an archer.

3	Both have old faces, but they look spiffy with the shiny helmets and the superb torsos.

3	I?ll name the soldier Bravo the Stout and the archer Angler the Precise, for future references.

3	Now we come to the skellie.

3	Although some people dislike the new skeleton design, I personally prefer it to the old ones, since the arms are now poseable and the face much meaner.

3	The only problem is that the arms hang too low, but it?s not too noticeable when they have weapons in their hands.

3	And last, but not least, here?s the elusive skeleton horse.

3	I for one am very happy that TLC took advantage of that awesome prototype piece and made it into an official mass-production mold.

3	However, the horse is unfortunately one piece, but since regular Lego horses are as well, I don?t have a problem with it.

3	I do have a problem with the pose, however.

3	The legs are in quite an odd position, and I wonder why TLC didn?t make the front and back leg poses symmetrical.

3	Ah well.

3	The Finished Set: I have only two pictures here, since this set is so small.

3	First, here?s the completed crossbow.

3	I must say: FINALLY!

3	No more ridiculous horse mounted catapults or crazy fire wheel launchers!

3	Now we have realistic siege weapons, including the one included with 7090.

3	Plus, it actually launches okay, although not the best.

3	Here?s the other main attraction: the completed skeleton rider and horse.

3	I think it?s rather dramatic with that pose and the dark background, don?t you think?

3	;-) Playability: Okay, so there?s not much in this set, but a bit of imagination brings plenty of possibilities.

3	To show you what you can do, here?s a little story made only with this set.

3	;-) Overall Rating: Presentation: 9/10 Pieces: 8/10 Minifigures: 9/10 Finished model: 8/10 Playability: 8/10 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Final Score: 8.4/10 Crossbow Attack is a fine introduction into Castle, so I recommend it to any Lego fan, whether they are a castle nut or just want a cheap change of pace.

3	TLC has a knack with making great small kits these days, and I more than ever support them in their amazing rebound from their dark ages (between 1997 and 2004).

3	;-) Edited by KimT, 10 August 2008 - 01:33 PM.

1	Thanks for this review, and that great little comic!

1	About the skellies though (X-D), you have to admit that besides their long arms making the skellie legs look out of proportion, that they're just made poorly.

1	They're sticking straight out, as opposed to every other fig, which have a slight bend to make them look more natural.

1	Also, as I'm sure you've noticed, the pegs are on angles!

1	That makes it impossible for them to hold their weapons straight, and they can't even put their arms over their heads without stressing the plastic some...

1	I mean they're DEAD.

1	Well, at least undead, they're not supposed to be stiff, and personally I like the ragdoll look more, it makes them seem more dead :-P

3	Here is a review of the new Monster Dino creator set with power functions First lets start with the box which is much larger than it needs to be!!

3	It is one of the new style re-closeable boxes rather than the rip the sides style.

3	This set is typical of creator and comes with three sets of instructions.

3	The Monster Dino a kind of spider and a Crocodile The set comes with two of the new motors one small and one large, a sound module plus the new IR controler and receiver.

3	There is a mix of techniques in this set the core is mainly studless technic, there are some studded technic parts and most of the details are standard creator style.

3	There are two mechanisms one to control the legs and one to control the head and arms.

3	The leg drive is from the large motor and the arm and head are operated from the small motor The completed mechanism will stand on its own without any detail added The detail is added to the base unit to complete the model.

3	The operation of the Dino is very good the design for the motors and drives is very compact and well thought out.

3	The walking motion works well although there is no steering and it will fall over it it encounters obstacles.

3	The sound module is built into the head so when the mouth opens the Dino roars (sort of) Glyman made the comment that this set is ugly as sin and I tend to agree I think there are too many colour variations with different shades of grey, black and that lime green :-P which confuses the look of the finished model but I guess it might apeal more to younger kids.

3	I also do not like the spikes along the back, which glow in the dark, because the are loose and keep falling off.

3	This set is not cheap at ?70 but I guess this is because of the motors and IR controller.

3	While on this I was surprised how good the range was on the new controller it would still operate ever when not in direct line of sight.

3	I would give this set a 10/10 for playabilityit has kept the kid amused for hours I would give it 6/10 for value for money it is a bit pricey Overall 8/10 It took approx 3 hours to build and has been well played with I have posted some more images and some videos of the finished models on my brickshelf page HERE If you have any questions please ask Pete Edited by WhiteFang, 23 May 2009 - 06:28 PM.

3	*wacko*

1	The box is has really strange dimensions - it's very flat but has a large front - the 1:1 scale.

1	Regarding the spines, because they're made of the softer non-ABS plastic (the stuff the 1994 cutlasses and brown muskets were made of), they lose their shape a bit and so are hard to grip; they simply fall off.

1	I suppose TLC use loads of different colours because a single or two-colour dino isn't very nice to look at, especially when the surface isn't very smooth - it takes your eyes away from the surface and puts it on the colours.

3	Thanks for the nice review.

3	It's butt ugly to me but the motors + IR control seem pretty neat !

3	I didn't spot this great review earlier.

3	Thanks for the effort of posting all those pics and videos, they helped me decide that this set is worth getting.

3	Got this baby via shop@home a little early and I though it was time to post my view of this set : (Snefroe you NEED to get this one ;-) ) Sorry for the lack of pics but there are already many pics online of this baby So here it is : Best space set since... a way too long time This is my first new space themed set since more than 20 years and I must say that I’m not disappointed at all.

3	I have much to say about this little gem.

3	First, let’s cut it straight about the Martians minifigures: they are absolutely rubbish.

3	I can’t imagine how Lego could produce such atrocity.

3	This said; let’s move on to the dropship.

3	A real piece of art.

3	Reminiscent of the Aliens movie dropship.

3	The cockpit is spacious and provides a great field of view, too bad there is no hinges to open it, you must remove the canopy completely to switch pilot.

3	The drilling unit can be attached under the ship with the clever use of a rubber piece.

3	It stays well in place once attached, good point.

3	Some people don’t like the inclusion of the 2 containment area for the Martians and crystal on both side of the ship but I kind like it, it makes the ship less empty.

3	The 2 wings are complete with air intake, some armaments and 1 standard launcher on the right wing.

3	Normally I don’t like launchers but this one is very discrete and well integrated.

3	On the tail section are 2 thrusters that can be rotated and provide thus some “realistic” movements to the ship.

3	One of the last highlight of this ship is the landing gears, or I must say landing dishes.

3	6 medium sized radar dishes provide and incredible stability to the set.

3	They are quite sturdy and can take a beating.

3	I’m not going to review the alien spaceship in detail since it’s quite uninteresting.

3	I consider it more like a bonus addition to the set than anything else.

3	The look is passable and there are some interesting building techniques in it.

3	That’s all.

3	To end the review, a little pros/cons table.

3	(We all love pros/cons table :-) ) Pros: - Incredible design - At last a decent space set - Modular functions - Quite Sturdy - Beautiful - Great value for money Cons: - Martians are rubbish - No hinges for the canopy - The drilling unit could use some more details.

3	Score: 9/10 By the way , I added a nice cool feature on my site , you can download the stickers for some sets that I own.

3	Before building I always scan the stickers, we never know it could come handy.

3	check this out on my site (you need to go in the Lego lists on the left): [VTX] Classic games

1	Of course, right before I post this I see that Ickelpete reviewed this set earlier in the week.

1	Sorry for being redundant but it is already written so here ya go: Monster Dino Reviewed by Dunamis Set 4958 792 Pieces $89.95 from LEGO Online Store Build time 3.5 hours Here we go with another offering from the Creator line.

1	I?m kind of fond of these sets as they are pretty imaginative and usually have instructions for multiple models.

1	I like the reusability of all the pieces and the varied things you can build.

1	The Box: The box that LEGO shipped this thing in was absolutely huge!

1	When I first got this in the mail, I thought I had won the lottery and they had shipped the UCS Falcon early.

1	Once I opened the shipping box, I was surprised to see an unusually large Creator set box.

1	The box itself is pretty standard Creator type box but this one shows off the Power Functions prominently on the right side of the box.

1	The back of the box shows some of the motorized features as well.

1	Opening the box is a matter of breaking two seals.

1	We?re back to the reusable cereal box type tab system for those of you who stay up a night wondering about LEGO?s next box design.

1	Inside the box we have a bunch of sealed bags.

1	Immediately the power brick, remote and motors stand out as they are each in individual bags.

1	Also, there are three manuals.

1	The Manuals: The three manuals are 76, 76 and 56 pages in length.

1	They are laid out well and are pretty standard with all the usual trimmings: - Piece call outs for each step - Parts inventory at the end of the primary model build - Page numbers Color separation in these manuals were fine for me.

1	Interestingly, the instructions for the primary build took a full manual plus about a quarter of another manual.

1	Random manual photos: Parts list I?ll explain a bit more below, but it would have been nice to have some written documentation on all the functions of the motors, remote and receiver.

1	Such as motor load guidelines and specific explanations of all the remote control functions.

1	It is severely lacking in this area.

1	The Pieces: Obviously, the pieces we?re most interested in are these new motors and wireless remote control.

1	Note that before you fire this bad boy up, you had better BYOB.

1	Since this is prominently a European community, I had better clarify my acronyms.

1	Over here across the pond, BYOB usually means ?Bring Your Own Beer?.

1	In this case, it still means bring your own beer (I?m on my second Heineken right now) but in addition to numerous bottles of beer you will need a total of NINE batteries to get through this set.

1	I kid you not: Anyway, there are two motors (a small and a large) each with its own very unique name according to the manual; the smaller one is called ?motor?

1	and the larger one is called ?XL motor?.

1	Very creative indeed!

1	The battery box takes SIX AA batteries and there are two compartments to hold them.

1	Here is the first: That seems pretty normal.

1	However, the back side of it holds the other three batteries and it seems to be very poorly designed: Note in the photo above where the bottom battery is placed.

1	Compare it to the previous photo and you will see the difference.

1	I played around with trying to get that bottom battery out and you better pack a lunch (or BYOB) because it is no small task!

1	Why couldn?t they make this compartment just like the other side?

1	There is a single power cord connector and a three position switch.

1	The middle position turns the power OFF and the other two positions seem to provide the same functionality in either position as far as I can tell.

1	Perhaps a little blurb in the manual would have been nice to clear things up a bit.

1	The remote takes three AAA batteries.

1	It is fairly small and lightweight even with the batteries installed.

1	It has two thumb controls which could be levers if you insert Technic bars or even pins.

1	The two controls are color coded and match the plugs on the receiver to control two separate motors.

1	In addition, there is a four position switch which I assume changes the channel.

1	Finally, there are two tiny levers that seem to have no function.

1	I?m not sure if they are a trim control or variable speed control.

1	I messed with them and didn?t notice any difference in the motor speed.

1	Again, some documentation from the incredibly verbose LEGO manual would have helped.

1	As far as the rest of the parts, it?s really a mixed bag.

1	There are a lot of varied parts in this set to the point that there is almost one of everything.

1	Lots of Technic gears, pins, studded beams, studless beams, axles, wheels, etc.

1	Also, lots of little 1x1 slopes in various colors, teeth, horns, etc.

1	You can?t really say it is a parts pack because there is not enough of one thing to make it a parts pack.

1	A couple of notes: It seems the quality control issue on the axles has been fixed.

1	I initially reported this back when I reviewed the 8285 about a year ago.

1	All the axles worked fine for me.

1	The color quality control issue is still alive.

1	Check out the different shade of red in these two parts: Also included is the sound brick.

1	This looks just like the other sound or light-up bricks we have been seeing lately.

1	It does have a load dinosaur ?roar!?

1	sound embedded in it though so hide the younglings if they are a bit on the skittish side.

1	Finally, I?ve never seen one of these before (although someone will no doubt rattle off a dozen sets where you can find this part in about 5 seconds): No, I am not referring to the studded beam, I put that in the photo for scale.

1	The Build: The build was fun and was fairly straightforward.

1	As I mentioned, there is a lot of Technic parts, so if you are not a fan of the Technic line you should run, not walk away from this one.

1	There were no gotchas to speak of, but you need to pay careful attention to the placement of the wires that go from the motors to the receiver.

1	They kind of sneak them around a bit so watch closely.

1	Otherwise, it was fine.

1	Here is what is left over: So far, I have only built the primary model.

1	As seen on the box, there are instructions for two more models.

1	Both of the other models seem less complex than the primary model and are likely quicker builds.

1	The Dino took me about 3.5 hours which included some time to screw around with the motors.

1	I?m an old school Technic fan from way back in the 80?s so I had some familiarity with the old Technic motors.

1	Obviously, 25+ years has improved some things and these seem much more powerful.

1	The Design: If you have built the 4507 Prehistoric Creatures then some of the design will feel familiar, especially the head and tail.

1	It is almost like they took the dinosaur from that set and figured out how to motorize it.

1	This is not necessarily a bad thing, just a comment.

1	The set does a good job of showing off the features of the new motors and remote.

1	It is nice to see how one motor can perform multiple functions.

1	In this case, the small motor makes both arms move and opens and closes the mouth of the dinosaur.

1	When the mouth is completely open, it pushes the activation switch on the sound brick which emits the ?roar!?

1	sound.

1	Pretty cool.

1	The ?XL Motor?

1	handles the walking feature of the dinosaur.

1	There is both forward and reverse.

1	Forward works really well while the reverse just makes the dinosaur look like he is doing a Michael Jackson moon walk.

1	(Wow, I never thought I would use Michael Jackson?s name in a LEGO Dinosaur set review!)

1	It is almost like the dinosaur can?t get traction going in reverse.

1	However, as noted previously forward works really well.

1	This guy actually gets going at a pretty good clip.

1	As you might expect, he kind of waddles like a duck since there is no articulation in the knees.

1	It is a bit awkward but it works.

1	The ?XL Motor?

1	seems to kick out plenty of power.

1	Overall, the design seems to be a mixed bag.

1	The way the tail is attached seems to be an afterthought.

1	The arms look to be too small.

1	However, the walking mechanism and legs/feet are pretty cool as well as the head and mouth.

1	I guess it is a reasonable effort to get people introduced to the parts and we?ll see designs improve as time goes on.

1	Here are a few views of our new friend: But What About The AT-AT???

1	Of course, the real reason you are reading this is that you hope I will have some epiphany on how all this relates to the new walking AT-AT.

1	Judging from the box on the AT-AT, it looks like we get one motor.

1	I don?t see the remote which is a disappointment as I hope it is not controlled by a switch on the body and you either turn the AT-AT on or off.

1	If that is the case, the first thing I am doing is scavenging the receiver and remote from this set to add to the AT-AT.

1	Granted, it could be that it comes with a remote but is just not seen on the box.

1	Also, the AT-AT box looks like one of the images shows that the head turns.

1	I sure hope this is controlled separately as it would be really lame to not be able to control this independently from the walking feature.

1	I?m kind of skeptical on the walking feature of the AT-AT.

1	I suspect it will be rather cumbersome but hopefully I will be pleasantly surprised.

1	Needless to say, this is all speculation but those are my initial thoughts based on this set.

1	Overall Thoughts: It?s an OK set.

1	Kind of pricy but I suspect a large part of that is due to the motors and remote.

1	I haven?t built the other two models (they seem less interesting to me) but at least it has some variability.

1	Also, you get a ton of different parts which can either be a good thing or bad thing depending on what you are looking for.

1	The dinosaur is average.

1	The color selection is marginal (black and lime green?)

1	and the tail section is just lame.

1	I appreciate it more for the mechanical functions and how the motorized parts work.

1	It does do a good job of waking up my dog who seems pretty irritated by it.

1	It is a nice set to show off to the neighbors or the endless caravan of my wife?s friends that seem to materialize out of nowhere.

1	People are quickly impressed by it and then promptly move along once you start trying to explain how it all works.

1	I?m a bit disappointed that the manual did not explain more about the remote and motor functions.

1	I suspect that there is more than meets the eye and I?ll just have to play around with it to find out.

1	It would be nice if LEGO had a website that showed all the cool functions of the motors and remotes so we fully understand the capabilities.

1	Final Rating: 72% Build 9/10 (Pretty quick and fun.

1	The mechanical part is cool) Functionality 6/10 (It is a Creator set so you have multiple builds.

1	As far as it being a dinosaur, it?s just OK. Motorized parts are cool though.)

1	Design 6/10 (Partly cloudy.

1	Some things are cool, others are lame.)

1	Parts 8/10 (New motors and remote are cool.

1	Lots of varied parts included but nothing to write home about.)

1	Price 7/10 (It is kind of expensive) Edited by WhiteFang, 23 May 2009 - 06:23 PM.

3	This is both my first set review and post about a Star Wars set- (even though I have been collecting them since '99).

3	I got this one early this year so I thought I would post a review on it.

3	Please bare with me- I am not a great photographer.

3	So with that in mind, here goes!

3	Front of the Box: 75083 AT-DP Box-Front by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Back of the Box: 75083 AT-DP Box- Back by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Shot of the Bags: 75083 AT-DP Bags by whitesidewjw, on Flickr The sticker sheet (I normally don't apply them, but for this I am going ahead and putting them on): 75083 AT-DP Sticker Sheet by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Minifigs- I really like the two AT-DP Pilots, but the best Agent Kallus really does shine.

3	Of course we get an extra stormtrooper: 75083 AT-DP Minifigs by whitesidewjw, on Flickr No new molds in this as far as I can tell, however these printed 4X4 domes are really great.

3	I can see lots of uses for these in space MOCs.

3	75083 AT-DP New Printed Elements by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Bag#1 Complete- Nothing earth shattering here- an easy build: 75083 AT-DP Bag #1 Complete by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Bag #2 Complete: 75083 AT-DP Bag #2 Complete Cockpit Seats by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Cockpit assembly: 75083 AT-DP Cockpit Assembly by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Bag #2 Complete 75083 AT-DP Bag#3 Complete by whitesidewjw, on Flickr "Foot" Assembly"- I like how they positioned the slopes 75083 AT-DP "foot" assembly by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Complete AT-DP 75083 AT-DP complete by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Complete AT-DP-Side View 75083 AT-DP Side view (Complete) by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Complete AT-DP- Over View 75083 AT-DP Complete- overview by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Complete AT-DP Rear View 75083 AT-DP rear view by whitesidewjw, on Flickr Extra pieces 75083 AT-DP extra pieces by whitesidewjw, on Flickr The Verdict: Minifigs- 5/5- We get a total of four figs.

3	I like the two AT-DP Pilots and Agent Kallus is a well done minifig.

3	I can complain about another storm trooper either Parts- 3/5- Other than the dome pieces I commented on before, there is really not any new parts in this.

3	If you build space, star wars, or machinery, this will still be a welcome assortment.

3	Experience of Build 4/5- This really was a fun build.

3	It came together fast but was challenging enough for its target age group.

3	Playability 5/5- This thing is much more sturdy than it looks.

3	The legs take a little bit of effort due to the double locking hinges but hold together very well.This is a very minor complaint.

3	Value 4/5- Typical- $49.99 for 500 pieces- I must admit I paid a little more than MSRP due to shipping but I can't complain about the value.

3	Overall: 21/25- I really believe this is one of the best walkers that Lego has designed.

3	The only changes I would make would be adding real control panels in the cockpit and it would be nice if lego made a real widow to fit in with these types of builds rather than a transparent tile over another plate.

3	All in all, I would recommend this set and I hope the rest of the 2015 Star Wars sets are on par with this.

3	I also like how the spring shooters are pretty much hidden in the frame, nice job!

3	Lego's affiliation with six wheelers go back a long way.

3	I think the first one was released in 1981, more than 25 years ago.

3	This year, Lego added another one to the family, Mars Mission's "Rhino 1", as its title sounds...

3	It's been a while since i've bought and opened a large box, so maybe this isn't a surprise to most of you, but the box does not open at the front, as with many larger sw boxes, but at the side.

3	The two printed seals(or whatever people call them) have gone as well, being replaced by one larger print in the middle of side... the box also isn't as thick as a large sw box, like the sandcrawler...

3	The general size is, however, still quite large.

3	PICT0001.JPG 281.91K 102 downloads the back side shows the Mars Mission theme sets... eccept the Rhino!

3	I guess it shows this set will be released as a TRU exclusive or something, only to show up in Legoland shops and maybe Lego shops...

3	It's a shame really, because this is by far the best set of the theme.

3	PICT0002.JPG 285.42K 89 downloads When you open the front cover, you see a larger picture picture of the Rhino.

3	Obviously, it seems to be some sort of multifunctional truck.

3	i think the basic function is to drive around and explore.

3	For that it has a drilling device and six giant wheels.

3	PICT0003.JPG 273.7K 82 downloads The set comes with two instruction books.

3	i'm afraid to say they did not resolve the gray/black colors issue.

3	Colorwise, the real thing does not look like the instruction book because of it... PICT0004.JPG 302.63K 75 downloads The Rhino looks really big because of the six giant wheels.

3	I guess it's more or less the same size as M-tron's Magnetiser with the big difference between the two being that the wheels have been turned around, creating a unique wheel design for a Lego model PICT0285.JPG 290.59K 83 downloads PICT0277.JPG 286.26K 80 downloads the wheels look very cool, even though the first couple of wheels stand a bit closer to each other.

3	Don't know why that is.

3	hm... |-/ and they could have used a bit more body, but the design is pretty good.

3	i know, "Armagheddon" isn't far away... |-/ PICT0292.JPG 216.75K 70 downloads The suspension of the wheels is a bit flimsy.

3	sure, it allows the truck to move around in a more realistic way than the old sets, but it's not as flexible as some older sets, like sw's CTT.

3	Nor do the wheels have much body.

3	the black bars you see on top of the wheels are more "window dressing" then functional... PICT0293.JPG 244.78K 88 downloads The over all shape of the Rhino is kinda "bulky", it looks more like a beatle than a rhino, if you're asking me.

3	It has three major sections, but i wouldn't call it a modular building though...

3	The cockpit is the first section.

3	It's spacious and detailed.

3	PICT0290.JPG 262.77K 0 downloads PICT0291.JPG 299.75K 87 downloads The cockpit hangs down from a weird angle.

3	it's attached to a large vertical technic brick that is part of the Rhino's main structure, so it's not a seperate spaceship, which is a shame... oh well... you can't have it all, i guess... PICT0301.JPG 291.13K 78 downloads ah yes... stickers all over the place, but they're cool.

3	the mid section of the Rhino dominates the basic shape of the model.

3	It's as if those two large white parts form a strong and thick shield, protecting whatever is inside from whatever is outsde.

3	PICT0007.JPG 213.22K 67 downloads unfortunately, there is nothing inside.

3	it's extra space needed to house the spaceship.

3	That's really a shame; a command center of some kind could have given the rhino a bit more "panache".

3	PICT0286.JPG 251.35K 87 downloads However, what's really great, is the way in which they fit together: one side has an orange 1x2 plate that fits in between two white 1x3 plates of the other side, creating yet another unique shape for a Lego model.

3	But again, it's a shame they didn't do more with this section... X-O PICT0283.JPG 287.75K 82 downloads The third and last section is a platform for a space ship.

3	PICT0299.JPG 289.5K 77 downloads PICT0287.JPG 199.78K 75 downloads The platform itself isn't really special.

3	no details, no stickers,... it's just a skeleton to carry the spaceship, nothing more nothing less.

3	No, your space ship doesn't fall off, even if you rotate the platform into a launch position, pushing the weight of the ship backwards.

3	In fact, the position of the ship onto the platform is so solid, it's kinda difficult to imagine how this ship flies off.

3	|-/ The ship on the other hand, is pretty cool.

3	It's all sorts of things at the same time it seems.

3	It transports two aliens, but also a small car that reminds me of the small sets of Spacepolice 2, blacktron 2,... PICT0295.JPG 307.4K 85 downloads PICT0298.JPG 268.13K 75 downloads PICT0294.JPG 276.84K 76 downloads the shuttle reminds me of a Star trek shuttle and i think it needs some modding, but i do think it looks pretty nice.

3	sure, the cockpit is a bit too low, a pilot needs to lay down instead of sitting down and the dropping mechnism, if there is one at all isn't all that brilliant either...
