3	Edited by iamded, 31 August 2007 - 05:15 AM.

2	Lego 41062 Elsa's Sparkling Ice Castle Lego managed to get a Frozen licensed set in the new wave of Disney Princess sets.

2	However, I'm VERY surprised by the size.

2	It's a $40 set and comes in a small Friends-style box (roughly 12"x12" size) - I almost didn't see it on the shelf when I was looking for it because it's so small.

2	I mean, I know it's only $40 but it's a friggin' CASTLE.

2	And why did Lego only make this a smaller set?

2	If they'd made a $200 Frozen castle they still would have sold every one they could produce.

2	They made big Harry Potter Hogwarts sets and those sure sold.

2	And have you SEEN the toys in the Frozen section of stores?

2	HUGE playsets for Barbie-sized dolls.

2	But I suppose I'm getting the cart before the horse here, reviewing before I've even opened the box.

2	So..... Name: Elsa's Sparkling Ice Castle Set Number: 41062 Pieces: 292 Price: $39.99 Minifigs: 3 Theme: Disney Princess Year of Release: 2015 Links: Bricklink Peeron Brickset The Box The front of the box is standard Lego fare, other than the large Anna and Elsa in the bottom right corner.

2	Oh, and surprisingly, nowhere on the box is the normal minifig lineup.

2	The only way to know what characters are included is to look at the set pictures.

2	The 1:1 This set uses one of the minidolls as the actual size sample.

2	That's probably not a bad choice since the minidolls are not nearly as well known as a minifig.

2	The Back On the back, the play features are shown in insets around a rear view of the castle.

2	Like Friends sets, you also have an array of play accessories.

2	The Seals Is this standard on 2015 sets or is this specific to this set?

2	I've never seen 3 tape seals on a set.

2	Even huge modulars or Technic sets only have 2, so 3 on a set this small seems excessive.

2	Perhaps Lego expects people to try to steal the dolls?

2	If so, why bother with extra tape?

2	A tiny pocketknife makes quick work of the tape so the third strip doesn't even slow you down.

2	The Contents In the box are 2 instruction booklets (bent), a white plate, a sticker sheet, and 3 numbered bags of parts.

2	The Stickers These are very hard to photograph since they're shiny.

2	I mean polished chrome shiny.

2	Those dark lines across the corners are not really there, they're reflections of my ceiling.

2	The Manual Backs The back of one booklet has a Friends "Win!"

2	girl.

2	The other has an ad for the Lego Disney Princess website.

2	That site is SO girly there's even sparkles following your mouse cursor around.

2	So I didn't stay too long or look too deeply.

2	The Sample Page The interior pages of the manuals are on lavender backgrounds.

2	It's standard Lego instructions with part callouts and insets when needed.

2	The Build, 1 The first thing you build is Anna, but I'm not showing that yet.

2	Then you build this little picnic scene.

2	It's tiny but effective, and nice to have something not icy in the set since the movie has the "In Summer" song for Olaf.

2	I'm curious what's in that sandwich though - green and pink?

2	After the picnic is the Olaf build, but I'll save him for later too.

2	The Build, 2 Next is this small sleigh.

2	It has an amazing amount of style for something so small.

2	The curved front and decorative whips on the back make it look sleigh-like instead of blocky.

2	But come on, it already had pink accents, are the pink flowers really necessary?

2	Technically, yes, so the whips can mount to them, but still, it's just over-girly for my taste.

2	The Build, 3 The sleigh needs a ramp to help it rocket along (for a couple inches, at least).

2	The ramp starts like this, with a hidden lime green jumper plate that gets a cookie on it.

2	I couldn't remember anything in the movie like that, so I asked my wife and she couldn't either.

2	A hidden cookie under a hill?

2	The Build, 4 After putting the tilting 2x8 onto the base and adding decorations, this is the result.

2	A lime green bucket holding a pair of ice skates, a flower (in the snow, really?

2	), green and white round studs that I assume are supposed to be grass and snow?

2	The Build, 5 The sleigh looks huge sitting on top of the tiny hill, but it actually works pretty well.

2	Assuming you're on a smooth surface like a table, you can give the sleigh a little nudge and it'll shoot down the ramp and a few inches across the table.

2	The unevenness of the slopes vs the blue tiles holds the sleigh in line well, and the bumps in the slopes don't seem to hamper anything.

2	The Build, 6 Moving on to bag 2.... man that's a lot of colors in this base already.

2	And I'm already starting to feel like there's trans-blue cheese thrown around randomly.

2	The Build, 7 Continuing (and rotating), some steps and even more colors thrown in.

2	Magenta?

2	In Elsa's ice palace?

2	I sure don't remember any of that...

2	The Build, 8 Wait, seriously?

2	An ice cream stand in the castle?

2	That is what the magenta is for?

2	I kinda actually like the looks of it, but it doesn't fit the set.

2	The Build, 9 Spinning back around, now there's a light aqua spiral staircase added along with a roof.

2	This is where I'm really starting to wonder about Lego's thinking.

2	Those light aqua stairs, and the light aqua 1x4 tiles, are exclusive to this set (as far as I know... it's possible some other 2015 sets use them, but nothing in Bricklink yet).

2	Seems expensive (to produce) to me, when there's no huge reason to need them.

2	Another blue for the tiles would have been fine.

2	And the spiral stairs?

2	Really?

2	Elsa's castle is KNOWN for staircases, but NOT spiral ones!

2	There should be a huge straight ice stairway out front or sweeping curved stairs inside, but not a spiral.

2	The Build, 10 And now we finish the tree.

2	Again, why?

2	Where is there a tree next to Elsa's castle?

2	And so weird... with ice hanging from green branches that have both snow and flowers on them.

2	Huh?

2	Did Lego watch a different movie?

2	The Trans-Light Blue Bits Before looking at the upper level, a brief pause to look at some other parts.

2	Here's the 1x2x5 brick in trans-light blue and the 2x4x6 rock panel in glitter trans-light blue.

2	Do those look like the same blue to you?

2	And again, ANOTHER unique part for this set.

2	Why do those rock panels need to be glitter, when Lego made the same panel in trans light blue in 2013 and 2014 for SuperHeroes, Friends, and Chima sets?

2	Apparently Disney REALLY wanted glitter, because there are a bunch of trans-glitter parts in the new Princess sets.

2	There's trans-neon green cones for Jasmine; Ariel, Jasmine, and Sleeping Beauty all get glitter trans purple cones.

2	So there's a bunch of new glitter parts for 2015.

2	The Build, 11 Back to building - time to add the upper level.

2	We get a bedroom with a decent bed, although stickered.

2	The Build, 12 The other side of the bedroom has some little accessories.

2	Perfume and a crown I assume?

2	The Build, 13 Time for walls and a roof.

2	I like the small white macaroni bricks for a wall, but what's with the lavender fence piece in the center?

2	I'll grant that it looks nice (a common white fence would have been a little boring), but it's ANOTHER unique piece to this set.

2	The Build, 14 The very top of the castle is built separately.

2	Not a whole lot to say here other than why is there a torch in an ICE CASTLE?

2	The Finished Castle Once the roof is put on, the castle is done.

2	And that big purple star on top says everything to me about the styling.

2	It just doesn't look like modern Lego to me; it looks like this should be an old Belville fairy tale set from around 1999.

2	If I saw a photo of just the castle with no figs (or picnic blanket), I'd assume that's what it was.

2	The Oops, Not Actually Done Yet Accessories At the end, there's a few bits left to add.

2	There are these dark purple skis (yup, another unique part) in the lower level.

2	Let me tell you, they're a pain to get into that location, at least with my big man hands.

2	More Accessories The top level gets a stickered book.

2	The sticker has a nice castle image on it that is, while not quite exactly the castle from Disney World, VERY Disney-looking.

2	I actually had to google and see if that's the castle they use in their logo.

2	Nope, but it's the same style.

2	The Leftovers There are a LOT of extra parts in this.

2	That's almost 10% of the part count in the set right there!

2	They are pretty useful overall though.

2	It's great to have an extra "carrot" and brown "branch" for Olaf, since you know those will get lost as he's played with.

2	The Figs Finally, the reason for the set.

2	Let's face it, the castle set is just an excuse to make these figures.

2	And they're GREAT.

2	I mean just fantastic.

2	The print on them is just such a good match to the real characters.

2	Compare to the cartoon version from the front of the box.

2	Elsa's hair is a little darker than the cartoon, but overall these are just dead on.

2	If I had to pick out a flaw, it's the "spell" Elsa is holding.

2	It's too bad she can only shoot it forward with her arm down like that.

2	It'd be nice to have the end of the splash part bent 90 degrees so she can have her arm forward and the spell shooting forward too.

2	Oh, one other thing.

2	The minidoll heads don't press down tight to the body like minifig heads do.

2	There's still exposed neck.

2	It looks nice, but it means Elsa's cape can swing around.

2	The Fig Backs Elsa's cape is glittery on the back and you can see the removable bow in her hair.

2	The Full Set One final issue.

2	When you put Anna on the sleigh, her cape doesn't have enough flexibility (since it's a wraparound kind) and so it folds out funny.

2	That's why on the back of the box it shows her standing on the back of the sleigh with Elsa in the seat.

2	Edit: How on earth did I forget to comment on those orange flowers to each side of the castle?

2	I'm pretty sure Elsa did NOT have any flowers blooming outside her castle!

2	The Conclusion Hm.

2	I really wanted to like this set, but I just can't quite bring myself to.

2	It feels like Lego pulled a random castle design from the files then redid it into white and trans blue to look icy and allow a Frozen tie in set.

2	The figs are great, but the castle isn't.

2	I guess the real castle in the movie would be a boring set and this one has play features, but it just is too different for my taste.

2	The Ratings Value: 7/10 - $40 for less than 300 parts is high (especially when so many of the parts are tiny, but on the other hand there's a LOT of rock panels and 1x2x5 trans blue panels), but the figs help save it.

2	Design: 4/10 - Not one of Lego's best.

2	Not as bad as the lows in the 90s, but not a great set.

2	Minifigs: 10/10 - Possibly even a 12/10.

2	They ARE the reason to buy the set .

2	Playability: 8/10 - There are a bunch of play features, but they actually detract from the design, so I had to knock off a couple points.

2	Parts: 7/10 - A bunch of impractical unique parts (how often do you need dark purple skis or a lavender fence piece?)

2	but also a bunch of nice parts if you wanted to make your own icy scene.

2	Overall: 7/10 - A great bunch of figs, but I'd recommend not bothering with the manuals.

2	Just use the parts to build your own castle that's better.

3	Two of my daughters are building this as we speak.

3	I agree the design is a lot smaller than I would have liked, but they're loving it.

3	No question the figures are the real draw here.

3	And at 6 and almost five years old they're doimg a good job building so far.

3	At least for the 4-6 range in my house, this set is a home run.

3	Thanks for the great review, Mostlytechnic!

2	I managed to get two sets for my twin girls for Christmas, and would have to agree with your ratings (the Anna and Elsa figs are indeed excellent)

3	Very nice review, mostlytechinc!

3	Once I saw this set I was interested in it for the colours and pieces...thanks for this review to shed more light onto it!

2	Edited by m0dulo, 13 January 2015 - 10:03 PM.

1	Hello everyone, I am back to share with all of you, another of my Legends of Chima polybags review.

1	It will be pretty comprehensive since the finished built will be quick and will be focusing more of what kind of fun that you can derive from there.

1	This polybag was bought in September 2013, when I visited LEGOLAND Malaysia and I did not hesitate to put this in my shopping basket.

1	Name: 30253 Leonidas Jungle Dragster Theme: LEGO System / Legends of Chima Year: 2013 Pieces: 30 Minifigs: 1 minifigure Price: USD N.A, GBP N.A, EURO N.A, SGD N.A Resources: Brickset, BrickLink An original polybag image of the 30253 Leonidas Jungle Dragster Back view of the original polybag image of the 30253 Leonidas Jungle Dragster The road scout of the Lions Tribe This polybag design is definitely plan to be the quickest and fastest dragster to recce enemy front by making a swift scout for the Lions Tribe.

1	I believe by the sound of the name, Jungle Dragster, it might just be suitable to use in jungle terrain.

1	Well, I don't quite agree that this is a 'Dragster' even though it has the kind of open view concept of rolling in fast but it does not have the length of a typical dragster, similar to this Town polybag design, for example.

1	Still, it is nice to have smaller variants of their vehicular supremacy.

1	Instruction Manual (Front) Instruction Manual (Back) The LEGO building content With just 30 LEGO elements, you can be pretty quick to be able to display these laid out content.

1	After the built is completed, these are the remaining spare parts.

1	I am fond of the wheels which are some useful parts, other than that, there are nothing spectacular about it.

1	My name is Leonidas and I belonged to the Lions Tribe Do not be mistaken of his name, Leonidas to be the King of Sparta who led the brave men of 300 Spartans Warriors to fight to the death against the Persians.

1	Instead this character is based on the bio resided in LEGO.com, you will realise that he is aligned with the Lions tribe and is a proud Lion foot-soldier.

1	He may have that goofy idiotic look but he can be very serious in his commitment to discharging his duties.

1	You are able to observe his nice back view printing which reveal his black and blue sash.

1	Leonidas has a dual facial feature to reveal his much serious appearance.

1	Leonidas is one of the common characters available in the Legends of Chima universe.

1	It can be found in a total of five sets.

1	It is a great pity that there is no weapon being made for him in this polybag design which will certainly make a fine addition.

1	The completed built of the Jungle Dragster This is the main design of the Jungle Dragster which is very simple looking.

1	There is no distinct fighting capability from the vehicular design and it look just like a regular patrol vehicle.

1	One thing I like about this, is the close distinct colour schema of the Lions Tribe.

1	Other than that, there is nothing special about it.

1	Moving off with my Jungle Dragster To conclude, this polybag is really meant for LEGO fans or collectors who appreciate Legends of Chima or wanting to sample the Legends of Chima theme.

1	It is a very simple built, but yet could form a decent force size for recce purposes before sending in the big arsenals to whack their enemies.

1	Either way, I will only suggest you to buy it if you really love this theme at an inexpensive price.

1	Otherwise, it is perfectly alright to give this a miss.

1	Summary review Playability: 4/10 (You need to have more Lions Tribe vehicles in order to bring the best and fun out of it since this is more of a supporting vehicle.)

1	Design: 4/10 (Simplistic built of the dragster and main focus is just acquiring the minifigure.)

1	Price: 4/10 (Bought at about USD$7, which is not an awesome price, so get it if you can get it more than half of this price.)

1	Overall: 4/10 (If only you are a huge mega fan of the Legends of Chima, then you need to get this.)

1	I gave it a "2" based on my Review Score Card.

1	What about yours?

1	I hope every one of you enjoyed reading this simple review of mine.

1	Comments and Criticisms are strongly welcomed.

1	Pictures can be found in My Flickr.

3	Out of nowhere this set appeared at my local TRU.

3	Hadn't been expecting this one for a while, so a nice surprise.

3	*sweet* Firstly the box.

3	Nice pic on the front.

3	Good selection of minifigs.

3	The officer and pilot look cool with their dark blue trousers.

3	A new R2 unit as well.

3	Don't remeber this in the film, but great to have one in a new colour.

3	*wub* Back of the box shows some of the ship's nifty features.

3	First thing you notice when you open the box, is the awesome selection of bricks.

3	This makes a for a great parts pack.

3	Loads of unusual red and dark red pieces.

3	It's so refreshing to see a Star Wars set that isn't predominantly grey.

3	There are also two instruction booklets.

3	As soon as you open the first booklet you hit an error.

3	Why would I want two Obi-Wans?

3	:-| It's also at this point that you come across a big disappointment.

3	On the box you get a flesh Qui-Gon.

3	What is actually in the box is an EpIII Obi-Wan.

3	Come on LEGO - why change it?

3	|-/ All the figures look impressive in the flesh despite the BIG mistake.

3	Once I started the build it progressed rapidly.

3	Red pieces seem to be a lot easier to find.

3	Lots of clever techniques.

3	Quite a few Technic elements get used at the start.

3	It reminded me of building a Technic set from the 80s at times.

3	Here is the main body half way through the build.

3	The landing mechanism is a nice touch.

3	Its not fully retractable, but still folds away nicely.

3	You find the ship keeps tipping over as you build it despite the feet, as it's only at the end thay it all becomes evenly balanced at both ends.

3	Here the feet are extended.

3	You can also see the yellow knob that rotates the radar on top of the ship.

3	Landing gear up viewed from the front.

3	Here are the radar.

3	A great collection of dishes.

3	They spin easily with little friction.

3	Here is the ship at the half way point.

3	The front works well with the top flipping up to squeeze in the pilot.

3	More to come... :-)

3	7665 Review Part 2 The second half of the build goes quicker than the first.

3	Once you start to add the engines, the ship really begins to take shape.

3	The main body of the ship has a few surprises hidden away under a removable cover.

3	Inside you get some retracting guns, a storage box, a little shuttle and space for a droid and figure.

3	Here is everything you can fit inside.

3	The guns are concealed behind the side vents.

3	Pushing them forward causes the vents to open.

3	Closed: And open: The final feature is the passenger area/escape pod.

3	Inside is plenty of space for two figures.

3	The pod cleverly attaches by pushing the front section of the ship forward, sliding the pod in, then returning the front.

3	Everything locks together and is held securely in place by an elastic band.

3	:-) Here's a couple of pictures of the final model.

3	It's not the most beautiful creation ever, but it is an excellent representation of the ship from the film.

3	The angular shape actually suits a LEGO build well.

3	There's one more useful feature.

3	The whole ship can be safely and comfortably picked up by two ball ended Technic pins towards the back end.

3	It balances well at this point and does allow you to swoosh the ship around much more easily.

3	This was the most enjoyable Star Wars build I've had in a long time.

3	Everything progresses nicely with almost no repetitive bits.

3	The ship looks good and is also HUGE!

3	*sweet* Compare it to the 6211 ISD and you'll see it's only fractionally smaller.

3	When I first saw pictures of this on the internet I thought it looked OK. Once you see it for real it is much more impressive.

3	For ?69.99 in the UK I'm not complaining.

3	It's the best value Star Wars set of the year so far.

3	To conclude: Pieces: 9/10 Minifigures: 7/10 (would be a 9 apart from the stupid Qui-Gon/Obi-Wan head error) Playability: 8/10 Originality: 9/10 Set Design: 8/10 Overall: 8.2/10 The box says this is a Limited Edition set (whatever that means).

3	So if you're planning to get it I'd suggest you grab it at the first opportunity.

3	I'm glad I did!

2	REVIEW - 42039 - 24 HOURS RACE CAR INTRODUCTION When the preliminary images of the "Le Mans Racer" surfaced somewhere last year (2014) it got a lot of praise.

2	This changed dramatically when the final images of the 24 Hours Race Car showed up.

2	The front side of the car, especially the head lights, and the curvature of the side of car had changed a lot.

2	The car obviously still resembled the prototype, but the new design raised a lot of eyebrows.

2	The new design was considered a step back instead of forward.

2	Eventhough I still liked the design, I must admit I liked the earlier design better too.

2	With the emphasis on past tense liked.

2	I am not sure anymore and this review will show you why.

2	Like the Arctic Truck this set has a B-model which is well worth checking out.

2	That's why this review includes both the A-model and B-model.

2	For people who are on the fence, the B-model might actually convince them to buy the set after all.

2	Let's see what this set is all about!

2	Note: All images can be clicked for hi-res versions.

2	SET INFORMATION Number: 42039 Title: 24 Hours Race Car Theme: Technic Released: 2015 Part Count: 1219 Box Weight: 2110 gr Box Dimensions: 47,8 cm x 37,3 cm x 8,7 cm Model Dimensions: 40 cm x 18 cm Set Price (MSRP): €99.99 / $?

2	/ £99.99 Price per Part: €0.082 / $?

2	/ £0.082 Links: Brickset, Bricklink THE BOX The box measures 47,8 cm x 37,3 cm x 8,7 cm and weighs well over 2kg (2110 gr to be precise).

2	The width of the box is the same as the box of the Arctic Truck.

2	This box also feels like it's filled to the brim.

2	THE FRONT The front shows a picture of the main model in action, with radial blurred wheels to emphasize the motion of the car.

2	The lower right section shows the dimensions of the model.

2	Upon completion, it will measure a length of 40cm and a width of 18 cm.

2	THE BACK Like the front, the back side has exactly the same setup as the box of the Arctic Truck.

2	The top shows the functions of the model, while the lower left side shows the B-model and the lower right side shows the motorization options.

2	The picture of the B-model looks so cool, it could be a model of it's own.

2	At this point I was very eager to build both models and compare them.

2	THE SIDE One of the sides usually shows a part in 1:1 scale.

2	This time it's one of the wheels indicating the size of the model.

2	CONTENT OF THE BOX The box contains: 1 Book(let) 1 Sticker Sheet 13 Bags 4 Tires INSTRUCTION BOOKLET Since I own two copies of the set, I also received two instruction booklets.

2	What's catching my eye is that my second copy is supplied in different packaging than the first one.

2	It's for the first time (that I am aware of) that the instruction booklet and stickers come in a sealed bag, without cardboard back.

2	Hopefully this will be a new standard for all sets with sticker sheets.

2	Instead of multiple booklets, this set contains a single square bound book.

2	In earlier reviews I have epxressed my preference for a single book.

2	I don't see any advantage in having 2, 3 or even up to 6 booklets.

2	STICKER SHEET Like the actual model, the sticker sheet looks very vibrant.

2	The bright green, white and black color combination has found it's way to the stickers as well.

2	Either you love 'em or hate 'em.

2	Since I started writing reviews I have been applying stickers and I am happy I started doing it.

2	Stickers do give the model it's finishing touch.

2	BAGS WITH PARTS Thirteen bags with a total of 1219 parts (give or take a few) are supplied in the densily packed box.

2	The rims and flex are sealed in a bag as well.

2	Sometimes looking at the bags makes you wonder what the logic is, behind the distribution of the various parts across the different bags.

2	Well this time it really got me confused.

2	Take a look at two of the bags below.

2	There's a bag containing all the 3L Blue Pins.

2	Then there's a bag with various parts....and a single 3L Blue Pin.

2	I figured this might be an error, but both of the sets have the same anomaly.

2	TIRES The tires have been supplied unbagged, as usual.

2	HIGHLIGHTED PARTS This chapter describes new and interesting parts.

2	This set actually contains a lot of them.

2	This set also contains an abundance of panels.

2	If you aren't into panels, this isn't the set for you.

2	CHANGEOVER CATCH This year (2015) the new changeover catch parts were released.

2	It's a combination of three parts.

2	The advantage of the new parts is that the red gear is the same on both sides, which avoids mounting it the wrong way around.

2	It also avoids the changeover catch slipping out of the driving ring, like it used to do.

2	You can apply lots of pressure, but the catch doesn't slip out.

2	PINS Some of last year's new pins are also included in this set.

2	12 x Pin with Pin Hole and 21 x 3L Pin with 1L Axle.

2	Securing Technic Beams can be quite simple with the new Pin with Pin Holes.

2	The new 3L Pin with 1L Axle gives you more possibilities when connecting Beams and other parts.

2	Below are two example situations where the new pins have been used.

2	Granted, the examples below can be accomplished by using other techniques.

2	However, some predicaments from the past can be easily solved by using these new parts.

2	Like me, you will most likely appreciate the ease of use.

2	ENGINE AND SUSPENSION Also included are two Steering Portal Hubs and Steering Portal Hubs with Ball Joint Arms and four Steering Portal Axles for driving and steering the vehicle.

2	These parts are commonly used nowadays.

2	The picture below also shows some other parts, like gear rack, steering arms and suspension.

2	FRAMES This set comes with a single 5x7 Frame and three 5x11 Frames.

2	PANELS This set contains a whopping 47 panels in three different colors.

2	I personally like panels a lot and I do appreciate the variety we have at our disposal lately.

2	This set even contains a new 13x3x2 Curved "Mudguard" Panel.

2	NEW 13x3x2 CURVED PANEL This is the first set to contain the new 13x3x2 Curved Panel.

2	Looking at the pictures doesn't do these panels justice.

2	In real life they are actually quite big.

2	I figured they would be smaller, but they are even longer than the 11 x 5 frame, with a length of 13 (including the attachment points).

2	Hopefully this part will be available in other colors as well, preferably white, for adding variety to your EV3 robot.

2	19L WHITE FLEX-AXLES The White 19L Flex Axles have only been released in a single set, the 8461 Williams F1 Racer in 2002.

2	Current prices on Bricklink are as high as 15 Euros!

2	Needless to say we are very happy with the return of these White Axles.

2	Now we can build Jeroen Ottens' awesome Alfa Romeo 4C Spider for a decent price as well.

2	I am really happy that useful rare parts are being used more often by TLG designers PART LIST Here's the complete list for all 1219 parts.

2	As you can see in the Highlighted parts section, this set contains a lot of interesting and useful parts.

2	If you don't own sets like the 8070 - Supercar, this might be the set to pick up if you want to start building your own supercar.

2	THE BUILD Enough with all the set and part information, let's build the model.

2	REAR SUSPENSION The build starts with the rear suspension and drivetrain.

2	As you can see in the picture below, the length of the Axle between the Steering CV Joint is 4L, where it usally is 3L.

2	This is an indication that the finished model will be a bit bigger than usual (8070 for example).

2	The finished suspension is one of the cleanest suspension setups I have seen in an official model.

2	It's pretty basic, but it works like a charm.

2	This setup is defintely worth using in your MOC.

2	Here's a video: After attaching the suspension to the frame you rotate the module and secure it.

2	At this stage the rear section of the chassis with suspension is almost finished.

2	V8 MID-ENGINE Extending the chassis forward results in the picture below, where the front spoiler is already visible.

2	What's also visible is the V8 engine placed right in front of the rear axle, resulting in a Mid-engine setup, perfectly suited for sports and race cars.

2	Two exhaust pipes have been fitted on either side of the engine, together with two hoses attaching them to the engine.

2	The instructions are easy to follow, although you sometimes you need to bend the beams a bit.

2	Minor improvements are possible here and there, but nothing shocking.

2	FRONT SUSPENSION The front suspension is a bit more complicated than the rear suspension, which makes sense considering the fact it contains the steering rack.

2	The shock absorbers are placed in a different angle than the rear ones, resulting in a somewhat stiffer front suspension.

2	All in all the front suspension is well designed and the steering rack can be easily powered with a Servo Motor.

2	The picture belows shows the front suspension attached to the chassis.

2	If you follow the official instructions to motorize the model, the area in front of the suspension is used to mount the battery box.

2	When you are modding this model to make it Full RC this area can be used to mount the servo motor.

2	GEARBOX Like the gearbox in the 8070, it's not used to switch gears powering the drivetrain.

2	It's used to switch between two functions, opening the doors and the hood/bonnet.

2	The gearbox is located at the left of the vehicle, near the cockpit.

2	The mechanism to open the doors is located on the left side, while opening the hood/bonnet is taking place at the right side.

2	To accomplish this, some axles traverse under the cockpit to the other side of the vehicle.

2	Following the axles to other side of the vehicle and adding some gears, results in the situation below.

2	The video below shows the gearbox in action.

2	DOOR OPENING MECHANISM The mechanism to open the door is comprised of some Knob Wheels, Links without Stoppers and Pins with Towballs.

2	Take a look at the doors opening and closing.

2	THE FRONT Using the new mudguards and various other panels you finish the front of the car.

2	The front is probably the most controversial part of the car.

2	This is caused by the preliminary pictures shown before the release of this car.

2	In the early pictures the front of the car had smooth curves and beautiful lines, while the final car lost these smooth lines and got a more blocky look in return.

2	I must admit that at a first glance, the new design lost some of it's appeal.

2	However, this model grew on me pretty rapidly.

2	The headlight design can be found, in more or less the same way, on several real Le Mans type race cars.

2	THE REAR The rear of the car looks great, with the stickers continuing from the mudguards to the panels underneath the spoiler.

2	The two exhausts sticking out give some details to the back.

2	I absolutely disagree with all the negativity surrounding this car.

2	Maybe it's one of those models which needs to grow on you.

2	FINISHED MODEL Here it is, the finished model.

2	I know some of you don't like the looks of the car, but I think it looks great.

2	The color scheme is outstanding.

2	The new (for Technic) bright green parts, combined with white and black make this car look very vibrant and colorful.

2	I am not a big fan of the green used in the 42008 - Service Truck, but I do like this bright green a lot.

2	It fits perfectly well with the Mindstorms EV3 set.

2	The curves on the side of the car are not as smooth as some of us hoped, but I still think the car looks more than acceptable from the side.

2	The stickers add some nice details to the car, giving it that characteristic race car look.

2	The model looks great in pictures, but it does even look better in real life.

2	I love this picture of the front of the car.

2	However, I do wonder if a dedicated 24 hour Le Mans Racer has the seat and steering positioned off-center?!

2	Using the good ol' Google Machine I come to the conclusion that they do have centered seating and steering, at least the majority of them.

2	There's ample space in the cabin, which makes me wonder why TLG decided to place the seat off-centered.

2	The rear view looks cool too, with some of the suspension showing and the two exhaust pipes clearly visible.

2	The bottom view is very useful to determine the size of the car in studs.

2	It measures approx 59 x 27 studs.

2	The chassis looks organized and well designed.

2	The engine has been placed close to the ground, which is perfect for the weight distribution.

2	A low center of gravity improves the handling of the car.

2	I really enjoyed building this baby.

2	The build is very clean and organized, although there are some steps where you need to bend the beams a bit to get things into place.

2	Seeing the model come to life and seeing it grow to pretty impressive proportions is very satisfying.

2	For me it was fun, but I reckon kids will go nuts over this set and the build.

2	SIZE COMPARISON What became obvious during the build, but what's emphasized when you have finished the model, is that it's quite big!

2	The size of the car is pretty impressive.

2	The pictures below show the car next to the 42030 - Volvo L350F.

2	The side view emphasizes the size of the car.

2	It's even longer than the Volvo, if you dismiss the bucket.

2	PARTS LEFT Some parts left.

2	Nothing out of the ordinary.

2	FEATURES AND FUNCTIONS Unlike the B-model, this model doesn't implement any unexpected features.

2	The functions it does implement are exactly what you would expect from any car.

2	Steering (HoG) Working fake engine Suspension Opening doors (gullwing style) Opening bonnet/hood Opening trunk Gearbox for switching between functions Unfortunately the steering wheel hasn't been linked to the HoG (Hand of God) steering mechanism.

2	Placing the seat in the center would have provided an easy way to link the steering wheel to the steering mechanism.

2	it's a shame we hardly see actual steering anymore.

2	Opening the hood actually opens up the entire rear section of the car, providing you with easy access to the motor compartment.

2	The mechanism to open the hood works properly, which results in smooth opening and closing of it.

2	The same goes for the gullwing style doors.

2	Both functions are operated manually and you need to switch with the lever to the left of the cockpit.

2	These two functions are also the ones which can be motorized by placing an M-motor near the cockpit and a battery box in the trunk.

2	All things considered I think this car offers lots of playability.

2	The model is solidly built and the functions are easy to operate.

2	I'd say it's pretty safe to let your kids play with it.

2	B-MODEL Unlike the A-model, the B-model for this set received (almost) universal acclaim, and I can see why.

2	Often the B-model is a pale shadow of it's part donor.

2	In this case the model looks so good, it could be a model of it's own.

2	It even incorporates a neat feature, which actually deserves to be in the A-model.

2	There's a lot a variation in the quality of digital building instructions TLG is providing, but these ones are of very high quality.

2	The picture below shows most of the chassis with suspension, fake engine and gearbox in place.

2	FINISHED MODEL Some concessions have been made, but overall the car looks fantastic.

2	The black of the roof has been extrapolated from the hood, which definitely works for me.

2	The rear section of the car feels a bit empty, but the panels do cover up most of it, so it's hardly noticeable.

2	The V8 stickers will be upside down if you use the parts from the A-model.

2	Since I could apply new stickers, I have placed them using the proper orientation.

2	The bottom of the car shows the chassis.

2	It's obviously a bit smaller than the A-model's chassis.

2	FEATURES AND FUNCTIONS Taking the functions into account, this model isn't playing second fiddle to the A-model.

2	Besides the obvious functions like steering, opening doors and hood, this car features folding fog lights, which deserve a better podium than a B-model.

2	Steering (Hog) Working fake engine Suspension Opening doors (manually) Opening hood/bonnet (manually) Opening trunk (operated by gear) Folding fog lights (operated by gear) Gearbox (used to switch functions) FOG LIGHTS One of the most interesting features of the B-model are the folding Fog Lights.

2	It almost feels a bit weird that a feature like this is implemented in the B-model, instead of the A-model.

2	Below are 4 steps showing how the mechanism works.

2	I have also included a video.

2	The mechanism is somewhat reminiscent of fork mechanism used in the 8109 - Flatbed Truck, which has been described in Efferman's Review.

2	Take a look at the video to the fog lights in action.

2	PARTS LEFT A fair number of parts left, which isn't uncommon for a B-model.

2	SUMMARY To summarize how I feel about this set, you need to take a look at the picture below.

2	The combined image reflects the quality of this set....or better yet....sets!

2	You actually get two great models, for the price of one.

2	You don't like the A-model?

2	No problem, you can have lots of fun with the B-model.

2	I can't stop playing with the fog lights, it's mesmarizing.

2	The color scheme on both models is outstanding.

2	I simply can't emphasize enough how well this color scheme pleases the eye.

2	The regular green is dull and boring, but this bright green really pops out, especially when combined with black and white, and possibly some red details.

2	Black, white and a little red?!

2	Sounds familiar?

2	Yes, bright green can easily be combined with your EV3 robots.

2	So while you are combining the bright green with your robot, why not use the great new curved "mudguard" panels.

2	These new panels are introduced in this set and they look great.

2	They open up a lot of possibilities in the design department.

2	The build of the A-model is outstanding.

2	It is fairly simple, but since it's so clean, I really enjoyed it a lot.

2	I think the build should be entertaining, which doesn't mean it needs to be a real challenge.

2	And let's be honest; when is a build really challenging?!

2	The rear suspension is a good example of why I liked the build.

2	It's very simple, yet very effective.

2	Works like a charm.

2	The same goes for the other functions in both models.

2	And the star of the entire show can be found in the B-model.

2	How's that for a surprise?!

2	Being aware of the fact that I like this model a lot better than most of you seem to do, I really encourage you to give this model a chance.

2	The sheer size is impressive, the color scheme is awesome and you get a bonus model, which is actually worth building.

2	SCORE Okay, so how do I grade this set?

2	8 DESIGN Open to debate, but I like it a lot.

2	8 BUILDING EXPERIENCE Fun and clean build.

2	9 FEATURES Superb function in B-model steels the show.

2	9 PLAYABILITY Both models offer lots of playability 8 PARTS Lots of new parts and cool existing parts.

2	10 VALUE FOR MONEY Two models for the price of one.

2	8,7 TWICE THE FUN I hope you enjoyed this review!

2	More pictures can be found on my Flickr page.

3	Fantastic review Jim, from the quality of the review alone it is easy to see how much hard work you have put into it.

3	I'm with you on the instruction manual, I much prefer one quality bound book over umpteen stapled booklets.

3	Already have 2 of these sitting in the build queue, one for display model as I'm a fan of this one and one to build the B model then dissemble for parts, so I'm already sold on his set but still very much enjoyed taking the time it deserves to read through the review and ogle at your pro photography.

3	Great review with fantastic pictures.

3	As for the model, I'm glad that they chose to make it less pretty - real Le Mans prototypes are rarely a sight to behold.

3	It is function and aerodynamics over form.

3	I would, however, have preferred more realism for the sake of learning: - The front shouldn't open like that - instead it should be easy to remove the whole front cover, leaving the suspension easy to work on.

3	- The aero seems to be realistic, except for the rear end where there's no indication of a venturi channel.

3	This should have been easy to include.

3	- There is no fuel tank, nor fixed fuel connector right behind the cabin.

3	- There are no air jacks!

3	Seriously!?

3	This is one of the most unique features of a race car like this... and LEGO forgot about them.

3	Instead they automated two functions which are manual on a real race car.

3	- The top cars at Le Mans are hybrids with ingenious systems.

3	I would have loved to see the front wheels connected to some kind of spinning apparatus indicating a kinetic energy recovery system.

3	If I get this set...

3	I'm going to make some modifications.

3	This is a mega review.

3	You've taken the right pictures and the video demonstrations of the mechanisms really help get the good points of the set across.

3	What's more amazing is that the review still feels very concise and to the point.

3	You've actually convinced me to put this set on my list and not just as a decent parts pack.

3	Lasse D, on 12 March 2015 - 08:47 PM, said: - The front shouldn't open like that - instead it should be easy to remove the whole front cover, leaving the suspension easy to work on.

3	- The aero seems to be realistic, except for the rear end where there's no indication of a venturi channel.

3	This should have been easy to include.

3	- There is no fuel tank, nor fixed fuel connector right behind the cabin.

3	- There are no air jacks!

3	Seriously!?

3	This is one of the most unique features of a race car like this... and LEGO forgot about them.

3	Instead they automated two functions which are manual on a real race car.

3	- The top cars at Le Mans are hybrids with ingenious systems.

3	I would have loved to see the front wheels connected to some kind of spinning apparatus indicating a kinetic energy recovery system.

3	I'm not sure air jacks are the feature that will have people fawning over this set, and pneumatics are being covered rather well later in the year ... but I agree with everything else, most notably removable front and rear bodywork (the removable engine cover on 8674 would be a good starting point here) and the inclusion of some nod towards a hybrid system.

3	It's also worth remembering the preliminary design did have the Big Honking Fin (BHF) that is mandatory on all current prototypes, so maybe when that was removed any trace of a tunnel or diffuser went with it.

3	On the subject of steering wheels, all modern prototypes actually have left or right hand drive.

3	The regulations demand that both LMP1 and LMP2 cars are nominally capable of seating two people.

3	Of course in practise the "extra seat" is taken up by the hybrid system in LMP1 and electronics/extra cockpit access in LMP2.

3	However this doesn't change the fact that it would be easy to link the steering wheel to the HoG/front axle.

3	Edited by jono.rocky, 13 March 2015 - 10:53 AM.

2	Wonderful review, but I am still not sold on the set.

2	If we get more sets with the bright green I might be tempted to get it, but until then it is too few parts in bright green (too few different types, not the number of pieces) to be able to use that colour effectively in making MOC's.

3	True, but I must say I like the new colour, very 'fresh' looking compared to the rather dullish regular green.

3	Can't wait to build MOCs with it.

3	I have been waiting for this set since the pictures for the toy fairs eirlier in the year and I am glad to say I am not disapointed.

3	First the price it is not cheap at ?99.99 but I guess that is typical for a set with this amount of electronics in it.There is no parts count and I have not had time to add up the 2 pages of contents to get a figure.

3	First the box standard flip top with large internal picture and rip to open lid.

3	inside There are no numbered bags in this set which I prefer I like to open all the bags and put all the parts in the box before building.

3	Next is a picture on the electronics 2 XLmotors as lego describe them and 2 standard motors.

3	2 IR receivers and 1 IR transmitter I know these have been discussed before but I really like the thought that has gone into the transmitters/receivers each receiver has 2 outputs to corespond with the 2 controls on transmitter they also have a choice of 4 channels so one transmitter can control up to 8 independant motors by changing the channel switch.

3	The transmitter also has a neat motor direction switch so you can configure the transmitter operation.

3	The set comes with three manuals 1 is the main drive mechanism 2 is the cab and engine and 3 is the attachments front and back.

3	There is also the now standard parts list in the back of the third manual.

3	There is no alternative model instructions despite the pictures of one on the box however there is a reference to the technic website on the back of the box but at the moment the page only has an advert saying the set is to be released on 1st September so I guess I will have to wait untill then to see if the instructions will be online.

3	The build is fairly straight forward the main chassis is studless, the next picture shows the motors mounted into the chassis and the drive for the shovel and claw.

3	It also shows the V6 technic engine.

3	This next picture shows the IR receivers mounted on the back.

3	The battery box slots into the back and can be easily slid out with the removal of two pins which is useful because I can imagine I will need to change the batteries on a regular basis.

3	The next 2 picture are of the completed model Overall I was very happy with the finished dozer the functions work really well and as I have the monster dino I have used a second transmitter so I dont have to touch the channel switch, I have included some video On my Brickshelf page.

3	Unfortunately this set does suffer from some quality issues for example moulding marks on the plates, colour diferences, some of the pins not finished properly, some pins were very stiff and quite hard to push into the holes but the worst issue was an axle that would not turn freely in a hole which just adds extra friction into the system.

3	I am glad to see some studded technic in this set I much prefer sets that use both varieties of technic beam.

3	There are only 2 Fairings which is a great improvment over recent sets if TLC had tried to make the bulldozer shovel with fairings this would have been a complete disaster.

3	Marks for the set 8/10 for price with the number of motors I expected it to be greater.

3	9/10 for fun my kids love this type of set that does something when finished.

3	6/10 for quality TLC really need to work on this one.

3	8/10 overall I would definately get a second one if I see it in the sales.

3	Feel free to post questions but I will be on holiday next week.

3	More pics and Videos available HERE

2	lham, on Aug 9 2007, 12:00 PM, said: could you please please post the instruction boolets' number codes (located on the back in tiny print)?

2	so that we can download them from lego.com and have a look for ourselves.

2	When i read this i first though you meant set number but this model can't be found there yet and now i realize that you mean something completly different.

2	What is this code you're after?

2	EyesOnly, on Aug 10 2007, 04:16 PM, said: When i read this i first though you meant set number but this model can't be found there yet and now i realize that you mean something completly different.

2	What is this code you're after?

2	There is a additional code in the booklet (different for every one) you should find it from the front or back cover.

2	Also later editions have different codes.

2	Some examples: Set 7905 - 4497674 (Front Cover, Bottom Left) Set 8421 - 4284910 (Book 1) and 4284922 (Book 2) (Back Cover, Bottom Right) I'll bet the code is then used to "abuse" the Lego cache :-) Mig

3	The new small Technic sets have incredible functionality for their size, and this one is no exception.

3	With only 106 parts this crane can roll, extend, rotate, lift (and hold in any position) and has working stabilisers!

3	The boom extends the same as the other sets with this boom; simply pull it.

3	It works surprisingly well and due to circular ridges inside the boom the extension (which is just a standard beam) will hold in place.

3	The gear at the back controls the height of the boom.

3	As you can see the boom is only half extended.

3	Boom fully extended, half down.

3	The cable is kept in place via two gears and a blue pin, same as the 7905 crane.

3	Even under decent weights this works well.

3	The stabilisers however cannot handle much weight once the load is moved off axis.

3	The stablilsers are a very simple but effective design.

3	Another shot of the stablilsers.

3	This also shows how far the boom will decend.

3	The boom height mechanism works well also.

3	I love the cab design.

3	Overall this is a remarkable achievement for the low price.

3	I bought it for the boom piece as I want to improve the crane that came with 7998 7898 ( :-$ ).

3	I highly recommend it.

3	Alright, so I usually do quick photo reviews when I get new sets.

3	That's what I'll do here, but there's quite a few photos, so I thought I might as well make its own review thread.

3	So, I got the Kwik-E-Mart by paying just2much on an early eBay copy.

3	I think it's worth it, as this week I'm gonna be super busy, so I was able to build it Saturday and stuff.

3	Here's my video review, I think it's one of my best: Well, let's get onto this photo review.

3	The set is $200 USD with a little over 2100 pieces.

3	The official release is April 15th for VIP members, May 1st for everyone else at LEGO Stores.

3	And, if you want full size pictures, check out my Flickr by clicking here.

3	The minifigures included are great.

3	You get three exclusive minifigures (one being a completely exclusive character- the first time LEGO has ever put an exclusive mould in a Direct to Consumer set), and you get three of the series most popular characters in their normal attire for those who missed out on the first Simpsons minifigures series.

3	The Kwik-E-Mart's exterior is loaded with lots of sticker details.

3	The only printed detail you'll see in the exterior is the dial pad in the phone booth, which has appeared in some other licensed themes since last year.

3	( ^^^ right here is there the store can be opened- a simple Technic pin and receiver keeps it in place and allows for opening and closing) The roof of the store includes the garden shown in the Paul McCartney episode.

3	The roof can be slided out/in once you open it with the hinge part.

3	Here's a look at the store with the roof removed.

3	The floors are a nice sand blue color, coming with 8x16 thin plates: And, for the interior, from the view of the store opened with the hinges at the back that I mentioned earlier: The left front corner, which includes some arcade machines of Bonestorm and Great White Hunter, an amazingly done Buzz cola soda machine, juice machine, the checkout counter, ect: The right front corner, with food aisles, freezers, and a frozen Jasper sticker: The back left corner, which includes some nice coffee kettle builds, the donut tray, hotdogs, ect: The right back corner, which has a door leading to a very small hallway that only has a mouse and cheese in it.

3	The hallway leads to the employees only door in the back, and it's very hard to get in the door way (not that there's anything to do inside there): Also included is Clancy's copcar, which fits three figures: Here's a look at the piece list in the instructions, click on each to be lead to an enlarged version of the pic: Also included are some awesome printed pieces, and two unprinted coffee cups!

3	Honestly, I think this set is perfect.

3	The price is fantastic, and has a great PPP ratio.

3	They really went above and beyond by including Snake in this set.

3	I honestly think it's better than the Simpsons House in terms of accuracy and the value here- so many cool pieces printed and in exclusive colors.

3	So, that's my quick picture review.

3	Hope you guys enjoyed, and I'd love to hear your thoughts!

3	Thanks 'j2g' for another review, one of my favourite parts of the set......the half eaten donut on the dashboard of the police car.

3	Brick On Review On 'j2g' !

3	Thanks for the review, your video was very well done, seeing those sticker sheets is daunting.

3	Thanks for the review.

3	I can't help but think the minifigures are the weak part of the set.

3	Snake and Apu are great but the rest....

3	I don't know.

3	They kinda redundant now.

3	They could at least give us new torso printing, like Homer wearing his jacket or Bart wearing his blue t-shirt or Marge wearing her coat.

3	Or, as I said in the discussion thread, I'd have included Jasper in CMF series 2 and a Frozen version here.

3	Overall, the set looks kinda smaller than what I thought.

3	(Snake's bag needed a $ symbol printed, because it looks like he is stealing gargabe ) Pretty good review overall

1	I recently acquired 90% of this set, so I thought I would do a review of it.

1	Please note that half of the Mini-figs are wrong, and there are some part substitutions.

1	This is the only set that comes with this plate.

1	There is a depression under the grey plates to the back.

1	The pool depression can be easily covered by three quarter circle plates... which just happen to be included in this set.

1	(Good set design Lego!)

1	The stairs are old Fabuland ones, and have been used in a few other sets.

1	This is the only one that has them in "ParaPink" however.

1	What is the difference between "ParaPink" and "Pink"?

1	Dunno...

1	The big windows are in only two other sets, both of them DACTA ones!

1	The smaller ones were in one other Paradisa set.

1	The interior, while simple, works very well.

1	I love the coffee machine.

1	A cute car came with the set as well.

1	The bird house is a nice idea as well.

1	Once the current visitors leave I will probably be breaking this set.

1	I wish Lego would go back to these sets as they always had some great parts in them.

3	Note, that there are only three different colors used in that set (actually there are 4, but you can?t see the dark grey ones).

3	11 round bricks altogether.

3	Luckily enough it was an old one, with old dark grey.

3	I don?t know if TLC ever produced this set with bley.

3	See what I mean?

3	Before reviewing them individually, here is a general pic.

3	2/ The lighthouse One of the main reason to own that great set !!

3	Sure it suffers from accute stickeretite (sad but :-D ).

3	T worst is that door), but nonetheless a great and simple building !!

3	Great white/red colour scheme, and a really fantastic 2 turning lights !!

3	I really like the yellow top of the lighthouse, it adds to the comic atmosphere of that theme instead of having a more plain red/white only.

3	The rear has nothing really fancy, except tools to fix it in case of problems hehe.

3	The only thing I modified since I didn?t build the third polybag is that I got rid of the trechnic parts on the right of the lighthoue to replace them with regular ?logs?

3	All hail the tower King !!

3	:-D 3/ The school and pontoon I really like that little building and its great to see that once again TLC uses the amazing dark blue color !!

3	Its really a simple design but looks fantastic and can be used for many things in a town hehe I also really like the combination with those dark bluish grey slopes !!

3	The rear reveals the desk, stickers on the wall (d?oh !!)

3	and two clams serving as chairs (really like on the show).

3	Its really great to see that TLC stays really as close to the show as possible.

3	The pontoon again is simple yet really cool and effective.

3	And its really nice to have 2 lifesaving boueys.

3	The only thing I modified since I didn?t build the third polybag is that I got rid of the trechnic parts in front of the pontoon to replace them with regular ?logs?

3	On the overall, I think its really a great set !!

3	Apart from the crap stickers, I think TLC should have ditched (or simplified) the third playability polybag to lower the cost !!

3	Oh well, parts are always usefull (except those one part shitty palm trees !!).

2	It looks like a good set but I would rather get the neighborhood one.

3	The set, and the other Designer sets that came out with it (especially 4888) are incredibly well designed sets.

3	I wish Lego would go back to doing sets like these as I loved the multitude of instructions and ideas.

3	The last batch of Creator sets had zero ideas, even though I know several were made.

3	:'-( Anyway, less whining, more review.

3	The lion is the main model.

3	His mouth doesn't fully close, but it does open more.

3	The head works well from most angles.

3	I love the dark orange bricks; great for rust...

3	He is quite solid, but the joints take the weight well.

3	The neck goes side to side and rotates, but doesn't go up and down.

3	The body is built in two parts and pinned in the middle.

3	With what is left you can make what I think is a hyena, a silly plant MOC... ...and what I believe is a vulture.

3	There are also instructions for a few other models including a bat, boar and a snake... which I quite like.

3	He can be built at the same time as... ...this cute little lizard.

3	Overall this is a great set with an excellent blend of colours and pieces.

3	I wanted it for steampunk potentials.

3	LEGO 75915 Pteranodon Capture I'm glad to review this nice set; 75915 Pteranodon Capture Name: Pteranodon Capture Set Number: 75915 Pieces: 174 Price: $19.99 Minifigs: 2 Theme: Jurassic World Year of Release: 2015 Links: Box The front of the box has the Jurassic World logo along with the set number, piece count, etc.

3	Its a decent box size for a $20 set.

3	Here it is compared to a minifigure.

3	Here's the back of the box.

3	It shows all of the features from the set an ad for the video game.

3	The back also shows a small picture with a silhouette of the dinosaurs from the line, along with their set numbers.

3	Instruction Booklet The booklet shows the same thing as the front of the box, nothing more, nothing less.

3	Near the back of the booklet, there is a picture with all of the characters from the sets.

3	The other page shows all the dinosaurs with a mini box that shows the size comparisons.

3	The Minifigures The minifigures in this set are Simon Masrani and an ACU.

3	Both of them have excellent printing on the front and the back.

3	The gun is the same one from TLM that the SSP used.

3	Simon Masrani is the only one with a double sided face.

3	His second face shows a scared/worried exp<b></b>ression.

3	He has a zipped up jacket or jumpsuit with a shirt underneath.

3	The ACU trooper only has one face which is a scared/worried exp<b></b>ression.

3	I would have a scared exp<b></b>ression too if I was about to get eaten by a dinosaur.

3	He has great detail on his torso and legs.

3	Let's take a look at the vest.

3	The vest is the same mold from the SSP in TLM I think.

3	It has the letters ACU on the front too.

3	The back is nothing interesting.

3	Pteranodon The pteranodon has great printing too.

3	The colors match the ones that the pteranodons from the movie have.

3	The wings, mouth, and head are a rubbery type of plastic and are easily bendable.

3	It uses the same mold from the pteranodon in the 2012 Dino line.

3	Here's a comparison between the two.

3	Spare Parts The spare parts aren't many, just a few extras.

3	The Helicopter At first the helicopter was 'meh' when I first saw it on the box.

3	Now that I've built it, I've got to say that I really like it.

3	Its my favorite helicopter of all of the ones I've built.

3	Its sturdy and sleek.

3	It's not too bulky either.

3	The first play feature in this set is the net launcher.

3	It works pretty well, not one of my favorite features but it does what it's meant to do.

3	The other play feature is on the other side.

3	Its a stud shooter which can be used by a minifigure.

3	You can put it on their hand or you can leave it there and let someone operate it.

3	The shooter can fold up inside the helicopter as well.

3	There are stickers on both sides of the helicopter and they also have the Jurassic World logo with Dino marks.

3	Final Verdict Value: 9/10 - For $20 this set isn't that bad.

3	The parts count is a little low for a $20 set but the price is probably because of licensing.

3	Other than that, it's a great deal, I would've hoped for maybe some bait for the pteranodon but that can easily be fixed.

3	Design: 9/10 - I REALLY love the way this helicopter looks, it's sleekness and design is great.

3	The only flaw this has is the huge net launcher, it's too big in my opinion.

3	Minifigs: 10/10[/b] - The minifigures are extremely detailed and it even includes an exclusive minifigure.

3	Playability: 9/10 - There are many things you can do with this set.

3	The swoosh factor is great and so are the play features.

3	Parts: 10/10[/b] - They're useful parts and there isn't many huge specialized pieces in here either.

3	Overall: 9/10 - This set is great for fans of Jurassic World, it's also a nice parts pack.

3	There's one exclusive minifigure in here too which makes it even better.

3	Having a little fun with the set Hope you liked my first review here on Eurobricks!

3	Please leave any suggestions on what to improve, thanks!

2	Robin Creations, on 04 May 2015 - 02:07 AM, said: Nice review!

2	Although, that picture of the ad reminded me of how some of the things surrounding Jurassic World (Lego, that is) seems hastily put together.

2	Just look at that the minifig.

2	He is Star Lord's head and hair, Indiana Jones' torso with different arms, and City legs.

2	To me, that seems a bit weak, especially for a video game.

2	Oh yeah, I just noticed that

3	Yesterday I went to Toys 'r Us and bought the Dilophosaur Ambush.

3	Beside that the shop had a display of the JW polybags.

3	For €3,49 I picked up two of them.

3	Now here is my little review of this pretty nice set.

3	First some data: Line: Jurassic World Year: 2015 Pieces: 29 Price: €3,49 Packaging: Polybag Ok, lets start with the polybag itself.

3	It is a standard size and had plenty of room for all the parts.

3	The front depicts the whole set with a little hexagon on the right with a seperate picture of the dinosaur and its name.

3	In this case the Celophysis is called Gallimimus.

3	Weird choice Next is the instruction sheet.

3	It is a doublesided paper with every building step in clear sight.

3	The part selection is nice.

3	There are only a few but all of them are pretty usefull for all kind of builds.

3	There are two parts which stood-out.

3	Both are printed tiles.

3	The first one is the yellow/black warning tile in 1x4.

3	You can't have enough of that.

3	The second one is a 2x2 tile with the Jurassic World logo on it.

3	That's pure awesome.

3	The bigger sets seem to have only sticker for that, so this little set is a perfect way to get hold of this nice tile.

3	The leftovers.

3	Nothing special.

3	Here is the complete trap.

3	It is a basic build and functions pretty well.

3	In the end the parts are more interesting as the build so it will definitely end up as a parts-pack.

3	Now on to the star of this bag.

3	The Celophysis/Gallimimus.

3	I don't know why Lego decided to call this dinosaur mold any different, but I think it has to do with movie-connection and the will to not produce a new mold.

3	Nevermind, this figure is great and the colour is very bright and totally stood out.

3	Pretty beastie.

3	A comparison between the 2015 Gallimimus and the 2012 Celophysis.

3	The final set in all its glory.

3	Final verdict: It is a great little set.

3	The parts used a nice and usefull.

3	The printed tiles are the secret stars of this set and the dinosaur is fun two.

3	With a few packs of these you could easily build a Celophysis pack with lots of Jurassic World signs on their way.

3	Highly recommended.

2	nice little review!

2	now i definitely have to check if the toys r us in dortmund has it, too!

2	I wonder where this design came from!

3	Lego 31036 Creator Toy and Grocery Shop Thanks to EuroBricks for making this review possible!

3	For years, Lego has offered a house of some sort in the Creator line each year - with the standard Creator 3-in-1 instructions, that's given us a very wide variety of housing.

3	In 2014, they added a business option with their 31026 Bike Shop and Cafe set.

3	This continues into this year's Toy and Grocery Shop set.

3	These shops are smaller than the very detailed modular buildings, but that should help them fit in better with the other City sets, and this also lets them get into more kids' cities with their lower pricetag.

3	Name: Toy and Grocery Shop Set Number: 31036 Pieces: 466 Price: $39.99 Minifigs: 2 Theme: Creator Year of Release: 2015 Links: Bricklink Peeron Brickset The Box The front of the box shows the "A" version model out of the three, plus insets of the B and C versions.

3	I like the sorta-European looking backdrop; it goes well with the styling of the buildings.

3	Interestingly, the main model is shown opened up for play, while the two insets show those versions folded.

3	The Box Top On the top of the box, Lego helpfully shows that with 3 of these sets, you can make a whole street.

3	The Box Back On the back, you get to again see all three versions together, but this time, folded.

3	It's a little creepy though with those clones running around :) The Manuals Yep, three actual, printed manuals.

3	There's nothing indicating them as being A, B, and C models, but it's pretty obvious looking at the designs which is the "main" model and which are the alternates.

3	The Contents Bags of parts and two plates.

3	Nothing terribly exciting to see here....

3	The Minifigs Nothing new here, but two nice figs none-the-less.

3	Well, Bricklink does say that both figs are unique to this set, but there's not any new parts to them.

3	The closest thing to rare is the female head - it's only in this set, 2013's Dragon Mountain Castle set, a UK store grand opening set, and one of the 2014 Holiday freebie sets.

3	The faces aren't that unique, but I guess this exact combo of two faces on the head is.

3	I love the kid torso with the spaceman on it.

3	The Minifig Backs No back printing on anything here except for an alternate female face.

3	Sorry.

3	I do like that her two faces are so different though.

3	That's much better than when a head has a "scared" and a "more scared" face.

3	The "C" Build Enough with the basics; let's build.

3	I'm going to review them in the same order I built them, backwards.

3	Since you can tell immediately looking at the 3 designs that they're going to use different numbers of pieces and so forth, I figured I'd build the smallest first lest it seem like a letdown.

3	All three have some basic similarities - the two plates are hinged to give a building that opens for play.

3	They also do have interiors, which you can see starting to form here.

3	The "C" Build, Front It's a pretty quick build, so it's done already.

3	Here's the front of the building with it opened up.

3	Like this, it appears to be two separate stores, a newsstand and some sort of shop you can enter.

3	All the printed tiles help give the newsstand a detailed appearance, but I'm not sure why they've got a $100 bill lying on the ledge...

3	The "C" Build, Rear From the back side, the interiors are pretty plain.

3	The shop half has a plant in a jar and a weird chair, and the newsstand just has a register.

3	The "C" Build, Sides Here's the two sides of the folded building.

3	On the hinge side, there's a bunch of windows in a disjointed wall with random colors.

3	On the other, why did they put in a huge window when the set does include a trans-clear door that could have gone there?

3	And you get a small patch of plants, like so many sets seem to have these days.

3	The "C" Build, Extras That's a lot of leftovers there.

3	And not just little stuff - multiple doors, stairs, etc.

3	And unused sand green is always a little sad....

3	The "B" Build, 1 A pretty similar start, with the hinge and little garden and some tiles along the ground.

3	The "B" Build, 2 Now we see a big windowed wall, some details like lights, and how it has the usual alternate model "weird part usage" - like a 1x4 brick with side studs being used over the doorway, even though those side studs will not get used.

3	The "B" Build, Front The finished building gives us a nice little post office, with a letter-carrying bird on the roof.

3	Hope that's not their normal method of delivery!

3	Something about the colors just doesn't work for me though.

3	The combo of white / light grey / dark grey / black / sand green plus tan is just too much.

3	The tan window and door frames I don't like.

3	The "B" Build, Inside On the inside, things are weird.

3	The counter on the left is ok, but the light above the door (with a yellow clip?

3	ugly!)

3	is too big, and everything else over there by the door doesn't make much sense either.

3	The "B" Build, Sides I like the front side here, except the colors are still too much.

3	The bench, greenery, mailbox on the corner, and streetlight are all nice.

3	The boy is a little creepy though - binoculars in hand PLUS a telescope on the roof of the post office?

3	Why?

3	The hinge side shows more of the weird colors you get in the wall, but that's going to be hidden when the set is open.

3	Plus we even see that on big modulars at times, so it's not SO terrible.

3	The "B" Build, Leftovers Again, a lot of leftover parts.

3	It's obvious this was another alternate, but it'd be nice to see more of them used to make a bigger building.

3	But let's move on to the model that DOES use them all...

3	The "A" Build, 1 The first half starts like this.

3	Maybe it's just my bias, but it already feels like a more detailed build.

3	Bottles on the wall, the yellow and red awning over the window, etc.

3	The "A" Build, 2 The other half starts off with detailed work too.

3	I think that's a red vending machine.

3	The stairs are also VERY solidly built.

3	I also appreciate the effort to get that diagonal base where a door will be - it's such a nice touch to have sections of a building that aren't right angles.

3	The "A" Build, 3 Not too much has been added, but I wanted to showcase the tiny toys before they get hidden by a wall.

3	That robot and train are just fantastic little micro builds.

3	The "A" Build, 4 Things are coming together quickly.

3	The walls, windows, and doors get the first floor nearly done.

3	I'm still not big on the sand green and tan combo, but I do really like the red and yellow awnings.

3	The "A" Build, 5 It appears the shop owner lives upstairs, since we've got a bedroom forming here.

3	The bed is a little plain, but the table and lamp on the other half are great.

3	And my big fingers did not like putting all those railings on the balcony, with the telescope posts and tile tops.

3	Knocked quite a few off before I got them all done.

3	The "A" Build, Front And it's done.

3	All the details make this set really feel like a mini-modular.

3	The roofline has great greebling, and the shop contents, and on and on.

3	It's not perfect though.

3	The tiny car above the toy store door isn't nearly as good as the toys inside.

3	And the kid's yellow scooter?

3	The wheels aren't even on the ground, much less able to roll.

3	The scooter looks decent though, so that counts for something.

3	Well, at least as long as you are at this angle, since the boy's only got 1 foot on the 1 stud wide scooter.

3	The "A" Build, Inside Most of the interior has been seen already.

3	The roof though does a nice job of being interesting for a roof.

3	A skylight, the edge rails, etc.

3	And you can see there's not much "wrong color" in the walls.

3	The "A" Model, Sides An interesting building when folded up.

3	Very tall and skinny.

3	You can tell it's not really meant to be displayed this way - it's meant to be open.

3	The good - lots!

3	I like the awning, the diagonal door, the flowerbox under the upper window, the folding gate on the balcony that lets it be used in open or closed mode, and the green / white / blue colors.

3	The bad - well, the stairs end short of the upper door, I still don't really like the tan doorframes (I think black would have been better), and why don't the upper floors match up in size?

3	The "A" Model, Leftovers Ah, that's more like it.

3	Just a few small pieces left as spares.

3	The Errors You might have to click through to the full-size versions, but I did catch a few weird errors in the manuals.

3	First, in the photo of the newsstand, the map in the front corner is on there sideways.

3	The map does have a clear north arrow printed on it.

3	On the second image, the boy's feet are hanging off the edge.

3	Just unusual to see an alignment error in the manual like that.

3	The Comparison Here are this set and the modular Detective Office side by side.

3	There's a huge difference - as you'd expect.

3	But is the difference MORE than you'd expect?

3	This set is 466 parts, $40.

3	The DO is 2262 pieces and $160.

3	5 times the parts, 4 times the price.

3	Looking at them side by side, I'd expect a bigger difference in both.

3	The Conclusion So, what's my conclusion on this model?

3	I love the main model, but the alternates are meh.

3	It's a nice set for someone looking for a town building other than police and fire stations, but who isn't ready to move to the modular line.

3	Compared to the modulars though, it seems overpriced.

3	Part of that is because the huge modulars are actually a great deal compared to other Lego sets.

3	I'm also a little surprised that it's so small, when you compare it to the City sets like a police station.

3	Those are generally designed with much more open space, letting them be more of a playset.

3	This one is small and cramped, so it'd be tougher to play in.

3	It's not really a City set though.

3	The Ratings Value: 7/10 - It's under the 10 cents a part mark, but that's largely due to having a TON of tiny parts.

3	All those flowers and decorative 1x1 round studs add up quickly!

3	Design: 7/10 - Good and bad on the colors, and there's a big difference between the quality of the main vs alternate models.

3	Having so many leftover pieces is one thing when the Creator set makes 3 very different models (ie a boat, plane, and truck).

3	When it's 3 buildings, it seems wasteful to have so many parts leftover.

3	Minifigs: 6/10 - I'm not sure they both fit the set.

3	I suppose the boy is going to the toy store and the woman is going to the grocery?

3	But there's no storekeeper in either.

3	The woman doesn't look like a storekeeper to me, so that's why I assume she's another shopper.

3	I love the boy, but the woman is just so-so - except that I do appreciate the head having two very different expressions.

3	But again, that doesn't fit the set.

3	I can't see her scared face being used.

3	Playability: 6/10 - The shops are detailed with registers and so forth, but it's all so tiny it'd be hard to play with the figs in it.

3	Parts: 9/10 - Tons of windows and doors, plus nice sand green bricks.

3	But some things (the large blue curves used on the roof for example) are weirdly specialized and would be hard to use in another building design.

3	Overall: 7/10 - I'd recommend doing what I did - build the alternates first, then the main since that's how you'll want to leave it.

3	I'd really like to see the price a little lower compared to other sets (again, the part count is inflated due to SO MANY tiny parts) and the finished building is tiny, but it's loaded with neat details.

1	designed to hit a price/brick count point rather than provide a solid set in the Creator Town tradition).

2	This seems like half of a set compared to the previous Bike Shop/Cafe.

3	As a fan of Creator houses, I really want to like this set.

3	However, I think that Creator houses have long filled a niche that's neglected elsewhere: residential houses.

3	We haven't had a larger residential house since 2013; I'm not sure if these sets have anything to do with that, but it seems like they may be the replacement for larger houses.

3	And I'd much rather have a larger house set than a set like this.

3	I also agree with many others here; something about it just feels incomplete.

3	I think that the various City business buildings we've gotten in recent years (including those in this year's City Square--which is much more expensive than this, but also contains much more) make for better buildings at this scale.
