2	I'm a big fan of anime and have watched some mechas like Full Metal Panic, Neon Evangelion: Genesis (it is a mecha!)

2	and Chobits (Well... She is a robot...), so I was curious to see what this new Exo Force line was all about.

2	The colorful sets and manga-like characters didn't persuade me right away, but the urgent need for a couple of white 3x3 wing plates made me purchase this little thing.

2	It cost me 70 DKR as you can see on the box.

2	This is 9.30 euro, or about the same an American has to pay for the new Republic Cruiser.

2	Pretty expensive for so few pieces (90 + a spare technic pin) The box An action-packed box with one of the sides being oddly empty except from the LEGO-logo.

2	What's inside There is a small building instruction, two polybags (no bag building here) and a sticker sheet with alarmingly many stickers.

2	The build It takes so little time to build this set that I didn't get to take any pictures of the process.

2	Every step was accompanied by an element description although I doubt most of you will need that with so few pieces to keep track on.

2	Most of the dark green bricks have a sticker - even the slopes where the rough surface makes stickers fall off easily!

2	There should also have been a sticker on the windshield, but I wanted to keep that piece clean for better usage later.

2	(I'm one of those who keeps stickers on the bricks) The model You want to see this model from the front, as the back is pretty much neglected There isn't much for the pilot to grab a hold on either.

2	He is pretty much a sitting duck up there with the screen giving him only partial cover.

2	There is a huge wrench next to him which kind of symbolizes the crudeness of the mech.

2	The set isn't called "Cyclone Defender" for nothing.

2	The right arm might hold an ordinary light assault riffle, but the other has a spinning disc with samurai swords which you can turn with the yellow knob on the backside.

2	Those of you who have seen Robot Wars might remember the incredible power of this melee weapon from a robot named Hypnodisc.

2	It would have been nice had there been a pull-back motor to power the disc (I'm sure LEGO has a lot of these in stock), but the simple mechanism still works reasonably well.

2	The riffle comes off and a pin makes it easy to hold with the hand, but the disc is fixed to the arm.

2	It is also a problem that the swords get misaligned quickly during play.

2	The minifig I really like this minifig because of the neat idea with an expression on each side that LEGO has made a standard for Exo Force.

2	Posability Most mech-moc'ers show off their creations using Gundam-like poses.

2	With two joints per leg (one being the ankles) and one for an arm I thought of some less serious poses: Crawling (Silent like a ninja!

2	): Belly gliding: Kick off!

2	; Upside down: Final Rating I have to disappoint you here.

2	This is my first set in this line and I have absolutely no idea of how good it is.

2	The last robot I bought was the awesome 6889 Spyrius Recon Robot for the same price, but it is in a completely different genre.

2	The set had what I expected (two white wings) and is as such a no-nonsense set.

2	I guess it would be of more use if you have some more Exo Force, which I don't.

2	6/10 Ups: Has great minifig, weapons and is easy to build.

2	Downs: Crude design and a bit too expensive for what you get.

2	(Brickshelf gallery)

3	A funny review with cool pics, thanks Lasse D. A somehow mediocre mecha design, but a beautiful dark green color!

3	Upside down mecha yoga exercises on!

3	:-D

2	Nice review :) But... You paid HOW much?

2	This set is priced around 7 Euros here in Germany, which is a very fair price for what you get in my oppinion.

2	It?s a little disappointing though, that I couldn?t think of any alternate builds for this set, and there are no inspirations on the box or the EF website.

2	9.30 euro is MSRP here in Denmark.

2	7 euro would have resulted in a nicer reception from my part, but the strong marked position of LEGO in its homeland together with the general high prices (because some of us are supposedly rich...) makes the prices less bearable.

2	DJ Force, on Sep 17 2007, 11:02 AM, said: I guess that?s what some people refer to as "sarcasm" ;) Oh... 8-| My bad... :-$

3	I couldn't find a review of this wonderful set in here, so here it goes!

3	I got the set for MSRP (180kr = 24 euro) which is a fair price here in Denmark.

3	As all other Creator sets there are instructions for several models (3 in this case).

3	The box The box is a little larger than City sets in the same price range.

3	The primary model is shown on the front while you see the secondary ones on the back.

3	What you get 312 pieces in 5 polybags and two building instructions: one for the primary model and the other for the rest.

3	The built It was impossible for me to speed build this model because of the nifty functional details from the retractable landing gear to the wings that can turn by means of the handle in the back of the model.

3	It took me a full hour to build it because I had to "test" how it all works together.

3	The finished model The landing gear isn't fully enclosed when retracted and the models are sub-minifig scale, but I still love the design of the models.

3	The doors for the rear wheels open as you pull the wheels down and the final piece of functionality comes from the wings that can either tilt (the horizontal stabilizers) or have elevators.

3	Wing in, wings out, wings in, wings out... Ratings As a whole I actually like this set even more than the Big Rig.

3	The models are just as diverse but the added functionality makes the plane more fun to play with than the rig.

3	Price: 7/10 - A good price, but not a bargain as the Big Rig Design: 9/10 - There could have been a sligtly higher level of details in the main model, but all models are really good looking and I especially like the design of the hovercraft.

3	Functionality: 10/10 - I guess you could ask for working rudders, opening cockpit and so on, but the plane is really filled with movable parts and the turning of the wings works really well.

3	Secondary models: 7/10 - A hovercraft!

3	How awesome is that!?

3	If only the last model was just as inventive instead of a standard helicopter... Modifiability: 8/10 - The bricks are in ordinary colours and there is a good variety of them giving you plenty of possibilities for MOC'ing.

3	You can easily make the main model into something that looks more like an F-14.

3	9/10 Probably as good as it gets for a Creator set in this price range.

3	It is entertaining to both build and play with, looks good and the secondary models are worth building as well!

3	(Brickshelf gallery)

3	Thanks!

3	It isn't too hard to convert the plane to Mini-fig size either.

2	I just got set number 7721, the new special edition crawler thing in woolworths in croydon, england.

2	Apparently it is a woolworths exclusive over here and i didnt expect to see it on shelves for a while yet.

2	Pleased to get it, just about to start building it.

3	i got a set of this but i planning to sell away to earn money to buy another set since im almost broke right now.

3	:-D i got a set of this but i planning to sell away to earn money to buy another set since im almost broke right now.

3	:-D

2	Does anyone have a box pic of this set?

2	DP8

3	It is no secret that Marvel is one of the most successful companies right now.

3	From the Avengers to the X-Men and down to even the most obscure characters like Ant-Man, every one of their movies has been a big hit until now.

3	The latest Marvel movie, Fant4stic, was released last month and while I have not seen it yet, I'm sure it's just as great as their other movies.

3	I mean, it has the word "Fantastic" in the title after all!

3	And being the smart business that they are, The Lego Company decided to get in on the hype early and capitalize on this movie's undoubtful success two years in advance by making a set featuring Fant4stic's main villain, Dr. Doom.

3	Now that's what I call forward thinking!

3	But did they do a good job with it or were they being overhasty?

3	Let's find out!

3	Set Number: 76005 Name: Spider-Man: Daily Bugle Showdown Theme: Marvel Super Heroes Subtheme: Ultimate Spider-Man Year of Release: 2013 Pieces: 476 Minifigs: 5 Price: $49.99 USD S@H description: Quote Swing into the Daily Bugle and stop Dr. Doom™!

3	Dr. Doom™ and his henchman Beetle™ are attacking the Daily Bugle in their speedy jet to steal Spider-Man's™ secret identity.

3	It's up to Spider-Man™ and Nova™ to swing in and stop them!

3	Trigger the Daily Bugle's explosion functions to cause destruction as the jet fires missiles!

3	Stop Dr. Doom™ from hitching the jet's anchor hook to the safe with Spider-Man's secret inside!

3	Knock Beetle™ off the building with the swinging web attack and drop Dr. Doom™ inside with the rooftop trapdoor!

3	Then fly Nova™ in through the broken window with the dumpster catapult function and send those villains back to where they came from.

3	Includes Spider-Man™, Nova™, Dr. Doom™, Beetle™ and J. Jonah Jameson™ with accessories and weapons.

3	The first thing that comes to mind after reading this description is: Wow, that's a lot of TMs!

3	Anyway, here are some resource links for this set: Brickset Bricklink Rebrickable The Box Since this set is based on the Ultimate Spider-Man cartoon, the box has the usual USM design with the red Marvel Super Heroes background, an illustration of Spidey in the upper right corner, and the USM logo in the lower right.

3	As usual, there is a minifig line up in the lower left, and since this was before the terrible redesign, you can see the full body of the minifigs.

3	I really miss this type of line up.

3	There is quite a lot going on here: Doctor Doom attacking the Daily Bugle in his jet while simultaneously reaching for J. Jonah Jameson below with his jet's claw, Spider-Man (reluctantly) swings in to save him, while Nova fights off the Beetle.

3	It's a pretty cool scene, even though it's not very accurate to the show.

3	In "Beetle Mania", the episode that this set is based on, the Beetle was indeed out to kill JJJ, but it was in order to stop him from exposing his identity, not Spider-Man's (although Spidey was next on JJJ's list).

3	And while he is a recurring villain on the show, Doctor doom had nothing to do with this plot and didn't even appear in the episode aside from a brief cameo.

3	It's awesome that they included him anyway, though, so I'm not gonna complain.

3	Note that the tower is so tall that it wraps around the top of the box.

3	There, you can also see a scale reference with the Spider-Man minifig.

3	On the back of the box, you can see the interior of the Bugle and all of its play features which there are quite a few of since this is a playset.

3	It's all illustrated pretty well, although Lego's choice of sound effects is still a mystery to me.

3	I don't get why they don't go for Spider-Man's signature "Fwip!"

3	instead of "Fazzing!"

3	and I didn't know that a breaking window made the sound "Btoom!"

3	but I digress.

3	Contents Inside the box you will find three instruction booklets (one smaller than the others), a comic book, a fairly large sticker sheet, five numbered bags, and two loose pieces: A white string piece and a gray 16x8 plate.

3	There aren't really any notable pieces and nobody cares about the comic bock (no offense to the artist), so lets get right to the instructions.

3	They are pretty straight forward and easy to follow.

3	Some of the pages have a ghostly image of Spidey, Nova, and Dr. Doom in the top right corner which is fitting since these are all minifigs that appear in this set (which is strangely not something that can be said for many other Super Heroes instructions with this type of artwork).

3	Minifigures As with most Super Heroes sets, most people will get this set mainly for the minifigs, so without further ado, let's talk about them.

3	Spider-Man is the same old bootless one you get in almost every USM set.

3	Not much to say about him.

3	Some might complain that we don't get Spidey's alter ego Peter Parker in this set, but in the USM cartoon, MJ is actually the one who works at the Daily Bugle, not Peter.

3	Curse the creators of this cartoon for ruining our chances of getting a new Peter Parker minifig by trying to mix things up.

3	Next we get J. Jonah Jameson.

3	He appeared in a Spider-Man 2 set before, but this is a complete redesign.

3	He now has a blue suit with a red tie, a unique face print, and that combed-back hair in dark gray.

3	This new hairpiece doesn't suit him at all and the old flat top hair was perfect for him in my opinion, so I don't know why they changed it.

3	The good thing about this change, however, is the fact that this piece is exclusive to this set in that color.

3	Nova on the other hand is spot-on.

3	He comes with a new helmet mold and some nice torso printing.

3	However, he, too, is missing his boots.

3	TLC should have started making dual-colored legs a long time ago.

3	Here are some reference images to compare them to.

3	Okay, so JJJ's hair may not be completely black in the show, but I still think they should have given his minifig a black hairpiece.

3	His suit is also not quite the right color.

3	He rarely appears in person in the show (including the episode this set is based on) and is usually seen on screens around New York, so this is the best picture of him I could find.

3	I guess I should be happy they included a minifig of him at all.

3	In the episode, it was actually Mary Jane who was at the Bugle during Beetle's attack, so it would have made more sense to include her, but we got her in the Spider-copter set one year later, so that's ok. All three of them have back printing.

3	In JJJ's case I'm using that term loosely since it is only comprised of two lines, but it's nice that they went through the trouble of adding them.

3	Both JJJ and Nova come with angry alternate faces.

3	It almost looks like they're trying to out-angry each other.

3	Who do you think looks angrier?

3	Let me know in the comments section below.

3	Now let's talk about the bad guys.

3	Even though he would be better off in a Fantastic Four set, it's great to finally get Victor Van Doom, one of the greatest Marvel villains ever and in comics in general.

3	He comes with a dark green hood which was new and exclusive in that color at the time, and he is the only minifig in this set that has leg printing.

3	Beetle is a regular minifig with wings.

3	The metallic printing on his face and torso is pretty nice, but I wish it would have continued onto his legs as well.

3	The Beetle looks quite accurate to his on-screen counterpart.

3	The only thing that could have improved him is a new helmet mold with pointy eyebrows/antennae.

3	Doctor Doom, however, looks nothing like he does in the movie.

3	I just don't understand how Lego could have messed him up so badly.

3	Maybe they were working off of early concept art or something.

3	Here is a back view of Doom and Beetle.

3	Beetle would be a pretty boring minifig if it wasn't for his wings which are awesome with their holographic texture.

3	They are so mesmerizing, I could look at those things all day.

3	This piece also appeared in trans.

3	light green in the Galaxy Squad sets which came out at the same time.

3	Here they are without their gear.

3	As you can see, they both have back printing as well.

3	And no, Doctor Doom does not come with an alternate facial expression, which is fine since you can't see much of his expressions due to his mask anyway.

3	Here's a look at Dr. Doom and Nova without their headgear.

3	Some say that Doom's face looks too cartoony, but I think it looks fine.

3	Nova is wearing stylish goggles as a way of explaining his white eyes.

3	It's a far better explanation than the Bat-sweatband.

3	They did the same thing with the masked Wolverine later.

3	Here are all the figs with their accessories.

3	JJJ comes with a camera so that he can take "more pictures of Spider-Man!"

3	Beetle comes with one of those overused ADU guns which is a very poor representation of his wrist-mounted blasters.

3	I hate to say it, but even those bulky new stud shooters would have been a better representation of his weapons.

3	Spidey comes with his usual string of webbing and Nova comes with some Iron Man style translucent studs.

3	The weird thing is that they are red while his powers have a blue glow in the show.

3	Doctor Doom sadly doesn't get any accessories, but who needs weapons when you have a jet with a claw and flick-fire missiles.

3	The Build The first bag contains Spider-Man, a brick separator, and the parts to build the ground floor of the DBC building.

3	After a quick and straight-forward build, you get this.

3	The dumpster and street lamp are separate from the building and since the lamp post is not built onto any baseplate and is quite top-heavy, it gets knocked over pretty easily.

3	Maybe it's meant to be that way, but I would have preferred it if you could stick it onto the baseplate of the building on which there is unfortunately not enough space to do so.

3	As you would expect, the second bag has the parts for the first floor of the building.

3	This is also the bag that contains Beetle.

3	After another fairly simple build, you'll find yourself with a two story building with a spiderweb one side and a fire escape on the other.

3	However, you have to apply three stickers during this section of the build which is never fun.

3	Can you guess what's in bag number 3?

3	Yup, the second floor of the building.

3	You don't need superpowers to predict that one.

3	Also, this bag contains Nova and Jameson.

3	The build of this section is a bit repetitive since the second floor is mostly the same as the first and it takes slightly longer to build since you have to build the rooftop as well.

3	Also, in addition to the two window stickers you have to apply ten 2x2 tile stickers!

3	Trying to do this without having any of them being crooked is a real pain in the megablocks.

3	The next bag contains Doctor Doom and the cockpit of his jet.

3	Doom's cape is in the usual square white box and the string for the claw is folded up in a piece of tape.

3	Here's what you get at the end of this section.

3	Looks more like an escape pod than a jet at this point.

3	The final bag is the smallest as it only includes the few parts needed to finish the Doom jet.

3	Once you build the wings and tail, you stick them onto the cockpit via Technic pins and you're done.

3	Spare Parts These are the parts that are left over after the build.

3	There is the brick separator of course, an extra antenna, and the usual little bits and bops.

3	What's really awesome, though, is that they give you an extra pair of Beetle's wings!

3	Considering what a neat piece this is and that this is the only set in which it comes in trans-black make this a very welcome spare that you can use in your customs.

3	The Finished Set Here is the complete set.

3	The DBC building looks quite tall, especially when you count the antenna.

3	Comparing it to a screenshot from the episode, the general look of the building is there, although there are some inaccuracies.

3	Aside from the fact that it is obviously way down-scaled, the screens that show JJJ ranting about Spider-Man should have been hexagonal, not square, and should have wrapped around the building.

3	However, considering how many stickers you would have had to apply if they would have made it accurate, I'm actually glad they kept the screen mercifully small.

3	Much like Doctor Doom himself, the Doom jet didn't actually appear in the Beetle Mania episode.

3	However, it did appear in a later episode titled "Not A Toy" in which Spider-Man plays around with Captain America's shield, accidentally drops it in Doctor Doom's Latvarian embassy and has to try to retrieve it.

3	And yes, that episode was as godawful as it sounds.

3	Here's a screenshot of the jet from that episode.

3	Like with the DBC, they managed to capture the general shape of the vehicle, although it doesn't look quite as good as in the show.

3	The color scheme is too dark and it looks kind of blockier.

3	Let's take a closer look at the jet.

3	There is no real way to reel the claw in unfortunately.

3	However, there is a stud on the back of the jet that you can stick it onto.

3	Needless to say, this is not the ideal way of storing it.

3	I would have much preferred it if they would have attached it onto winch instead.

3	The engines on the wings can be turned, even though they don't turn in the show, and there is a flick-fire missile on each side.

3	Even if it's not much to look at, at least it's a very swooshable vehicle.

3	On top of each wing there is a tile with the emblem of Latvaria.

3	There was no such emplems on the jet in the cartoon, but they are useful pieces that make it clear whose jet it is, so I'm glad they included them.

3	There is nothing inside the cockpit except for a seat and unless you want to ruin Dr. Doom's nice dark green cape, I wouldn't put him inside of it.

3	They could have at least printed a control panel onto that empty 2x2 tile.

3	Play Features Since this is a playset, let's look at all the play features it has to offer.

3	Like all playsets, the building is open in the back so you can play inside.

3	On the ground floor, there is a potted plant and... nothing else.

3	Seriously?

3	Is this all they could come up with for this floor?

3	They could have included a security desk, a lounge, a second plant, or anything else!

3	As it is, it's just a boring empty lobby.

3	The first floor is a bit more interesting.

3	There is a safe, a swiveling chair, and a pin board with various pictures of Spider-Man.

3	There is one tile that reads: "The true identity of Spider-Man" which is supposedly what the villains are after.

3	I wonder how Jameson got this information in the first place.

3	Speaking of Jameson, the second floor is devoted to his office where he can sit and yell at his non-present employees, demanding "more pictures of Spider-Man!"

3	It also has a swiveling chair as well as a desk with a lamp and a computer.

3	There is a Technic beam connecting his desk with the ceiling of the first floor which you can remove in order to take off the upper half of the building, but it's difficult to do, so I don't recommend it.

3	As you may have noticed in the picture above, there are a few red pegs sticking out of the building.

3	These are for triggering the play features.

3	Most of them are on the roof.

3	There is one on what looks like an air conditioning unit.

3	If you place Spider-Man holding is web-string on the jumper plate in front of it and push the peg, Spidey goes bungee-jumping off the building.

3	Wee!

3	There is also one that sticks out of the side of the building which when pulled triggers a trap door.

3	The third red peg on the roof can be used to pop off the DBC sign.

3	Why is it called the DBC, you ask?

3	It stands for Daily Bugle Communications since in this version of Spider-Man, the Daily Bugle is not only a newspaper, but a news TV station as well, one that promotes its own highly biased views.

3	So basically the Fox News of the Marvel universe.

3	I guess if you're an old school Spider-Man fan, you could just leave off the "C" and have it just stand for Daily Bugle.

3	The sign above the main entrance wont be so easily modified however.

3	There is also a peg between the first and second floor which when pushed pops out one of the windows on the first floor.

3	The safe is only attached to a couple of jumper plates and has some jumper plates on top of it as well, so you can easily attach the Doom jet's claw to it and rip it out of the building as seen on the back of the box.

3	There are also some SNOT bricks on the corners of the building that you can attach spiderwebs or Spidey himself onto for some wall-crawling and webslinging action.

3	This is not so much a play feature as it is just a feature, but as I mentioned earlier, there is a fire escape on the left side of the building.

3	This was a neat idea as it helps it feel like a building in New York City, but it is executed very poorly.

3	There is no hole big enough for the minifigs to climb down through, so they would have to climb down the ladders from the outside which makes no sense.

3	No wonder Spider-Man always needs to rescue people from burning buildings.

3	There is one more play feature in the form of the dumpster.

3	You can open the lid, put a minifig inside, and make them jump by hitting a tab in the back.

3	Remember, this is before the introduction of super jumpers, but nevertheless it's a pretty strange place to launch minifigs out of.

3	I guess even Super Heroes like to do some dumpster diving.

3	You don't think this was funny?

3	No?

3	Well, me neither, but that's the type of humor that this show loves to use.

3	Sigh.

3	Anyway, let's get on to the ratings.

3	Ratings Design: 2/5 - The set looks ok.

3	Despite many inaccuracies, the DBC building and the jet somewhat resemble their on-screen counterparts and don't look too bad, but they definitely could be better.

3	Build: 1/5 - A mostly unchallenging and repetitive build with an attrocious amount of stickers.

3	Minifigs: 4/5 - Definitely the strongest point of the set.

3	Some of the figs could be better, but four out of five of them are exclusive to this set.

3	Doctor Doom is easily the best and probably the most desirable one - unless the Fant4stic movie portraits him so badly that nobody will be interested in him, but that's impossible.

3	Playability: 4/5 - As you would expect from a playset, the playability is quite high, although I still feel like there could have been more.

3	Parts: 3/5 - Not many rare parts.

3	If you're looking for parts for building your own skyscraper with tan walls and lots of doors and windows though, this set is for you.

3	Price: 3/5 - At 476 parts for $50, this set is a bit pricey, but it is somewhat justified by all the large window and wall pieces.

3	Overall: 3/5 - This set is mediocre at best.

3	Playsets are always a good choice for Spider-Man sets since they give Spidey something to swing from, but unfortunately they are rarely pulled off well.

3	The jet is blocky, the building is bare-bones, and the price feels too high.

3	The only reason to get this set are the four exclusive minifigs.

3	This set was discontinued early this year, but if you still see it on clearance somewhere, go ahead and get one for the minifigs and parts, or buy multiples and use the parts to build a better DBC building.

3	I hope you enjoyed this review.

3	It is part of the Reviewers Academy's 7th Anniversary.

3	We're not doing a big celebration this year due to other commitments, but look out for more reviews with the 7th Anniversary banner soon.

3	Now, if you'll excuse me, I am off to see Fant4stic.

3	I hope it's as fantastic as it promises to be!

3	(2 hours later) I was wrong!

3	I was horribly, horribly wrong!

3	The exposition felt like it was from a 3 hour film because it was so long and towards the middle it started to drag.

3	The ending was terrible.

3	Hello everyone!

3	By now many excited LEGO Star Wars fans have started receiving their UCS Falcon.

3	Some of us here enjoy writing reviews and sharing our thoughts.

3	I mentioned to Yoda that I was planning on doing a review of this set but it would likely take me a few weeks (of 1-2 hours per night) to finish building the set.

3	Yoda suggested that I do the review as I go so everyone could see the progress of the set.

3	What a great idea!

3	So, here is the first entry.

3	Feel free to comment along the way.

3	I will try to post photos and updates every night on the build then wrap up the review when I complete the set.

3	If you have any specific questions or photo requests, please be sure to ask.

3	UCS Millennium Falcon Reviewed by Dunamis Set 10179 5195 Pieces $499.95 from LEGO Shop at home The Box: Obviously, this is a box like no other.

3	First of all, it comes in its own shipping carton.

3	Inside of that, there is a standard LEGO carton.

3	Finally, inside the LEGO carton, we have the actual Millennium Falcon box and a nice little letter thanking you for buying the biggest LEGO set ever.

3	Shipping box (Naboo set provided for scale) LEGO Carton and letter LEGO Carton The Millennium Falcon box is really quite nice.

3	There are lots of photos and it does a good job of ?selling?

3	the set.

3	There are 8 individual pieces of tape that keep the lid on the box.

3	The limited first edition comes with a seal on the lower left corner.

3	Millennium Falcon Box (Naboo set provided for scale) Lifting the lid straight up reveals one compartment of several bags on the right.

3	On the left, we find a thin, square box (like a pizza box) that contains the official certificate of authenticity, two sticker sheets and one enormous manual!

3	Under the pizza box, we find two more compartments each filled with several typical LEGO bags.

3	The box weighs 24 pounds!

3	Stickers Pizza Box Pieces in compartments Not quite sure what the little 30th anniversary sticker is for yet.

3	The Certificate of Authenticity is on heavy paper and is suitable for framing.

3	More to come tomorrow.

3	It's late here.

3	Good idea to make this review while you build the set.

3	I'll be monitoring your progress and feedback.

3	The box so huge!

3	Impressive!

3	Nice review.

3	I'll be watching and waiting for the rest.

3	The Manual: The gigantic manual measures 17?

3	x 12?

3	and is almost an inch thick.

3	It is spiral bound with a cardboard like front and back and it is 314 pages.

3	Interesting decision not to break it up into multiple manuals.

3	It is almost unwieldy at this size and thickness.

3	Unfortunately, the manual is not available electronically from the LEGO website.

3	Hopefully, it will be soon.

3	Missing were the little instructions at the beginning telling you to not build this beast on shag carpet and to sort out the 5,000+ pieces before you get started.

3	I guess they figure if you got $500 to spend on this thing, you can build it however you want.

3	As usual, we get the regular LEGO manual features: - Piece call outs for each step - Parts inventory at the end of the manual - Page numbers - Photos of all the other 2007 sets at the end of the manual Manual (paperback book provided for scale) Various manual photos (8x8 plate provided for scale) I'm about 2 hours into building and sorting.

3	I'm trying to stay a day ahead in my posting.

3	The build has been easier than I thought so far.

3	Despite the massive number of pieces, it has not been too hard to sort and find what you need.

3	Build photos will start appearing in tomorrow's entry.

3	The Build: The build is going quicker than I thought.

3	I am sorting as I open the bags that I need.

3	Some bags are in multiples so it is easy to pick them out.

3	The build is a tad repetitive as the framework of the ship is somewhat symmetrical.

3	Here are some progress shots: Note that two plates (1x4 and 1x8) are stacked in between Technic beams.

3	Then the part below is assembled to hold the structure together.

3	This took about an hour of sorting and building: I'll post another update tomorrow.

2	The Minifigs: As you can see, the minifigs are really nice.

2	They even throw in an extra fleshie head!

2	No doubt these will fetch quite a bit on the Bricklink and Ebay markets.

2	I?m keeping mine.

2	Continuing the Build This photo shows how well this model is put together.

2	Notice that they use four of the three-hole beams per side to hold this together.

2	I remember reading that you can hang this model from the ceiling.

2	I don?t doubt it.

2	These right angle Technic pieces are used to reinforce the structure of the model.

2	You can see them used here: I was shocked at how many light gray plates are in this set.

2	I have TWO tubs full of these: The infrastructure is now complete: I got hung up for about an hour looking for one of these: Turns out, LEGO gave me an extra left wedge and shorted me a right wedge.

2	So frustrating!

2	I had to stead one off my 6211 Star Destroyer.

2	It is not a very common piece by the way?

3	I have been taking photos for this review for a few months and I finally took the rest of the photos last night.

3	All the parts.

3	If you want tan, this is the set to get!

3	Main model.

3	The garage is a great addition... ...but the car only just fits!

3	The main house is very nice looking.

3	The windows extend to the sides... ...but not the back.

3	The chimney and drainage work very well, and I love the "basement".

3	I think the front works very well.

3	When I was making this I was multitasking doing weight training; do a set, do a step, do a set... and I ended up missing one of the row paths.

3	I discovered this after I finished the basement.

3	:-| The removable roof reveals BYO floors.

3	Probably why this is called a Model house!

3	The roof was quite interesting to build.

3	This is my first large house set so it all was very new to me.

3	I love the garage door.

3	More nice pipework.

3	This photo I mis-focused but there isn't much to see anyway!

3	The door is a nice touch.

3	The grill to the right on both sides is not just decoration as it hides the hinges for the door.

3	I also made one of the sub-models.

3	I was considering keeping this but I decided against it.

3	Once again the sides have windows... but the back doesn't.

3	The truck is there to make the photo more worthwhile!

3	The roof to this one doesn't come off easily as all the tiles are used for the front.

3	Just to clarify; these houses aren't attached so you can arrange them however you want.

3	The fronts are quite elaborate and it seems that Lego were trying to make this almost like a simpler market street.

3	The truck is too small for a minifig... ...but it probably was my favourite car.

3	Thoughts I highly recommend this set.

3	In most countries it is good value for money, including Australia.

3	The design is excellent and three instructions are included.

3	(The third is a school.

3	If anyone has made it and wants to post photos feel free!

3	At least one person at EB has made it.)

3	I love how each house has its own car.

3	Due to the way the primary model is made it is a bit weak at the corner, but that was a design choice.

3	My only real complaint about this set is how Lego is going though a mould transition and thus some roof slopes are rough, others are smooth.

3	I can accept either, and Lego has been moving to smooth slopes for years now, but to have a set with about 50/50 is annoying.

3	(The MTT was the same.)

3	But that is my only gripe with this excellent set.

2	tall with raised hands and 9 ??

2	with hands down.

3	Edited by Richard Dower, 19 October 2015 - 04:42 PM.

3	Remember when I said in my review of 7090 to expect a review after I went to ToysRus?

3	Well, somehow things didn?t work out, but fortunately I?m finally reviewing my latest purchases, starting with 7091 Catapault Defense, which happens to be one of the best sets in the Castle line.

3	The Box and Instructions: Lego box art is at it?s highest point ever these days, with lots of special effects and great action poses.

3	The castle theme is no exception, and 7091 isn?t either.

3	I?ll let the box speak for itself: I love the back of the castle boxes as well, since they give another action scene and other neat info like a layout of all the accessories.

3	The Contents: Only the bare essentials as usual: piece bags and instructions.

3	I seriously wish they still put mini catalogs inside sets like they did when I was young, but I guess they are too expensive to make or something.

3	Ah well, can?t have everything.

3	No picture of the instructions this time, but since that isn?t necessary I?ll just say that they are fine, and do not have a problem with distinguishing dark gray from black.

3	The Pieces: Here?s your basic shot of every piece included, minus a few extra pieces like an extra Viking horn and black skeleton leg.

3	Not too shabby for a 10 USD set.

3	There?s a lot of nice pieces in 7091, as you can see (and this doesn?t include the accessories or minifig parts!).

3	The brown plates, wheels, and spoked things are always useful, and the dark blue and gold slopes are really cool.

3	However, there?s also a fair amount of technic in here, so be warry.

3	As usual for the castle line, 7091 has a heaping helping of accessories.

3	Most of them are old pieces recolored, but the ball on chain (what?s the actual name, could someone tell me?)

3	and the shields are brand new.

3	I actually like the new skeleton weapon, since it?s fairly detailed and was really the only way TLC could make a part like that.

3	And yes, the shields ARE printed (quite nicely too, if I do say so myself).

3	Plus, you get Viking horns (always useful to have), a grey boulder, a basket, and 3 helmets.

3	Not a half bad deal, eh?

3	Oh, who am I kidding ?

3	it?s awesome!

3	Minifigures: Ah yes, one of the highlights of any castle set.

3	You get 2 soldiers and 2 skellies this time, all with different weapons.

3	The two soldiers are just regular Crown troops with different faces ?

3	nothing special, except that they are awesome anyway.

3	The skeletons on the other hand are much more interesting: an archer and a black skellie!

3	Archers cool, of course, but I know many don?t like the printing on the black skeletons.

3	Well, let me say that I don?t mind it so much.

3	The only real problem is that the eyes are dark red instead of just red, which makes the printing a bit less noticeable.

3	And I?ve been through it before that the new skeleton molds in general don?t bother me at all ?

3	go skeletons!

3	The Finished Set: Alright, there?s two builds in this set, and I?ll start with the smaller: the skeleton barricade.

3	Okay, so it?s nothing special, but it?s cool all the less.

3	The shield on the front and the slanted spears are nice touches.

3	Here?s just how the skeletons can tower over their own barricade: with a little step.

3	Ah, the catapault.

3	The lovely catapault.

3	Seriously, I love TLC?s design.

3	Very effective, and also very realistic, especially compared to KK.

3	Love the side details and the swiveling base, and you gotta love the clever use of that basket.

3	Playability: Yes, I?ve made it a tradition now to write stories for any castle set I buy (and this isn?t the last one, you can be sure of that!).

3	Here?s one featuring everything in 7901: Oh, and here?s a small ship I made out of all the pieces in this set plus a couple extra figures and weapons from my copy of 7901.

3	Not half bad, IMO, considering what I had to work with.

3	Overall Rating: Presentation: 9/10 Pieces: 8/10 Minifigures: 9/10 Finished model: 9/10 Playability: 8/10 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Final Score: 8.6/10 Once again, I highly recommend the reviewed set.

3	Castle is possibly the best theme this year, and this set is one of many that prove it.

3	As with all castle sets, it?s best if you buy several if you want to truly enjoy it, but this set alone is also impressive in both design and pieces and minifigures.

3	Get at least one if you have even a slight liking for Castle.

3	I am currently starting to save for 2008 but for Christmas i think i want the Skeleton Carridge and the Naboo N-1 Fighter.

3	It's that time of year again when the days get shorter, the nights get colder, and children all around the world stare longingly into warmly lit toy shops and prepare their wishlist to send to Santa.

3	This is also the time when The Lego Group releases their latest Winter Village set which has been an annual tradition for the past seven years.

3	These sets have been very popular, especially among AFOLs, and are always highly anticipated.

3	However, while some entries in this series have been more popular than others, none has been as controversial as this year's set, the Winter Toy Shop, which is a re-release of the first Winter Village set, 10199 Winter Toy Shop from 2009.

3	It seems that many think that this set didn't need to be remade and would have preferred a new set instead, or that it is not different enough from the original and will be redundant in a completionist's collection.

3	Does it deserve all the hate?

3	Let's find out.

3	Disclaimer: I don't own the 2009 version, so I can't compare them visually, but I will do my best to let you know what is different in this version.

3	If you do need a visual reference, you can refer to Svelte's excellent review of the original.

3	Set Number: 10249 Name: Winter Toy Shop Theme: Creator Year of Release: 2015 Pieces: 898 Minifigs: 8 Price: £59.99 / $79.99 / 69.99€ S@H description: Quote Welcome to the Winter Toy Shop!

3	The holiday season has arrived and the toymaker is busy finishing off his latest creations!

3	Outside, children ski and snowboard, and a freshly built snowman sparkles in the light that shines from the toyshop tower.

3	Help decorate the huge tree that stands at the center of the square, play with the curious kitten on the cozy wooden bench or join in with the carolers beneath the ornate streetlamp.

3	This charming set also features a ladder, trees in various sizes, jack-in-the-box, a toy biplane, helicopter, rocket, train, race car, truck, robot, tugboat, teddy bear and a wrapped gift.

3	Have fun building this enchanting winter wonderland!

3	Includes a snowman and 8 minifigures with assorted accessories: a male caroler, female caroler, a woman, 2 men, 2 boys and a girl.

3	S@H Bricklink Brickset The Box The box art of this set is similar to that of the original, but there are some notable differences.

3	The Christmas tree is on the right side of the image this time while the park bench is on the left and of course it features this year's design for Creator boxes with the dark blue stripe along the right side and the "Expert" logo in the top right corner.

3	There's also a small picture of the back of the toy shop and the background looks less cartoony than on the original.

3	The back is also very similar, showing a different angle of the toy shop along with some close-ups, although this time there is no minifig lineup.

3	Instead, the minifig lineup is on the right side of the box.

3	It also includes the accessories that each minifig comes with and some of the toys.

3	On the left side of the box there is a thumbnail of the box art and the set name in six different languages.

3	They also want to make sure that you know that there are batteries included by saying it in dozens of languages.

3	The top of the box features the inventory and a 1:1 scale reference with the female caroler.

3	On the bottom there is a picture that reminds you that there is a light brick included in this set, in case that wasn't clear from the front of the box, and it confirms that yes, it is a bad idea to put it in water, in case you were planning to go swimming with your Winter Toy Shop.

3	The Contents Inside the box there are two instruction booklets and two groups of bags, one for each instruction booklet.

3	While two groups of bags is not as many as there usually are in other sets of this size, it's still better than the first version of this set where the bags weren't numbered at all, so this makes the build a bit easier.

3	The large bag in Group 1 and the two large bags in Group 2 have a white stripe going down the middle of the bag and only have one group number printed on it along with some other number and some kind of scan code.

3	I have no idea why they made this distinction for these bags or what that code is for, so if any of you know the purpose of this, please let me know in the comments below.

3	Here is a random instructions page.

3	As you can see, the building steps can get quite challenging as they sometimes include many different pieces in one step, especially when it uses a lot of brown pieces which are very dark and hard to see in the instructions, living up to the set's status as an expert-level set.

3	Most of the time, though, the instructions are pretty clear and easy enough to follow.

3	There are some parts in new colors in this set that weren't in the first version or any other set until now, such as that large, flat Technic arch in dark green, the jester hat in orange and blue, one of those new 2z2 round jumper tiles in brown, a golden frog(!

3	), and a snowboard in dark blue.

3	There are also some rare Friends parts that make their Creator debut here such as the skis in azure and that new clear 1x1 round tile with a tiny tube coming out of it which is usually used as a stand for Friends accessories and is a very useful piece, especially for SNOT techniques (and no, I'm not talking about the type of snot that many people usually have stuck in their nose around this time of year).

3	There are some printed parts as well, such as the clock tile, the letter tile, and the register slope like in the first version of the set.

3	We also get a new face print for the white cat which is more in line with other modern cat designs.

3	But the best part is the shop sign which is printed this time around.

3	It features a lovely wood pattern, the words "toy shop", and a toy soldier on both sides of the sign.

3	Which is ironic since the shop doesn't seem to sell any toy soldiers like this, but it looks so good on the sign that I won't sue them for false advertising.

3	The Minifigs Let's start with the most unique figures in this set, the carolers.

3	These two were also the highlight in the first version of the set, but in the original they both had the same head (this one -> ) which featured a very questionable facial expression that could easily be taken out of context.

3	In this version, they have unique faces which look much better and help distinguish their gender.

3	The male caroler uses Lord Vampyre's torso which looks quite snazzy on him.

3	Maybe this is Lord Vampyre before he became a vampire?

3	The female caroler is easily the best minifig in the set, though, because in addition to her exclusive head, she also gets an exclusive torso and skirt print!

3	A huge improvement over the generic unprinted one in the original.

3	She also gets the queen hair in dark brown and Aragorn's lined cape instead of two combined regular capes.

3	This set truly is the Return of the Queen!

3	The snowman is technically not a minifig, but as you can see here, he is exactly as tall as one and he is the first thing you build after the minifigs, so I included him here.

3	He has mostly the same design as before, except this time he has robot claws for arms instead of levers.

3	Which is good since they allow him to hold accessories such as his broom.

3	His carrot nose is included separately again.

3	The carolers both have back printing while the snowman looks no different from the back than he does from the front.

3	Here you can see the black side of the female's cape.

3	This lined cape is so much nicer than the solution they used in the original.

3	Next up we have what I assume is a married couple who are likely the parents of at least one of the kids, as well as the toymaker who I will call Geppetto.

3	The man in the pinstripe suit was not included in the first version of the set, so he's a bonus minifig!

3	These guys are fairly generic, but they have some detailed torso prints, so they look pretty nice.

3	Geppetto seems to have gotten younger since the release of the original set since his gray hair has now turned dark tan and he doesn't seem to need glasses anymore.

3	The men both have back printing, but the woman is the only one in this set who doesn't get a back print.

3	Why you gotta be so discriminating against women, LEGO?!

3	Last but not least, there are the kids.

3	One of the boys wears dark blue pants, a green jacket, and a wool cap.

3	He looks a bit like a lumberjack, so let's call him lumberjack boy, or Jack for short.

3	The little girl wears an outfit that wouldn't look out of place in the Friends theme with a lavender scarf and pants.

3	I'll call her Lavender.

3	The second boy is wearing an Octan jacket and a sports helmet which makes it ironic that he is the one not doing any winter sports on the box art.

3	I'll call him President Business Junior, or PBJ for short.

3	All of the kids have fairly detailed back printing which makes up for the fact that much like the adults, they are made out of mostly common parts.

3	PBJ's helmet and scarf cover up the back of his head nicely which is important as you will see in the next picture.

3	What's also great about these figs is that half of them have a double-sided head.

3	Here you can see PBJ doing his best Macaulay Culkin impression.

3	I also removed his scarf so you can see the printing on his torso better.

3	But he's not the only one who seems to be easily scared.

3	The mother also has a very alarmed expression.

3	Maybe she got surprised by the Jack-in-the-box or maybe she just realized how expensive toys are nowadays.

3	You can see the female caroler's back printing here.

3	Her alternate expression is a non-singing face which is very nice to have and I wish the male caroler could have one too.

3	She looks quite cute with those rosy cheeks.

3	But the most adorable out of all of them has to be the little girl.

3	She comes with a pouting sad face that will melt your heart.

3	Please, don't cry!

3	I'll buy you any toy you want, just stop looking at me like that!

3	The Build The first half of the build is dedicated to the surroundings of the toy shop.

3	It includes the Christmas tree, the park bench, the snowman, the toys, the carolers, Jack and Lavender.

3	The large bag contains two smaller bags with small pieces, a white box that contains the caroler's cape, and the jester hat in its own little bag.

3	The first thing you build after the minifigs and the snowman is the toys.

3	This version of the set has a lot more toys than the original which is good because I always felt that the first Toy Shop was a bit light on toys.

3	Also, the ones that were in the original have been updated.

3	For example, instead of the two pairs of skis, you now get one pair of skis that use the new ski mold and a snowboard.

3	The Jack-in-the-box is mostly the same, except it now has an orange and blue color scheme instead of the red and blue from the original.

3	This change was probably not necessary, but hey, at least we get a new jester hat out of it.

3	And instead of the brick-built teddy bear you get the new teddy bear mold.

3	I have mixed feelings about this change because I actually kinda liked the brick-built teddy design and using a specialized mold seems to be going against the spirit of Creator sets, but on the other hand I can't deny that the molded teddy looks better than the blocky old one.

3	Meh.

3	The new toys include a tugboat which has some rounded Technic pieces as its hull, a biplane, a rocket, a helicopter, and a truck that cleverly uses roller skates for its wheels.

3	These are all quite brilliant designs that feel like micro versions of Lego City sets and make a great addition to the set.

3	Here is a back view of some of the more complex models.

3	As you can see, the Friends accessory stand has been cleverly used to hold the biplane's fin in place and to provide a stand for the helicopter.

3	The Jack-in-the-box has a hinged lid.

3	The only thing that bugs me a bit is the T-piece on top of the helicopter that holds the rotor in place, but I can't think of any better way they could have done it.

3	Next is the ladder that is used to decorate the tree which is exactly the same as the first version.

3	The supports are on a click-hinge, so they can be adjusted or folded away.

3	Then, you build the tree itself.

3	You begins, of course, with the stand which is mostly the same design as before, but this time the plates at the bottom are brown instead of white and have golden studs as feet.

3	Next, you build the first layer of branches.

3	The main difference in this version of the tree is that this one actually has a brown stem rather than just a Technic axle on which you stack the layers of branches one by one.

3	You wont be able to see the stem in the final result, but I like this change as it makes the tree more realistic.

3	Then you add the second layer of branches.

3	This one doesn't have lights/candles and attaches to the lower layer at an angle using the four trans-yellow studs close to the stem.

3	The third layer is added.

3	This one has lights again.

3	Each layer is similar in that they are all made out of green plates that are built around a 4x4 ring plate, but they get smaller each time and are constructed differently enough for the build not to feel repetitive.

3	With the addition of the fourth layer, we get close to finishing the tree.

3	Lastly, you add one more layer and the tip of the tree.

3	Now it's time to decorate the tree!

3	However, it's not as fun as it sounds since that requires you to add lights to the two chains/ropes first which can get a bit repetitive.

3	The clips holding the lights to the chain were white, but this time they're pearl gold which looks much nicer in my opinion.

3	The next part of the build is the park bench with the streetlamp and the little tree.

3	This is a fairly quick build with not much to it.

3	The fishbowl helmet parts are a useful piece that you don't see too often, so it's nice to get them again in this remake.

3	The design is pretty much the same as in the original set except for the wreaths on the streetlamp which use a green life preserver instead of a round 2x2 plate.

3	This is another instance where they use a specialized piece instead of a brick-built solution, but I'm okay with that because unlike with the teddy bear, this part was not originally intended to be a wreath, so it's still nice part usage.

3	The second half of the build is dedicated to the toy shop itself and includes the couple, Geppetto, and PBJ.

3	Please note that there is a fourth 6x10 plate burried under the parts.

3	You begin by tiling the floor, setting up the walls, and adding the interior items such as the fireplace, the cash register, and the toy displays.

3	Next, you add the walls, windows, and the door and the ground floor of the shop is finished.

3	So far, the build is the same as the old toy shop, except this time they decided to have the white stripes on the marquees be the longer ones instead of the dark red ones for some reason.

3	I don't know why they did this and kinda would have preverred to get dark red 1x1 plates instead of white, but it doesn't detract from the look of the shop, so I don't really care.

3	Now we begin with the upper floor.

3	This is where things start to look a little different.

3	Can you tell the difference?

3	The difference is that this time they attach the roof using clip-hinges instead of bulky Technic constructions which gives you more space on this floor and allows it to look more like an actual attic.

3	They even tile the floor next to the frog clock.

3	Aftter adding the roof, the build is finished.

3	The main roof feels a bit loose since it's only attached to the building by one side.

3	I'm not sure if this was an issue in the old toy shop, but it's not a big deal.

3	I just wouldn't pick the set up by the roof.

3	What I do like is that they used double cheese slopes on the awning on the outer wall of the tower instead of singles which makes it a bit easier to build.

3	I like how the supports under the tower roof now match those of the main roof.

3	The wreaths have also been updated like the ones on the streetlamp.

3	And those Technic arches under the roof look a lot more like garlands now.

3	On the original, they were dark gray, so I didn't even know they were supposed to be garlands and assumed they were part of the architecture.

3	The shop sign looks a lot better now that it is printed.

3	The old one just looked like a white flag.

3	I also like how the small plates under the marquee give it a wavy look and they included two trees in different sizes on the right side of the shop.

3	The back is nice and open and allows you to see the rest of the toys, the robot, train, and race car, all of which have just as much of a simple and clever design as the other toys.

3	The clock looks much nicer with the new golden frog.

3	Because golden frogs make everything better.

3	Spare Parts There are quite a few small parts left over, including a roller skate and one of those Friends accessory stands which will come in handy.

3	The Complete Set Here you can see the full set together.

3	It looks quite nice and festive with all the little details and there are many scenes that you can play out with it: You can have the minifigs decorate the tree, have the kids play in the snow, have the carolers sing by the bench, have the toymaker build some toys in his workshop, or have the parents buy presents for their kids.

3	It's a festive, toy-filled Winter Wonderland!

3	The fireplace looks cozy and I like the brick pattern going up the chimney.

3	The entrance of the shop looks a bit empty aside from the cash register.

3	I feel like they could have displayed some more toys here, but oh well.

3	Being a set targeted at teens and adults, there aren't really any play features aside from the light brick which is attached to a hinge, so you can either activate it by pressing the button with your finger or tilting the brick upward so that the button is pressed against the roof.

3	However, since the roof is not connected in the middle and only attached on the sides, it tends to split open a bit when you do that, so I'm not sure if attaching the roof this way here was such a good idea.

3	Nevertheless, it looks quite nice when the light is lit.

3	Ratings Design: 5/5 - This set is as gorgeous as it was back in 2009!

3	The small updates that they made are mostly good ones, although the absence of a brick-built teddy is a bit disappointing and the new way the roof is attached, while not as bulky as before, makes the roof slightly unstable, but those are just nitpicks.

3	Build: 5/5 - There are some interesting building techniques here, such as those on the tree, the roof, and the toys.

3	The fact that the parts are only split into two groups and the part callouts can get fairly complex makes it a challenging, enjoyable build.

3	Minifigs: 5/5 - They did a great job updating the figs in this set.

3	While only 3 of the torsos in the original had any printing, all of the torsos have printing front and back in this set, even the skirt and cape of the female caroler.

3	You get two exclusive heads and half of the heads are double-sided, plus you get 8 instead of 7 minifigs.

3	You really can't ask for more in a Creator set.

3	Playability: 4/5 - This set is more meant to be displayed than to be played with, but there are plenty of things to play with if you want.

3	All the different minifigs, accessories, and set pieces make for endless possibilities for play.

3	It's especially fun to swoosh the micro vehicles around.

3	Parts: 3/5 - There are lots of good parts here.

3	Most of them are fairly common, but there are some rare parts and some even in exclusive colors.

3	Price: 4/5 - This set costs $20 more than the original, but considering that this set has nearly 900 pieces, including some rare and exclusive ones, as well as more minifigs with much better printing, I think $80 is still a fair price.

3	Overall: 5/5 - So what's my opinion of this set?

3	For a remake, I think it's great.

3	They managed to make a good set even better.

3	Are the changes minor?

3	Yes.

3	Are they an improvement?

3	Mostly, yes.

3	Were they necessary?

3	Perhaps not, but it's good that they made them instead of just re-releasing the exact same set.

3	So if you didn't get the first Winter Toy Shop, I can highly recommend getting this one.

3	If you do already have the old version, this one might still be worth picking up for the hugely improved minifigs and rare parts alone.

3	As for the controversy over re-releasing the Winter Toy Shop, I can see where the haters are coming from, but I find their complaints to be quite petty.

3	I can understand if you're disappointed because you already have the first Winter Toy Shop and were looking forward to a new set this year, but there's always next year.

3	If you're a completist and feel like TLG is forcing you to buy a set you don't need, you're wrong.

3	Nobody is forcing you to buy anything but yourself.

3	If you decide to buy every set in a theme no matter what it is, that's your problem, not LEGO's.

3	So put down your torches and pitchforks and just be glad that they improved the set design and gave us another chance to buy this classic set.

3	There are far worse things that can happen in this world than Lego re-releasing one of their most popular sets.

3	Sorry for that little rant.

3	So what is your opinion on re-releases like this?

3	Please cast your vote in the poll above.

3	I hope you enjoyed this special Eurobricks Reviewers Academy review and would like to thank The Lego Group for the opportunity to review this set.

3	Happy Holidays everyone!

3	Bat-Toys by Okay Yaramanoglu, on Flickr

3	Thanks for a great review first of all.

3	I do like the upgrades and changes made from the original 2009 set, more colours and parts are offcourse available today than back in 2009.

3	It does look like a great set and i would really realy have loved to get it myself if i had the funds.

3	However their are so many other sets thats first priority for me this december and next year, so sadly i might have to pass on this if its not that i can get it redicioulusly cheap at some point.

3	And yeah, we should appreciate that LEGO does keep sets coming, even if its just upgrades from earlier releases.

3	Town is known for a new police and fire station every year, cant see why a new toyshop is so upsetting.

3	Once again thanks for a great review.

3	And happy holidays to you as well.

3	Nice to see they finally updated that generic screaming face from the 2007 Castle line.

3	Awesome review, Oky.

3	I have the old set so I won't be picking this up.

3	Great review.

3	You almost make me want to buy one.

3	I don't know what it is with these sets.

3	On the one hand they are so nicely designed and cute on the other side I never seriously consider buying one.

3	I can't explain what it is that holds me back.

2	For the first four years, my mother-in-law got me the new winter village set for Christmas; after the last two, which didn't really fit thematically in my display, I had hoped for a new one--particularly since my daughter is getting to be around the age where she can play with them.

2	I mention her specifically because I've seen lots of people dismiss those who are a bit disappointed as rabid adults who don't care about kids getting cool sets, and I don't think that's fair.

2	I may have to see how much some of the parts go for on Bricklink.

2	The rerelease is better than the original, but not good enough that I'd want to spend $80 to get a set that's nearly identical to one I have.

3	REVIEW - 42044 - DISPLAY TEAM JET INTRODUCTION The smallest of the 2016 sets, is the Display Team Jet.

3	It doesn't seem to have lots of functionality, but maybe the landing gear is retractable.

3	This set kind of reminds me to the 9394 - Jet Plane, although it's obviously a lot smaller.

3	As you can read in my review of the 42052 - Heavy Lift Helicopter basically anything flying is +1 for me, so let's find out if this set also fits the bill.

3	Note: All images can be clicked for hi-res versions.

3	SET INFORMATION Number: 42044 Title: Display Team Jet Theme: Technic Released: 2016 Part Count: 113 Box Weight: 193 gr Box Dimensions: 15,4 cm x 13,8 cm x 5,9 cm Set Price (MSRP): € 9,99 Price per Part: € 0,088 Links: Brickset, Bricklink THE BOX Being a small set, it obviously comes in a small box.

3	The Display Team Jet is an Aerobatics Jet, used in air shows.

3	On the box it's flying rather high, but at least it's at a safe distance from the crowd.

3	Front side shows the main model, together with a small section indicating you can use Digital Building instructions to build this model.

3	BACK SIDE The back side shows the B-model, a Stunt Plane.

3	And again a reference to the apps for Digital Building instructions.

3	More on the Stunt Plane later.

3	CONTENT OF THE BOX The box contains: 2 Instructions Booklets (A- and B-model) 1 Sticker Sheet 3 Technic Liftarms 2 Bags INSTRUCTION BOOKLETS Both the instructions for the A- and B-model are included in the box.

3	STICKER SHEET A lot of stickers for such a small set.

3	Apparently no panel is left untouched.

3	LIFTARMS Three liftarms unsealed, nothing out of the ordinary for a small set.

3	BAGS Two bags containing the rest of the parts.

3	HIGHLIGHTED PARTS This section describes the new and/or otherwise interesting parts.

3	YELLOW 5L AXLES The 5L Axle in Yellow has never been released before, so it's one of the new parts for this year.

3	BLACK 7L FLEX AXLES For the layman this seems a common part, but the 7L Soft Axle actually has never been released in black before.

3	Combined with the re-release of the 19L Soft Axle in black, this will open up lots of possibilities.

3	For those of you thinking you've read this text before; you are right, the new Drag Racer contains these new 7L Flex Axles too.

3	WHITE PANELS This small set comes with a whopping 10 panels.

3	Great for the ones who like panels.

3	Not so great if you think TLG is using too much panels lately.

3	RUDDER This part, the Small Bionicle Wing, is the same as the one used in last year's 42033 - Record Breaker.

3	PART LIST This set contains 113 parts, all listed below.

3	THE BUILD This is the collection of parts, used to build the Jet.

3	It sure looks like we are getting a landing gear.

3	The build is fun, but pretty straightforward.

3	There aren't any special or cool techniques used in this set.

3	It almost took me more time to apply all the stickers than to build the actual model.

3	FINISHED MODEL The finished Jet does look cool though.

3	The white and yellow color scheme, combined with the stickers, work really well.

3	I have seen people refer to the plane as being orange, but it's definitely yellow.

3	Technic (or LEGO in general) tends to have some color variation when it comes to yellow.

3	I do concur this is the warmer variant of yellow, but it's not orange.

3	The back of the plane looks nice too, although I am not a big fan of the rudder part.

3	It looks too detailed, compared to the other panels.

3	It's not a big deal though, and maybe it's just me.

3	PARTS LEFT Only three common parts left.

3	FEATURES AND FUNCTIONS This set has a single feature and that is a retractable landing gear.

3	It's operated by the black 12T Double Bevel Gear near the cockpit.

3	In the following picture you can see the landing gear retracted.

3	This image shows the landing gear when the plane is ready for landing.

3	Hopefully the pilot will roll the plane before landing, but you probably know what I mean VIDEO Here's s short video demonstrating the Display Team Jet.

3	B-MODEL This set also includes the building instructions for the B-model, a Stunt Plane.

3	The building experience for the Stunt Plane is more or less the same as for the Jet.

3	Well, what do you expect when both models are planes with a limited number of parts.

3	For an alternative model the Stunt Plane looks fine.

3	There's not a lot of functionality in this plane, but it's worth mentioning that the tail wheel allows the plane to roll on a flat surface.

3	The plane also has working propellors.

3	Both functions are demonstrated in the video.

3	Unfortunately, the landing gear of the Stunt Plane is not retractable.

3	PARTS LEFT A couple of extra leftover parts, but it's nice to see that most of the parts have been used in the B-model as well.

3	Actually, there's probably an extra yellow Technic Smooth 1/2 Bush left.

3	I just found it on my desk, but it could belong to one of the other sets.

3	VIDEO Here's a video demonstrating the Stunt Plane.

3	SUMMARY Two nice planes for 13 bucks, that's basically what you get.

3	Both models look good and the set has some interesting new parts.

3	Especially the 7L Flex Axle will be very popular.

3	It comes with a decent collection of white panel, although they are very common nowadays.

3	Both models have limited functionality, but each of them has at least one function to give the model some playability for kids, other than the swooshability that is.

3	Okay, it might lack some proper functions, but I still think kids will love this set.

3	I can see kids running around with one of the planes in their hands.

3	All in all I think this set delivers what you'd expect.

3	SCORE Let's see how this set flies!

3	Remember that the grades are based on it being a small set.

3	Obviously a set like this, cannot be compared with a Mercedes flagship.

3	8 DESIGN For a small set, the model looks very authentic.

3	7 BUILDING EXPERIENCE No surprises.

3	7 FEATURES Just the retractable landing gear.

3	8 PLAYABILITY It has swooshability, so I see kids running around with this model.

3	7 PARTS Lots of panels, if you are into that.

3	8 VALUE FOR MONEY Can't go wrong with these small sets.

3	7,5 FUN FOR KIDS More image can be found on my Flickr page.

3	Thank you for reading.

3	I hope you enjoyed it.

3	So this set showed up in stores yesterday, and i immediately picked two up.

3	Got this at the weekend, mainly for the parts, but built it first.

3	Agreed with other comments - awesome swooshability.

3	REVIEW - 42046 - GETAWAY RACER INTRODUCTION Starting with the 42010 - Off-road Racer and 42011 - Race Car in 2013, TLG released two sets in the first half of each year, using a pullback motor.

3	The pullback motor allows the model to be pulled back, followed by forward motion.

3	Usually there's no apparent relation between the two set, other than the ability to combine them into an alternate build.

3	This year there seems to some sort of Cops and Robbers scene going on.

3	A Getaway Racer and a Police Interceptor.

3	That can't be a coincidence.

3	Makes you wonder who will be victorious, the good guys or the bad guys.

3	Let's find out!

3	Note: All images can be clicked for hi-res versions.

3	SET INFORMATION Number: 42046 Title: Getaway Racer Theme: Technic Released: 2016 Part Count: 170 Box Weight: 302 gr Box Dimensions: 26,0 cm x 13,8 cm x 5,9 cm Set Price (MSRP): € 19,99 Price per Part: € 0,118 Links: Brickset, Bricklink THE BOX The box has the same dimensions as previous year's pullback motor sets.

3	In the lower right corner there's a visual explanation of the pullback mechanism.

3	The dark model with it's decals sure looks like a cool hot rod.

3	CONTENT OF THE BOX The box contains: 1 Instructions Booklet 1 Sticker Sheet 2 Technic Liftarms 1 Pullback Motor 3 Bags INSTRUCTION BOOKLET Just a single booklet.

3	Unfortunately no booklet for the alternate model.

3	STICKER SHEET The sticker sheet contains a lot of cool stickers with flames and skulls etc.

3	PULLBACK MOTOR AND LIFTARMS The pullback motor and two liftarms are found unbagged.

3	BAGS A total of three bags containing the majority of the parts.

3	HIGHLIGHTED PARTS This section describes the new and/or otherwise interesting parts.

3	Actually, this set is the only set of 1H 2016 which doesn't use any new parts, not even parts in a new color.

3	TIRES The Getaway Racer uses four low profile tires (Tire 37 x 22 ZR).

3	RIMS The rims are Wheel 30.4mm D. x 20mm in Pearl Gold, found in 12 other sets.

3	PANELS This set contains three #3 Panelsand three #4 Panels in black.

3	PART LIST This set contains 171 parts, all listed below.

3	THE BUILD This being a small model, I won't show any building steps.

3	Let's skip right to the finished model.

3	Below you can see the end result.

3	In my opinion the model looks great.

3	It's got that hot rod vibe going on and the stickers add darkness to the vibe.

3	Slight problem with this set is that it really needs the stickers to finish the look.

3	Otherwise it's quite dull, with black and dark grey liftarms and panels.

3	The rear view shows the pullback motor connected directly to the rear axle.

3	In this image you can also clearly see the exhaust pipes on the side, which are very well executed.

3	The 3x3 Technic Discs with stickers, used in the rim, result in only seeing a part of the rim.

3	This works very well with the golden rims.

3	The bottom view shows the chassis of the car.

3	Nothing really noteworthy, as you would expect from a pullback set.

3	VIDEO The following video gives you an overview of the finished model.

3	PARTS LEFT These six parts are left after building the model.

3	Seems about right.

3	FEATURES AND FUNCTIONS This being a pullback motor set, it only has a single feature.

3	The video below demonstrates the acceleration of the vehicle.

3	My girlfriend was kind enough to catch the model before it fell to the ground.

3	Or did it hit something before it fell to the ground?!

3	VIDEO This video shows the pullback functionality.

3	B-MODEL The alternate model is a combined build with the Police Interceptor, which you can see on the back of the box.

3	Unfortunately the instructions for the combined B-model are not included, so I didn't get a chance to build it.

3	This would make for a fun challenge, building the B-model without the instructions.

3	SUMMARY Pullback sets are not the most technically advanced models, so you can't expect any other functionality than hitting the walls in your house.

3	However, I think they are very appealing to kids.

3	The fact that this year's pullback sets form a duo adds to the fun.

3	In my opinion TLG hit the nail on the head with the Getaway Racer and Police Interceptor.

3	The Getaway Racer looks very badass, which is something you don't see every day in a Technic set.

3	SCORE How do I grade the bad guy in this year's duo.

3	8 DESIGN It looks so cool, but it does need the stickers.

3	7 BUILDING EXPERIENCE Nothing out of the ordinary.

3	7 FEATURES Limited to the pullback-and-drive functionality.

3	7 PLAYABILITY Combined with the Police Interceptor, kids will love it.

3	It does need it's Nemesys though.

3	7 PARTS Collection of common parts.

3	Gold rims could be interesting.

3	8 VALUE FOR MONEY Pullback sets always deliver a certain value.

3	7,3 HIT IT!

3	More image can be found on my Flickr page.

3	Thank you for reading.

3	I hope you enjoyed it.

3	I almost purchased this today because I like the wheel / disc combo so much.

3	Another great review Jim!

3	And again i love the model, those pearl gold wheels This one definitely goes on the "buy on sight" list
