3	Lego 42049 Mine Loader Thanks to Lego and EuroBricks for making this review possible!

3	This was supposed to be a preview-review, before the Dec 1 release date for the set, but it got stuck in customs or something and didn't arrive in time.

3	Well, I'd rather do a good, late review than a rushed review, so here it is.

3	Name: Mine Loader Set Number: 42049 Pieces: 476 (I think) Price: $39.99 (I think) Minifigs: 0 Theme: Technic Year of Release: 2016 Links: Bricklink Brickset The Box Another standard Technic box, not that there's anything wrong with that.

3	It is a littler weird that the mine loader is shown OUTSIDE the mine, but whatever.

3	The Back of the Box Again, very standard.

3	It's oddly technical, showing the exact angle of the machine when turning, but that's the sort of nerdy detail that Technic people like.

3	The alternate Mine Cutting Machine model looks interesting and unusual as well.

3	The 1:1 Part The 1:1 part on the top of the box is especially helpful with this set.

3	These mining machines are very oddly proportioned, since they need to fit in mine tunnels, so it's hard to judge the model size based on the wheels or seat like you can an ordinary set.

3	The Contents You get manuals for both models (a single book for the B and two books for the main), a medium size sticker sheet, 4 bags, and 4 loose tires.

3	The Special Parts This set has 4 of the new mudguard panels in yellow, two cylinder halves in red (a new color), some of the new color red and yellow axles, a couple of the new-ish Technic spacers, some of the axle-pin combination pieces, and a couple swords!

3	I'm pretty sure that's "an antenna" and a spare.

3	The Start of the B-Model Since I like the main model better, I'm building the alternate first, so that's how I'll write the review.

3	There's "power" for something (probably the engine) being taken off the one axle here.

3	Overall, a pretty standard Technic frame beginning with some structural beams, a frame, and using liftarms to support axles out to the sides.

3	More of the Frame The far end of the model has some obvious steering mechanism being formed, as well as a pivoting arm right in the center that's probably the connection from the Hand of God knob.

3	The Steering Yup.

3	Called it.

3	Oddly, there is a different turning radius between right and left right now.

3	I wonder if that'll get fixed... More Mechanisms That's looking more Technic now.

3	Sad to see a u-joint being used just as a fixed straight connection like that, but it is the alternate model...

3	The Engine Block Because all engines should be enclosed in a red cylindrical housing, am I right?

3	The Chassis It's definitely coming together now.

3	And yes, the B-model instructions tell you to put the stickers on.

3	It doesn't matter whether you build the main or alternate first, you'll get the stickers on (almost - there were a couple leftover that didn't get used in the B-model).

3	Almost Done With the rest of the body done and the wheels on, you really get the scale of this machine.

3	That blue seat is tiny compared to the rest of it!

3	And yes, the uneven steering lock got fixed.

3	After putting the wheels on, you add a couple of "pin with ball" pieces to the underside to restrict the steering.

3	They didn't do that at first so that you could turn the axles sharper while putting the wheels on, which made it easier to do.

3	The Grinder Keeping in mind the scale of the machine, this thing looks terrifying!

3	The tan gear at the back drives the spinning blade up front.

3	The red bushes near the turntable let you adjust the angle.

3	All Done The arm quickly attaches to the body and it's done.

3	Sadly, that tan gear doesn't connect to anything - it's just a knob so you can spin the blade by hand.

3	Raise Your Hand, If You're Sure... (I think I'm dating myself with that title...) This thing has massive reach.

3	I'm imagining this inside a mine, grinding away the rock overhead.

3	Pretty viciously effective machine!

3	The crank on this side of the model is used to raise and lower the arm.

3	Works well, and the grey spacer makes it nice to use since it spins freely.

3	The Leftovers Not much left for a B-model.

3	Nice usage!

3	Starting the Main Model The main model starts similarly to the alternate, with a frame, some axles, and a drive connection from one axle to something later.

3	Getting Complicated Already We're only a few pieces in and we already have three separate gear trains going on.

3	There's the axle driving the tan beveled gears inside the frame at the bottom.

3	There's more tan gears in the middle, and there's also a black gear sticking up as a knob that turns the grey connector in the center.

3	The Body is Done I skipped ahead quite a bit, but it was a bunch of standard Technic building.

3	You've got a fake engine with fan at the back, driven by one of the rear wheels, a knob sticking up for steering, and an axle coming forward to open and close the claw.

3	The Claw!

3	I like that they used a link system to open and close the claw instead of just gearing it.

3	The axle comes forward from the chassis (it's the red axle) with a couple u-joints for flexibility and drives a worm gear.

3	That rotates a gear below with a 2 stud liftarm on each side.

3	Those arms have pin with towball in them and then a link going from that short liftarm to the claw.

3	It's a small rotation of the liftarm, but makes the claw open widely and works very well.

3	Raising the Claw A few black liftarms join the claw to the body of the loader and allow it to move up and down.

3	It's a simple mechanism there - one yellow beam goes back and connects to a lever that lets you raise and lower the claw.

3	When raised (as shown), the lever locks in place by going just slightly past the centerline.

3	And It's Done Add some wheels, a cab, and some wheel arches and we're done.

3	It's a great looking machine, pretty unique, and looks like the real thing.

3	The main difference from reality is these usually have a scoop for moving loose rock.

3	Since we've had so many scooping vehicles in the past (tracked loaders, the Volvo L350F, excavators, etc) the claw here is a fun change and adds to the playability for kids.

3	Like the real thing, the body stays very low so the cab only has to stick up a little bit for the driver to see all around, because mines are cramped and busy areas.

3	From the Rear This angle is great.

3	I love the use of the new mudguard panels to make a nice curve to the back of the loader.

3	The antenna is a little weird, but perhaps they had a big pile of flat silver fencing swords to use up.

3	The black gear just to the left of the antenna is the claw control.

3	Rotating that gear opens and closes it.

3	The back end is a little lighter than a real machine would be, but Lego wanted to leave the engine exposed so you can see the cylinders moving.

3	The Conclusion So, what's my conclusion on this model?

3	I like it a lot.

3	It's simpler than a big set would be, but it's got lots of design and playability crammed in a mid-sized set.

3	It's a unique vehicle.

3	However, it does have a few flaws.

3	The steering on the main model needs some drag added.

3	As is, you basically have to drive by holding the steering knob since it'll bend if you push it from behind.

3	I don't like the use of pin with pin hole as mounting points for the orange and red trans plates for lights, since they can turn slightly and be at weird angles.

3	The antenna is unnecessary and in the way.

3	But none of these flaws are dealbreakers or even big deals.

3	They're minor.

3	The Ratings Value: 10/10 - Less than 10 cents a piece, lots of useful liftarms and such, nothing too weird or single-use.

3	Design: 9/10 - Looks very realistic for the size of the set, good functionality, not too dependent on stickers Minifigs: n/a - n/a Playability: 9/10 - Controls aren't perfect (loose steering, small knob for claw control) but very functional and cleverly done.

3	Parts: 9/10 - Nice selection, although heavy on the standard yellow and black.

3	Almost zero studded parts.

3	Overall: 9.5/10 - It's a great intro to Technic set - a unique vehicle, good functionality, nice part selection, and decently priced.

3	I like it a lot and plan to keep it around as a finished set.

3	Great review with high quality pictures, well done!!

3	I'm glad you took the time to do it properly.

3	Cool that you have built both models.

3	I agree with the mudguards.

3	They sure look good on this model.

1	I was waiting especially for review of this set.

1	Let me add few things about this... thing.

1	It all will be complainging of person who works with these type of machines, so if you just want a unusual machine in your collection, ignore my complaining :) I see underground loaders almost every day, and believe me, this model would now work in the underground mine.

1	First of all, its cab should stick out more from the frame.

1	Each loader has cab placed out of the chassis, to provide better view for the driver.

1	In this class of machine it would help a bit, but in low loader ones it is extremely important: This is the view from the cab of a low profile loader (looking at front - and yes, front of the machine is where engine is placed, because at least at KGHM all machines drive engine forward): Another thing about that cab is that seat and steering wheel/joysticks are placed perpendicularly to the machine chassis, to provide same view for driving forward and backwards.

1	So another weak spot of the set.

1	The model lacks of trans clear lights on the engine part, because all machines that work underground have same lamps on front and back.

1	Another thing that comes to my mind is that warning light and antena would not live too long in the mine, becuase it could be torn apart by ramming into tunnels roofs.

1	It does resemble shape of underground machine, but not a loader.

1	Only machine that comes to my mind is something that are used for moving/placing hydraulic support jacks in tunnels.

1	Sorry for poor quality, I didn't find better picture of it: It does have claw, four wheels and articulated chassis, but have much greater range of movement of the arm.

1	Anyway, I'd give it at least 3/5 for overall look.

1	Model itself, as a set, looks unfinished (or cut down on pieces after visit of an accountant...) For me it looks like engine part was built differently, with knobs for steering/claw operating sticking out from back.

1	Claw needs almost seven full turns of the worm gear to close from opened position, and is rather annoing to use it in way it is built in this model.

1	Bracket that holds bevel gears responsible for steering is rather loose, being hold in place by single 3/4 pin.

1	On the other hand, the steering works very well.

1	It seems that lack of differential will be more common in LEGO sets, becuase it is another model that have fake engine driven by single wheel (like in old russian RC cars...).

1	I am OK with that, but it is a pitty that this model has only R2 engine.

1	Thing that I do not like the most in this model is how the claw arm works.

1	First of all, it barelly lifts the claw of the ground, the movement could be much better.

1	And it has major design flaw - universal joints are not placed in line with articulation points, and this is main reason of 5L axle not being suported on both sides under the turntable.

1	While rainsing the arm, it bends a little!

1	I really would like to see this model built differently, with normal bucket and better range of movement.

1	Edited by M_longer, 05 December 2015 - 11:08 PM.

2	Thanks for the thorough comments!

2	I agree that the set has some limitations, both in construction and realism, but I think they're acceptable given the pricepoint and size.

2	The antenna is definitely ludicrous - I really do suspect they had a surplus of the swords to use up!

2	And yes, the way the steering knob is mounted is loose.

2	I also noticed that the u-joints to the claw are not in the right spot like you mentioned, but didn't include it since it still works fine.

2	That axle coming forward to the claw has a very long unsupported section that does bend a bit when you raise and lower the claw.

2	It works, but is a bit of a cheat that I'm kinda surprised they let through.

2	I just checked and the bucket from 8043 is a couple studs too wide for this set.

2	I'm betting that was seriously considered, but it'd have meant scaling the whole thing up and that would have put it into a higher price point.

2	Or they could have pulled the mold for the 8x14 bucket back out and remade it for this set...

2	I really like the model you built!

2	And that's interesting about the cabs being basically flush with the top but sticking out the side.

2	In image searching as part of my research, I found both that style and ones like this, with the cab sticking up more (like the photo of the Caterpillar one in my review).

2	I wonder if that's a US/European difference, or different types of mining, or what, because both styles definitely exist in the real world.

1	and also good points pointed out by m_longer ;) this set doesnt appealing to me neither, but before i knew what it was i was thinking it was interesting but now... its so simple, a set close to 500 pieces with only 1 real function, and the entire rear section looks unfinished.

1	Great review!

1	One thing reaaaaaally bothers me about this set, both models have the engine connected to one wheel, the other wheel on the "powered" axle is just left to rotate freely, and that really bothers me, as it did in 42022 (on 42022 even more TBH, since its main feature is being a frigging car).

1	Looking at the pics it isnt even a space issue (as it was in the hot rod, where they "needed" to route the steering through), so they just cheaped out and didnt bother fitting a diff in there (or even a live axle link) Im not very interested in this set (not into construction stuff), but i think this is a worrying trend :(

3	Thanks for review, mostlytechnic.

3	Not a must have for me, but this set have nice assortment of parts... new turntable, new panels (i like yellow).

3	And if i'll buy two of this sets - i'll get enough wheels for proper 18-wheeler.

3	And rubber connectors, that i almost don't using at all, but want to have more and more) Edited by Victor Imaginator, 06 December 2015 - 02:19 PM.

3	Lego 42045 Technic Hydroplane Racer Thanks to Lego and EuroBricks for making this review possible!

3	This was supposed to be a preview-review, before the Dec 1 release date for the set, but it got stuck in customs or something and didn't arrive in time.

3	Well, I'd rather do a good, late review than a rushed review, so here it is.

3	Name: Hydroplane Racer Set Number: 42045 Pieces: 180 Price: $19.99 Minifigs: 0 Theme: Technic Year of Release: 2016 Links: Bricklink Brickset The Box Standard Technic box.

3	Action photo, 2-in-1 logo, inset of functions.

3	And the new "try our app" logo in the corner.

3	The Box Back More standard stuff with the B-model and a larger app ad.

3	The Contents 3 bags, two manuals (yes, despite all the ads for their instructions app, they included printed manuals for both the main and B models!

3	), a BIG sticker sheet, and two loose black beams.

3	The Interesting Parts There's a lot of panels in this set.

3	Some are new colors (the blue curved panel) and the L-shaped blue panels are a new mold.

3	I see them being used as mudguards on future sets (or maybe even this year; I haven't looked at the other 2016 Technic sets in detail yet).

3	The hose, soft axle 7 long in black is new as well.

3	The normal 7 axle in yellow is a new color too, and I have no idea why it's in this set.

3	Both models use it in invisible places, so there's no reason other than making it easier to grab the right length axle to have it.

3	I assume other sets this year are using it, but I'm not sure.

3	The Manual And the dumbing-down continues.

3	Now they have to show people to compare axle lengths to the 1:1 prints on the page that have always been there.

3	But how does the 1:1 work on the app?

3	Might have to look into that... (for the record...

3	I pulled out my phone and tried to find the app in the Google store.

3	Couldn't find it.

3	So then I went to the Lego website shown on the page and it had a link to it.

3	Turns out it wasn't showing up because it's tablet only, so Google wasn't showing it to me on my phone.

3	I'll try again later with a tablet...) Starting the Build Two Technic standards.

3	A bunch of pieces linked together to make a specific pattern of holes, and an engine block.

3	Some Weirdness This felt very weird to me - making the crankshaft for the engine, they have you build it right to left.

3	I don't know if it's because I'm a lefty or what, but it felt awkward.

3	I need to look in some old manuals and see if it's always been this way... (nope!

3	I randomly looked at 2013's set 42000 Racer, and it builds it left to right.)

3	Assembling the Core Here's the core of the racer, upside down.

3	The engine block, some gears at each end, and a couple boat studs for smooth gliding.

3	And yes, they cheated and those are only attached on two studs instead of all 4.

3	I'm always amazed at how Lego geometry keeps finding interesting ways that it works.

3	Like here, with those boat studs.

3	They fit perfectly into the bottom of the brick and against the beam.

3	The Front End Up front we get a standard blue seat with a couple "hidden" wheels behind it.

3	A boat doesn't typically have wheels, but these will drive the mechanisms of this model, so we'll let it slide.

3	An odd part choice here though - in the very front there are two tan "axle pin without friction" parts holding that 3 long liftarm on.

3	Why?

3	There's no need in either model for the non-friction pin, and there's lots of the normal blue axle pins in the set.

3	So why include these two different pins?

3	And All Done!

3	It looks like a huge jump here, but it's really not.

3	The front and rear connect to each other, and then a bunch of big panels are added that make the model look WAY bigger.

3	The stickers on this set really make it work.

3	Without them it's pretty bland and boring, so I recommend using them.

3	From the Rear At the back we have a fan to propel the boat.

3	That's not so accurate.

3	All the images I can find of real-life boats use props in the water.

3	But since this is a non-floating model, we have to make some tweaks I guess.

3	There also should be fins going down into the water for stability and hydroplaning, but again, had to drop that.

3	Here's an example of a real boat: You can see they nailed the overall look quite well.

3	The Underside For those that want to see the mechanicals, here's the underside of the model.

3	Minifig Scale Technic?

3	Nope, not quite.

3	A fig will fit the seat, but sticks out of the cockpit and can't fit a helmet at all.

3	So close...

3	Starting the B Model Again with the engine block, but this time an opposing 4 instead of inline.

3	An Odd Part It's rare for Lego to include parts specific to the B-model, so I was curious when I found this 2-axle with pin, a fairly new part.

3	In the main model, it's used in a place that a normal 3 pin would have been fine, and it's the only one of these in the whole set, so it obviously must be needed in the B-model.

3	Sure enough, there's an assembly here that needs it: The Front of the Boat More upside-down building.

3	And that silver piston is basically only there as a spacer.

3	It has no real function.

3	(Yet.... it turns out later an axle goes into it, so it's a support for one end of the axle.)

3	Adding the Wheels We keep building around the engine.

3	This model uses the same wheel setup as the main model.

3	Taking Shape The B-model instructions tell you to put the stickers on in case you haven't - they actually did a good job making the sticker work on either model.

3	But the silver piston used as a cross-brace is a bit weird.

3	It can spin, so that axle hole on the side ends up facing whatever way it wants.

3	The Back End The flex axles are used here under the panels just for appearance and to support the exhausts at the right angle.

3	Same fan propulsion as the main model, and just as wrong here :) Worse, the gearing is switched.

3	In the main model, the pistons and fan spin pretty quickly as you push the boat across the floor.

3	In this one, they turn very slowly.

3	More Instruction Weirdness I'm always curious at how Lego decides to do instructions.

3	Here's how the panels on one side of the boat are assembled.

3	For the mirror image on the other side, they tell you to put all 3 pins into the short panel as step 1 (2 black and a blue), add the white piece as step 2, and then add teh second panel and stickers as step 3.

3	Why two different ways?

3	All Done Here's a similar angle as most of the official images.

3	Looks ok.

3	I noticed though how obvious the wheels are.

3	The back of the box image is a lower angle that hides them more.

3	And I like the mudguard panels as seats.

3	Pretty clever.

3	From the Side I'm not fond of the profile.

3	It doesn't sit level like I think it should.

3	The wheels are a stud too low sticking out of the bottom.

3	The Underside Like most B-models, there are compromises.

3	There's pins and axles sticking out, but that's what you do when faced with a limited piece selection.

3	Minifig Scale Yet?

3	Nope, not quite.

3	A bit too big this time.

3	I think the driver is supposed to sit in the seat with knees over the front of the guard (where the grey pin is).

3	So the minifig is way too small.

3	Spare Pieces Very few leftovers in this B-model.

3	The Conclusion So, what's my conclusion on this model?

3	The B-model is fairly meh, and too similar to the main model.

3	However, I LOVE the hydroplane racer itself.

3	It looks great and is very swooshable.

3	For the price, it's surprisingly large thanks to the big panels on the sides, Yes, this is one set that really needs the stickers to look good, but they look great and are well worth putting on.

3	The Ratings Value: 9/10 - Close to 10 cents a piece, and a fairly large model for the price.

3	Design: 9/10 - Looks great other than the tiny fan on the back.

3	Minifigs: n/a - I was tempted to give a score since a minifig almost fits, but that'd be cheating.

3	Playability: 8/10 - Not much functionality other than the engine and fan spinning, but very swooshable and sturdy enough to be played with.

3	Parts: 9/10 - A bunch of panels (including some new ones), just about every kind of Technic pin, and quite a few thin liftarms .

3	Overall: 9/10 - The set is a solid winner, as long as your satisfied with the main model.

3	Again, great review with superb pictures.

3	The white and blue certainly works very well with your dark backdrop.

3	Thorough review for such a small model.

3	Small in size but great as a set.

3	Tell me, why did I let you review this one?

3	!

2	Quote And the dumbing-down continues.

2	Now they have to show people to compare axle lengths to the 1:1 prints on the page that have always been there.

2	But how does the 1:1 work on the app?

2	Might have to look into that... (for the record...

2	I pulled out my phone and tried to find the app in the Google store.

2	Couldn't find it.

2	So then I went to the Lego website shown on the page and it had a link to it.

2	Turns out it wasn't showing up because it's tablet only, so Google wasn't showing it to me on my phone.

2	I'll try again later with a tablet...) Funny thing is that they changed colour of 7L axle to yellow, and on that picture it still is in LBG.

1	My opinion on the frictionless axlepins is that the flex axle might be easier to stick in them than in regular/blue axlepins...

1	Didn't actually try it though :-) Edited by MajklSpajkl, 05 December 2015 - 11:46 PM.

3	I am glad that you did not rush this or the Mine Loader review.

3	Could it be that the fan in the back is like a turbo prop propulsion.... Just reaching here.

2	MajklSpajkl, on 05 December 2015 - 11:45 PM, said: My opinion on the frictionless axlepins is that the flex axle might be easier to stick in them than in regular/blue axlepins...

2	Didn't actually try it though :-) Frictionless pins have accurate round hole, while blue friction pins have something squarish.

2	Flex axle will fit in both, but using tan pins doesn't require strength.

2	Conncetion with tan pins is weaker too.

2	Im a bit undecided on the set though, it has some nice parts (4 cil engine in such a small set!)

2	and it looks good, but also a bit small and simple, not sure if it stands up to the standards of the small tracked loader or similar for sets of this size, and as a parts pack (for panels/flaxles) the display team jet is infinitely better.

2	Ill probably pick one up, but right now i really want another tracked loader... (last one was sacrificed to the MOD gods)

3	Nice review, thanks Nice little set, I might buy me one

3	REVIEW - 42038 - ARCTIC TRUCK INTRODUCTION Arctic vehicles aren't new to LEGO.

3	Back in 2000 the Town theme already had several small orange arctic vehicles.

3	In 2014 TLG again released a number of Arctic sets in the City theme (formerly known as Town).

3	Some of these sets are actually pretty big, containing over 700 parts.

3	Looking back in history it seems that Arctic sets may have found their origin in the Technic theme.

3	Although these sets were white instead of orange, they are unmistakenly Arctic.

3	The 1986 Technic Arctic Sets contained the infamous Technic Figures.

3	Unfortunately the 2015 Arctic Truck doesn't contain any Technic Figures, but nonetheless it's great to see a new Arctic vehicle in the Technic line, not counting several snow scooters.

3	Let's see if the new Arctic Truck lives up to the expectations.

3	Note: All images can be clicked for hi-res versions.

3	SET INFORMATION Number: 42038 Title: Arctic Truck Theme: Technic Released: 2015 Part Count: 1219 Box Weight: 2110 gr Box Dimensions: 47,8 cm x 28,0 cm x 7,2 cm Set Price (MSRP): € 79,99 / US$ 84.99 / £ 59.99 Price per Part: € 0,088 / US$ 0.093 / £ 0.066 Links: Brickset, Bricklink THE BOX The box measures 47,8 cm x 28,0 cm x 7,2 cm and weighs around 1385 grams.

3	The box actually feels pretty heavy which means it's filled properly.

3	This seems to be a trend in the Technic theme.

3	Slightly smaller boxes can save shelf space for retailers.

3	THE FRONT The front of the box shows the main model and in the lower right corner there's a image with the dimension of the model.

3	It's 40cm long and 18cm wide.

3	THE BACK The upper part of the back of the box shows the functions of the main model.

3	The lower left section shows the B-model, which looks very promising (more on that later).

3	The lower right section shows the motorization options for the main model.

3	The crane (partially) and the bed can be motorized.

3	Besides motorization some LEDs can be added as headlights.

3	THE SIDE On of the sides shows one of the newer smaller style panels.

3	This is the first time it appears in orange.

3	When you take a look at the sticker you can see that it's not symmetrical.

3	Not sure why TLG "cut of" one of the sides of the stickers, since the position of the panel is very suitable for a continuous sticker.

3	CONTENT OF THE BOX The box is pretty densely packed, which is better than semi-filled boxes.

3	It feels like you actually bought something which matches the box size.

3	The box contains: 2 Booklets 1 Sticker Sheet 8 Bags BOOKLETS & STICKER SHEET Unfortunately the instructions and sticker sheet haven't been packed with cardboard protection, which results in a curved sticker sheet and slightly bent instructions.

3	In my case this wasn't so bad.

3	At least no real damage.

3	HIGHLIGHTED PARTS This set proves to be a great parts pack, especially when you might have missed some of the 2014 sets.

3	BLACK LINK TREADS Usually the Link Treads come in Dark Blue Grey, but this sets includes 96 Black treads, which is great if you'd like to replace the DBG ones in your MOCs, or other official sets.

3	UNDERCARRIAGE AND SUSPENSION Several parts are included to build the undercarriage driving the treads.

3	Four Large Tread Sprockets and eight Small Tread Sprockets, which are used as return sprockets.

3	Also included are four Steering Portal Hubs and four Steering Portal Axles for driving and steering the vehicle.

3	Several frames, including two C-shaped Pivot Frames and two Steering Ball Joints to create an undercarriage much like the 4x4 Crawler.

3	The set even includes two H-shaped Frames (a.k.a.

3	Dog Bone Frames).

3	NEW CHANGEOVER CATCH PARTS This year (2015) three new parts have been introduced to improve the changeover catch.

3	More on these parts later.

3	NEW PIN CONNECTOR Another new part for this year (2015) is the "1L Round Pin Connector", which looks like a pin connector, but acts more like a bush.

3	NEW PINS Furthermore this sets includes quite a large number of three (relatively) new parts.

3	17 x Pin with Pin Hole, 14 x 3L Pin with 1L Axle and 11 x 3L Pin with 2L Axle, which have been introduced this year (2015).

3	When the new 3L Pin with 1L Axle was introduced in 2014 it was only a matter of time before the new 3L Pin with 2L Axle would appear.

3	Both new Pins are a great addition to the parts portfolio.

3	PANELS Last but not least this sets contains a fair number of orange panels, including the 3x11 Panel in Orange, which is the first time we've seen this part.

3	PART LIST Below is the entire part list for the 913 parts.

3	As usual this part list can be found at the end of the second booklet.

3	THE BUILD The build immediately starts with some of the new parts, used to build the compact gearbox in the center of the model.

3	Notice the two 20 Tooth Bevel Gears.

3	One would have been enough to drive the 12 Tooth Bevel Gear, so the second seems to be useless.

3	TLG probably used it in the A-model, because they needed it in the B-model, which you can see later.

3	The front and rear suspension are almost identical.

3	The front side also has the 13L Gear Rack, used for steering.

3	The picture below shows the steering rack on the front suspension in more detail.

3	At this point you have more or less finished the chassis.

3	The gearbox is in place and the majority of the functions has internally been connected to the right gears.

3	The small turntable shows where the crane will be attached later on.

3	At the end of the first booklet, some of the bodywork has been attached to the chassis.

3	The orange-black color scheme never fails to please me.

3	Throw in some cool stickers for the extra effect and we have a winner.

3	If you decide to motorize the model, using PF, the top of the cabin can be lifted to accomodate the battery box.

3	The chassis uses lots of orange (and some black) panels to give the model it's distinctive look.

3	The protective black bumber/railing is a nice addition which adds something to the exterior.

3	The dumping bed at the rear can tilt to empty it's load.

3	It's operated by a Mini LA.

3	The Treads, which look very cool in Black, are driven by a Large Tread Sprocket and returned by two Small Tread Sprockets.

3	The front and rear sections are identical.

3	Building the undercarriages feels a bit repetitive, which is a problem for most tracked vehicles.

3	FINISHED MODEL Adding the crane to the model finishes the build.

3	Your model should look something like this.

3	When you take a close look at the finished model, you realize this is something else.

3	It's trully a unique vehicle.

3	The color scheme is brilliant and the fact that it's an Arctic Truck is really neat.

3	It's a welcome change for the Technic line to see a vehicle like this.

3	This picture emphasizes that's it's a very cool vehicle.

3	Imagine this beast plowing through the snow!

3	As far as I know it's not based on a real life vehicle.

3	If's probably a combination of several vehicles and some imagination.

3	I can be totally wrong though.

3	The rear of the vehicle shows the crane and drum, placed on the tipper bed.

3	From this angle you can see some of the internals of the model, the gearbox behind the cabin for example.

3	The crane can be partially motorized (rotation and base), while the boom is operated manually.

3	What I like a lot is the protective railing around the vehicle.

3	LEFT OVER PARTS Some leftover parts, nothing noteworthy.

3	FEATURES AND FUNCTIONS This set has several functions/features: Steering Driving Suspension Crane Tipping bed STEERING As you can see in the image below the steering mechanism has quite a bit of negative caster (please correct me if I'm wrong), which causes the treads to rotate a bit upward/downward instead of only to the left and right.

3	DRIVING You mention driving as a feature?!

3	Yes I do and let me explain why.

3	Normally I would ommit this as a feature and take driving for granted.

3	However, driving this vehicle (on a flat surface) causes it to simply slide over the surface.

3	For other arctic vehicles this would be a plus, but with a tracked vehicle it limits playability.

3	This is one of the main drawbacks of these tread, they simple don't work properly on smooth surfaces.

3	SUSPENSION The suspension is working properly.

3	You do need to apply some pressure, but all things considered it's not too bad.

3	CRANE The crane has four degrees of freedom: Base rotation Lower boom Upper boom Hook It does what it's supposed to do.

3	Base rotation and lower boom can be motorized and switched using the gearbox, while the upper boom and hook are operated manually.

3	TIPPING BED The tipping is operated via a Mini LA.

3	CONCLUSION While the set does offer various functions and features, driving and steering is a serious issue.

3	Therefor this set is more likely to be showcased than to be played with.

3	B-MODEL Instructions for the B-model are of high quality.

3	Looking at the image below, you will see what I mean.

3	Here's the finished B-model, a tracked Jeep with a communcations device.

3	This alternate model looks so good, it could easily have made it as a main model.

3	One thing that does pop in mind; how would this look with tires?!

3	More on that later.

3	When you are in the artcic region it's imperative to have proper communication channels.

3	Since there's no internet backbone, you will need a big antenna of some sort.

3	This B-model actually features a small trailer wagon with a transmitter/receiver.

3	Here's more detailed image of the B-model, without trailer wagon.

3	I would buy this model in a heartbeat if it were a main model.

3	Simply gorgeous.

3	The side view doesn't give away that this in alternate model.

3	The stickers also work really well in this model.

3	And again, nothing to complain here.

3	The model even has a small crane at the rear, operated by the Mini LA.

3	Here you can see the arctic fleet, comprised of both the A-model and B-model.

3	I bet these two can get some work done!!

3	A bit of a messy picture, but this should give you an impression of the size of both models.

3	LEFTOVER PARTS Not too many parts left, which is obviously a good thing.

3	ALTERNATE MODEL WITH TUMBLER TIRES Just like me, you probably have been wondering how this model would look like with (Tumbler) tires.

3	Well, here it is.

3	As I imagined it does look great.

3	Admittedly, these are not the type of tires we ought to use, but to be honest; I don't really care.

3	Again, the negative caster results in quirky steering.

3	The tires are a bit too big, so they hit the chassis when you compress the suspension.

3	While this has absolutely nothing to do with an arctic vehicle, I really love this picture.

3	SUMMARY We're almost at the end of my review, so what do I think of this set.

3	Let's start with getting the Elephant out of the room; this set lacks proper driving and steering.

3	Does that make it a bad set?!

3	Definitely not!

3	It's a great set, but it lacks some playability when it comes to moving the vehicle.

3	The crane and tipper bed do work properly, so there's still some playability left.

3	Does this set look cool?

3	Definitely!

3	I think it's one of the coolest (no pun intended) and most original models of recent years.

3	The orange and black color scheme works great and the stickers are well designed.

3	The B-model is of very high quality and some might even prefer it over the A-model.

3	And if you are not interested in either of these models, this set provides you with a variety of great parts!

3	All in all I think this is a great set!

3	Maybe not to play with, but it scores high on all other criteria.

3	PROS Original model Great color scheme Lots of interesting parts Great B-model CONS Steering and driving don't work too well Repetitive build of undercarriages (minor con) SCORE Below are my scores based on different categories.

3	8 DESIGN Original and good looking model.

3	7 BUILDING EXPERIENCE Fun to build, albeit a bit repetitive.

3	8 FEATURES Packs quite a few features.

3	7 PLAYABILITY Some features work, some don't.

3	9 PARTS Comes with interesting parts.

3	9 VALUE FOR MONEY Two great model in a single set.

3	8 COOL!

3	As a bonus, here's picture of the main model with Tumbler Tires.

3	Why?

3	Because we can!

3	Very timely review Jim.

3	My wife has just surprised me by giving me this set a few days ago and I have just built the A model two days ago and B model yesterday.

3	I agree with all that you wrote above.

3	I don't have Tumbler tires but I have 9398 tires.

3	Driving is smooth but steering + suspension will be bad as you said due to negative caster and tires hitting the chassis.

3	Anyway, tonight I will destroy the B model and rebuilt this http://www.busterhau...8-c-model.html.

3	I was supposed to publish it together with the 42039 - 24 Hours Racer, but it somehow got backlogged.

3	After completing the reviews for the 2016 sets, I felt I needed to finish it (was already 90% done).

3	That C-model looks cool!

1	Right now I'm a bit disappointed with the Arctic Truck - smaller sets offer more functions and teach you much more.

2	THERIZE, on 14 December 2015 - 09:32 PM, said: I could be wrong but I am 100% sure that I've seen this review before.

2	Nequmodiva, on 14 December 2015 - 09:48 PM, said: You switched the sides for the panel with the unsymmetrical sticker.

2	Otherwise you would see that the cut off part is where there's a beam in front of the panel.

2	That's probably done because the beam could possibly damage the sticker, either while building or while placed against it for a long time.

2	Or it's simply omitted because it wouldn't be (completely) visible This is probably the only reason (for TLG choosing to provide an asymmetrical sticker), but looking at the sticker sheet, I also believe they simply didn't have the space on the sheet for a symmetrical solution.

3	Thank you for the mention.

3	REVIEW - 42001 - MINI OFF-ROADER INTRODUCTION Technic Mini models are sometimes regarded as models not worth buying.

3	I don't agree with this opinion.

3	Whether it's a special part or innovative building technique, almost every Mini model has something that makes the set worthwhile.

3	This time I will be reviewing the 42001 Mini Off-Roader.

3	This model is not a smaller version of an existing model, so there's no real comparison with a bigger brother, or sister if you will.

3	Nor does the model resemble a real life brand or vehicle, so it is what it is, a Mini Off-Roader.

3	Note: All images can be clicked for hi-res versions.

3	SET INFORMATION Number: 42001 Title: Mini Off-Roader Theme: Technic Released: 2013 Part Count: 100 Box Weight: 165 gr Box Dimensions: 15,5 x 14,0 x 4,2 cm Set Price (MSRP): 9.99 EUR DE / 7.99 GBP / 12.99 USD Price per Part: DE 0.100 EUR / UK 0.080 GBP / USA 0.130 USD Links: Brickset, Bricklink THE BOX The box measures 15,5 x 14,0 x 4,2 cm which is obviously not very big.

3	The weight of the box is approximately 165 grams.

3	FRONTSIDE The front of the box shows a though four wheel drive off-roader challenging a fierce rocky mountain trail...now does it?!

3	What the box actually shows is Mini Off-Roader challenging a small foam rock formation, much like rocks used in Star Trek The Original Series, yet smaller The box also states that this model is for the age of 7 till 14.

3	More importantly, the 2-models in-1 logo is clearly visible, which means this set can be used to build two different models.

3	BACKSIDE The backside shows a picture of the alternate model and a smaller version of the original model.

3	The conversion arrow and the 2-in-1 are printed to clarify that the main model can be converted into a secondary model.

3	SIDES One of the sides shows the 2-in-1 logo and a picture of the main model.

3	Another side shows a picture of one of the wheels in actual size and again, a picture of the main model.

3	CONTENTS OF THE BOX The box contains: 2 Booklets 2 Bags 4 Tires BOOKLETS This set contains two booklets which is not very common for a set this size.

3	Both models share the same chassis, which is why the build has been divided over two booklets, one for the chassis (8 pages with 10 steps) and one for the bodywork (34 pages with 23 steps for the main model and 20 steps for the alternate model).

3	BAGS The box contains only 2 bags which is to be expected from a set consisting of 100 parts.

3	One of the bags is filled with liftarms, panels, rims and two elastic bands.

3	The other bags contains all the other parts, like pins, axles, connectors, etc.

3	Opening the bags results in the following collection of parts, with the exception of the tires.

3	No abundant number parts that will add real value to your collection.

3	Nevertheless, there are some interesting orange parts and elastic bands.

3	TIRES The tires are provided seperately (i.e.

3	not contained in the bags).

3	From the picture you can see that these tires have a front and a back side, so you should pay attention when fitting them to the rims, which have two different sides as well.

3	HIGHLIGHTED PARTS This section describes the unique and/or highlighted parts.

3	VERY SMALL SMOOTH TECHNIC PANEL (#21 AND #22) These two small Technic were new at the time of release and this set was only one of two sets containing them in orange.

3	The other set is the 42007 - Moto Cross Bike.

3	At the moment of writing there's a third set containing these parts, the Black Champion Racer.

3	Side A Side B SMALL RUBBER BAND I was under the impression that these White Rubber Bands weren't that common, but it seems that these bands are as common as dirt.

3	But hey, you can't have enough rubber bands!

3	THIN LIFTARM 1x5 WITH AXLE HOLES Like the panels, these Liftarms were also new at the time of release.

3	Looking at the the frequent usage in other sets, this part has proven to be a most useful mammal.

3	THIN LIFTARM 1x3 Not a very rare piece per se, but if you are not into Bionicle, this liftarm part can be hard to find.

3	Your other option would be to buy the 9390 - Mini Tow Truck, or the 8305 - Dual Bikes from a while ago (2000).

3	LONG PIN WITH CENTER PIN HOLE This relatively new kid on the block is currently used in many Technic and non-Technic sets and has well proven it's worth.

3	AXLE PIN CONNECTOR HUB WITH 2 AXLES Like the previous part this newish part is also quite helpful in certain situations.

3	PART LIST Here's the complete list for all 100 parts.

3	BUILDING EXPERIENCE The build starts with the chassis of the Off-Roader.

3	After connecting some liftarms two elastic bands, one on each side, are attached to the towball pins.

3	This is all there is to the suspension, plain and simple.

3	The two elastic bands contract the L-shaped liftarms, which results in the long ends swiveling downwards.

3	The video below demonstrates the suspension.

3	The simplicity doesn't do it justice, because it works like a charm.

3	The suspension is very smooth with the right amount of stretch and resistance.

3	This great working suspension adds a lot of value to this set.

3	To quote John Hurt in the movie Contact: "Why build one when you can have two at twice the price?".

3	I have purchased two sets so we can simultaneously see both models and make a proper comparison.

3	Below you can see two identical chassis which will be used for both versions of the build.

3	At this stage we have arrived at the end of the first booklet, which only took about ten minutes.

3	Not surprising, since the first booklet only has 10 building steps.

3	Progressing to the second booklet, you need to choose between building the main and alternative model.

3	That's a choice I don't need to make for this review, so let's start with the main model.

3	MAIN MODEL When building the bodywork there's a rather peculiar building technique, which you wouldn't expect in an official LEGO set.

3	The Axle and Pin Connector Hub with 2 Axles only protrudes halfway into the Double Bent Liftarm.

3	The Thin 1x4 Liftarm which is added in one of the following steps makes sure the hubs stay perfectly in place, but I was still surprised to see this technique.

3	The finished bodywork for the main model looks like....uhh...well.....I don't know exactly.

3	It doesn't bear any resemblance to a real life model, which makes it hard to judge.

3	One thing's for sure; it's not the best looking Technic Mini Model.

3	The bodywork can be attached to the chassis by using a 7L axle and two bushes, one on each side of the chassis.

3	ALTERNATE MODEL Unfortunately the alternate model doesn't look much better than the main model.

3	It's even a stud less wide, while you would like to see slightly more body, matching the size of the tires and chassis.

3	Attached to the chassis the body is even more out of proportion.

3	It's not really ugly and the color scheme is great (obviously this goes for the main model as well), but the body simply doesn't match the chassis.

3	I can only imagine that this model is supposed to have a chibi look, much like the Microfighter Star Wars models.

3	COMPARISON The following section shows a selection of images from different angles to compare the main and secondary model.

3	The main model has a bit more volume, while the alternate model has a more sporty look.

3	FRONT VIEW The main model has headlights which are attached at a higher point, while the alternate model has headlights which are placed more closely next to each other.

3	REAR VIEW A slightly different setup in both models, where the main model again has higher placed rear lights.

3	SIDE VIEW The side view shows that the panels are used differently in both models.

3	The main models uses them as doors, while the alternate model uses them as engine cover (bonnet).

3	TOP VIEW The top view reveals that the main model might have room for a minifig PARTS LEFT The left image shows the parts which are left after building the main model, while the second image shows the parts left after building the alternate model.

3	As you can see, the main model uses slightly more parts than the alternate model.

3	FEATURES Besides the awesome suspension, which we already have discussed, there aren't a lot of features in this set.

3	There's actually a single feature, which is only present in the main model....opening doors!

3	Wow, impressive!

3	Well, maybe we can't expect too much functionality in such a small model.

3	SUMMARY The Off-Roader is a fun model which is fairly easy to build.

3	The suspension is simple, yet very effective.

3	The model could do better in the design department, but the suspension offers great playability and that is what this set is all about.

3	The orange parts are not very common so they are an added bonus.

3	All things considered this set is definitely worth the few bucks you need to spend on it.

3	PROS Great suspension Fun to play with Some (semi) rare orange parts Great color scheme CONS No resemblence to an actual off-roader Not the best looking model SCORE Below are my scores based on different categories.

3	6 DESIGN Not the best looking Technic model.

3	7 BUILDING EXPERIENCE The suspension makes it fun to build.

3	7 FEATURES The suspension makes up for the lack of functionality.

3	8 PLAYABILITY The model has Car-Swooshability.

3	7 PARTS Some interesting orange parts.

3	8 VALUE FOR MONEY Great present for the younger builders.

3	7,1 ELASTIC Hope you enjoyed it!

3	Thanks for reading and please rate this set at the top of this topic!

3	Once again, excellent review Jim!

3	Than you for not skipping this small but pretty great set.

3	I also got two of this and I have to say, I really admire the nifty suspension.

3	Building a third bodywork for the same suspension system is still on my backlog.

3	The suspension is indeed awesome.

3	For it's size, this is a great set!

3	Looking at the grades, I seem to have lowballed the score.

2	Sad, i miss this set.

3	Here is the review...for Broadside's Brig 6259!

3	A set from 1991, with a handsome count of 64 pieces, 3 figures, and a sale price of $8.75!

3	The building(and parrot): We'll start off with the front.

3	It looks like a good solid building to hold those scurvy dogs!

3	We yonder over to the left side: And see a nice open back: And yonder to the plain right side: Back to the left, we find the corner, with a nice area to rest your tired soldiers!

3	We see the platform in the corner, a lovely place for soldiers to stand on!

3	It's a bit...skimpy, so watch your step!

3	The middle is blocked by some stones, assuring security!

3	But still open enough to stand in!

3	The jail is cramped, and fits only TWO people, but we only need one prisoner in this set :-) !

3	Moving up is the watch tower, a place for your soldier stand and stand watch or for silly parots to sit on!

3	Here's the front middle part, again those stones blocking the way!

3	Figures and Accesories: We have a delightful number of a soldier, a sailor, and a scurvy pirate!

3	A lovely parot!

3	And a generous assortment of weapons!

3	That concludes our review.

3	Overall: It's a fantastic little set, and great for army and supplies and bricks gathering!

3	I can't find any faults with this set, it's just the neatest little thing you've seen in a port *wub* Highly recomended *y* .

3	And to end our review: A comic!

3	During the annual Thanksgiving Road Trip to the relatives, I stopped by the TRU in Portland, OR.

3	Lo and behold, the new Mars Mission sets!

3	Obviously, I bought them.

3	;-) The box: Not much to say.

3	Standard box art for MM sets, nothing new.

3	The parts: Some good parts here.

3	Even if you don't like the set (Which I highly doubt after I've had my say :-P ), it's a decent parts pack.

3	I noticed that some old parts have been renewed.

3	I know the wheel has been used in the '07 sets, but the cockpit and hitch I haven't seen in a while.

3	The VLDSS (Very large DSS).

3	Grr.

3	New part.

3	At least, I think it is.

3	Someone slap me if it isn't.

3	Thanks for posting the picture of this new MM set.

3	When I first saw the Mars Mission sets I was a little apprehensive about the design and the aliens (They could have at least make movable arms :(), but anyways when I bought the small fighter I was totally hook.

3	My fave set from the line is the mech.

3	During the annual Thanksgiving Road Trip to the relatives, I stopped by the TRU in Portland, OR.

3	Lo and behold, the new Mars Mission sets!

3	Predictably, I bought them.

3	I present to you: the MX-41 Switch Fighter!

3	Man, what a long name.

3	The box: Standard MM.

3	On the front, it shows the Fighter in flight mode, and a yellow note telling you that it transforms.

3	The back shows three pictures showing it happen.

3	The parts: Once I open the box, the first thing that comes out is a bent and rolled up instruction booklet, and I was forced to put it under a stack of beer books for an hour.

3	Then, there's the DSS.

3	Yes, two of the stickers do feature a cobra.

3	I wonder why, because this set's decal should be a beatle.

3	X-D Decent parts, nothing too special.

3	Then, I noticed this little part.

3	It's used for the flick-missiles, but I have no idea what else it would be used for.

3	:-/ The Build: The alien ship: When I looked at the box art for this set, I was releived to see that the aliens don't have another curved-forward wing ship.

3	Instead, they have this little beauty, which appears to be the Alien Mini Cooper- small and hot.

3	*wub* Anyway, partially completed.

3	Even if you don't like the set, it has some nice green flame peices, which work nicely for space laser swords.

3	Fully completed.

3	The only annoying bit about it is that the crystal-holding thing in front wobbles all over the place.

3	The alien fits into it by way of impalement.

3	It must hurt getting in and out.

3	Switch fighter (cockpit): The set makes good use of the Alpha Team cockpit.

3	For controls, it has a meagre handlebar that the astronaught can't even reach.

3	The rear "shell" of the fighter starts out around the alien containment chamber.

3	It's a bit odd that the containment chamber has an alien sticker, because the instruction booklet lists it as holding crystals.

3	The crystal canister is held back by a technic pin.

3	This is, without a doubt, the ugliest color arrangment EVER.

3	Warning: Mass stickers.

3	:-X The cockpit fits into grooves in the "shell".

3	Then it clicks into place in a 1x1 brick with a horizontal clip.

3	The wing "mechanism": The wing.

3	For some reason, the body of the "mechanism" has a blue brick.

3	*wacko* The wing and "mechanism" connect to prevent the fighter doing a nosedive while in tank mode.

3	The wing "mechanism" completed: The underside: The body and wing connect by way of a miscolored red brick.

3	I have no idea why it's red- black would bave been much, much better.

3	Completed.

3	Tank mode: All in all, this looks pretty neat.

3	The wheel base is pretty short, but it's not bad.

3	Transform!

3	The set transforms neatly, if ungainly.

3	Without "Anti-grav" support, it would fall forward on it's nose each time it transformed.

3	Jet mode.

3	It's all right, but it could be a bit better.

3	The "shell" keeps slipping back forward to the "tank mode" because there's nothing to stop it sliding.

3	Spare parts: Overall: I thought this set was great.

3	It could do with some fixing, such as the mismatched colors, but it should be a definate buy for MM fans.

3	Brickshelf Gallery (When available)

3	cool review.

3	I'm actually liking that new missile part as it seems to combine a bar with a pin.

3	But it's a real eyesore if you ask me.

3	Frankly I'm in love with this thing.

3	Anyway, why do I like it?

3	Those jetpack/backpack things the robots are wearing, and if they are jetpacks, as the back of the box suggests, then the use of chaisaws is quite nifty and innovative.

3	The minibot is cool, and certainly an interesting gimmick.

3	Sure, they don't look quite as good in some of the other sets, but here it looks great.

3	The overall structure and design are cool too.

3	It's always nice to see an 'irregular' mech, and this is no exception.

3	It's especially cool whee the spines are concerned.

3	Plus, on top of all that, it's got a nice selection of parts, including some lovely new ones, and the inlaid box is interesting.

3	Well worth getting, I think.

3	Here is my review of the set 6265 Sabre Island!

3	Overview: Sabre Island was release in 1990 an it contained 92 pieces and its retail price was $15.50.

3	It comes with 3 Imperial Blue coats, and a nice outpost for them.

3	The pictures + full review: Anyway, you can see here a picture of the box, the model shown on the box differs from the actual model slightly.

3	...And the back of the box, which shows some nice alternative models from the pieces provided.

3	A close up of two or three of the alternative models.

3	And now for the minifigs.

3	I prefer the Red coats over the Blue coats but these minifigs are nice, and for the number of pieces one gets a fair amount of them.

3	The set itself makes a nice small outpost, it comes complete with a palm tree, a cannon (with ammo) on a turntable, a small tower a nice large Imperial flag and a little red row boat!

3	Here is a shot from ground level showing the cannon and Blue coat (patrolling the out post!)

3	The rowing boat was a nice touch, and it comes with a small flag too.

3	"No Pirates will avoid the wrath of myself and my mighty Island!"

3	The top of the tower is rather plain and simple which in some ways is good, as it keeps the whole set detailed yet not crowded, but I feel a little something should of been added to the top though.

3	The back is lacking any type of walls, so one can play with the minifigs inside, yet their are also no stairs or any other ways for the Blue Coats to climb up their tower either!

3	The rag tag pirates attack Sabre Island!

3	But never fear, The Lord Of Pies is here!

3	Me throwing a pie at Captain Ironhook from another angle.

3	Overall I think this is a very good, if somewhat simple set, and makes a great cheap Imperial set!

3	Comments, thoughts and Opinions are welcome!

3	(And sorry about the darkness in some photos, I have not had time to take photographs when it is till light recently, for when I return home it is dark |-/ ) Edit: Fixed, Thank you!

3	INDEXED I'm going to have to start dodging cannon balls soon if i don't start making some pirate mocs.

3	*pirate* Anywayz, I've had my Shell Service Station set # 6378 built exactly by "the book" and sitting around for the longest time.

3	With the recent twinning of my "town" with Dr. Sinister, I needed a gas station that could handle a lot more traffic (especially military traffic and these new 6-wide vehicles X-D ).

3	Here be a thumblink to the original station at BL: I love this station so much, but it really needed some modernization.

3	The reopening of this station received a lot of attention, even the local police stopped right over.

3	One big upgrade to this station is the selling of propane tanks, which is generally a rare commodity from the lego towns i've seen.

3	X-D Also at this service station is a propane tank refilling station.

3	The milkman is our first propane customer.

3	The interior has also had an addition and many upgrades.

3	For instance, this building now has florescent lighting, a big frig in the back, and more shelf space.

3	*y* Oh look!

3	there's the officer purchasing a mountain dew.

3	Now that there's more shelf space, we can sell more than just 1x1 round yellow bricks and levers.

3	We now have available 1x1 round plates and 1x1 round cones available in multiple colors!

3	:-D With this upgraded gas station, hopefully this town will bring in more business and customers into my small town.

3	X-D P

3	I want to decode them.

3	My 2nd review (what a veteran) ... again, found this set via a shop assistant, in my local TRU (Portsmouth, UK) this evening.

3	Comes in at ?44.99, which, is pretty steep, but, you get quite a bit for your money.

3	Front of the Box : Back of the Box : Back of the Box Closeup : Contents : It was a nice surprise to get numbered bags ... not had a large set with numbered bags for quite a while, at least in none of the sets I've bought recently!

3	Didn't take a close up of the stickers, but I was quite disappointed that the curved pieces had stickers ... if they could print the ATT curved pieces, why not these?

3	Minifigs : Oh ... and there's a nice backprint on the Pilot figure : Now, the build was pretty good ... you build the plane first (after the minifigures).

3	Quite an interesting build in a way, becayse for a while you think the back is the front ... and then you realise, heh!

3	Now ...

3	I've not seen the film in a while, but I don't recall a guy flying a plane with a fishing rod ... don't flame me if this is what happens, see earlier point regards not seeing the film in ages!!

3	:-P After that, you build the temple in stages, starting with the entrance first, and then the holey floor section with the spears.

3	These spears are just loosely placed into technic holed bricks.

3	Quite easy to make em flick out but they can go anywhere!

3	hehe Entrance : Holey Floor & Spears : These two parts are hinged and on an angle to each other and the gap makes for a handy bottomless pit, complete with pole for Indy to swing over with his whip.

3	After that, you create the door and the ratchet mechanism to keep it raised.

3	After that, you add the runners for the ball and the swinging knives trap.

3	Swords Trap - Before : After : Finally, you build the statue that holds the efigy.

3	Nice bit of construction here, especially the way that everything falls over once the efigy is removed.

3	Do be careful when putting the curved bits on though ... it appears one of the edges on mine has slightly bent when putting it on ... nowt noticable though.

3	Temple : Preparing to steal : Run!!

3	You can see that the temple has toppled and debris has fallen all around ... And then, as he goes through the door, the door falls (he gets his hat) and then the rock ball starts a rolling!

3	Ruuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuun!!

3	The stickers were a pain though ... there's no room for a border around the sticker here!

3	Beware!!

3	After all that is done, you join all the pieces together and it makes more a really good playset.

3	Plenty of opportunity for recreating scenes here!

3	Idol Closeup : Total Set : Spares : Yet more spare stickers??!

3	(sorry, i've already put the spares in my box of bits!)

3	Overall, 8 out of 10 ... lots of play value and a pretty nice build.

3	Too many stickers though ... and defo poor arms for the skeletons!

3	Because of exams and other obligations, I haven't posted this sooner.

3	Seeing that no-one else has reviewed this set, I thought I might as well do it myself.

3	The set in its entire glory (minus the slammer, instructions and the (obviously) massive sticker sheet) The four cars included in this set; a muscle car, a sports car, a roadster and the police off-roader(!

3	): Because the police obviously have no clue that an off-roader is useless for catching street-racers, no less a batmobile-ish sports car, it will always trail behind: But the police have a trick up their sleeve - the drawbridge: Gotcha!

3	And the mechanism that makes it all tick: The motor is nothing more than a (slow) pull-back motor.

3	Push down the bridge, the latch will hook on to the gear and keep it in place until the latch is released.

3	And there's the new gas station.

3	Staying within theme, this gas-station is, like the tanker in 8147, from the company Fuel 4 Speed: There's a notable presence of detail here, such as the soda-dispenser, water (coolant?)

3	bottles and other accesories, two fuel pumps and bumper-level railings to prevent cars from crashing into them.

3	There's no interior however.

3	And as demonstrated here by a loyal Octan-employee and a pursuing officer, the gas station is built to minifig-scale: My impressions of this set: As a collector of tiny turbos, and yet to miss a set, I got this one regardless of what it included.

3	The gas station is indeed very nice, and the minifig-scale accesories were unexpected.

3	The lack of interior is no big issue, and the both the station and bridge can with ease be implemented into a mini-fig town.

3	The bridge also solidly built, and includes the ramps in its design, so it can be lifted, with ramps attached, without breaking apart.

3	The slammer included in the set is identical, apart from the white color, with those in 8147.

3	The cars are also very nice, altough I am yet to get used to the yellow batmobile, as I've grown accustomed to calling it.

3	I also love the off-roader's chunky tires, they make perfect wheels for the newer minifig-scale cars.

3	I never consider price/parts ratio, and here it would, for me, be irrelevant, because it will never be demolished for parts.

3	The play value is what I would consider pretty good, and while the bridge won't rise with a car on it, it's still strong enough to stay open with a car tipping over the edge.

3	Hmm.

3	Every nerve in my body is saying that this sets is worth roughly 8/10, so: Verdict: 8/10 Edited by WhiteFang, 23 May 2009 - 07:01 PM.

3	Indexed

2	The only negative is with the drum of the mixer, although the angle can be adjusted you cannot tip the contents out of the mixer.

3	So here it is, the long expected ;-) review of the town plan: I bought it at the Legostore Riem Arcaden last Saturday.

3	I paid 149,99 EUR for 1981 pieces.

3	This set is separated in 4 parts.

3	1: the Service/Gasstation 2: the cars.

3	the petrol pump and the fountain 3: the cinema 4: the town hall The Service Station has a lot of really nice details, like tools for the car repair, or the table with the cashpoint and the foodstation (there?s a croissant, a banana and a apple in this set).

3	One of my favourit parts is the trolley with some tools, you can see it at brickshelf.

3	At the second part are only a few pieces and i needed not much time to built the 2 cars, the fountain and the petrol pump.

3	There?s something at the truck i don?t understand.. maybe i did something wrong.. but.. the truck has no backlights.. *wacko* I like the petrol pump, that?s why i post a pic of it: The cinema is the highlight for me.

3	It has also really nice details, like the popcorn table or the gumball or candy machine.

3	The colours sheme is really nice, the front of the building with the big displays is a cool idea.

3	Overall a really nice building.

3	The town hall has also a really nice colour sheme, i love that dark green mixed with the white stairs.

3	A lot of plants around and in the town hall.

3	As you can see some figs who married there.

3	Not more to say about this building.

3	See the pics and enjoy it: Overall this set is a must have!!

3	I nabbed the JSF and the Rogue Shadow and scampered home to take pics with my new camera.

3	*wub* The box: The same as the other '07 boxes.

3	Nothing new.

3	The back shows the various features, with "pop out R2."

3	:-| Luckily, the intruction booklet and the DSS were intact- not folded like the last MM set I got.

3	I won't go too in-depth on the build, since *vader* posted a very in-depth review here.

3	The start of the build: The body of the fighter starts out long and skinny.

3	The JSF's landing gear allows it to sit comfortably without getting in the way while swooshing.

3	R2-D2's launching device.

3	R2 in position.

3	When launched...

3	...He often gets stuck if you don't press the button hard enough.

3	:-/ Looks like R2 needs to lay off... whatever it is robots eat.

3	So far: The flag stickered.

3	It's a big sucker sticker.

3	Completed.

3	I forgot to add the nose stickers before I took the pic.

3	Warning- the nose cone sticker is actually two stickers.

3	I thought it was one, peeled of one of the stickers, and put it on the middle of the two 1x8 plates, and didn't notice the other sticker.

3	*wacko* Various completed shots: I think this was a beautiful little set.

3	R2's launching unit and the flick missiles are annoying, but easily fixed.

3	I plan to add proper cannons in place of the flick missiles.

3	Anakin is a great minifig, but he doesn't look so well standing next to my other figs.

3	Wow, I'm surprised no one had done this already.

3	First off, this is a truly lovely set that many people should own, even though it's SOLD OUT on the S@H :'-( .

3	now lets start off with an overview.

3	*Note*: I was missing a few of the pieces (the rabbit, the trike) when I toke the pics.

3	The figs and a cat.

3	The engine: I really love this thing.

3	It's a beautiful 0-6-0 steam engine with a tender.

3	This is probably the most detailed steam engine Lego has given us.

3	I loved it so much, I made a non-holiday version for my town.

3	The flat cars: I like these, but they seem a bit simple.

3	Their cargo is good for Christmas or a birthday party.

3	The passenger car: It resembles the green passenger car we got a while back, but I like the interior in this one a bit better.

3	The caboose: a simple caboose like the one from 2001. the sad thing about it is thats there is no interior and it's hard to take the roof off.

3	Overall: I like this set, but it is kind of hard to use during the non winter months.

3	The price is kind of good, but with that price, it should have came with the motor.

3	I give it a 9/10 Happy New Year!

3	Okie guys and gals, here s time for some droid exploration with my review of set 7670.

3	As a general statement I have to say its really a neat set that is not that expensive for what it holds.

3	1) Box art Like always I will start with pics of the box art.

3	BTW, notice anything guys ?

3	No bloody crappy DSS.

3	Yes, finally a set without stickers and that feels great :-D 2) The Mfs Nothing really spectacular there.

3	Beach House Reviewed by Dunamis Set 4996 522 Pieces $29.95 from Target Build time 90 minutes Yet another interesting Creator theme house.

3	This one comes fresh of the 2008 line of sets and promises 3 different models.

3	Packing 522 pieces (albeit a lot of 1x1 plates) for only $29.95 it was hard to pass this one by as I was foraging for the new 2008 Star Wars sets at the local Target.

3	Plus, I was itching to do another review since I had finally fully recovered from my marathon UCS Falcon review which took the better part a month to complete.

3	The Box: The box is pretty standard Creator type box which shows off the three models (beach house, Caf?

3	and ?towering?

3	apartment building.)

3	The back of the box shows some of the features of the three models.

3	Interesting features of the three models prominently displayed on the back include: - Food counter complete with coffee (espresso) maker and food warmer (with chicken leg!)

3	- Home office complete with laptop (and the ubiquitous coffee cup.)

3	- Flip up roof granting access inside of beach house.

3	Note the satellite TV dish and even rain gutters along the roofline!

3	Opening the box is a matter of breaking two seals.

3	We?re back to the reusable cereal box type tab system that we saw so often in 2007 sets.

3	Note the parts inventory is on the side of the box as well.

3	This is a nice feature.

3	Once inside the box, we are greeted by eight sealed bags plus two yellow 16x2 plates and a green 32x16 baseplate.

3	Thank goodness there is no DSS (dreaded sticker sheet) but alas there are no minifigs.

3	In addition, there are the three manuals (one for each model) and they were stuffed into my box with the care of kid trying to put 10 gallons (or liters if you prefer) of candy in a 5 gallon bucket.

3	But hey, we?re not collecting manuals here so who cares if the manuals are all bent and warped?

3	The Manuals: The three manuals are 74, 72 and 48 pages in length.

3	They are laid out well and are pretty standard with all the usual trimmings: - Piece call outs for each step - Parts inventory at the end of the primary model build - Page numbers Color separation in these manuals were fine for me.

3	Plus, we get the usual verbose LEGO instructions on not dumping all your pieces outside in the grass and not to dump all your pieces into a single pile.

3	Thanks for the tip, TLG!

3	Parts list The Pieces: Pretty standard stuff here and as I mentioned, lots of 1x1 plates and tiles (at least 100.)

3	However, we do get quite a few windows and a couple of doors.

3	A majority of the color is black and yellow.

3	I did see a few pieces that I was not familiar with so I?m going to show them below.

3	Keep in mind I?m not a parts jockey so bear with me if I think a part is brand new for 2008 and it was actually released with the classic space line.

3	2x2 Window (fixed) and 4x3 window that opens: The follow photo shows the window glass (same as in Corner Caf?

3	), door glass and new black parts.

3	Turns out these black parts are used as wheels.

3	I showed the window glass because it still contains the molding circle just like they did before.

3	It is hard to see from the photo, but it is there.

3	The door glass I think might be new: I don?t recall seeing these 2x2 round plates with clips before and I thought I would show the mail only because it is printed and not a sticker: I know these are common, but didn?t they have four studs on top?

3	These only have two: How about this sloped 4x3 window that opens: Overall a nice assortment of parts with nothing juniorized.

3	The Build: The build was fun and was fairly straightforward.

3	Once you figure out which of the three models to build, it goes pretty quick.

3	Here are a few shots: See how the inside is made: Look at the detail with the flowers and even the outside water faucet!

3	Outdoor seating area: Upstairs being built: Upstairs with opening roof (notice the satellite TV dish): Check out the patio on the upstairs complete with outdoor light and rain gutters!

3	Here?s my favorite, the BBQ grill.

3	At least we know where those new parts go: Finally, check out the tree.

3	No juniorization here!

3	Here is what is left over: So far, I have only built the primary model.

3	The others look interesting, especially the caf?.

3	The Design: The design was well done.

3	Very rich in detail.

3	I love how there are no juniorized parts.

3	The house is accessible by taking off the top floor (like Caf?

3	Corner and Market Street).

3	There is an internal staircase as well.

3	There is no interior to speak of in the beach house, but there is in the other two models.

3	The only real negative is that it is kind of small when you get it done.

3	It would be nice if it was about 50% bigger.

3	Here are a few views of the beach house with a few minifigs thrown in: Check out the close-up of the caf?

3	which I think looks great: Also, here is a photo of the interior of the apartment building where you can see the office and computer: Overall Thoughts: It is a really nice set.

3	A tad on the small side but it has some great detail and lots of features.

3	Quick enough to build all three models and would fit real nice into an existing town plan.

3	Is minifig scale, but does not come with any.

3	Lots of window parts and black slopes.

3	Is a nice diversion from the onslaught of Clone Wars ships that we can?t remember seeing from the movies.

3	Final Rating: 84% Build 9/10 (Pretty quick and fun.)

3	Functionality 9/10 (It is a Creator set so you have multiple varied builds.

3	Diverse enough to keep the kids entertained.)

3	Design 10/10 (Excellent and well thought out.

3	Outstanding detail for such a small model.)

3	Parts 6/10 (Fair, nothing earth-shattering but lots of slopes and windows.)

3	Price 8/10 (Price ratio is good but you get a lot of little parts.

3	Would be better with minifigs.)

3	Edited by WhiteFang, 23 May 2009 - 06:38 PM.

3	Thanks for the review Dunamis, this is a great little set!

3	I'm also very impressed with Takuto20's mods.

3	I've been trying a few of my own.

3	I liked the tower block design, but a lot of stuff needed fixing.

3	Firstly I added a 4th wall, and made it so the storeys could be lifted off like in the other models.

3	I also added flowers on the windowsills and doorways out on to the balconies.

3	Still to be added is an extra door for the top floor which I'm going to get from the new doors and windows pack.

3	I added a chimney that goes all the way up the back of the house, and has a fireplace on every level.

3	Each floor is fully furnished with a fireplace, wash basin and bed on the upper levels... ...and a corner sofa and coffee table, plus an extra large fireplace on the ground floor.

3	Finally here is my idea of what to do with two copies of this set!

3	All the parts pictured are from 2x 4996, except 5 extra fence panels and the minifigs.

3	The house on the left has it's garden at the rear.

1	1.

1	BEFORE BUYING Even if I am City fan, those new sized planes are really not mine cup of tea, my love to Lego is firmly frozen somewhere between years 1980-1995.

1	Main reason to buy was, that I wanted to write a review at Czech Afol web Kostky.org.

1	I bought it three days ago via web advertising, price was +- 35 USD.

1	2.

1	AFTER OPENING THE BOX As presumed, some very big parts and three bags, and as an additional bonus lot of Danish air free of charge.

1	First sight told me, that this will be really short and easy building.. 3.

1	IMPRESSIONS DURING BUILDING ...and it was really true.

1	30 minutes of lazy building.

1	Bag 1 - plane.

1	Bag 2 - plane gondols with supports.

1	Bag 3 - wings and propellers.

1	When I saw the way, how is this plane made, I was strongly thinking to play Money for Nothing from Dire Straits as a music accordant with whole set.

1	4.

1	IMPRESSIONS AFTER BUILDING - LOOKOUT Juniorized creeps.

1	This is my first plane in this scale and for 99% the last one.

1	Lack of details, lot of ugly big parts, from whole set you can see the main development target - to keep RRP at some certain low level.

1	Inner space of airplane absolutely undone, no details, no luggage, no computers, nothing at all!!

1	Just a lot, lot of air!

1	The very only details in whole plane are the stickered pilots desk and some kind of seat constuction.

1	5.

1	IMPRESSIONS AFTER BUILDING - PLAYABILITY But, what is playability at this set?

1	Hydroplane, which cannot float (as seen on enclosed photos) ?

1	If TLC will make some new kind of big parts used for gondolas, to make the plane floating, they will for sure make no other damage.

1	Juniorization couldn?t be higher.

1	You even cannot drive across the carpet with the plane.

1	So, how to play?

1	Open the doors, open the cabin part, and turn with propellers?

1	Weak, Weak, Weak!

1	6.

1	RESUMED IMPRESSIONS Sadly I must say, that at limited release sets TLC?

1	boat seems to sailing to the worst part of the coast.

1	After quite good 7344, perfect 7899 and 7900, strange, but acceptable 7998, juniorization came back with 7906, followed with this ugly Playmobilized 7732.

1	7.

1	FINAL WORD In fact, even 15 USD seems to be too much for this kind of set.

1	35 USD, expected RRP in our country, is really overpriced to hell.

1	Neither set, nor minifig is not interesting.

1	TLC maybe knows about juniorization as well, as nowhere on the box the number of pieces isn?t written.

1	If you my AFOL friends want to spent your bucks, better give half of the price to African orphans.

1	You will save your money, and you will have a good feeling!
