3	Hello and welcome to another Redman set review!

3	Well, actually, the first Redman set review!

3	I'm your host, Redman, and today I adorn my medieval outfit to tell you about the Impulse set simply titled "The Knight".

3	This is a great set, with 14 pieces, 2 of which are spare, and a minifig with 2 weapons, 2 helmets, and some shiny armour.

3	All this is packaged in a tiny box, just short of 10 cm?

3	(or 3?

3	inches?

3	), with a neat little instruction manual that folds up to the size of the weapons rack included in the set.

3	As you can see, this set only costs a measly 7 NZD.

3	(Disclaimer: Redman not included.)

3	Here we see the box, clearly showing what the box holds.

3	On the top we see a 1:1 scale picture of a minifig, for those new to Lego, or who have forgotten how big a minifig is I guess.

3	:-/ X-D The instruction manual, showing the nice and easy built, with me for size comparison.

3	:-D (*Sorry about the dark image, I had to lean over the light to get a birds eye pic.

3	;-)*) Here we see the 2 different soldiers you can make with the set; a knight, and a guard or standard troop or soldier or whatever you want to call him... (Note, each set comes with only 1 minifigure, and additional accessories.)

3	Of course you know I'm in the picture just for the sake of it, I'm not really one of the soldiers.

3	X-D The neat little weapons rack, or rather equipment rack, as it holds not only a weapon but a shield (except the ovoid ones), helmet, and armour.

3	Nice and easy storage, so your equipment won't get dirty lying around on the ground.

3	:-D One of the spare parts is another of those robot hands, so you can stick that in place of the shield and allow the rack to hold 2 weapons.

3	Just thought you'd like to know that.

3	:-$ And here we see the nifty little structure of the thing.

3	It can even support a whole minifig!

3	Note the grey stud on the bottom bar is a spare part, I just find it better used there to hold the armour.

3	:-) Huh?

3	I don't remember this picture... 8-| It appears I drifted off, and these guys don't look too happy I overtook their weapons equipment rack.

3	:-$ I should go... X-D So, in conclusion this is a great set for army building, at a reasonable price, with nice equipment, and it can be picked up as a little extra with your normal shopping.

3	X-D That's all for today folks!

3	*sweet* [/Redman] So, what do you think?

3	Should I continue with these Redman Reviews ?

3	(:-P), or just stop now?

3	X-D Comments and criticism welcome!

3	:-$ ~Peace

3	Lego City Truck & Forklift Set # 7733 Pieces: 343 Price: $24.99 (USD) Store of Purchase: Toys R'Us Release Date: January 2008 After discussion of the mysterious yellow cargo contained in this new City transport set and a visit to my local TRU, I purchased this set.

3	I was immediately pleased with the price/piece which I think is pretty reasonable (343 pieces for $25).

3	Starting with the box, great City artwork boasting "Special Edition": Tha backside of the box (no alternate models comes as no surprise): The dreaded decals (I was looking for the skull and bones for radioactive, but no such luck): My favorite part of the set, a very clever forklift: Side view: And the backside: What I like about the forklift is the bars across the top giving the vehicle a "real-life" design.

3	The double wheels in the front with two pieces that can hold the wheels also adds to a clever design: I like the figs (although not much new - perhaps I'll make the driver into a werewolf later): The set includes three cargo pallets, the first some sort of fuel with gauge: The 2nd, two Indy containers, and a square 2x4 brick (I have not put the decals on yet): And the mysterious yellow cargo.

3	Your guess is as good as mine :-$ .

3	On to the truck, the front section: The front grill: Another angle: The back: I like the opening mechanism that is very simple, but works well.

3	Also is the large plate tile piece inside.

3	I like this because the entire interior has no studs: And the trailer section of the truck: Orange and yellow tail lights: And the rear trailer open: The complete set: Summary: This is a neat set that reminds me a bit of classic Lego City (but larger).

3	It is very playable and has a lot of accessories adding to the value.

3	The build was very simple, and enjoyable (took me about an hour).

3	It is a great addition to a number of City sets including the Cargo Ship, Container Stacker, the World City Cargo Train, and the new Cargo Plane.

3	As I mentioned previously, I have not yet put on the decals that I'm sure will really add to the overall look of the set.

3	The forklift is awesome and I like the cargo containers.

3	The truck could have benefited from a few additional details (chrome smokers, and an undercarriage box that really opens).

3	Considering everything, I would buy this set again.

3	Hope you enjoy and perhaps this mysterious cargo will make its way into a Brickster Mystery.

3	*y*

3	I got this set last week and just to add a few of my own points CONS: - The forklift spring feels a bit flimsy - I don't know how long it will last or how much stress it would take - and the end coil isn't really heavily secured to the lift mechanism.

3	It's the Exo-Force of City sets!

3	The truck set does look less plain with them on though.

3	I would reccomend lining them up with the green brick in the second container rather than applying the first lot without a guide or they may end up uneven - It's very hard to put the minifig in the forklift without dismantling (or breaking open) the set slightly - The cargo box attached to the main cabin of the truck doesn't hold very strongly - Minifigs are dull - that dark blue torso with pattern is way overused - green stickers are a different green to the bricks themselves PROS: - lots of nice pieces including the large white panels and cargo pieces, and i like the green/ white colour scheme - the cargo doors open well and the hingeing mechanism doesn't stand out to the detriment of the rest of the set (as some people have complained about the mail airplane) - studless floor in cargo containers makes it easy to move pallets in and out - fits in better than the Heavy Hauler to a minifig sized city - new 1x1x4 slope!

3	(at least I hadn't seen it before) OVERALL - nice set with some good pictures, although a bit flimsy, and way too many stickers - the same issues I have with the Cargo Plane as well (although that had more colour issues).

3	Greetings, and welcome to another Redman Review!

3	I'm your host, Redman, and today I adorn my medieval outfit to tell you about the Impulse set simply titled "The Knight".

3	No wait, that's the old script.

3	X-D I mean, "The Good Wizard".

3	*sweet* The other Castle Impulse set (the first being 'The Knight'), this is a wonderful, and in my case unexpected addition to the Castle line!

3	I did not expect to get a nice good wizard, but rather another plain white skellie for the Impulse, and was pleasantly surprised when I saw the first picture of this set.

3	The Impulse sets give you pieces you wouldn't expect to see in such small sets, for example, The Knight came with the armour, and this comes with an owl, a gem, and a crystal ball piece.

3	It comes with 11 pieces, including the wand, owl, and gem, and no spares, which doesn't really matter as it doesn't need any.

3	The box sports the set number, age range (which I blissfully ignore X-D), awesome Castle logo, and the assembled set, with the usual 1:1 scale picture of a minifig.

3	The back of the box shows pictures of the boxed Skeleton Tower and King's Castle Siege sets.

3	Note the price is in New Zealand dollars, and is really the same prica as any other Impulse set.

3	Next are the instructions, which are separated into 3 parts, 1 for the minifigure, 1 for the table, and one for the bird stand.

3	Very simple, also worth mentioning is the parts numbers are next to their respective parts, for replacement parts etc.

3	On the back we see (on the top half) pictures of Skeleton Prison Carriage, Skeleton Tower, and King's Castle Siege, this time not of the boxed sets, but the sets themselves.

3	On the lower half we have 8 pictures, each of the different Impulse sets.

3	The Wizard's torso is plain sand blue, with no patterns or anything, but it doesn't really matter is his beard's in the way.

3	;-) The head is that same old 'white fade to grey beard' head, but the white beard covers up most of the grey.

3	My favourite part is the pants, I love that we're getting printed belts and legs again.

3	His belt has 4 gold crosses (as seen in, if you look closely, the new Crownie's torso and the Crownie archer's torso) and a belt buckle, and the legs have a bottle, a coin, and a small bag.

3	Nice little wizard-ey items.

3	The, er, items, no, accessories, no, models?

3	The stuff in the set include a little stand for the owl, and a table utilising the new 4x4 round piece in light bley, with the crystal ball in the middle, encasing the yellow gem held on by a 2x2 circle piece in blue.

3	Why blue, I'm not sure.

3	Maybe it's because the crystal is yellow, and the Crownie's colours are blue and gold, so the blue piece with the yellow crystal symbolise the Crownie's colours.

3	Or maybe TLC just felt the need to include an odd colour.

3	:-P In conclusion, this is a wonderful set, with some neat accessories, and it doesn't really need to be bought in the masses, after all, you needs an army of owls and wizards?

3	:-| :-P So it works fine as a single set, and adds a more fantasy feel to your Crownie army.

3	That's all for today folks!

3	*sweet* [/Redman] Thanks for reading another of my Redman interviews, any suggestions on how to/what to do to improve it is greatly appreciated, as are all comments and criticisms (except those blatant thoughtless criticisms that don't help at all :-P)!

3	~Peace Edited by KimT, 10 August 2008 - 01:31 PM.

3	geez i thought $6 was bad :-X Edit: who typed megablocks in my post..i didnt,???

3	Well, since no-one seems to have done one for this set, here we go....

3	Here's the complete set in all its glory.

3	Yes, I really like it, but then, Tabletown has the capacity to support it and my green Army have their eyes on it as a potential military transport as well.

3	:-) I'll start out with the little airport ground car thingy - very neat and functional, here are views front and back: Next up, the steps which allow the plane crew to embark and disembark: And to round off this little trio, the cargo loading platform, here in its lowered position.

3	Note the prong thingy sticking out from the rear: And here raised.

3	The prong thingy is now hinged up to support the back of the platform and keep it level: Here's a slightly different angle so you can see the pieces under there: The all-important cargo itself!

3	Hmmm...not much for a plane this size...

3	The cargo pallet slots neatly onto the loading platform: Here's the complete set of ground equipment - all attached: And so onto the plane itself.

3	Note that unlike the other large planes, the main wing sits at the TOP of the row of bricks making up the side of the fuselage: I took it apart a little so you can see the internal construction of the fuselage.

3	Note that the cargo area is really small, right at the back.

3	What else is this thing carrying?

3	Illegal immigrants?

3	:-) A picture of the rear of the fuselage, just because I like the sticker: Front landing gear.

3	WAY better than on the other large planes.

3	I don't know if this is a new piece or what but I've had no problems with it at all, and my kids have been playing with it as well: The rather sexy rear undercarriage - this area reminds me of one of those giant Russian transport planes - wicked: Those angled grey slopes atop each side of the rear undercarriage annoy the heck out of me as they KEEP COMING OFF whenever I pick the plane up.

3	I think a 1x4 plate on top to bind them together might solve that.

3	A slightly blurry view (sorry) from underneath.

3	The gear LOOKS like it might be capable of retracting internally, but alas, no.

3	This is a shame as there's certainly enough room in there and it's a wasted opportunity IMO.

3	Might have to modify that... A view of one of the four engines, I personally think they look too small and should have something under the wing as well to make them rounder: Cockpit: Crew door, open.

3	I LOVE the smooth action of these doors and the way they seal flush against the fuselage when closed: Cargo door, open: Crew door with docked ladder: Cargo door with docked loading platform: Cargo slots inside and locks into place the same way it sits on the loader, neat: The minifigs, sorry this one is a bit blurry: And that concludes this week's "Show and Tell".

2	*n*

1	I loved the pics in the catalogues but was a bit disappointed by the build and end result.

1	My own thoughts: CONs: - as noted, the cargo space is really small considering the size of the plane, although I can see this is restricted due to playability - without the barrier in the middle, the cargo would slide all over the place while the plane was being swooshed - the cargo 'lift' (I'm not sure how else to describe it) is very weak and snaps off, although it is a clever design I think it's badly implemented - there is nothing to hold the cargo pallet to the cargo lift truck so it tends to slide off all over the place as soon as the truck moves - colour issues - I had at least 3 shades of green with the larger plane pieces and noticeable variances even with identical cargo hatch pieces.

1	At least one of them also came quite scratched, which was a little disappointing - At $79.95 AUD it's $10 more than the Passenger Plane was with less pieces and figs, and no printed pieces whatsoever!

1	more $ for less, methinks.

1	PROs: - Lots of nice cargo crate pieces and even the stickers for these are pretty good.

1	- landing gear piece adjusts very well to height differentials so the plane doesn't lose its gear as often as the earlier passenger planes - the hinging mechanism works very well to open the cargo holds - opens very smoothly and is not noticeable - I'd definitely like to see more of this technique - the little vehicles work well chained together and are all good small designs OVERALL: - I really like the large planes since 06 but I don't think they've still quite hit the nail on the head.

1	Whereas the earlier planes were a little flimsy, this one is sturdier but has its own issues.

1	The look of the Cargo Plane is nice, and the new landing piece and cargo hatch pieces are really great, but some design weaknesses and colour issues detract from the overall product.

1	It's a shame as with a bit of tweaking this could have been a must-have set.

3	Wow, that's a great review of a great set Dr S!

3	*y* As you yourself have already noted, this has the potential to be a fantastic military MOC!

3	With a bit of modification you can get the engines to be rounder, or perhaps do away with them completely and replace them with jet engines.

3	*sweet* Though I can't think of a system to retract the undercarriage at the top of my head it seems like there's indeeed more than enough potential to do so.

3	It reminds me rather of an Ilyushin Il-76, one of my favourite cargo planes.

2	In the meantime leaving Marion behind to fight them off.

2	:-P The whip is bendable but it will always snap back into a coil, its some type of bendy hard plastic *Scoring Figs- 9/10 Model- 8/10 Playability- 8.5/10 Overall Satisfaction- 4/10 (would be 9/10 if it wasn't for the stupid Anakin head error!)

3	Hello and welcome to another, oh wait, first Batbrick and iamded review!

3	Today us two sworn enemies will be reviewing the Creator Cargo Chopper, here is the front of the box: And while pushing iamded to his doom, here is the back: Haha!

3	Ouch!

3	Oh dear...here are the parts anyway...

3	Here is the instruction of the first model, the Cargo Chopper.

3	I love Creator sets for the different models, they always excite me.

3	Just ignore me finishing off my nemesis in the background.

3	Something very interesting that I liked in the instructions was this step where you must add those three 2x2 yellow rounded pieces under the chopper.

3	This is for support while you build, which is handy, and later you take it off: And even later use it as the cargo.

3	I found that to be rather innovative and clever, as well as - Hey!

3	What are you hitting me for?

3	Both instruction booklets have the same back: Now heres the Chopper itself.

3	I love the design of it, it isn't quite minifig scale but its great all the same.

3	This is my first non-Xpod or House creator set, and it sure is fun.

3	Here me and iamded go for a dizzy ride.

3	I love the nose of the copter, and the landing gear is fantastic.

3	A shot from the other side.

3	Oh dear, it seems we've been a bit sick from that ride, and were vomiting transgreen 1x1s.

3	The cargo itself is nicely made, though I forgot to put on two tiles here :-$ .

3	It fits in real well with the chopper to, and the line is great for giving iamded the wedgie he deserves: This is my first power function set, so I was pretty excited.

3	The motor is intergrated really well into this set, and is activated by pushing that little 3x2 plate with the 1x1 slopes on it forward, until it hits the motor button, that orange knob.

3	Another point of interest is the use of bley barrels on each side.

3	I like this as I don't have those pieces in that colour.

3	A shot of the motor.

3	Its really simple, all you do is pull the hook out to any length that allows, then press the orange button and it will wind it back up.

3	This makes the Chopper pull the cargo up into its bay, and iamded pull me here reluctantly to a whacking: A top view, is that MY head?

3	A view of the chopper without the cargo in it.

3	I love the lowered cockpit: The leftover pieces from building: (NOTE: iamded's head does not count as set piece) And a final shot of the set with me and iamded.

3	Oh, it appear we're dead, oh dear... Hope you enjoyed this review, soon I will post the two alternate models.

3	I loved this chopper, its great to play with and has nice construction.

3	It also has some handy pieces too.

3	The motor function sounds like a gimmick but is well intergrated into this model.

3	Well worth the price, so far this is another win for Creator I say!

3	So far I recommend this model, but later we'll see if the alt models are up to scratch.

3	Also, since this is my first review, comments and criticism welcome on everything.

3	Batbrick Away!

3	6258 Smuggler's Shanty Overview Smuggler's Shanty was released in 1992, it consisted of 69 pieces, 3 minifigs (two pirates, one Imperial) and it cost $9.25 (USD).

3	The set itself is a small but rather sturdy den for the pirates!

3	Review: The minifigs consist of two pirates and one Imperial.

3	The minifigs are not all that rare, which is disappointing, I would of liked a rarer fig!

3	But still it is a good cheap source of pirate and Imperial figures.

3	Here is an overall shot of the set, which includes the three figs, the shanty which is made using palm leaves pieces, and a nice grey shark nibbling at the soldier's oar.

3	A close up of the soldier rowing hard in his boat.

3	I would have preferred to have a normal soldier with shako hat, as I have more officers than normal soldiers now!

3	: And a close up snap of the main structure.

3	Note the wine glass, which was a nice touch!

3	Funnily enough, only 4 pieces of treasure were included in this set, compared to the usual 8 gold coins in other sets.

3	A view from the back, which also gives a good view of the pieces used to construct the shanty mainly simple black 1 by 1 bricks: The Shanty looks good from most angles but their are a few where the roof construction looks rather odd, but that is just a minor nitpick!

3	Yet another view from the front,, this time at a slightly different angle.

3	The yellow base plate looks rather nice too, I prefer it over the tan pieces we trend to get nowadays: "Attack!!"

3	The Stupid drunk pirate in the background does not even notice!

3	Overall I think this is a rather good set, despite some shortcomings, such as the lack of treasure and odd roof from some angles.

3	The shark, Imperial soldier and useful parts make up for it, and of course the price is cheap on most auction sites, I got mine for a mere ?5 ($10), with the cheapest price on Bricklink being $8.

3	Rate the set then leave your comments, thoughts and opinions!!

3	!

2	Edited by Ardelon, 21 September 2014 - 03:40 PM.

3	Hi guys.

3	I picked these up the other day, but it's taken me this long to get round to posting the reviews.

3	So, here we go: Tub comparison with a minfig (thanks Brainbox): The lighting changes a bit throughout the photographs, as it was going dark outside, so I only really had my desk light, and I kept getting in the way.

3	4837 Mini Trains Now the box I really like.

3	It's no different to those of last year's sets, but the colour here is simply fantastic, and really seems appropriate for the theme.

3	So this is what you get inside.

3	All the pieces are still inside the bag, the optical illusion was accidental :-D .

3	No pieces of particular outstanding interest, but the dark green cheese slopes are rather nice.

3	Look out for those later.

3	1 2 3 This is the main model, and uses all the pieces in the set (bar these two, which according to the inventory are spares, but as with all my other Creator sets, I'm cheating and leaving them in).

3	This is far and away the best model of the three, and evokes the iconic version of a steam train.

3	The green looks superb, but I'm not sure whether that's due to the model itself or the actual colour.

3	Moving on, we get to the second model: 1 Leftovers (yes, I admit, I was using a piece of paper) This isn't actually a bad model.

3	I don't think it's quite as nice as the previous one, but it's not bad.

3	It's different from the first model as well, which is good.

3	Too muich of the same can be a bad thing.

3	Finally, we come to the third model: Leftovers Now...

3	I'll be honest.

3	I don't really know what this is.

3	It's not that good a model compared to the other two.

3	That's all I can say, really.

3	And of course, all the pieces fit into the tub.

3	Overall: I have to say, I do like this set, despite the weak third model.

3	The strength of the primary and secondary models make up for any weaknesses in the third, and I can imagine the pieces being fully usuable in building other trains.

3	While the basic idea of these tubs isn't quite as good as the X-Pods with regards portability and general 'niceness' they aren't bad.

3	And for a fairly cheap price (?3-4) as well.

3	4838 Mini Vehicles This is one of those set boxes that you see because of the ridiculously loud colours.

3	Sound marketing scheme if you ask me.

3	I've managed it again.

3	There are pieces outside the bag.

3	Or are there?

3	Now these I like *y* .

3	1 2 (I don't know what the clip is for, there isn't one on the other side) 3 4 5 This is the main model of the set, and again all the pieces are used bar these three, the spares.

3	It's quite a nice model, although the car's a bit odd.

3	Still, I like the ramps, and the colour scheme reminds me just a little of G1 Ultra Magnus.

3	Hmm, I think that boom arm could do with refixing... 1 2 Leftovers This is actually quite nice as well.

3	It's that classic breakdown truck, and the boom arm itself is quite nice, with quite a bit of movement.

3	Another solid model.

3	1 Leftovers I'm surprised by the amount of detail here actually.

3	Not only have TLC included a spare wheel at the back, but also what looks like a trailer hitch, which all adds to the 'realism.'

3	Another nice model to round out a nice set.

3	And in the tub.

3	Overall: I'm not sure which of the two I like better.

3	When I bought them, and on the way home, I much preferred the train set.

3	But after building this set, I'm not sure.

3	This is another good set from the year when TLC seems to be giving us so many.

3	There are some good pieces in here too, and while there's nothing unique, they're still good.

3	So, thanks for reading, hope it helped someone, and if there are any requests, I'll see what I can do.

3	That's requests for pics, not songs ;-) .

3	So here it is finally, my first ever review of a lego set..oh wait, it's actually 2 sets.

3	So i don't really know how to do it right, but i'll try the best.

3	(Sorry if some pictures are a litte bit dark, but i'm not really into photography and i got bad light here) Let's Start with the Dwarf's Mine Defender: Theme: Castle 2008 Set Name: Dwarf's Mine Defender Number: 7040 Pieces: 86 Price: ?9,99 (EUR) First, as always, the box: The back, a few instructions on how the defender works, for those how don't know ;-) : And the instructions: We continue with the minifigs, sorry i forgot to make a closeup of the dwarf: And finally the mine defender itself, i personally think it isn't as bad as maybe some people think.

3	The chain for the catapult is great i think: I kinda love those controls, the mechanism with the rubbe rband actually works pretty well, but only on a not-glossy underground.

3	That's pretty much all of it, it's small but i like it a lot.

3	So let's go on to the tower raid now, which would be my absolute favorite of those new sets.

3	-------------------------------------- Theme: Castle 2008 Set Name: Tower Raid Number: 7037 Pieces: 364 Price: ?29,99 (EUR) Again, first the box & Instructions: We got 2 sets of instructios here, one for the tower and one for the siege tower: The Minifigs, we got one archer and one soldier here, both with the torsos of the 2007 sets: Now thw orc side, starting with the great leader, with the new armor and the golden helmet (i love those pieces!

3	): Closeup of the armor & helmet: Then we got another orc-knight: And the prisoner, with handcuffs!

3	The Crownie Tower looks great overall, though there is something i don't really like about it, but later on that.

3	Now the back, and that is what really bothers me, there areno walls on the first floor except the one with the wall-piece and the door, and theprison also is open at the back.

3	The orc easily could jump out there: Not sure what these are all about, they really don't add much to the set: Enough rant now, let's go on with a pretty sweet detail, the golden crystal on the little table: The wall piece on the first floor you can ram in: And finally the very best thing of this set, the amazing orc siege tower!

3	From the front: The great working ram, you can pull it back very far and it got pretty much power: Here we got another sweet detail, the siege "platform" that moves out by pulling a cord in the back of the tower: Finally a picture of a bit siege action: If you ram in the lower wallpiece, the brown shelfs of the prison-floor collapse and the prisoned orc is finally free!

3	Summary: Likes: As i mentioned before, i really think that's the best ever produced siege tower, it's got so mich details and works extremely well, also the overall look of it is magnificant.

3	The destroy-mechanism of the tower is pretty cool too, the brown door is a fine detail too.

3	Nothing much to say about the mine defender, i like this little set, and there's nothing really to bother about it.

3	Dislikes: The Back of the tower.

3	That's really the only thing that's a bit bad imo, they could have put there 2 more walls on the first floor and something to lock the prison easily.

3	Final Thought: The Tower Raid for me personally is the best of the 2008 sets so far, it's got great playability and looks simply good.

3	My opinion: Buy it!

3	Green Grocer Reviewed by Dunamis Set 10185 2,352 Pieces $149.95 from The LEGO Store (Glendale, CA) Build time 6.5 hours Holy guacamole!

3	Almost exactly one year after Caf?

3	Corner was released we get the third installment in the increasingly popular LEGO exclusive town series.

3	Combined with the famous 10182 Caf?

3	Corner and its trusty companion 10190 Market Street this trio makes the foundation for an amazing city block of LEGO goodness.

3	For those new to this series of sets, check out my reviews of the two previous sets in this line: Cafe Corner Market Street I would not necessarily recommend reading too many of my reviews in one setting as you might experience loss of brain cells and/or drowsiness.

3	You have been warned.

3	So, how does Green Grocer stack up to the two previous sets you ask?

3	Well, follow along kind reader and I shall attempt to unravel this question.

3	The Box: The gigantic box is pretty standard and looks amazingly similar to the Caf?

3	Corner box.

3	The back of the box shows some of the features of the green grocer as well as a lot of the cool interior that was absent from the previous sets.

3	In addition, we are shown an image of the three sets together and a small insert image showing how they connect together (as if we could not master that difficult maneuver?)

3	Opening the box is a matter of breaking two seals.

3	As it seems to be the norm now, we have the reusable cereal box type tab system that we saw so often in 2007 sets.

3	However, upon opening the tabs we are pleasantly surprised to find a cardboard tray!

3	Have not seen one of those in a while.

3	As you can see in the photo, we have two 32x16 green base plates, three instruction manuals and a bunch of bags that are broken into four groups: Group 1 has 12 bags and goes with the first manual and builds the first floor.

3	Group 2 has 9 bags and goes with the second manual to build the second floor.

3	Group 3 has 14 bags and goes with the third manual for the top floor and roof.

3	And one bag that is not numbered and hence you can open it whenever you feel like it.

3	There are no stickers ?

3	Yay!

3	Moving right along, we get to the three instruction manuals.

3	The Manuals: The three manuals are 55, 47 and 47 pages in length.

3	They are laid out well and are pretty standard with all the usual trimmings: - Piece call outs for each step - Parts inventory at the end of the second manual - Page numbers Color separation in these manuals was fine for me except dark bley and black.

3	We get a nice photo of all three sets together: Plus, we get a nice tip showing how to split up the bags and what goes where.

3	Those additional pieces you see in the photo just below the numbered bags are the pieces that come from the single un-numbered bag (along with the base plates).

3	Parts list Random manual shot The Pieces: Upon opening the first set of bags, one thing is clear; there are a TON of little tiny pieces!

3	The minifigs are included in this first section as well.

3	Interesting to note that there are a handful of printed pieces and as I mentioned previously, no stickers.

3	We also get a host of new and exciting pieces to add to our collection.

3	Keep in mind my scope of LEGO sets is generally centered around Star Wars, Technic, Creator and the occasional racer set so what is new to me might have been around 15 years.

3	At any rate, here are some of the more interesting pieces: Again, note the printed tiles.

3	This time around, LEGO has decided to include 33% more minifigs than the Caf?

3	Corner and Market Street sets.

3	Yes, we get four minifigs instead of three!

3	Here are the cast of characters: Pictured (left to right) is Sir Top Hat, Miss Jenny Blue Overalls, Patti O?

3	Furniture and little Timmy Cub Scout.

3	I?ll leave it up to the minifig aficionados to decipher which torsos are new and to tell us all about the hairpieces.

3	I can say with reasonable certainty that the four yellow smiley heads are not new (somebody check that?)

3	Don?t forget the lovable little cat named ?Tom?.

3	He is the arch-rival of the mouse ?Jerry?

3	that lives downstairs: Overall, there are a lot of pieces, large variety and wide range of colors.

3	The Build: If you have either of the two previous sets, you will feel right at home here.

3	Just like in the previous builds, it seems like the first ten build steps are consumed with laying a bunch of 1x1, 1x2 and 2x2 tiles everywhere.

3	Almost feels like 30% of the pieces are used up right away (see below).

3	There are several sections where you build various parts of the interior.

3	Take a look at the cash register/counter below: And the beverage cooler: And the produce stand and everything that goes in it: Looks like someone has mail: Looks like someone just had a baby: This set is incredibly well done and gives inspiration to go back and add similar items to Caf?

3	Corner and Market Street.

3	As before, the average builder is introduced to some new building techniques like using the hinge plates to make the angles on the front of the building as shown below: Also the top of the roof shows some interesting ideas: Overall, it is a really fun build that kept me entertained the whole way.

3	The Design: This is a great set with lots of little details.

3	I especially like the little mouse hole in the wall leading to the Jerry the mouse?s area.

3	They even included a little slice of cheese!

3	It seems the designers can?t get away from the ?usual?

3	staircase which I always feel is way too big.

3	Maybe future designs can incorporate a spiral staircase to save room for other things in the model.

3	One welcome addition is the fire escape as seen below: I?m going to show a bunch of examples of various items in the set so you can get the feel of the amazing detail in this design.

3	Take a look at the lamps (torches?)

3	just outside the door: And the streetlight with fire hydrant: Brickwork and archway: Awning: Here is the back side of the building.

3	Note the trashcans and yard tools: Here is a close-up of the railings on the second story balcony and the second photo is the finished product with curtains in the window.

3	Nice use of cups to make the banister on the second floor: Here is the fireplace on the second floor: Second floor staircase with Tom?s hiding spot: Check out the radiator on the third floor: More third floor: Nice grandfather clock and rug (third floor) Check out the deck that is up on the roof.

3	Complete with two chairs, table, umbrella, flower pots and grill: Interesting use of minifig hammers on the roof: Finally, here is what is left over when we?re done: A couple of shots of the front: A shot of the back: And here are all three together: Overall Thoughts: This is an incredible set and the best of the three in my opinion.

3	It is hard to top Caf?

3	Corner but I believe Green Grocer just did.

3	I absolutely love all the details and building techniques that went into making this set.

3	There is a ton of different parts and wide color selection.

3	As usual, we get a bunch of tiles and small plates, but that goes with the series.

3	Also, we get four minifigs and lots of minifig accessories.

3	I?m giving this set a score of 100%!

3	I thought about it and I really don?t know how they could have made it any better.

3	In short, RUN don?t walk to go pick this set up!

3	Final Rating: 100% Build 10/10 (Excellent - Lots of nice interiors, details and accessories to build.)

3	Functionality 10/10 (Outstanding.

3	Raises the bar with interior and detail.

3	Think Caf?

3	Corner on steroids.)

3	Design 10/10 (Excellent ?

3	can?t say enough good things about it.)

3	Parts 10/10 (Great selection and diverse colors.

3	Great minifigs.)

3	Price 10/10 (Price ratio is excellent but lots and lots of little parts.

3	Well worth the price.)

3	As alway, feel free to comment, complain and question what you see here.

3	I'd like to hear your feedback on this amazing set.

3	Wow, another old technic set review by you.

3	Nice set, and thanks for that review.

2	Looks like you have the original 1989 version with the yellow top cylinders.

2	:-) I got one too several years ago, although I probably paid too much for it.

2	:-P On a side note, if that pneumatic tubing feels harder and stiffer than the modern type, I highly recommend that you don't use it and buy some of the newer stuff off Bricklink instead.

2	TLC originally used a different material for the tubes and this stuff degrades the nozzles (on pistons, switches and so on) over time.

2	The old tubes also grip the nozzles much more firmly and if you aren't careful when removing them, it's actually possible to rip off the nozzles completely.

2	X-O I had this happen a few years ago, although TLC replaced my broken pistons for free.

2	I got rid of that stuff for good after that, although the pistons on my Power Crane still have slightly discolored nozzles.

2	Edited by CP5670, 10 March 2008 - 04:57 AM.

2	CP5670, on Mar 10 2008, 05:53 AM, said: The old tubes also grip the nozzles much more firmly and if you aren't careful when removing them, it's actually possible to rip off the nozzles completely.

3	Thanks for the photos, Eric

3	Thanks for another fun review!

3	This set is high on my list of things to buy, I love cranes, built many and bought many including the classic 8460 from 1995 and the more recent 8421.

3	That threaded axle never stopped intriguing me...

3	It was use in so few sets (I believe 8851 contained one as well?)

3	and I still don't know why it's better than any other axle.

3	Congratulations with a near mint copy of this set!

3	:-)

2	simonwillems, on Mar 10 2008, 01:32 PM, said: That threaded axle never stopped intriguing me...

2	It was use in so few sets (I believe 8851 contained one as well?)

2	and I still don't know why it's better than any other axle.

2	The purpose of the threaded axle is to carry tension.

2	Regular axles are used primarily for carrying torsion (for gears), sometimes for compression (8855 landing gear, helicopter skids), and sometimes just for looks (roll cages, canopies).

2	But used in tension, connectors will usually just pop off.

2	With the threads and the corresponding nuts, this part can be used to squeeze parts together (like the pen in the plotter of 8094), or to hold heavy assemblies onto turntables (like 8862 and 8851).

2	With the power crane (8854) reviewed here, that is the complete list of sets which used this part.

2	I wrote about it here: http://www.ericalbre...1984.html#Parts Eric

3	As I bought it, I didn't even know I would also get a box.

3	It just said: all parts with building instructions.

3	After opening the parcel I was like: "woah... woooaaahhh" and so on.

3	;-) I love LEGO-boxes because as a child I stood in the toy stores starring at the boxes, only seeing the front and the back, nothing more.

3	This brings back some memories... :'-)

2	Blakbird, on Mar 10 2008, 09:45 PM, said: I wrote about it here: http://www.ericalbre...1984.html#Parts Eric Thanks for that information, it opened my eyes as to the function of the threaded axle!

2	:-)

2	Hi!

2	This is my third (old-school) technic set review!

2	I don?t want to talk much, please enjoy just the pictures!

2	#1 the parts: #2 building: The two axles, you can see in the middle, are not connected and don?t belong to each other.

2	The axle on the left side is for the steering, on the right side for the engine.

2	The dark-gray ?Technic Gear 16 Tooth with Clutch?

2	allows the connection from the differential gear to the engine, trough the axle for the steering.

2	The V6-engine: The winch: That?s a part you don?t see everyday: a 1x2 Rack.

2	It only reappears in 2 sets from 2001 and 2004.

2	(The Rebel Wrecker has been released in 1994.)

2	The ?Front double wishbone with anti-sway bar?-suspension (yeah, I got it from Technopedia!

2	X-D ) The finished model: #3 random shots: I really like this picture!

2	Authoritative, isn?t it?

3	I also sort out the pieces the same way if I'm rebuilding a model.

3	*y* This set packs a lot of functionality into a fairly small size, but was rather expensive for its size ($70) when it was still available, compared to other sets of that time.

3	You can also rig up the Technic flag sticker that it comes with to the main model.

3	I've done that on mine.

3	You may want to reinforce it with tape if you're going to leave the model on display though, as it will break up over time due to UV exposure like many stickers do.

3	I had to do that with mine after it started to crack, although it still looks pretty good.

1	the only original stickers are the front headlight-patterns on the 2 red 1x2 bricks.

1	The others have been destroyed - must have been the bad decaying sticker quality that breaks when you'll remove it - so I printed them.

3	Thanks for reviewing this classic set.

3	I got it when it first came out and still love it: the suspension, steering and robust look of the model haven't been done that well ever since.

3	This set puzzled me though, back in the days.

3	The rear suspending part containing the differential and some gears was shown different on the box from the instructions.

3	In the instructions it showed that the (grey part of the suspension) in the back had to be made using a 1x2 smooth tile and 4 cornerplates (2x2) in grey.

3	The box however showed a much sturdier solution using a 1x8 tile and a 1x8 plate.

3	It is also visible on the cover of the instructions.

3	The pieces I mean are in this picture: BerndDasBrot, on Mar 9 2008, 07:05 PM, said: Otherwise, great set!

2	Thanks!

2	You've just motivated me to go on a "senseless-preliminary-design-errors-hunt"...!

2	A few things I've discovered: Left Side (Alternate Model): the steering link can only be put in place with a little violence... the handlebar (?)

2	is turned (far more than it's actually possible) although the wheels are straight.

2	Right Side: The 1x8 Tile simonwillems pointed out The half bush right next to it is... *can't_find_the_words* ..."wrong".

2	Could be that the Technic Triangle is missing.

2	The "windscreen"- 1x6 Technic Plates are mounted with 1/2 pins instead of Axle Pins with half bushes.

2	Who can find more...?

1	I taped over it and it's holding up well now, although it's a little frayed along one edge.

1	This is actually the earliest set I've seen that uses this crappy sticker material (which is unfortunately very common today).

1	Even other Technic sets had good stickers for many years after that.

3	This set includes a medium sized DSS (xwingyoda), a bag labeled one, and HUGE bag labeled two, the 1 bag contains a smaller bag, and the two bag includes two smaller bags.

3	5 bags in all.

3	Also pictured are the instructions.

3	I have linked it due to the non-resize.

3	But they glow.

3	A real quick build.

3	BerndDasBrot, on Mar 21 2008, 07:07 AM, said: Hi!

3	This is my forth (old-school) technic set review!

3	Since blakbird pointed out that all my technic reviews are red, I chose a yellow dune blaster for today!

3	This is my second 8829 and I also noticed that the engine turns very hard.

3	The alternate model is really (sorry to all those of you who like it) crappy.

3	I mean- a nice idea, but not with this wheels!

3	:-| Anyway: a really beautiful Technic-set!

3	*reminiscing* (this word exists, does it?)

3	thanks for viewing the pictures, I hope you enjoyed it!

3	Please comment if you want to!

3	A great set review, as always.

3	Nice try making a review of a set that was not red.

3	It almost worked!

3	Maybe next time.

3	*sweet* One thing I noticed is that a bunch of your pictures are missing the beam that goes over the left hand wheel as a fender.

3	Like this picture: What kind of camera do you use?

3	The pictures have very good depth of field, meaning that both the foreground and the background are in good focus.

3	This is usually hard to do without a very small aperture.

3	Yes, "reminiscing" is a word.

3	It means to fondly remember the past.

3	I also noticed that the engine was sticky.

3	Set 8408 has the same problem.

3	It took me forever to figure out what the problem was.

3	If you take the engine out of the model, it turns nice and smooth.

3	Then when you put it back in, it works terrible.

3	It turns out the key is that, in the back, there is an 8 tooth spur gear and a 24 tooth crown gear used as a spur.

3	If you look at Technica, you will see that there are two different crown gears.

3	One of them works well mated with an 8 tooth on parallel axles, and the other one doesn't.

3	The difference is only supposed to be longer teeth, so it really should not matter, but it does.

3	If your set works bad, try switching the crown gear to one of the other variety.

3	Worked for me.

3	Eric

3	Toa_Of_Justice, on Mar 21 2008, 08:10 AM, said: That looks like a very nice set!

3	:-) In your opinion, how does it compare to the current Dune Buggy?

3	-Toa Of Justice IMHO, 8829 is much better than 8296.

3	First, 8829 is a lot bigger.

3	I really like the huge rear balloon tires.

3	They both have rack and pinion steering, and they both have trailing arm rear suspension with a V-2 engine.

3	I think the body on 8829 is a little more well done.

3	For 8296, I think the alternate tractor model is much better.

3	For more comparisons, see Technicopedia.

3	Eric

2	Blakbird, on Mar 22 2008, 09:49 PM, said: One thing I noticed is that a bunch of your pictures are missing the beam that goes over the left hand wheel as a fender.

2	oh no.

2	I forgot to put it back.

2	I wanted to make a photo with this beam alone... 8-| Blakbird said: What kind of camera do you use?

2	The pictures have very good depth of field, meaning that both the foreground and the background are in good focus.

2	This is usually hard to do without a very small aperture.

2	The camera belongs to my dad.

2	it's a panasonic lumix dmc-fz30eg: Blakbird said: One of them works well mated with an 8 tooth on parallel axles, and the other one doesn't.

2	The difference is only supposed to be longer teeth, so it really should not matter, but it does.

2	If your set works bad, try switching the crown gear to one of the other variety.

2	Worked for me.

2	Wow!

2	you're right!

2	Never thought of that!

2	thanks!

2	I made a SCAN (!)

2	of those two gears: You can notice the longer teeth (first pic).

3	Hello All Apologize for digging out a such old post.

3	Recently I got a bag of Lego Technic parts where there have been mixed three sets: 8858, 8829 and 8235 The resurrection of 8858 has been described by me in a separate post.

3	Going back to the Dune Buggy – when I saw it for the first time back in 1994 I did not like it, as I was always big fan of 8840 (which I consider to the day the best looking Buggy) and set 8829 looked to me ugly.

3	So there were those all parts in the bag… then I though why not build it ?

3	And I started to do it.

3	When I finished I was very surprised how the final look of this set is!

3	Really taking my words back.

3	Unfortunately in the bag there were missing some parts and I could not rebuild the back spoiler.

3	So I made some changes to it and make it from spare parts that I have and it came out acceptable.

3	I also added some additional parts such as “fake” steering wheel, “Rally” logo, antennas.

3	I have also reverse mounting of the rear tires – why Lego did them like that I never know – as I think they look better this way.

3	Set: well the review has been already made by owner of this post so I will only add few things into it.

3	Engine – V2 (aired cooled?)

3	is driven by 4 gears -> from the single wheel (no differential as in 8840) using two old school z14 tooth bevel , then by z24 tooth crown and z8 tooth type 1.

3	Actually the (as in most old sets) the pistons are moving very fast (not as in current sets) and smooths – I needed to extra clean all engine parts as there was a lot friction.

3	Suspension – set has “engine bay” working using two old gray shock absorbers 6,5l – the movement is not big but works very nice, better then in 8840 in my opinion.

3	Steering – this is a bit odd as there is no direct connection to HoG as in most old sets, but first the gear rack is moved by z8 then two z14 tooth where reverse movement is taking place.

3	Later connection of two old school z14 tooth bevel goes to HoG Details – this is the most that I like in this set, specially how the use of axle pin connector perpendicular and 1x10 bricks with 3x3 cut corners and plate 1x5 toothed ends 2 studs with center axle hole are making the body shape – is just wonder.

3	Tires – the balloon rear are pretty nice the front is a new version of those that were in 8840.

3	What I do not like: 1.

3	Missing of Technic Figure (8840 had it.)

3	2. no steering wheel in the original set 3. no differential – but having in mind that Lego has introduce 24-12 teeth would be difficult to build the transmission in such small space where the engine is.

3	I will shortly upload new pictures and post them here later on .

3	Over all – I think it is worth buying it as it is very payable !

3	Actually very payable and runs smoothly , the steering, suspension – perfect Thank you and regards

2	Pictures of my restored set 8829 (I was almost 96% complete, and for missing parts I add of my own) The seat is black and not blue (as one was missing in my 8858) the spoiler is different, steering wheel added (not connected to wheels) and some additional items to make it look better) this is how I change the tire orientation The "new" rear spoiler: I still need to "clean" front rims Edited by AOW, 26 November 2015 - 12:32 PM.

3	I can also remember trying to build engine in such way that it works smooth without success.

3	Anyway I think its "studless version" - set 8048 is much better.

3	Finally, after a very frustrating incident with the Internet Explorer 7's 'Back' button, I present to you my very first review.

3	This is a review of set 8158 Speed Racer Vs Snake Oiler, it's also the first review of a Speed Racer set on EuroBricks.

3	Also you should know that I didn't put the stickers on as they can be quite valuable later on down the road, so I'm sorry for the lack of stickers.

3	:-$ So without further ado I present to you my first review.

3	This is V.2 of my review of set 8158, enjoy... Theme: Speed Racer Set:8158 Speed Racer Vs Snake Oiler Price: $19.99US Pieces: 242 Minifigs: 2 First off pics of the Box, Instructions, DSS, Minifigs, and New Parts: There are so many stickers they had to number them!

3	X-O SO's sunglasses are chrome Gold.

3	8-?

3	Close-up of the hemets.

3	New parts include, First System Lego hubcap, new more curvy fenders, curved windshield, and a S-shaped connector piece.

3	Now onto the Build, First Speed Racer's Mach 5: Back part of the car.

3	The cockpit of the car.

3	They connect with the new S-shaped piece.

3	Front part of the car.

3	Front and cockpit also connected using the new S-shaped piece.

3	Side view of the car, so far.

3	Underside of the car, so far.

3	Adding more detail.

3	Ground level front view of the car.

3	Side view with added detail.

3	Underside with newly added axles.

3	Demonstrating how the new hubcaps are put on.

3	Now on to building Snake Oilers Orange-ilicious racer: Back part of the car.

3	The cockpit of the car.

3	They are connected using the S-shaped piece.

3	Front part of the car with seemingly random color choices.

3	*wacko* The front and cockpit are also connected using the new S-shaped piece.

3	Adding Orange-irific fenders.

3	Side view of the car so far.

3	Adding more detail.

3	Smoothing things over.

3	Ground level view with Lime Green "eyes" and white "fangs".

3	Side view with more detail.

3	Rearword view of the car with newly added cuve-acious windshield.

3	No hubcaps!?!

3	:-| Now onto finished views of both cars, First the Mach 5: Side view with sweet hubcaps.

3	Up close and personal with the Mach 5.

3	A rearend shot.

3	"I got hubcaps, I got hubcaps!

3	", Speed racer.

3	Now SO's Snake Racer, yes thats what I'm calling it.

3	:-P :-D Beautiful!

3	Blurry, :-$ rearend pic.

3	"Watchout it bites!

3	", Snake Oiler He's ready to take on SR, Hubcaps or no hubcaps!

3	>:-) Racin'!

3	Now for some comparison shots: Hope you all like V.2 better then V.1, I know I liked it better.

3	X-D Seriously though I even learned a thing or two doin' this last version.

3	;-) Now it's time for my summary: Overall a very well designed and executed set.

3	It's only downfalls are that there are way too many stickers, 32 to be exact, :-| and there are no cool contraptions on the cars to take out the other racer.

3	A great buy for $19.99, I reccomend this set to everybody because of the reasons I staed above and because even I, who is not a big fan of Speed Racer, X-O was drawn to this spectacular little set.

3	Price: 10/10 Pieces: 8/10 Too many stickers.

3	Minifigs: 9/10 Needed some accessories.

3	Playability: 8/10 Needs some cool contraptions on the cars to take out the other racer.

3	Overall: 35/40 General Tarful Edited by imperialshadows, 01 June 2008 - 12:07 PM.

2	Hi!

2	This is my forth pre-old-school review.

2	As promised: a yellow-set !

2	My 8862 arrived today, survived the washing machine coaster and actually was real fun to build!

2	#1: information: This set contains 664 parts (only!

2	I thought I’d be far more!)

2	and was released in 1989 in the TECHNIC theme.

2	Be sure to visit Technopediaif you want to know more!

2	#2: building instructions: Wow these instructions are used!

2	I'm not used to this after all this sets with unread instruction booklets...

2	The pneumatics page: The last step for the alternate model: #3: the parts: Wow!

2	Look at all those technic beams, gears, pins...!

2	(A few parts are missing in this photo!)

2	#3: building: The left worm gear is for the outriggers, the right one for turning the “rear boom” The three 12L Axles: left one: outriggers, middle one: steering, right one: erm… rear-boom-rotation.

2	The two worm gears in the front part: left one: lifting the bucket, right one: dumping the bucket.

2	The turning-mechanism for the “rear-boom” is finished.

2	Once again a toothed 10L axle.

2	The Boat Weight 2x6x2 is hidden underneath the radiator grill.

2	Okay… many hoses and a nice, comfy seat have been added.

2	Now you can recognize the Backhoes real shape.

2	Only with a little violence it’s possible to lift the bonnet (?)

2	through the Pneumatic Pump.

2	Yeah, outriggers.

2	Same technique that the 8854 uses.

2	The finished “boom / jib / scoop thing” (=BJST) :-| X-D The finished loader bucket.

2	And to end the building process: the same picture from the introduction.

2	(OFF-TOPIC: “It is all part of the miracle of nature!

2	- The circle of life!” #4: functionality: This time, I tried something new!

2	I hope you can spot something - if not: Technopedia!

2	Okay, here we go.

2	#5: random shots: I’ve got way too many pictures this time, so I refer to my brickshelf folder.

2	Until it’s moderated you can follow the multilingual links!

2	eins deux three quattro fem zes sédem osiem #6: final thoughts: Definitely worth buying!

2	As a child I thought it looks hideous - but today I’ve found out it’s totally fun to build and freaking functional.

2	Three things I want to mention though: The BJST can only be slewed (a new word!)

2	if the outriggers are deployed.

2	It is also possible that the BJST will reach the ground (danger of grinding or sticking) even if the outriggers are deployed.

2	The two mechanisms for the loader bucket can actually interlock, and the 14 tooth gears might break / disentangle from the axle.

2	thanks for viewing the pictures, I hope you enjoyed it!

2	Please comment if you want to!

2	:-P They came out with the modern turntable the year after this set, which mostly negated the need for these screw axles.

2	I think their only use now is to hold non-Lego objects onto models, like the Technic pen in 8094.

2	I guess you can try to make linear actuators out of them, but they're often too rare and fragile for that.

3	BerndDasBrot, on Mar 23 2008, 02:32 PM, said: Hi!

3	This is my forth pre-old-school review.

3	As promised: a yellow-set !

3	My 8862 arrived today, survived the washing machine coaster and actually was real fun to build!

3	The finished “boom / jib / scoop thing” (=BJST) :-| X-D thanks for viewing the pictures, I hope you enjoyed it!

3	Another great review and a wonderful set of pictures.

3	I like your nomenclature for the BJST.

3	Acronyms always sound nicely scientific; much better than "digger".

3	No one would know you made it up until they found out what it means.

3	I also really like what I will call your "kinetic photos".

3	They convey a sense of motion and show the range of the mechanism without the big file sizes of animations.

3	How long of a shutter speed did you use?

3	The secret to not getting too much friction in the turntable is using extra nuts and jamming them together.

3	You don't want to actually clamp the nuts tight across the turntable.

3	You want to jam two nuts tightly together at each end which prevents them from unwinding, but still leave a little free play (gap).

3	This way it will hold the assembly together but not prevent it from moving.

3	Mine moves quite easily.

3	This same concept is used on the pen plotter or 8094.

3	"Slewed"?

3	I think that's a word.

3	How about "slewn" or "slain" or "slewifacated"?

3	I think "rotated" is best.

3	*sweet* Eric

3	WOW thanks for putting up this thread, that reminded me that I own that one too.

3	*sweet* And I loved it as a kid.

3	It is a combine (farm equipment) which is just as good as 8274.

3	I liked it so much that I bought two copies of this set so I could display both.

3	My favorite alternate model (not counting Universal Sets) is the 8480 submarine.

3	*skull* White is pretty rare.

2	You know: my english skills ;-) I was thinking you could somehow attach a 16-tooth dark gray gear (the one that spins freely around axles) to the nut, which would make the axle move in and out when the gear turned and convert the gear's rotary motion to linear motion in a fairly compact package.

2	Although there are other ways of doing the same thing that don't use such rare parts, and the 2008 Technic sets will come with pre-built linear actuators anyway.

2	Did you had something like this in mind?

2	if the toothed 10L axle rotates the axle nuts want to rotate too but they can't because of that 2x4 Technic Plate.

2	So they'll decide to move along the axle.

2	The 1x6 Bricks on each end make sure that the axle won't move in or out.

2	I also see from your room photos that you have the 8839 Supply Ship which has lots of white.

2	This is a really nice set.

2	8462 is hard to call old school, but at least it uses regular beams.

2	The air tanks are the best part of the set.

2	I wish LEGO had used them more often, especially on the highly pneumatic sets.

2	The tank makes all the difference on 8459.

2	You are right, 8458 is certainly not old school, but it is a great set with wonderful suspension.

2	It is of the same era as the Super Street Sensation with all of the panels for body contouring.

2	8868 is Technic at its best.

2	There is nothing else like it, especially with the compressor.

2	Quote Did you had something like this in mind if the toothed 10L axle rotates the axle nuts want to rotate too but they can't because of that 2x4 Technic Plate.

2	So they'll decide to move along the axle.

2	The 1x6 Bricks on each end make sure that the axle won't move in or out.

2	Thanks for your feedback!

2	While the assembly you have drawn would work as a linear actuator, I would not recommend it.

2	The torsional stiffness and strength of an axle are proportional to the polar moment of inertia, a section property.

2	Most of the stiffness comes from the outside of the cross shaped axle.

2	But in the threaded axle, you lose all the stiffness of the outer area because it is not continuous.

2	This means you only get stiffness and strength from the small core.

2	I think the threaded axle would bend and break very easily if subjected to much torque.

2	Eric

3	Quote 8462 rocks as a blue set.

3	I just got it a few weeks ago.

3	Let's see... 8462 also is one of the last TECHNIC sets I would call Old-school.

3	8479... okay too, but 8458 is IMHO not.

3	Yeah, the Tow Truck was the last set that still used mainly studded beams.

3	They made many changes to Technic the following year, with models becoming predominantly studless and making heavy use of the flexible axles/hoses and decorative panels.

3	The Technic logo and box art style was also changed a lot.

3	I really like the overall construction of that set.

3	The model is fairly lightweight but extremely sturdy.

3	It must be one of the strongest large sets they've released.

3	Quote Did you had something like this in mind?

3	That's basically the idea.

3	As Blakbird said though, it wouldn't be very powerful and would put the axle under some stress.

3	The linear actuators they're bringing out this year do the same thing and should work much better.

2	X-D ) Blakbird said: While the assembly you have drawn would work as a linear actuator, I would not recommend it.

2	The torsional stiffness and strength of an axle are proportional to the polar moment of inertia, a section property.

2	Most of the stiffness comes from the outside of the cross shaped axle.

2	But in the threaded axle, you lose all the stiffness of the outer area because it is not continuous.

2	This means you only get stiffness and strength from the small core.

2	I think the threaded axle would bend and break very easily if subjected to much torque.

2	The toothed 10L axle doesn't look very robust, you're right.

2	On brickshelf I once saw another version using a worm gear and a halfbush being moved along another axle.

3	Some time ago I sort of complained about the fact that there was not much Technic represented in the Eurobricks community (this was the topic, if someone is interested).

3	I am glad to see someone took that complaint serious and started reviewing technic sets on large scale to show us how fascinating the theme really is!

3	This review is once again an excellent one, I really enjoyed reading it.

3	I must buy this set sometime soon because I always liked the three-way pneumatic system it came with and the overall look of the machine.

3	For many years it seemed out of reach, much to expensive and hard to come by as a kid.

3	Now as an adult there are many ways to acquire this wonderful set.

3	This is a review of Speed Racer set 8159 Raxer X Vs Taejo.

3	This is my second review and the first review of this paticular set and the only one on EuroBricks... at the moment X-D So without further ado I present to you my review... (I like that saying so much I decided to use it again in this review, it's originally from my review of 8158, which can be seen here.)

3	Note: Sorry that this review got delayed, but there was a hostile takeover of the computer, X-O don't worry everythings fine now.

3	X-D Set: 8159 Racer X Vs Taejo Theme: Speed Racer Price: $19.99US Pieces: 237 Minifigs: 2 Note 2: I did not take photos of just the new pieces this time because they're the same "new" pieces as in 8158, just in diff.

3	colors.

3	If you want to see a picture of them click here.

3	First off pictures of the Box, Instructions, DSS, and Minifigs: Not quite as many stickers as set 8158, but there still are quite a few.

3	Can you guess which ones which?

3	:-D Yes, Taejo's hair really is Red and Black, for Racer X's head TLG just reused the baddie's head from 7620.

3	|-/ Now onto the build: First Racer X's X Racer :-D (Thats not it's official name..

3	I think.)

3	:-$ Back end of the car.

3	The cockpit, and yeah there are no seats for Racer X's hiny, just a flat 2x2 Dark Bley plate.

3	The cockpit and rearend of the car connect using an S-shaped connector piece.

3	The front part of the car.

3	The fornt and the cockpit are also connected using an S-shaped connector piece.

3	Adding some details including Yellow fenders.

3	The underside of the car, so far.

3	Adding some more detail.

3	Newly added motor vents and smooth details.

3	Adding a front bumper, amongst other things.

3	Side view of the car, so far.

3	"No backseat driving, wait a minute, there's no backseat!"

3	The underside with newly added axles.

3	Demonstrating how hubcap piece is put on the car.

3	Now onto Taejo's GRR (Glorious Red Racer) :-P Front part of the car.

3	Cockpit, regular seats... check.

3	Cocpit and rearend of the car connected using S-shaped connector piece.

3	Adding some detail.

3	The front part of the car.

3	Front and cockpit connected also using the S-shaped connector piece.

3	Adding some fenders to the car.

3	Underside of the car, so far.

3	Adding some smooth details.

3	Taejos is the only car with an actual hood.

3	Side view of the car, so far.

3	Underside of the car with axels.

3	Now some finished shots of both cars: First Racer X's fine Black and Yellow racer Reminds me of an older Ferrari from this angle.

3	Up close and personal.

3	I'm guessing the 3 holes are exhaust outlets.

3	Racer X rollin'.

3	Now it's time for Taejo's Red racer "I could've sworn I ordered some hubcaps!"

3	-guess who... Taejo Racer X admiring Taejo's fine red automobile.

3	Up close with 'Big Red'.

3	Rearend shot of the car.

3	"I challenge you Racer X!"

3	-Taejo Racer X bein' a complete badass and smokin' Taejo.

3	>:-) Now for some comparison shots: (The Silver pocket knife is just to hold up Taejo's car.)

3	Now a shot of the extra pieces: Now if you combine 8158 with 8159, you get this: "Go, Go, Go!"

3	Now it's time for the summary: This set is an excellent buy at $20 dollars, it's well designed and has lot's of details, it also has very unique minifigs.

3	(Which are always good in a set.)

3	It's only downfalls are the lack of acessories for the minifigs and that there are no cool contraptions on the cars, and by "cool" I mean lethal to the other racer(s).

3	Now to the scoring of the set: Price:10/10 Pieces: 8/10 Too many stickers for such a small set.

3	Minifigs: 10/10 Unique and creative.

3	Playability: 9/10 Would have been perfect except for the lack of acessories and cool contraptions on the cars.

3	(But both are easily modified/fixed hence the nine.)

3	Overall: 37/40 A great set!

3	Bonus: Try and count how many times my Silver pocket knife appears and win... the knowledge of knowing how many times the Silver pocket knife appears.

3	:-P :-D This concludes the review, more pictures of either set 8158 or 8159 or both available through request, via PM-ing me.

3	As promised, and with only a single day of delay is my review of the 2008 set: 4994 Creator Fierce Creatures.

3	This small set is the same size and price range as last year's 4939 Cool Cars reviewed by prateek and dillthepill.

3	The box General info You get 193 pieces (vs 206 for Cool Cars) which is quite a lot, but most of them are small.

3	There are a lot of hinges and some good slopes and wings.

3	The building instructions contains three models, but no further ideas for inspiration.

3	Primary model: Spider The first model is a big spider which shares some similarities to the secondary model of 4895 Power in the design.

3	The legs each have 3 joints, where the ones in the middle have "stud joints" to be moved sideways while the rest use hinges for all joints.

3	There are 8 of them and it does get a little tedious with all the repetitive building in this relatively small model.

3	I like the design of the face with a lot of eyes and a big and ugly mouth, but the real gem is the X-pattern on the opisthosoma made using double/inverted slopes.

3	It is poseable and I think it looks more "fierce" when inverted.

3	Secondary model: Snake The face of the snake is nicely detailed with a splitting tongue and a mouth than can move a little.

3	There is a problem with the construction.

3	It uses stacked hinges for some of the joints, which are hard to pull apart without stressing the pieces.

3	Tertiary model: Fly I'm not completely sure what this insect is.

3	I will say it's a fly, although the tail and head are too pointy.

3	This is a neat little thing.

3	Conclusion Primary model: 8 It is a good design, but lacks some sturdiness in the legs.

3	They fall off a little too easily.

3	Secondary models: 6 They are pretty good when you look at the bricks that are available, but they don't wow you in any way and they suffer from the same issues as the primary model regarding sturdiness.

3	Alternate models: 3 It is hard to come up with alternate models with so many small pieces and plates that are only 1 stud wide.

3	The colors might make you want to build a Spyrius space ship.

3	Playability: 8 The models have many movable joints and you can put quite a scare into your minifigs when their town gets attacked by these creatures... unless some EN forces are there to protect them.

3	Price: 6 Creator sets are known for their great price to bricks ratio, but this set doesn't quite measure up to sets like Cool Cars.

3	Pieces: 7 The pieces aren't great by themselves, but who doesn't need a fist full of hinges, slopes and basic plates in standard colors?

3	I don't think this is a must-have set like the big rig was last year.

3	The pieces are great and it has a nice primary model, but the set lacks a bit when it comes to the usual strong Creator qualities like alternate models and price.

3	(Brickshelf gallery) Edited by WhiteFang, 23 May 2009 - 06:30 PM.

3	Enchanted Island 6278 Pictorial Review Original price: $66 Pieces: 412 Figures: 7 This 1994 set marked the beginning of a new era for Lego Pirates - it became a theme more centralised around playability and not so much grand ol' ships.

3	6278 Enchanted Island was the flagship set of the Islanders subtheme, heavily based around Polynesian and Native American concepts (In fact, TLC was successfully sued by a number of tribes for using bastardised Maori names, such as Kahuka).

3	It was released as a Legend set in 2001, but due to poor sales was discontinued again.

3	The largest of the Islander sets, Enchanted Island is a portion of an island with a river running through.

3	The left hand side features some sturdy buildings built into a tree-like structure on a rocky outcrop, whilst the left hand side features a tower built out of "wooden" posts and a large tribal statue.

3	The box cover shows all the details; it does, however, differ from the instructions' finished product in that it has been more aesthetically arranged - bushes e.t.c.

3	have been moved to fill in gaps and to not obscure other things.

3	The sides of the box show nothing particularly special, although in one scene it depicts the Islander Canoe chasing the Pirate boat with the treasure; just one way to play with the set.

3	The back of the box, however, is superb, featuring a large number of alternative models: a toothy statue, a Pirate tree (think Wolfpack) with an Islander base, Kahuka's throne, a fire-breathing statue and a souped-up boat for the pirates.

3	These, and many more, can be easily made because of the large diversity of pieces.

3	The set has a huge number of minifigures for its size, the third highest number in the Pirate range (The SES and the BSB being first and second, respectively) - a whopping 7!

3	5 Islanders, including the all-too-common King Kahuka, the elusive Islander babe and 3 standard warriors - this set alone will never leave you short of enemies!

3	2 pirates, Ironhook in his standard attire with a scurvy dog at his side attack the island, although they are only moderately armed - 2 cutlasses and a pistol between them; a musket would've been nice.

3	The Islanders, on the other hand, have 4 shields, a bow and quiver and 6 spears, not to mention the big pokey thing with horns on top (Weapon?

3	Idol?

3	Staff?).

3	A monkey, parrot and crocodile provide the obvious creature features, with a fair amount of gold to finish off.

3	In the instructions, the goblet does not have the lid, although it does on the box; it's a nice touch anyway - adding a little more diversity to the monotonous treasure stashes.

3	The pirates' boat is a nice 2 sail vessel, with oars for when the wind stops and a treasure map.

3	The sails are similar to those in Lagoon Lockup, but with an extra front sail.

3	It's an awesome little boat, better for raids than a rowing boat, but not too big that it can't sail up rivers.

3	It can comfortably fit 2 men and, at a squeeze, 5.

3	The sails are expensive if you buy them seperately; normally this won't be a problem, but they can cost aroun $5 each.

3	The Islanders' boat is a canoe with a sail and an outrigger to stabilise it.

3	The sail is beautifully done, with 2 spars taughtening it.

3	There is a clip for the rower to leave his weapon when at se and the mast can turn to get as much wind as possible.

3	It's quite a top-heavy boat, but it doesn't look hideous and without the mast/sail it looks great.

3	3 Islanders can fit in it, and more if they sit on the outrigger.

3	The markings on the canoe are stickers, but they look fine and are probably more robust than markings for their job.

3	Furthermore, they're waterproof!

3	*sing* Kahuka's throne can be carried by 2 loyal subjects... ...Or strapped to his pet crocodile!

3	The clips on the side can be used to rest his weaponry, or hold spears for battle.

3	The throne looks nice, although I'm not too sure about the blue against the red - I'd have prefered white as it would clash less... An overview of the island; it is built in 2 halves - left then right and then joined together loosley, so it can be seperated for transporting.

3	Around the back to the left and right, there are large open spaces that are great for battles - this set isn't so much about a large solid build, but creating a "village" - smaller structures linked by bridges.

3	And the back... To the far left is a platform built onto the rock, with access from the river via a ladder.

3	There's the standard Islander drum with the lovely zebra-skin part (Where did they get that?!).

3	I've never understood the white flag - I was under the impression it was used for surrender... Further along the rocky bank, there are some hinged palm leaves that swing upwards to reveal...

3	...The treasure!

3	It's an OK hiding place; not the best place to hide it, right where the pirates sail past, but it feels fabulous; it fits right in.

3	Above it on the rocky bank is the main structure.

3	It looks very disjointed when you build it (bricks all over the place), but once it's done it looks nice and rural, with leaves everywhere and the "balcony" where Kahuka is standing.

3	You get a nice roof made from 2 large palm leaves tilting down.

3	Around the back there's a slight shelter, a table for picnics and a ladder to access the upstairs.

3	I was rather annoyed that it is so open, but the set is designed from just one perspective... To the left is the bridge to the other building... A nice, one piece bridge made of the softer plastic used for muskets and the post-1991 cutlasses.

3	It looks good, but be warned!

3	It tilts when you pull a pin, sending the pirates flying!

3	This contraption is a good idea, but it is very stiff and so doesn't swing, even when burdened by a minifigure - you'll want to modify this bit if you get it.

3	The other building looks like it is made out of posts and beams.

3	They are all red; brown would have been better, but it would have added too many colours to the range, just like the use of black for trees in some forestmen sets.

3	There are 3 clips for spare weapons; only 2 of these will ever be used when all the Islanders are armed, but it gives the pirates scope once they've been disarmed...There's another nice palm tree roof on top.

3	2 ladders give access...there's a total of 4 in this set - worth getting, eh?

3	Although they're 5p on Bricklink, for a KABOB, they're like gold!

3	At the top there's another hidey hole; the palm leaves lift up on hinges to show the treasure or hiding Islander.

3	It can be seen from behind, but this set is designed from one perspective only.

3	Nice cattlehorns too...alongside the slats you can see in the floor - 5 years later and it would've been a solid plate...

3	The big statue is one of the main selling point of this set, alongside the tilting bridge - they're the action features shown in every catalogue at the time, but it is not really special, just original.

3	The statue fits in with the theme perfectly - Kahuka's mask, his shield and this statue all depict the same deity, which is a nice "collectible" idea.

3	The back is rather plain, except the angled 1x1 bricks - a good touch.

3	I'm not sure why there's a black brick in the back of the head, but this is easily remedied; it could even be done with a brick from this same set, just swapping the two over... Aside from the head turning, the back can open to store sacred objects, or, in my opinion, prisoners, hence the gaps for breathing.

3	Either way, it's a lovely piece of architecture and deservedly a flagship element of the set.

3	There's your standard cooking pot floating around, although a 1x1 yellow stud as human flesh (remember, minifigs are yellow, no matter what the licensed themes say!)

3	is a superb finish.

3	This set is a stunning set for both kids and AFOLs who are just getting back into Lego/Pirates - it is a great army builder and, due to its release as a Legend, is extremely cheap on eBay - you should be able to pick one up for £18, or £15 if you're lucky.

3	For that you get a lifetime's supply of Islanders, 4 ladders, some wall panels, 2 baseplates (one raised and both with rivers and printed vegetation around the edge), a ton of weapons, a fair quantity of standard bricks, but most of all, a heap of vegetation: This is an easy to buy set, with normally around 5 on eBay at any time, and is well worth it, for the parts, the play and the nostalgia!

3	It can be easily modified; when used in conjunction with any other outpost, a much larger fortress can be made, especially if more rope bridges are used.

3	if you pick 2 of this fine set off eBay (It'll still be less than the original price!

3	), a huge complex can be constructed, giving you an instantaneous village for around £35.

3	Other Information Lugnet rating: 79/100 Brickset rating: 4.3/5 Bricklink price: New - $100 Used - $54 Edited by Phred, 05 April 2015 - 08:04 PM.
