3	Eldiano, thank you for posting about your desire to have this set.

3	I do own the set, and I do recommend it to others if they somehow find a used one.

3	The bricks are kind of sparse, but the the bricks it does come with are really nice, I love the figs, and the base plates are by far my favorite made by TLG.

3	Captain Braunsfeld, I suggest that you read through the link that covers topic bumping more clearly.

3	I apologize for the confusion Eldiano.

3	I do believe that I have found a way to remove the confusion of posting in old topics soon among the Pirate Staff and to the other members of EB, please stay tuned.

3	Sinner, on 18 July 2010 - 03:16 AM, said: 3.

3	LEGO reviews don't date.

3	Thus if you have something relevant to say then feel free to post in a topic, but if it's more than a few months old please make sure it's good.... and if it's been a few years it better be really good!

3	For example, if you liked the review or set and want to say so you probably shouldn't.

3	If you've got an answer to a question (such as "Does anyone have pictures of the alternate model?)

3	then by all means post!

3	What you shouldn't do is ask questions to the original poster; he/she may not even visit EB any more.

3	Fortunately I got this set on 2000 (not the released version, the original one).

3	And I said "fortunately" because it's a lovely set.

3	How could I rate it, but awesome?

3	A little Islander "army", the islander girl, Ironhook and that cool boat with two sails, the jail-polynesian statue.

3	I must recognize that I have a thing with the Islanders.

3	I know that they are weird, poorly based on the polynesian aborigens, etc.

3	But they are very original, broke with the traditional enemies, and gave to the Pirates theme an exotic and wild look.

1	I realized that building the chess set from the new pirates theme, they are two grey heads that reminded me of the king kahuna throne, which goes to say that I am hoping they bring back new sets, I just wish they were bigger.

1	I would love to build the old ones, but I would side more towards the newer model if they ever released them.

3	What an amazing (old) set!

3	I loved Pirates in my childhood, but that was before the Islander and Spanish stuff... mine were the BSB and soldier fortress with the big baseplate.

3	As I'm now returning to Pirates, I've tracked down most of the 2009 sets and of course bought the new 2015 sets... but knowing I missed this "middle" period of Islanders vs Pirates makes me a bit sad... those Islanders are soooo "Monkey Island" (those of my age likely feel the same) to my eyes!

3	Oh for a "Lemonhead" minfig... ;) I'm curious now how much this set sells for, given it was apparently one of very few Lego actually re-released!

3	I recently bought a MISB BSB that was an early 2000's re-release, and it was very pricey... but then, I suspect the BSB has a LOT more of a nostalgic following these days than this set!

3	Can anyone give me a rough idea what this set goes for in as-new condition these days?

3	Regardless, a fantastic review with some great photos of the whole set and minifigs... even though this is an old thread, I am glad someone else bumped it recently so I can add my thoughts too.

3	:) One thing I've noticed comparing the newest Pirates sets to the 80's ones I had as a kid (and these from the 90's) is the move away from baseplates and big "panel" pieces.

3	I actually like that in a lot of ways; whilst I miss baseplates being included as they are a great starting point for creating new things (and make the sets easier to "play" with), visually, I think Lego-designed model sets look better without them.

1	Welcome to EB.

1	I don't know what you're trying to say here but it isn't a good reason to bump this thread either.

3	Hi!

3	I've promised a lot lately.

3	I'll review 8868, 8880, Space Police II, Blacktron II... And I WILL.

3	It's just the time that is blocking me.

3	And my university.

3	And the fact that I just picked up 8460 in original box for only EUR 36,50...!

3	*sweet* The other reviews will follow - please bear with me.

3	And this set review is also a gift to this nice fellow who gave me the title!

3	That's what I'm talking about: #1 useless information with high numbers: This set contains 841 parts and was released in 1995 in the TECHNIC / Tech Build / Advanced (sub-) theme.

3	The bricklink price guide displays for “Used” a Qty Avg Price of $125.85 and for “New” a Qty Avg Price of $212.82.

3	I got it for $56,98.

3	Still can’t believe it.

3	:'-) This set was rereleased two times (8431 in 2002 and 8438 in 2003).

3	#2 the box: Front: Back: Open: The box is higher than other Technic boxes.

3	Why?

3	I don’t know.

3	8460 doesn’t have any real large parts.

3	Whatever.

3	Inlay: I wonder why TLG doesn’t make inlays anymore… They’re noisy and brake easily but are great for (pre-) sorting.

3	#3 building instructions: I will quote myself from the 8862 review: Quote Wow these instructions are used!

3	I'm not used to this after all this sets with unread instruction booklets... Triple-wow!

3	‘nuff said.

3	This is the “first” page.

3	(Fortunately Peeron offers scans!)

3	The last step for the alternate model and a few nice photos showing how the pneumatic pump will be erm- pumped.

3	Yeah.

3	Random page: I forgot the overall thoughts to the instructions: These are Technic instructions as we’re used to them: part count, easy to understand (okay, the string part at the end was too much for me) and the color distinction is okay too.

3	100 pages long and if I can trust my eyes the pneumatics page can be fold out.

3	(I don’t have this page but I assume it.)

3	#4 the parts: #5 building: An easy and fun build.

3	Okay, this could take some time.

3	My longest building review up to date.

3	The front steering: The rear steering.

3	The axle pin between the rear steering is for the axle which rotates the crane.

3	The two worm screws in the front are for the outriggers (they’re not linked.

3	One for each side.)

3	The small wheel in the back is for the rotation.

3	Adjusting front and rear steering.

3	outriggers are finished.

3	You can notice a 8 tooth gear that will rotate the Technic Turntable.

3	A steering wheel has been added.

3	Could be the same stickers like the alternate 8880 used to have.

3	The steering can be operated with both actinic lights (?)

3	No.

3	We’re far from finished.

3	I’ve got a lot of parts left at this point.

3	Wow.

3	A 4x4 corner plate!

3	Pneumatics and a winch: If you can’t recognize it on the photo: The Technic Beams are the erm- wrong/other side up.

3	The 1x6 Technic Beams on the left side are normal.

3	The axle that will extend the crane: 7 gear racks 1x4 the 1x6 Technic plate will keep the two pneumatic cylinders straight.

3	*sad* 8-| Huh?

3	Did you blink?

3	You missed a special part: The whole rotatable thing will be attached to the Technic turntable using two long Technic pins.

3	The pin on the right side should be in the middle of the three “turntable holes”.

3	On the right side, it’s the first hole.

3	Asymmetric!

3	Why?

3	Because we’ll add a cute cab!

3	#6 functionality: You can find the features in comparison to other Technic cranes here.

3	Technopedia, of course.

3	I made one "sentence" out of it: (please don’t find any mistakes.)

3	:-P “two axle rack and pinion steering, pneumatic luffing and gear driven telescoping via crank for the boom which can slew 360° on turntable driven via gear, crank driven hoist and gear driven outriggers at four corners which snap over center.” #7 random shots: Comparison to 8854: uuuh… once again a depth of field.

3	I tried to make it look authoritarian like 8858 but I failed.

3	Somehow 8460 looks cute.

3	#8 comparison to 8421 Mobile Crane / Crane Truck: I feel that a question concerning this will be asked, so I deal with it right now.

3	First of all: I don’t own 8421 yet.

3	I know.

3	A Technic freak really should own it.

3	Anyway: 8421 has more than twice as much parts as 8460, is motorized, features a V6-engine and a very neat mechanism to extend the crane/boom twice using a braided string with end studs.

3	Try to find out how!

3	Of course 8421 features (far) more than 8460.

3	IMHO 8421 should have been a copy of 8460, a set so successful that it has been rereleased two times, but the designers overshoot the mark.

3	8421 is a (breathtaking) monster.

3	Compared to it, 8460 looks cute - not pale!

3	#9 final thoughts: I got it on eBay in kind of good condition, for about 50 dollars.

3	I know that it has been worth the money in any point of view.

3	*wub* I didn’t use the word “old-school” for now.

3	I’ll change that: 8460 belongs to the favored few of old-school Technic sets!

3	thanks for reading and viewing the pictures, I hope you enjoyed it!

3	Please comment if you want to!

3	Ah, thanks sommuch again for that great review!

3	*y* *sweet* Man, I am so happy they made this set.

3	The new one seems too boring.

3	;-)

3	Somehow I competely missed your review when you first made it, I saw your pics on brickshelf and wondered about the review... You have managed to review my all time favourite technic set!

3	It was the first large Technic set I was given by my parents, when it first came out in 1995.

3	I played for hours with this set, making minifig seats in it (it was so huge there was room for four minifigs to sit next to eachother in front....) I made various applications for it, a bungee-jump system with a large rubber band, and lots of containers to be lifted.

3	The first changes I made included the inverting of the wheels and the disabling of one of the flashlight-steering wheels because they obstructed eachother.

3	By the way, the nob for your winch is yellow instead of black (I know this set by heart, so watch out :-P ).

3	I always liked those nobs.

3	I do own the 8421 and I can tell you: this 8460 is much, much stronger, it can carry more weight because the boom is lighter then the 8421: they are powered by the same two pistons... You know when you made it right: when the crane is in upright position, fully extended and you release the brake from the winch.

3	Does the hook lower without having to pull it?

3	If it does, you succeeded in constructing the set right.

3	The alternate model was great fun too, the pump is cleverly hidden and the crane folds up great between the cab and the loading platform.

3	You could easily mod it with a pneumatic claw on the crane, a motor to turn it and a compressor.

3	The only flaw was the loading platform which had no floor (only some axles).

3	Thanks so much for reviving my memorie concerning this great set!

3	*y*

2	I'm in the same situation as you; I have this set but missed out on the newer 8421.

2	This was a great set for its time but the 8421 definitely looks better to me.

2	I've been trying to find a good deal on it on ebay but it's pretty expensive, considering that it only went out of production last year.

2	Quote Inlay: I wonder why TLG doesn’t make inlays anymore… They’re noisy and brake easily but are great for (pre-) sorting.

2	The box designs in general are crappier these days than they used to be 10 years ago.

2	You don't see the old "featured parts" trays anymore and the boxes don't have the different sections either (these also acted as internal supports for larger boxes, so they were less prone to being crushed).

2	The cardboard material is also quite a bit thinner.

2	I think it's a result of TLC's overall cost-cutting moves since then.

2	Most people toss the boxes and probably don't care, but I keep all of them.

2	There was actually a time when the boxes used to be even stronger.

2	I have an old 8859 set and the outer box is made of a hard, styrofoam material, although they probably stopped using that for environmental reasons.

3	Here's a review of the second largest set in the Dragon Masters subtheme for castle month, Dark Dragon's Den!

3	Figs: The set comes with 3 Dragon knights, two of which have the dragon wings on their helmets(Sad thing is, one of my knights was missing the left wing on the helmet).

3	There are also the definitive dragon, Wiz the wizard (or Majisto if you prefer)two horses, and a hawk( try to find him in each picture!)

3	The set: there's a large spot under the mountain for the dragon to guard the treasure chest.

3	The chest has 2 red and green 1x1 circles in it.

3	Another gate in the back, along with a door for knights.

3	The right side of the mountain has a ladder and a removable rock face.

3	The left side has some stairs leading up to the top.

3	I love this tree design.

3	simple yet effective.

3	A shot of the top- Hey, what are you doing?!?

3	NO!!

3	Throw him in the dungeon!

3	Overall: This set when first released in 1993 was priced at $43USD, although that might just be because of the Juniorised pieces (6 BURPs!).

3	It's a fun set that provides excellent playability.

3	If you can find it at a $20-$30 price point, pick it up.

3	I always liked the BURPs, I don't know why.

3	Maybe because they were dark grey and dark grey pieces seemed a bit hard to come by at the time.

3	I always assumed that the dragon was, sort of, the mascot of the Dragon Masters.

3	The wizard was there to keep him under control so he wouldn't turn on them.

3	I always figured that the wizard was working with the Dragon Master King, and they were fighting against the Royal Knights (the dudes with the lion faces on their torsos), or whatever they were called.

3	I like this set a lot.

3	I think the castle theme declined after the Dragon Masters and Royal Knights themes were discontinued.

3	The new knights never really took the cake.

3	It's funny, but it seems, to me anyways, that when the Lego Minifigs lost their regular smile/smirk faces (whether they were masked by a beard or not), that's when Lego began to decline...a bit.

3	The Dragon Masters had their vicious faces and all, but they still had that smile/smirk underneath their rough exteriors.

3	The new knights look a little...less confident.

3	I own this set and I think its a great for a smaller fortress building.

3	There is a good selection of mini figs, the BURPS do detract somewhat from the set, but they do make it feel as if its in a large cave.

3	The cloth flags that are included are really nice and mine have lasted a long time.

3	The 8291 Dirt Bike comes from a long line of Technic bikes, and I think it's the best ever.

3	It looks great, and it's fun to ride around in the house.

3	I hoped to find a figure the right size for it, but none of mine would fit.

3	Unlike a lot of Technic models, it looks good from all angles.

3	Considering the size of the model it has a complicated way of connecting the engine to the wheel.

3	The rear shocks are just the right stiffness... ...and they have a good amount of travel.

3	I thought these shocks were new.

3	I need to get out more...

3	Functions: Shocks: Two front, one stiffer one in the rear.

3	Drivetrain: 2 piston engine linked to the rear wheel via gears and a chainlink.

3	Steering: Yes it does...

3	Stand: Retractable.

3	For the price, size and subject, what else could be added?

3	10/10 Parts: Considering that it has three shocks and a 40 chainlinks it's a great set for parts.

3	Some hard to use large parts are included, but they are not overused.

3	The usage of the green does limit part usage somewhat though, and I'll be struggling to find a use for those wheels for anything other than a motorbike.

3	8/10 Price: At $39.99 AUD for 248 parts it isn't the best value set.

3	The US price is $25.00 which is somewhat better.

3	It does have some more complicated parts however.

3	7/10 Looks: Lego seems to be moving away from the see-though look for Technic sets and this is a good example of it.

3	I'm not a big fan of fairings but I think they work great in this set as a fuel tank.

3	8/10 Fudge: This set was great for me as I have never had a Technic bike.

3	However for those that want this for just parts or have other bikes it could be a hard sell.

3	The alternate model (a chopper) is a complete rebuild (which I didn't make), and it's great that Lego have been including these most of the time lately.

3	7/10 Overall: Recommended.

3	8/10

3	I think the green motocross bike looks great.

3	I like the use of fairings on this bike.

3	The only thing I really don't like about the Technics bikes in general, is the "clumsy" design of the chaindrive.

3	It sticks way to much out to the side.

3	If they made a really big bike model, it would be more in place with this chain drive.

3	I'm not sure if it wouldn't be possible to design a shaft drive to the rear wheel, ala BMW style.

3	But the green "Kawasaki" look great with the front and rear suspension.

3	I have the Street Bike, 8420, a somewhat larger and more complicated set, and will probably add the motocross bike to my collection soon.

3	It would be great if Lego could make a line of bikes, like they do the Ferrari line.

2	Sinner, on May 18 2008, 05:18 AM, said: You must have been ignoring me!

2	It's been in my signature for weeks!

2	This is when shame kicks in...

3	I wasn't very interested in this set at first.

3	It seemed to be just a nice looking truck with a small motor... but when I found out it had a transmission I changed my mind!

3	Here is the transmission.

3	It allows the single motor to be used for two functions.

3	This system has been around for a while, and Lego seem to be using it more and more.

3	The Transmission Driving Ring alone (the red circle) goes for $5-15 USD on BrickLink, and you also need the Catch and Clutch Gear so I have been buying sets that have them instead.

3	I now have enough parts to make a Supercar gearbox.

3	(I bet a new supercar comes out next year now...) This is the gear that rotates the arm.

3	Note the colour of the 24 tooth gear; it seems to be a new gear trend.

3	A lot of work has been put into this truck looking real.

3	Personally I think they went too far as the truck seems to have been designed for a tilting cab, but it's disabled to prevent breaking the front.

3	Bottom of the transmission.

3	The bottom shaft lifts the arm.

3	Note that there are more dark grey gears.

3	The motor fits in very well also.

3	The bottom of the arm.

3	I was surprised by the usage of a 12 Tooth Bevel to link with the 36 Tooth Double Bevel as I had never seen that done before.

3	As you can see there is no room for any drive train.

3	Standard steering for a recent technic truck.

3	There is a hand-of-god at the cab top that links via two Knob Wheels.

3	It looks good from the back.

3	You can also see the white Clutch that connects the transmission to the motor to avoid burnouts.

3	It goes decently high, and can go a bit higher if you use the crane arm.

3	Compared to last years fire truck.

3	(If I didn't buy the fire truck for half price I would have been annoyed that Lego brought out what is almost a motorised version of the same set.)

3	Functions: Cherry Picker Arm: Motorised rotate and lift that links to a motor via a transmission and anti-burnout clutch.

3	Steering: Rack and pinion controlled via a hand-of-god linked by Knob Wheels Doors: Open and close.

3	Good functionality that works well, but I wish they made the cab lift and I'm a bit sick of the lame fairing door trick.

3	7/10 Parts: Motor, battery box, transmission, clutch, practical wheels, only two fairings, compact turntable... this is a great parts set.

3	10/10 Price: At $99.99 AUD for 726 parts it's OK value when you consider what you are getting.

3	The US price is $60.00 which is better, but still not great.

3	I bought mine for $80 AUD which was good however, and I suspect that the price is designed for easy sale...8/10 Looks: I'd buy this for the looks alone!

3	9/10 Fudge: The functions work well and I llked it more than I thought I would.

3	Oddly mine seemed to be missing a Axle Pin with Friction, but since it includes extra parts for the alternate model I didn't mind using one of my spares.

3	On the subject of the alternate model, it is a dump truck which is made out to be a total re-build, but it isn't.

3	It could have easily been done like Super Street Sensation was, but Lego have probably determined that instructions like that confuse people.

3	8/10 Overall: Recommended.

3	8/10

3	Set: 7627 - Indiana Jones - Temple of the Crystal Skull Pieces: 929 Price: $AUD149.99 Out of all the Indy 4 sets, this one seems to cop the most flak - which may account for the fact that the other 3 were reviewed weeks ago and this one has sat, unloved and alone, waiting for someone to turn their eye upon it (or, y'know, buy it).

3	Luckily I'm a sucker for spooky old temples, filled with devilish traps and hidden treasures, hissing fountains and overgrown foliage, creepy skeletons and crumbling stonework, so here it is: Indiana Jones 7627, Temple of the Crystal Skull.

3	Part 1: The Figs First off, the figs - 6 humans and 4 skellies (or should that be skullies? )

3	Indy, Mutt, Irina, and that sneery Russian guy that's in the 2 smaller sets.

3	Nothing new here.

3	Aha!

3	What have we here - two natives.

3	I wonder if hair is a sign of power in this culture, since one guy is completely bald and the other one has the most extraordinarily luxurious black mullet.

3	Somehow I doubt the movie will answer this question.

3	Back view - as you can see, the scalp tattoos are also popular in this tribe.

3	Fashion conscious!

3	(Note in the background the paws of the fearsome black jungle panther, ie my cat, curious as to see what the tribe was up to.)

3	Also, don't ask me why these guys are carrying axes rather than, say, spears.

3	And what everyone's been waiting for, the skullies - three of 'em and a conquistador skellie - very cute.

3	Note the backs of the crystal head have a plume-sized hole - or maybe that's just where they injected the blue brain-plastic.

3	Spooky!

3	I love these skulls, I wasn't sold from the initial pics but they have a very creepy smile and the head shape is just... weird.

3	With the large eyes, it's kind of Homer Simpson-esque.

3	And here we have the token vehicle in the set - a weird little tank thing with treads.

3	Kind of looks like a cross between the amphibious boat and a mini-tank.

3	I'm sure there's a military expert around here who can tell us exactly what it is supposed to be.

3	The treads are nice, but the rest of it is a bit thrown together.

3	You can tell they wanted to keep the dark green colour scheme but the budget only allowed them 5 parts to do so .

3	All in all, a mixed bag with the figs.

3	4 repeats from the cheaper sets which means we have one new native figure and the crystal skullies.

3	There are heaps of the old-skool skele heads scattered around the sets so those that prefer can replace the skullies with ordinary skellies.

3	Bizarrely, the top of the box which has the line of 1:1 figs pic (you know what I mean) doesn't have names for any of the characters, whereas all the smaller sets do.

3	Part 2: Box, Parts Front of box: Back of box: Two instruction books: Parts.

3	This set has come under criticism for being overpriced - myself included - but the official piece count is 900 plus, which is pretty good considering it also contains the baseplate.

3	6 big bags and 2 of those 12x12 bricks in dark tan.

3	(Note: set does not contain live Black Jungle Panther™) The DSS, helpfully comes pre-scrunched thanks to TLC.

3	Even in a $AUD150 set they can't get that right... sigh.

3	The dark tan baseplate.

3	Say what you like, I'm in love.

3	I know some people don't like these, but they were such a staple of Castle/ Pirates for so many years that I don't consider them a juniorised piece at all.

3	This one, recycled from the 05 Police HQ and 06 Hospital, is much better in design than the King Leo's Castle one as the different heights and asymmetry make it look much more like a natural piece of ground.

3	Perfect for MOCs.

3	And it's dark tan - how could anyone not love such a huge slab of dark tan?

3	Note this love doesn't extend to applying the stonework stickers which are, frankly, crap.

3	Random instructions page: Part 3: Temple of Doom - or just a doomed temple?

3	The complete set, front view.

3	Isometricish view: Back view: Top view: First impressions?

3	It's very dark tan, isn't it?

3	And green.

3	And bright green.

3	And dark green.

3	And dark red.

3	And normal tan.

3	And dark bley.

3	And pearl gold!

3	In fact, it's a bit of a mish-mash of colours.

3	I'm of two minds about this.

3	I kind of prefer the palette to be a bit subtler, but I can see that a playset designed for kids isn't going to sell bucketloads all tastefully done in shades of tan with lashings of dark-green foliage.

3	There's a huge amount of dark red in this set, which is always a welcome colour, but I'm not convinced it quite works with the 2 shades of tan on offer here.

3	On the plus side, there's also a huge amount of dark tan in ordinary 2x2 bricks, tiles, plates and 1x1 and 1x2x3 slopes, which is great for anyone wanting to stock up.

3	Let's take a closer look.

3	I'll do this roughly in order of the build itself: a) The big scary face.

3	This is a simple, fun build and very effective at projecting menace at the temple entrance.

3	It actually detaches very easily from the temple (as pictured on the box art) to allow easier access to the inside.

3	The eyes are flick-fire missiles, with Scary Face's hair conveniently providing ammo refills should you run out.

3	All in all, from me.

3	(b) The Back Spin the skelly head and stone steps appear - we haven't seen this feature in a while.

3	Nice to get these pieces in dark bley.

3	A conquistador hides under the stairs - this is a bit useless as the stairs can't fully extend while he's there .

3	Moving right... a trapdoor - what could possibly be behind it??!!??!!?

3	Answer: not much, really.

3	A little red stair.

3	I really like these 2 stickers though - very intricate.

3	The staircase leads to what I like to think of as the Crystal Skull Transmogrification Chamber.

3	Now, I know nothing about the movie except that it's supposed to be have a kind of 50s B-movie plot rumoured to feature (look away, spoiler-haters)..... aliens.

3	These weird, creepy gold chairs look made from the bones of aliens if you ask me, with their strange vertebrae and silver claws.

3	It wouldn't surprise me if bringing these aliens back to life was part of the plot of the movie... hence the crystal skull?

3	I guess we'll find out May 22.

3	In any case, transforming aliens clearly like a disco whirl as when you pull the handle, the whole of this assembly spins giddily around.

3	A very clever and simple trick - it's basically just a wheel under the platform but the effect is great.

3	Also under here is a bottomless pit (stickered)...

3	I would very much expect a villian to be thrown down it at some point.

3	"So, do you come here often?"

3	"I don't know who designed this club.

3	These chairs are REALLY uncomfortable."

3	NB.

3	I am really, really over those pearl gold 1x2 roof corner slopes which started popping up in the 2006 Castle range, infected Exo-Force and have now spread here.

3	Can we please have these in a different colour?

3	Or a different pearl gold piece?

3	Pretty please?

3	( c) Left tower (looking from the front) A small tower with a trans clear gem.

3	(d) Right tower Waterfall with booby trap.

3	I like the sticker, it's very cartoony, which fits with the set somehow.

3	When you turn the wheel, flick fire missiles spray out and hit whoever is on the stairs.

3	Both towers have a trap where if you move the skull, another one pops out from the dragon mouth.

3	(e) Central turret thing This thing is kind of annoying and doesn't really sit or work well.

3	It's kind of like a laser beam sending messages to space, I guess.

3	As the central dome rises, the two plates peel away.

3	I find it is a little bit tight to work smoothly and the two plates doesn't really sit well together at the top.

3	Maybe I just need to rebuild it.

3	I'm sure this will also be explained in the movie.

3	(f) Final trap - the stair that isn't there The final trap is at the front - as Indy goes down the staircase, you can push the red heads and all the 1x8 bley bricks come tumbling down.

3	Simple and works well.

3	(g) Alternate view Here's how it looks as pictured on the box with the head removed.

3	As you can see, this allows better access to the centre of the temple.

3	As you can see, sadly there is nothing actually interesting there except a staircase to the turret and 2 dark tan slopes which are just stuck there and look a little out of place.

3	I mean, come on, everything else has a splash of dark red and gold!

3	Your Destination: Nowhere!

3	Part 4: In Conclusion So after all those endless pics, what about the set itself?

3	CONS:As a playset, 7627 doesn't quite make sense.

3	Admittedly, the traps that are there are well-designed and unobtrusive.

3	On the other hand, there's a great big whopping entrance at the front - but I wasn't sure if the figs are supposed to sneak in through the backdoor and go up the spiral staircase and past the waterfall (as shown in the box art) or if they were meant to end up in the golden skull room.

3	The middle area doesn't really connect with anything, nor does the giant space turret.

3	It may be that some of these questions are answered in the film, but whereas with 7624, 7625 and 7626 I could at least picture a story myself (eg with River Chase is fairly obvious what's happening - a chase down a river with a croc and a communist staking them out)!, the Temple set is a little all over the place.

3	The design feels a little off to me - not really bad but not really great either.

3	PROS: On the plus side, the natives and crystal skulls themselves are great.

3	At 900+ pieces, this is also a great parts pack for dark tan, dark red, plant pieces, gold oddments etc.

3	I especially love the baseplate in that shade.

3	I like the overall shape of the temple - a big staircase with secret nooks and crannies.

3	The build is reasonably interesting and there are some clever tricks with the traps.

3	But upon reflection I shouldn't have to sell this set - it should be able to sell itself!

3	As I said before, I'm a huge fan of dark, mysterious old temples so for that I have to give it some love.

3	It reminds me of the big old Adventurers sets and the whiff of nostalgia is itself a powerful intoxicant.

3	However, for the price Lego is selling it in Australia/ Europe/ Canada I couldn't recommend it as a must-buy for full price when the smaller sets in this series are themselves so good.

3	Review done - woo!

3	Edited by imperialshadows, 01 June 2008 - 11:59 AM.

3	I know that alex54 had already reviewed this set beforehand, but I wanted to give my 2 cents (it is really more like $1.50) on this set I bought from toys 'r' us on friday (guess what, the price had not been increased by a dollar like all other sets, ).

3	This is my first review of a set ever, don't be too mean.

3	1) Box It captures the potential (I don't know how the scene plays out... for now ) action of the scene nicely and is very pleasing, good job TLC .

3	On the back it shows some of the play features of the set and a net little comic.

3	Indiana Jones seems to be surprisingly calm considering that he is about to be captured under a net and attacked by a snake (the thing he fears most).

3	1a) comic not much to say on this... 1b) screw up At the top of the box, both "Russian Guards" have the same grining face, in the set one has the generic bad guy face from 7620.

3	2) Contents The box opens up to reveal a quartet of bags, an un-crumpled manual (YAY!

3	), and a sticker sheet (BOO!)

3	2a) DSS Yoda said every for of rambling imaginable about this accursed item, I have nothing to say.

3	Meh... 3) Minifigs The only thing that has not really been discussed about the figs that you get in this set is that Marion has a slightly new torso.

3	4) Parts of interest When I opened up the baggies, these were the components that grabbed my attention.

3	A DARK GREEN alligator, a net piece that I Know has appeared in sets before hand ( I needed it for a MOC I am working on), some raft part that is probably very old, a ladder with two pairs of hindges, and a DARK brown version of this part.

3	4) Build (amphibious vehicle) This I one of the more enjoyable builds of the new line.

3	But that is just my opinion.

3	You start of with some thing very simple... By the end of the next page, it starts to bulk up More detail... Beginning to look like a car... 4a) Build (rear attachment) Bulk it up and add Taillights...

3	Done...

3	Slap it on to the main vehicle... 4b) Build (Front attachment) I am running out of things to say...

3	Bulk it up... Add some detail... Add a gun and headlights... And attach to the rest to get the completed vehicle... Add stickers...

3	I honestly think that the amphibious vehicle looks much better with the stickers than without... 5) Build (boat) This build goes by rather quickly and adds to the playability of the final set.

3	Base...

3	Apply clamps... Add more to engine...

3	Build more detail and a gun base...

3	Finished boat... Plus stickers...

3	I love how Lego slips in the product number into their stickers.

3	6) Build (tree fort) This is the weakest part of the whole set.

3	But I find my self liking it more and more for some odd and inexplicable reason.

3	That tan 6x6 will most likely see use in a pirate themed vinigete soon (not mine ).

3	Install net-launcher... You spend the next two pages building this... And putting it on... A tree branch that is an ugly mix of brown, dark brown, and frown... (our commie friend seems to like coffee a lot) Second branch... 3rd... (a wee bit to much on the coffee there, don't you think?)

3	Final step...

3	The only redeeming value of this section is how well the net launcher works, fantastically.

3	The rest is just utter fail.

3	7) Spare parts Very little in terms of what is left over...

3	Finished set... All in all, this set is a fine build and an excellent parts pack for dark green components.

3	I recommend this set strongly, despite its few weaknesses.

3	NIce review!

3	Got this set yesterday and U have to say, that amphibious vehicle rocks!!

3	While i truely fell in love one more time with the older lego city sets, i thought, why not make a review of one of the, in my opinion greatest city sets of all time.

3	Let's not talk too much, here we go!

3	Set Nr.

3	: 6395 Name: Victory Lap Racetrack Number of minifigs: 13 (!!)

3	Number of pieces: unknown Release Year: 1988 Starting with the beautiful old Legoland box: Front: Back, with some cool alternative models: Inside: We continue with the great minifigs, which are not less than 13!

3	I don't think there is any city set with more figures, is there?

3	Civilians: Race Crew & Assistant Personnel: Drivers: All: Here's a overview of the whole set: The "Rescue Rig" (don't exactly know how to call it) with trailer: The score board & Traffic Lights, which would be one of the details i love the most about this set: The next sweet detail, the Camera + Cameraman!

3	Of course we have a doc, if there is some kind of accident: The pit stop boxes, i love the small tool-holder with the axle and wheel behind it: The control room high above the racetrack: Ready to go?!!

3	That was it all in all,all i can say is, if you see this set anywhere on ebay ore somewhere else, get it!

3	Thanks for this review!

3	You have reviewed my most favourite town set of all times, I am so happy to own this one.

3	I actually is a story to go along with it: In the summer of 1998 I went on holiday with my parents to the country of Luxembourg, in the city of Wiltz we encountered a small toystore which still had this set for sale, (9 years after the release!).

3	I did not had the sufficient amount of money to buy the set and had to leave it at the store, I was practically in tears... Four years later we passed through Luxembourg and I remembered the city and the store.

3	We made a detour and stopped by the same store.

3	Every other old set was sold, the only one remaining was this one!

3	I bought it immediately and treasured it ever since.

3	I use the baseplates a lot in my cities, they serve well as roads with parking spaces next to them.

3	This was the first set I owned which had the huge 6x24 plates in them, I remember my surprise when seeing plates of such enourmous lenght...

1	Hello all, I don't believe there has been a review of this set yet, so I wanted to take this opportunity.

1	Up for review today is 8160 Cruncher Block and Racer X as part of Batbrick and iamded reviews: Here is the box, I have to say I love the art on it.

1	It's very colourful and makes the truck look a lot less crap than it does on the box.

1	Plus, you have to love the "Missile launching action" bit right, am I right?

1	Why are you all staring at me?

1	And here is the back.

1	Pretty generic, but shows some nice details and so forth.

1	Oh dear!

1	In turning around the box have I killed myself AND iamded!?

1	Okey dokey, up first is the best part of the entire set: the minifigs!

1	Racer X is wonderful, though coming with a boring Bruce Wayne face.

1	But it is Cruncher Block, his lady Driver Taejo that really shine.

1	Look at those awesome suits!

1	The cool faces!

1	Taejo has a ripped shirt!

1	Now up is the first building part of the set, with me and iamded looking rather slick in X's car.

1	While I'm not a big fan of yellow, it is very nice, and slopes in an underused colour is better than no slopes at all: Front view, the new windshields are fantastic: While a very cool car, it is rather silly of TLC to give us the exact same one we got in the smaller set.

1	I didn't get the smaller set with this car, so I'm still happy, but it is a bad marketing move: Sorry iamded, I know it's your birthday, but......VROOM!

1	Now for the second part of the build and my favourite, the front of the truck: Annoyingly enough, this part opens up to shoot a pointless rubber projectile: To do this, you open the roof (a nice detail btw) and pull back the mechanism, here: Thus blowing the front part open and launching it.....well, not far really The wheels and covers are pretty cool, and the front is nicely designed, the red looks good and the rear vision mirrors are a great touch.

1	And now for the most disappointing part - step three, the trailer: (Note - Clicky joint piece not part of set, just used to hold it up!)

1	That's right, almost the entire thing is open, even the "filled in" side has holes!

1	I'd certainly be cared to be back there, one bumpy hill and back you go!

1	I didn't put the lame computer stickers on, and the control area is pretty lame in general.

1	Not to mention Taejo (who is depicted on the boxart as standing at the desk, would most likely just be sucked out the back at those speeds!

1	There are some pluses too though, like the ridiculously awesome minifig paintings I'll be using for Wayne Manor.

1	Also note the "control" on Cruncher's desk that when turned, turns the gun at the bottom.

1	It's an alright feature: Here is an example, I've shot iamded on his birthday.

1	What?

1	It's a love ray!

1	Haven't you seen the Care Bears?

1	And though I'm not a massive fan of stickers, this is just too cool.

1	The little aquarium is very simple but very clever, using a printed piece between two clear windows to create the illusion of a tank: It looks much better in real life, trust me, and here is a side view to better explain: Now, to connect the two is a good thing, I like the way a simple technic piece assumes the job.

1	Oh, and behold my hand!

1	The completed truck, which, while a mixed bag, still doesn't look too bad (I guess): Now the completed set, which, despite its unbelievable large flaws, still looks cool.

1	(Warning, the kickass iamded and Batbrick figures do not come with this set): More pics here: http://www.brickshel...y.cgi?i=3147324 All in all: Minifigs: 5/5 - Racer X is beautiful, Cruncher Block and the Driver too, and Taejo has a ripped shirt, damn!

1	Design: 2/5 - Pretty poor considering the best part is available in a cheaper set, and only the front part of the truck looks cool, but still not truly awful.

1	Build: 3/5 - Despite having a bad trailer, it was a fun build and sometimes you need something that doesn't take ages to make.

1	Price: 2/5 - Overpriced easily, but Rogue Shadow is worse!

1	Fun: 3/5 - The mere concept of such an open truck kept me playing with this baby for hours!

1	Total: 15/25, not as bad as it would seem.

1	Overall I'm really glad I bought it as the minifigs are fantastic and the paintings and fish tank are cool.

1	It's fun, stupid and downright ridiculous, but while not a great set by any means, certainly isn't as bad in the brick as it looks in photos.

1	Until next time, Batbrick Away!

1	Edited by Batbrick, 13 June 2008 - 12:20 PM.

1	Awesome review Batbrick!

1	I don't see any appeal at all really in this set, but that's okay, as I want to stick to Castle anyway.

1	The car is the best part IMO, which you can get in a different set with another cool car and for a cheaper price.

1	But the main downfall to this set is the fact that the truck's trailer is half blown up and the survivors are magically staying inside and not being sucked right out of there, as you have mentioned.

1	I would have thought TLC would at least included some sort of cover that you could take on and off easily (kind of like the modular buildings).

1	Having said all that though, the front of the truck does look incredibly cool, and those minifigs are sweet.

1	Too bad they all have flesh tone printed on them.

1	So, while this may not be my set of choice, I can see the appeal... well, really I can't, but it's just my opinion!

1	I'm sure there are plenty others who would love to scoop this set up.

2	WARNING!

2	This reply may contain several minor movie spoilers.

2	If you haven't yet seen the movie and want it to be a complete surprise, do not read.

2	Batbrick, on May 10 2008, 06:05 AM, said: But it is Cruncher Block, his lady Driver Taejo that really shine.

2	Look at those awesome suits!

2	The cool faces!

2	Taejo has a ripped shirt!

2	I was originally skepitcal about the driver figure—I like the head, but I was trying to figure out why they put in a female minifig with no hairpiece.

2	After having seen the movie, I now understand why; Cruncher's driver is a fairly manly looking woman, and most of the LEGO hairpeices would make the minifig look too girly for the character.

2	:) Now that I know why Taejo's shirt is ripped up I don't mind the bits of fleshie color that are printed on it, but I do wish they would make some of the new torsos a little more head-colour agnostic...there's no real reason why Cruncher and his driver couldn't have had ties that came all the way up to their necks instead of having those little wedges of flesh showing through loose collars.

2	Yeah, they are low-level mafioso type scum, but they aren't complete slobs.

2	Batbrick, on May 10 2008, 06:05 AM, said: Front view, the new windshields are fantastic: They are indeed very nice, it's the main reason I started looking at the Speed Racer sets in the first place.

2	Batbrick, on May 10 2008, 06:05 AM, said: While a very cool car, it is rather silly of TLC to give us the exact same one we got in the smaller set.

2	I didn't get the smaller set with this car, so I'm still happy, but it is a bad marketing move: I think the error they made was in the smaller set though.

2	In the movie, the only time we see Cruncher's semi is when he's being chased by Racer X. Racer X and Taejo do end up on the same team for a cross country rally race (along with Speed of course), so I guess that's where they were going by putting those two together in the smaller set, but it would have been much more interesting for them to have made up a set with Taejo and one of the cars from the very goofy, comic book-gimmicky teams they are racing against.

2	Especially since one of the teams (that is chasing Taejo specifically) is a bunch of Army-wannabee loonies—I'm sure more people would have loved some sort of dark/sand green racer with one of the IJ Soviets at the wheel than another Racer X.

2	To summarize: Two Racer X's is bad, but it is the smaller set that should have been changed (imho).

2	Batbrick, on May 10 2008, 06:05 AM, said: Annoyingly enough, this part opens up to shoot a pointless rubber projectile: Thus blowing the front part open and launching it.....well, not far really As much as I normally don't like the stupid techic launcher thing, and would rather not see it in a set ever again (although one of these days I will make a giant multi-launcer rig out of them just for fun), at least there is a reason for it to be in this set, as Cruncher's semi has a missile launcher in the front end of it in the movie.

2	I think you're supposed to lift the panel that hides the missile before launching it, similar to the way that panels slide out of the way on the semi cab to allow for firing in the movie.

2	Batbrick, on May 10 2008, 06:05 AM, said: And now for the most disappointing part - step three, the trailer: That's right, almost the entire thing is open, even the "filled in" side has holes!

2	I'd certainly be cared to be back there, one bumpy hill and back you go I'm gonna chock this up to the standard LEGO philosophy of "playset" rather than "model" design for a lot of things.

2	The semi rig and Raver X's car are the models, the trailer is the playset.

2	Seeing as how the trailer is Cruncher's mobile office (rather finely appointed with lots of paintings and his pirahna "babies" in their tank behind his desk), and the intent seems more or less to have a playest bit in order for kids to re-enact the scene from the movie, I'm not going to give them too much grief over this.

2	They tried to capture the basic bits of the movie set (which we see mostly from the inside during the movie) and translate it into a playset type environment.

2	That being said, I do wish the back walls were more solid, as I see no reason for there to be gaps in the back wall when the front wall (or the "fourth wall" as the case may be here) is already conspicously absent.

2	Batbrick, on May 10 2008, 06:05 AM, said: There are some pluses too though, like the ridiculously awesome minifig paintings I'll be using for Wayne Manor.

2	Also note the "control" on Cruncher's desk that when turned, turns the gun at the bottom.

2	It's an alright feature: Could have been a little better, but it's such a minor bit of this scene in the movie that I can see why they didn't spend too much time and effort on it.

2	It would have been nice to have more paintings though, had the back wall been more complete (and I like your idea of how to use them :) ).

2	Batbrick, on May 10 2008, 06:05 AM, said: And though I'm not a massive fan of stickers, this is just too cool.

2	The little aquarium is very simple but very clever, using a printed piece between two clear windows to create the illusion of a tank: Definately a feature which is not showcased nearly well enough on the box art.

2	Since it is one of the major features of this set in the movie, it's nice to see it translate rather well into brick.

2	Batbrick, on May 10 2008, 06:05 AM, said: Design: 2/5 - Pretty poor considering the best part is available in a cheaper set, and only the front part of the truck looks cool, but still not truly awful.

2	That may be a bit harsh (but not much) given what I've said further up this post, but it probably only deserves a 3 at best, so I'm not realy going to quibble the point.

2	On that note: if I remember correctly from my visit to my local TRU yesterday in search of the new IJ sets (since local Targets seem determined not to get them in stock yet), they had this set on sale for around $35 along with an offer for a coupon good for $7.50 towards the purchase of a ticket to the movie with any Speed Racer toy purchase over $25.

2	I may be wrong on the sale price, but I know the ticket offer was there.

2	So, if you haven't seen the movie yet, and are interested in this set, TRU may be the place to go right now to get both at a slightly cheaper price.

3	General Grievous Reviewed by Dunamis Set 10186 1,085 Pieces $89.95 from LEGO Shop @ Home Build time 3.5 hours It is the start of summer here in California and along with the weekly deluge of new action films we start to see some of the next wave of Star Wars LEGO sets.

3	The latest offering from our favorite building toy company is none other than the infamous General Grievous!

3	No doubt you all know the story of Grievous; two parts Technic and one part human and his hatred of the Jedi.

3	Follow along as we get a close-up view of the mighty General.

3	No doubt the observant will wonder why I purchased this set from Shop @ Home instead of my trusty LEGO store in Glendale.

3	Well, it’s really as simple as two things: I’ve been traveling a lot and didn’t have time to drive to the store to get it AND gas is now $4/gallon and I would likely spend more in gas than the $9 shipping cost to get it to me.

3	So there you have it.

3	The Box: A gigantic box (much larger than expected) held the mighty General.

3	We’re back to the perforated tabs on the side and two stickers on the front that let the box lift open: Inside, we have 17 bags, two manuals and three stickers on a relatively small sticker sheet.

3	The Manuals: The manuals are not terribly thick in fact the second manual is noticeably thinner than the first.

3	They come in at 75 and 31pages.

3	Interesting to note on the back we see the next (and more interesting) wave of sets later this summer.

3	Nothing new to report on the manuals as they provide the LEGO standard of high quality and features we expect.

3	- Piece callouts - Models divided into sections - Large images - Page numbers Since there were links posted to the .pdf files of the instructions online, I’m sure you can all get an idea of the manual and the parts inventory.

3	However, for those of you without access to the Internet here are photos of the parts inventory pages: Random manual image: Features page: The Pieces: The short answer is you get lots and lots of little pieces in white, gray and black plus some big pieces in white, gray and black.

3	Mixed in the set is a fair amount of oddball pieces like minifig tools, Jedi hood and trans yellow dome.

3	Fear not, despite the eclectic collection of parts, it all comes together in the end (not unlike a typical day at work for me…) It is probably worth noting again that there is a heavy amount of Technic parts and pieces here.

3	The Build: The build starts off with a rather in-depth build of the stand in which General Grievous stands on.

3	Once you think you are done, you keep adding on to this (rather solid) base.

3	I bet there are 250 pieces just in the base alone!

3	It is quite nice when you get done with it though and really adds to the display.

3	I’m glad LEGO didn’t skimp on the base as it completes the model.

3	Once you get through all that, the rest of the build is a real thumb-bruiser.

3	Anyone who has built a decent size Technic set knows the feeling of your thumbs being sore when you are done.

3	You get the same effect here.

3	It is actually a fun build and I really liked seeing how the designers used all the various pieces to recreate a fairly accurate model of Grievous.

3	The model is built from the ground up as seen in a few of the progress shots: Here is what is left over: The Design: The design is quite good and is very accurate.

3	Some might be disappointed that since this is a Technic set we don’t have more articulation in the shoulders and have the ability to separate two arms into four as seen in the movie.

3	However, it would seem the real intent is for display and not functionality.

3	Here is a shot of the torso and the detail involved: Here are Grievous’ organs: Careful observers will note that my model is lacking two “arrow” stickers from the two white chest pieces.

3	I failed to see these on the sticker sheet and only grabbed the large Grievous sticker.

3	So, note that there are actually THREE stickers and not ONE.

3	Chest protector and respirator: Head and arms: I was a little disappointed that we got two yellow blades and no green blades on the lightsabers.

3	Note how all the lightsabers have different hilts which is a nice touch: Here are some shots of the completed model with a few other sets shown for scale.

3	He is actually pretty tall: You have the option to remove the top two arms and put in shoulder plates if you so desire: Detail on the back: Overall Thoughts: I’ve been saying for a few years that we should have a Technic Grievous set and we finally got one.

3	Designed more as a model and not a fully functional swooshable figure, Grievous is a tad flimsy.

3	You won’t want him to veer too far off his massive and sturdy base.

3	It would have been nice to have is cape with him (like the Technic Vader set).

3	I do like the size of the model and it is impressive to look at.

3	LEGO Star Wars System fans will likely want to think twice before purchasing but Technic and UCS fans should be satisfied.

3	Final Rating: 75% Build 8/10 (Very Good – Fun, relatively quick build.

3	Technic fans will be more pleased than others.)

3	Design 8/10 (Very Good – Some nice SNOT and Technic techniques.

3	A bit flimsy but the base is kind of cool.)

3	Parts 7/10 (A mixed bag of stuff.

3	Probably can’t get too many diverse builds from this except for other robot type models.)

3	Price 7/10 (Just OK – A bit stiff at $90 USD for a nice display model with limited functionality.)

3	As always, let’s hear your thoughts and feedback.

3	Hi y'all!

3	Guess what happened today?

3	When walked into my Toys 'R' Us in Fullerton, CA, just to buy a simple Tiny Turbo racer, what do I see?

3	All the Agents sets sitting on the shelf, ready for the taking!

3	I didn't have too much money with me, so I just got 2 of 8631 Mission 1: Jetpack Pursuit!

3	It's a really cool little set, so I thought I'd review this puppy for you!

3	I shall proceed in the order of the instructions.

3	So, let's get started!

3	The Minifigs Let's begin with the minifigs, Saw Fist and Agent Chase!

3	They are really cool, some of the coolest minifigs I have seen in a while!

3	I took off Saw Fist's wig & chainsaw so you can see his head and cybernetic arm better!

3	Here is a back view of Saw Fist, and - SURPRISE!

3	Agent Chase has a double sided head!

3	One side with his cool "mission face" with sunglasses and headset, and one with his casual Bruce Wayne type face (note, though, that it is not really the Bruce Wayne face).

3	His wig, btw, is Mutt's hairpiece in black!

3	Very neat!

3	Poor Saw Fist seems to be forced to always drag his chainsaw around for it is way too long to just hang down from his shoulder like a normal arm.

3	The Snowmobile Next up, we have the snowmobile, a sleek little vehicle with only minor design flaws!

3	The container with the jewel is attached to the vehicle by a single stud, so it doesn't fall off, but is easy to pick up!

3	In the pic below you can see the only two tiny design flaws: Thanks to the exhaust pipes, the laser cannon (or whatever it's supposed to be) can't be lowered any further than this.

3	Also, the corners of that slope-ish piece that the handle bar rests on are sticking out a little at the sides.

3	Other than that, it's pretty well done!

3	The Jetpack Finally, there is the Jetpack!

3	IMO, a name like Autogyro-pack or something would make more sense, but whatever.

3	Although a little bulky, the Jetpack is very well designed!

3	The rotor can be tilted back, and at the lower back of the Jetpack, there is hook with which you can grab the container with the jewel from the snowmobile.

3	What I like best about the Jetpack is that although it is attached to the minifig in kinda the same way as that of the Riddler, this one doesn't rotate around.

3	So, the Agent is being held in place steadily!

3	"See ya later, chainsaw-cyborg-dude!"

3	Stickers This set comes with a surprisingly large sticker sheet.

3	The reason is that half of it are extra stickers!

3	There are two large Agents logos and one Inferno logo - perfect for Agents MOCs!

3	There are also a star and a small, round sticker portraying the number of the mission.

3	The star seems to be part of some kind of game where you collect the stars from all sets on an Agents ID that you get from the Mission 5 set.

3	I don't know, though, if you get any gain from this except for becoming a full-status Lego Agent!

3	Below, you can find the list of parts from this set!

3	Click here for a better quality pic!

3	That's pretty much it!

3	I hope you liked this review and will run straight to your next toy store to get one or more of this set!

3	This was my very first set review!

3	So any questions, comments, or requests?

3	Any more pics you want me to take?

3	Would you like me to exchange the chainsaw with something else, or do you want me to try the Agent's new hairpiece out on another fig?

3	If so, just tell me!

3	See ya!

3	Edited by Oky Wan Kenobi, 25 June 2009 - 08:21 PM.

3	Judging by this set, the line is going to be promising.

3	I really like the figs and I'm glad to see that robot arm is actually a new arm mold.

3	Awesome!!

3	Can a minifig hand fit in the end or just the chainsaw attachment?

3	Could it fit an Exo-Force robot claw?

3	There's a lot of detail in the torsos and I like that the Agent's suit is like a moto-cross uniform.

3	I love that the snowmobile has a working tread.

3	Copmike, Ras and I tried to build a snowmobile with working treads, but we ended up using chainsaw blades in the end.

3	Great work Oky!

3	Coming in at around $50 US, Turbo Car Chase is one of the bigger of the new Agents sets.

3	A big box with a helicopter, car, and gate in it.

3	Seems like a winner, but how good is it really, and is it worth the cash?

3	Let's start with the Minifigs.

3	This set comes with a standard Inferno Henchman, Spy Clops, and Agent Chase.

3	The Henchman is you basic LEGO criminal type with a gun and a jumpsuit, nothing real groundbreaking here.

3	Spy Clops, on the other hand, is very cool for, technically, half of a Minifig.

3	His head has a neat electronic goggle print and the rest of him is a torso mounted onto a set of six legs made from Exo-Force robot arms.

3	The whole thing is really well done and neat as hell.

3	Agent Chase (Turbo Car Chase! )

3	seems to have a standard agent body and a double-printed face with one side a sunglasses and headset print.

3	The other face is a determined Agent look.

3	The set also includes a laptop with Doctor Inferno wallpaper.

3	The laptop is a new piece and works like the LEGO books that are in a lot of Harry Potter sets.

3	Molding on the keyboard is really well done and the thing can be held by a Minifig along either corner, but not in the middle and not while closed.

3	The gate in the set is nothing revolutionary by itself, and I sort of get the feeling that it was included to drive up the piece count and the set price point.

3	That being said, there are some things to like here.

3	For instance, the gate has four wheels of barbed wire attached to it.

3	The barbed wire is new and makes me want to start building some World War I trench MOCs.

3	The rest of the gate is fairly big and it has a handy ramp attached so that vehicles can roll through it easily.

3	The main feature of the gate is a sound brick.

3	It's much better then LEGO sound and light units of the past, when the gate is opened it depresses a button and an alert klaxon blares that sounds every bit like a prison-beak in progress.

3	The triggering action works surprisingly well and it's pretty much for this feature alone that I'm not going to immediately break the gate back down and add it to my parts bin.

3	The designers did make an effort to create more then just a fence though.

3	A nice control panel connected to a big spotlight crowns the piece, and a pair of cameras watch the opening.

3	It's really hard to mess up a LEGO helicopter, and this set is no exception.

3	The Inferno Chopper is a nicely proportioned and well built machine.

3	It looks properly menacing and has the uniform orange and black of other Inferno property.

3	It's armed with a set of four Technic pegs cleverly used as guns on outriding mounts, as well as a pair of the newer-style flick-fire missiles.

3	I personally don't care for flick-firing missiles, but these look decent enough and seem to stay put so I really can't complain about them.

3	Along the fuselage are a pair of intake pieces that I've never seen before and I'm guessing are new.

3	They're pretty well designed and will come in handy for MOCing down the road.

3	The action feature of the aircraft is the wench system.

3	This is very different then other LEGO wenches in that you build the entire mechanism and housing.

3	You can then use it to raise Spy Clops up and down from the bottom of the chopper using the rotor.

3	Now, this also keeps you from sitting there and just giving the rotor repeated spins to simulate flight.

3	I'm not too thrilled with that, but there are a hundred other LEGO helicopters out there with fully rotating rotors, so I guess I can let it by just this once.

3	As you'd suspect, the bottom of the cockpit is completely open, which makes this a vehicle pretty much solely for Spy Clops (Sorry Henchman).

3	But there is plenty of room beneath the body to attach a plate with some seats on it to accommodate another pilot without drastically altering the design, or even removing existing pieces.

3	The Turbo Car is a slick little honey of a LEGO car, and the silver pieces that make up the body work contribute a lot to that fact.

3	The front license plate appears to be an Exo-Fore code brick.

3	But it also hides the activation lever for the passenger ejector seat.

3	The seat works about as well as the Spruce Goose, which is to say not well at all, but here it's the thought that counts.

3	The interior of the car is really well done.

3	There's even a radar screen for keeping track of pesky helicopters.

3	But the Bond-like features don't end there.

3	A lever in the compartment raises pair of guns in the hood and a knob on the rear deploys a quad rocket system with more flick-fire missiles.

3	This is a car that won't be stopped easily!

3	The rear has two cones sticking out.

3	I'd like to think they're smoke nozzles or oil-slick sprayers.

3	All-in-all, this is a really good set.

3	The car is pure LEGO vehicle love and looks fantastic.

3	The silver pieces are very nice and it's a shame LEGO doesn't use metallic colors in System sets more often.

3	There are, however, a LOT of sticker for this set and I know how much that bugs a lot of people.

3	I personally like how much detail the stickers add to these sets and don't mind them so much.

3	The set also comes with an Agents ID card for Chase which you can put little star stickers on from other sets as you get them.

3	It's printed on a real nice piece of sturdy plastiboard and would be cooler if you could put your own picture and name on it instead of pretending to be Chase.

3	Sold by themselves, the car and chopper would be must-haves.

3	All tossed together with the gate sort of makes the set a little less then the sum of it's parts.

3	And with 498 parts (most of them small) that's not so hot.

3	It's only slightly over-priced in my opinion, but if you do shell out the money you won't regret it.

3	I'm very comfortable recommending this set to anyone.

3	Close to perfect, but the price and some minor flaws bring it back just a little.

3	I'd say 4.33, but out of 5 is close enough!

3	Looks cool, one of the best in this line.

3	Cant wait for review!

3	Chrome..... Can't wait for the review, Deino!

3	can't wait for the review the car is ly!!

3	!

2	ES.JPG 47.94K 110 downloads The ejector seat A long Technic axle runs the length of the front of the car.

2	It comes in to the seat area here and nests into the gray joint which is attached to the small gray Technic beam.

2	The beam is attached to the ejector seat (bottom white 3x2 plate) with a Technic pin.

2	The seat, in turn, is attached to the side of the car with a Technic pin.

2	The result is, when the axle is pushed forward, the gray joint and beam tilt the seat and "eject" a Minifig.

2	After about 20 shots the Minifig only went outside of the car 3 times...the rest of the time he just bounced around the inside of the car.

2	So they get an A for effort, but an F for execution

3	Hello all Eurobricks members, I will present to you a very short review on the recent Castle Battlepacks.

3	This time, I will be reviewing Skeleton Battlepack, and I hope everyone of you do enjoy viewing it.

3	This was a request that put up by hollisbrick in the Castle thread.

3	Initally, I thought it was a very simple set to do a review.

3	However, for the love of Castle, I decided to whip this up for every Castle fan out there.

3	This is an image of how the Skeleton Battlepacks look like.

3	I have bought 12 last packs of these in total so far but none of the Crown battlepacks yet.

3	There were snapped much faster, that I imagined.

3	Do pardon me for the poor lightning.

3	Today is a bad weather, it's hard to get natural light.

3	The Skeleton Gang For a single battlepack like this, with an attractive reasonable price.

3	You obtained a series of 5 skeleton mini-figs with tons and tons of useful castle accessories.

3	To me, it's a very very great buy, and it's a MUST to stock up for my army building!

3	Some add-ons!

3	However, I was not very satisfied with my Skeleton armies standards.

3	Therefore, I decided to make some slight modifications with some additional castle accessories that is stocked in my Castle warehouse.

3	After the makeover, Ok, this is what I called a real skeleton army.

3	This is mainly my opnion and it have to be aligned with my standards.

3	I felt this improved battlepack gives a punch to the exisitng battlepack.

3	The two soliders on the right, is able to align with the rest of my Castle Chess sets armies.

3	While the one on the left, it gives me a great archer back up with the quiver and helmet attached to him.

3	The ones, on the center especially the armored guard which equipped with the black nose cone helmet is my fave.

3	It is able to illustrate the "Elite" among the rest of the guards with its armor and helmet which was featured in my Castle Deep Forest Expansion MOC..

3	Promotion On!

3	In addition, the one which was hastly done with a modify mace, it looks rather simple.

3	In time to come, I will change it and gives a better equipment and look.

3	These are the remains.

3	I can use the axe for my dwarf in my dwarf mine defender.

3	In that set, there is no weapon for my dwarf and I have to get it from other sets.

3	The rest of the accessories, makes a very good stock up for future upgrading!

3	Overall: 9/10 This is not a playset.

3	It is mainly bought for its abilty to mass recurit any armies, and is a main love for all Castle Army builders such as me!

3	This set mainly have no major faults, and I love it so much.

3	Although, I have done some slight modifciations, but this set is a must for me to buy more and more!

3	Meanwhile, I will need to wait for the next shipment!

3	Hope everyone have enjoying viewing this simple review of mine!

2	Too expensive to be coming with only a few figures.

2	20$ earns you the same amount of figs, plus a catapult, barricade, two horses and a jousting divider.

2	Are you refering to these following sets?

2	Both these sets adds up to $18.00 (CAD) And the skeleton pack have the same price of $18.00 (CAD) *prices quoted from S@H I understand that 7009 and 7090 offers more pieces, horses and same amount of mini-figs compared to a typical battlepack.

2	IMO, I feel that all 3 sets are all army building sets.

2	7009 offer small catapult, 3 mini-figs, a skeleton white horse.

2	7090 offer a joust divider, weapon rack (good accessories), 2 mini-figs, a horse with barding and a skeleton black horse.

2	These sets have different purpose.

2	For me, buying multiples of 7009 is to build its catapult, white skeleton calvaries.

2	While 7090 is to build on Crown calvaries and Black skeleton calvaries.

2	However, Battlepacks have a different agenda.

2	It offered some castle accessories that is not available commonly.

2	For a Castle army builder like myself, castle accessories are always in demand.

2	The black robe, silver armor, silver short-axe are not very common castle accessories.

2	It can be used as a good stock up too.

2	I am not saying this battlepack is an one way solution to solve everything.

2	That's why, different sets are released to target on different purposes.

2	WhiteFang, although I realize that the battle packs are great specifically for building armies, and castle accessories (which is why its such a shame that I won't be able to buy these things ), while sdpirate's sets are more for a catapult, Calvary whatever.

2	The fact to the matter is with the battle pack you get: 5 minifigs with lots of accessories.

2	While with the sets that sdpirate showed us you get: 5 minifigs with an okay amount of accessories 3 horses (including two skeleton ones) A ballista A weapons rack, and a jousting barricade.

2	You cannot say that the battle pack contains the same amount of stuff that the other two sets have and therefore should be priced the same.

2	It just seems that Lego is ripping off Canadian army builders, to me if the battle pack contained a small catapult, or wall so that it contained about the same amount of stuff that the other sets had it would be fair.

2	It seems stupid that you will only get minifigs from one set, while you can get about the same amount of minifigs plus a bunch of other stuff from two other equally priced sets.

2	That’s why to me these battle packs are a rip off, because of what they contain, IMHO the Battle Packs seem to be only worth about 10 dollars.

2	For me, I will use these battlepack for army building purpose.

2	I always feel that every kingdom needs a considerable amount of soldiers to defend their kingdom.

2	Therefore, most of the time, the amount of soldiers will dictate how strong that kingdom is in my collection.

2	In the future, I hope to build large castle scenes, combined all playsets, armies everything together and developed a kingdom scene.

2	Of course, that is just a dream for now.

2	I am still currently not able to afford much space and time to do such big scale project at the moment.

2	Meanwhile, for this great castle theme, I am storing them at the moment and take it out when the time is ripe.

2	One day soon, I hope I can post an image or two of my armies.

2	Edited by WhiteFang, 28 May 2008 - 08:50 AM.

1	I don't think these new skeletons do it for me, but thanks for a good review

3	Hi gang!

3	As you all know, Indiana Jones IV has just debuted, and TLG has released a set depicting the Incan temple (7627) from the film's climax.

3	But Lego beat Harrison Ford, George Lucas, Steven Spielberg and company to the punch by nine whole years with Johnny Thunder's adventures in the Amazon Ancient Ruins.

3	The Vitals: Year of release: 1999 Parts Count: 453 MSRP: $80.00 The set included eight figures: (from left) Two skeletons, Dr.

3	Lightning, Gail Storm, Gabarros, Achu, Johnny Thunder, and Señor Palomar.

3	On the far right is my new sigfig, el Conde Voltio Villar.

3	Construction begins with Dr.

3	Lightning and his jeep.

3	It's a sturdy Adventurers-style vehicle, with fatter tires at the rear for better traction.

3	Next is Gabarros and his unusual boat.

3	The hull is from Belleville/Paradisa sets, where it is usually pink or white.

3	TLG ought to have put it in the Pirate theme, as it is a nice, intermediate size.

3	In this set, it is a small steamship.

3	The temple is built on modular 8x8 green bricks which fit into square holes in the baseplate.

3	This is the "treasure room."

3	This square has a nasty double-spear trap.

3	Careful...

3	This is the top section of the temple, crowned by Achu the (mummified?)

3	Incan.

3	More modular sections (these are from the front of the temple site, across the river from the main building).

3	El Conde: "You are too beautiful a woman to be wandering alone in the jungle, Miss Storm.

3	Please, allow me to accompany you."

3	Gail Storm: "I'm with Johnny, and I have a cutlass."

3	El Conde: "I'll be on my way."

3	Here's the finished temple, with all parts in place.

3	Now for the traps... "Hmm, a giant ruby to bring home to the king."

3	"¡Uf!"

3	"That was embarassing.

3	Miss Storm saw me fall..." "And now I've fallen again!"

3	"I had better rest here before something worse happens."

3	"¡Chispas!"

3	"That's it, I'm leaving this place!"

3	"Why me?

3	Why?"

3	The Verdict: This is a fine set, a set whose bare parts/price ratio does not accurately reflect the intricacy of its design nor the rarity of its parts.

3	I had to buy replacements for some of them, and let me tell you, they are PRICEY!

3	That green baseplate?

3	$14.

3	The little dark gray saucepan near the fire?

3	Not available on Bricklink at any price.

3	The brown boat hull?

3	VHTF.

3	With this set, parts quality trumps parts quantity.

3	And the minifigures are wonderful!

3	There's not a dud in the bunch with the possible exception of the very common Dr.

3	Lightning, and even he is not bad.

3	When you factor in the coherence of the color scheme and the brilliant traps, it is obvious that 5986 is a classic.

3	10/10 Edited by WhiteFang, 27 November 2008 - 05:33 AM.

3	A well designed set, very playable with a lot of nifty traps, a very good use of that raised baseplate and really nice crafts.

3	I saw the instructions of this set, but never atracted me Until now A great set an a excelente review.

3	Thanks for reviewing this rare set!

3	Since it came out in 1999 I have only seen this set in a toystore one single time, one single copy as well...

3	It was in the summer of 1999 in Belgium (Arlon) in a store called 'Maxi Toys' (Belgiums TRu, I think).

3	They had the three biggest Junglesets for sale there: these Ancient Ruins, The set with the beautiful black boat and the zeppelin.

3	Being into Adventurers at that time I had never seen the entire Jungle theme (not even in a leaflet or catalog) and surprised as I was I bought all three sets.

3	That was one happy Dutch boy in Belgium!

3	Surprisingly the two smallest sets made it in very small quantities to my local stores in Holland (except for the pontoon plane and small raft which was my very first Shop at Home order).

3	The spider's secret I bought off BL, which makes me the proud owner of the entire Jungle Serie.

3	Back to the set: This was the first time in a long history of collecting Lego that I had a deformed piece: an 2x8 red plate was twisted, I twisted it back and it still serves it's purpose...

3	I loved the whole steam-idea in this Jungle serie: the two boats both (including the one in this set) had nice steamengines and a very cool mechanic (yours has the wrong hat/hair btw) to come along with them.

3	The skeleton falling down on the end of a chain was the most intriguing part of this set for me, it worked really well and when you were done scaring minifigures you could winch it up again ready for the next go.

3	The only thing I did not really like about this set was the difference in wheelsize on the car, front small, back large and the way the palmtree consisted out of just three parts... All in all a great set that is becoming more rare and expensive as we speak/post.

3	Get it!

3	Edited by sdpirate, 28 May 2008 - 01:06 AM.

3	VHTF= Very Hard to Find.

3	To answer some earlier replies... No, there are no stickers in this set.

3	While some Adventurers sets of the era had stickers (the 5956 Zeppelin had tons), all of the interesting mesoamerican designs from this set are printed.

3	Also, simonwillems was correct; my mechanic is missing his hat, which should be a black kepi.

3	They're extremely expensive on BL, though (proving once again that this set has some awesome parts), so I ordered a replacement from Lego.

3	It's in the mail and should come soon.
