3	Its like having a little beach fleet!

2	So i just piced up a new digital camera and i thought what better way to try it than doing a review of my newest set.

2	The new 7738 Coast Guard Helicopter!

2	itsmy first review, so go easy on me!

2	lets start off with the small stuff.

2	First the mini figs.

2	You get 4 figs total.

2	Two helicopter pilots, a diver and a civilan to rescue.

2	The torso's are nothing new on the pilot and diver.

2	Same ones as in the last coast guard line.

2	But i like the colors alot better in this coast guard line than the previous generation.

2	The yellow and blue really work well together and the coloring on the badge looks great!

2	The civilian looks to be just a dock worker with an overall torso and a beenie.

2	The diver has nice vented helmet and a pair of flippers that suits his duty perfect!

2	Next we have an absolute work of lego art.

2	The rescue raft!

2	The orange flaps can be moved back for easy entry to the raft, as well as the white "support" beams with the caution tape.

2	I put support in perenthaces cause they really don't support anything.

2	Just there to fill in the gaps.

2	At the top of the raft is a red locator beacon, ccommunications antenna, and a cargo loop for lifting the raft.

2	lets move on to the interior of the raft.

2	Not much here.

2	But you can see the techinc beam that attaches to the top loop,and to the floor of the raft.

2	So far this has proven to be very sturdy and has supported the full weight of the raft quite well.

2	You can also see the white box that holds the equipment of the raft.

2	Here you can see the life saver tube.

2	Here's a shot with our dock worker peaking out the side.

2	The raft says max ocupants 4, but with the storage box, that might be a tight fit.

2	Now lets move on to the Helicopter!

2	in my opinion this is one of the best helicopters TLC has come out with to date.

2	I really felt they captured the look and proportions of a real Coast Guard helicopter.

2	it uses a lower hull and tail section of the new airliner, and cargo airplane.

2	It really seems to work well with this application.

2	The engines have good detail using new "cheese graders" as vents, as well as the new engine stacks that come in the new speed racer sets.

2	The rotors also appear to be new as well.

2	lets move on to the cockpit.

2	We have two seats for our pilots with a sticker sheet for intruments on a flat 4 wide plate.

2	There's also an antena being used as a flight stick.

2	Another shot with our pilots at the helm.

2	Now lets moveon to the high lihgt of this heavy lifting machine.

2	The med bay, and lifting winch.

2	http://www.brickshel...icopter_020.jpg here you can see the winch arm at rest, along with the medical strechter.

2	The bad part is that the med.

2	strechter doesn't include the ussually included fold away wheels.

2	here's a shot with the winch arm extened ready for rescue!

2	In the second shot you can see the drum that the wire coils up in.

2	It coils up via a recently new power functions "pull" back motor.

2	To operate, just pull out the winch cable, hook on your load, and presse this orange button on the side...

2	The bad part of the new power functions winch is that although its very smooth in its operation, its not very strong.

2	It will only lift the raft a couple inches before it runs out of torque.

2	It also has a tendency to want to pull the crane arm backin while its lifting.

2	It doesn't matter if its a light load, or heavy load.

2	The bay doors open on both sides for easy postioning of the figures and accses to the strechter.

2	Here we have our diver looking over his rescue-e. Nice and roomy if you don't mind a crane arm being in your way!!

2	At $39.99 and a peice count of 445, i felt this set was a great good considering what your getting.

2	The raft construction is very creative and is probbly the highlight of the set by itself.

2	The helicopter is probbly one of the best, if not the best helicopter TLC has ever came out with if you can get over its size.

2	in a scale of one to five.... Price- Peice count- Playability- Design- overall- .5 I would have given it a full 5 out of five, but since the winch can't pull the raft all the way, it didn't fell it right.

2	Even with this minor flaw, i still highly recomend this set!

1	I'm rather fond of helicopters and have built many different types.

1	This doesn't really remind me of any particular model, other than perhaps an EH.

1	101 Merlin and even that resemblance is very superficial.

1	Just for the record: this is a Sikorsky Sea King and this is a Sikorsky MH-53 (a derivation of the CH-53).

1	The only resemblance I see with the former is the colour scheme and with the latter the fact that it's got a fat rear-end, sponsons and six blades.

1	It doesn't matter though, because I really like it.

1	The colour scheme is great, the shape is nice, it's got quite a bit of detail and I just have to get my hands on the cockpit window and those new rotor blades.

1	When I first saw the large aircraft pieces a few years ago I figured they were very much single-use parts, but the tail end doesn't look too bad.

1	Pretty clever.

1	I like the raft too.

1	It really does look like the real deal.

1	That the helicopter can't lift it really isn't an issue, because in real life they wouldn't lift the raft either.

1	They'd use the rescue hoist to lift the occupants of the raft into the helicopter one by one (or perhaps in pairs).

1	Imagine a storm with a helicopter hovering over tall waves with a big fat raft strung from a cable underneath it.

1	The raft would catch a lot of wind and flop around quite a bit, causing it to loose all its occupants and also yanking the helicopter around, possibly causing the pilot to loose control and crash.

1	Bad idea!

1	Cheers, Ralph Edited by Ralph_S, 30 May 2008 - 11:09 PM.

3	Much like many of my favorite sets, this one has a base of simple bricks and plates and then from that solid foundation the rest is built out to be decorative or have the action features.

3	This gives sets a very solid feel as demonstrated in this set, the first Snowspeeder, and Galaxy Explorer.

3	The MM Armored Drilling Unit has a more technic base giving it a less solid appearance and though I like the set, that jet that luanches from the back is horrible, partially because of the useless orange containment things.

3	Tohst, on May 28 2008, 04:55 PM, said: The MM Armored Drilling Unit has a more technic base giving it a less solid appearance (...) Yeah.... it´s pretty sad, some of these new sets just look very cool at the outside, but appear to be hollow and blank at the inside, especially with the annoying use of studless technic beams.

3	To MOD these sets often means to change the whole inner frame, leaving us with a bunch of IMHO not really very useful parts.

3	It´s not a very honorable marketing strategy to produce set designs that´re aimed to look impressive and cool on the box art, but´re pretty useless in their inner structures.

3	Of course I don´t want to offend some Technic lovers, and although I always was more the System kind of guy, why can´t they just use some technic beams with studs at least?

3	I grew up with 'just imagine', with pictures of alternative models on the box, and I don´t think it´s that easy, especially for younger kids, to MOD some of these terrific blown-up sets like it once was with sets like this one here.... Implosion off!

2	Asuka, on May 30 2008, 02:17 AM, said: Of course I don´t want to offend some Technic lovers, and although I always was more the System kind of guy, why can´t they just use some technic beams with studs at least?

2	That's because of cost.

2	The older beams needed a four sided mold, and the newer ones need only a two.

2	LEGO do seem to be using both types more as of late though.

2	Asuka, on May 30 2008, 02:17 AM, said: I grew up with 'just imagine', with pictures of alternative models on the box, and I don´t think it´s that easy, especially for younger kids, to MOD some of these terrific blown-up sets like it once was with sets like this one here.... Implosion off!

2	I've never heard an official word (...perhaps I should raise a topic...) but I think that they don't show them any more because it became a support nightmare.

2	What do I mean?

2	I bet TLG was tired of letters and calls saying "Timmy can't make this model shown on the box.

2	Can you send instructions and the extra parts..." I know that for some recent models they were designed but not published.

2	Sinner, on May 30 2008, 01:38 AM, said: That's because of cost.

2	(...) I've never heard an official word (...perhaps I should raise a topic...) but I think that they don't show them any more because it became a support nightmare.

2	What do I mean?

2	I bet TLG was tired of letters and calls saying "Timmy can't make this model shown on the box.

2	Can you send instructions and the extra parts..." Of course it´s a money issue.... my question was more rhetorical.

2	But I still don´t like how they sacrifice inherent set design on the altar of cost saving efforts.

2	To be even more correct, I don´t understand why they try to make extraordinary cool looking sets with a pretty weak 'inner life'.

2	Yeah, they want to sell sets with something that looks exciting on the box art, but.... LEGO was (and fortunately, is, with many recent sets too) always more than just an impressive spaceship or S.F.

2	tank vehicle.... it´s the sum of the set itself and its parts and what you can do with it that makes out the full fun of it.

2	The best thing you can do with a new set, beside some UCS sets perhaps, is to MOD the set according to your own likings.

2	This is where 'just imagine' begins, and how kids start to learn how to MOC, at least it was like that to me.... Individualizing official sets, and looking on some cool alternative models gave me my first ideas and helped my imagination and skills to grow, back in these days when I was a wee child.

2	Books, movies and t.v.

2	series as a source of inspiration just came a little later....

2	I can see many people complaining about how to make the alternative models, yes, but just stop using them on the box art´s a very poor solution and a dangerous one too, at least in long terms.

2	Of course I know that you know all these things too, Sinner.

2	I just think it´s a shame, and a risk too, because TLC´s perhaps sacrificing more than they might know by yet.... Building with bricks is the main attraction of LEGO, not just some cool crafts to play around with.... others can do this too and maybe better than TLC.

2	If the kids of today ever forget about the fascination of being imaginative, TLC´ll only lose in the end.

3	Harley & Mistah J. I want to preface my review by admitting that I’m an unrepentant Harley Quinn fanboy.

3	I’ve been enamored with the character since she first appeared in Batman: The Animated Series back in the 90’s, and I’ve since followed her misadventures through her introduction into the regular Batman series during No Man’s Land, into her own series, and even on the short-lived and not-so-good Birds of Prey TV show.

3	So please excuse any pro-Harley bias.

3	So, down to business.

3	The 267 piece set retails for $30 US ($35 at Toys R Us) and builds up very fast and easy.

3	It consists of Batman’s Bat Cycle, Harley’s Hammer Truck, and brand new Batman and Harley Quinn Minifigs.

3	There is also no lack of weapons.

3	In addition to the usual bag of Bat-accessories and guns, the set also comes with a pair of gray revolvers.

3	Batman in this set has the new “armor” torso print and the hips are the same color as the legs, hinting that this is supposed to represent the movie style Batsuits more so then the traditional comic book “underwear over tights” look.

3	Harley Quinn is a very cool looking Minifig, and I haven’t grinned so much at a new Batman character figure since my first Batman Minifig a couple years ago.

3	The figure is very true to the character, and the torso has been accented with a few shape lines to try and distinguish her as a female despite the boxy body.

3	Harley’s jester cap is an interesting new piece.

3	It seems (to me at least) to be made of a slightly different grade of plastic then we’re used to.

3	It’s molded in red and painted with black and white, and it comes packed in its own separate little baggie.

3	I expect that this piece may have cost LEGO a little more then usual to produce.

3	Harley also has a buildable accessory, a giant mallet.

3	Sure, she can’t stand up all that well unless it’s held in specific ways, but it’s neat and most importantly, it’s funny.

3	It’s especially fun for smacking the everloving crap out of other Minifigs with.

3	The Bat Cycle is in bag number one and is a very fast build.

3	This isn’t some little Japanese sport bike like Nightwing’s cycle.

3	This monster is almost a car and seems to pack just the right amount of intimidation for the Caped Crusader to exploit.

3	Thanks to the thick tires (two in front, one in back) it stands up just fine on its own and rolls very well.

3	The huge exhaust pipes are a nice touch and give the thing a look of engine power.

3	The only real flaw is the inclusion of the flick-fire missiles mounted on the sides.

3	But, as with any LEGO model, they can be easily left out without hurting the look of the vehicle.

3	The hammer truck is the bulk of this set and a lot more fun then it looks.

3	Of the monster truck persuasion, the vehicle is designed and built with a surprising level of solidity.

3	The axle mounts are particularly impressive.

3	The big wheels and tires just beg you to drive this thing right over the Bat Cycle (or Batman).

3	The mega-mallet gimmick is also a surprise.

3	Not so much for its technical complexity, there isn’t any really, but for the fact that once you start turning the knob at the rear to swing the mallet back and forth, it’s really a lot of fun.

3	There are some low points to the truck design.

3	Again the flick-fire missiles are tacked on and there’s a cargo crate/bed set into the back for Harley’s loot of jewels.

3	The crate would have looked a lot better molded in black.

3	In brown it breaks up the look of the truck a little.

3	Speaking of which, the look of the truck is very pleasing.

3	The red and black Harley Quinn color scheme works really well on the vehicle.

3	There are a few stickers here, and unfortunately, the diamond patterned ones are applied over multiple bricks.

3	The rest, however, are great.

3	Not only does she have an “I Love Joker” bumper sticker, but she has a Joker playing card taped to her dash, I guess serving as a picture of her beloved Puddin’.

3	There is also a sticker for activation of the hammer, which boldly shouts HIT ME!

3	This is a fun set.

3	A neat new Batman vehicle and a big truck with lots of playability.

3	The Harley Minifig is a must-have for any Bat-Fan and, if you only get one of the Batman sets this year, I’d recommend this one.

3	The price versus piece-count on this set is a little bit of a deterrent though.

3	This might not be the best set for collectors on a budget or people looking for something completely new and innovative, but anyone buying this for a child can rest assured that the kid will get your money’s worth out of the set through its play value.

3	When added together and averaged out, the pros and cons of this set combine to give it a score of out of 5.

3	Even if Harley herself is a clean 6 out of 5

3	Thanks for the review Deinonychus!

3	This is an awesome set, It may just be my first Batman set

3	Hi all, so I was at "The Wal-Mart" yesterday and had the munchies and was looking for something to eat.

3	Somewhere along the line, I stopped caring about food and decided to browse the toy department to see what they had Lego-wise.

3	Usually, they have jack squat, but on this particular day they had a lot of new sets.

3	I impulsively picked this set up, along with Harley Quinn's Hammer Truck and the new little campsite from the Indy 4 line.

3	I must say, when I first saw images of this set I wasn't exactly thrilled or anything.

3	I mean, I didn't really see anything particularly special about it, but after purchasing it, I must admit that I would consider it a must buy for any Lego fan.

3	But enough babbling about myself.

3	Onward with the review (my first of an official set)!

3	In this picture, you can see everything you get with the set.

3	I thought the box-art was pretty nice looking.

3	The manual, on the other hand, took somewhat of a beating within the box, a common problem with most more recent sets.

3	I do have to say that I wish they would at least make some effort in fixing this.

3	They could just make a little thin cardboard "folder" to minimize bending and tears.

3	For Batman minifig collector's, the highlight of this set are the Robin and Penguin figs.

3	Previously, you could only get them in the pricey Bat-Cave set, but this set provides a much cheaper alternative.

3	One thing you will notice, however, is that Robin's hairpiece is a new mold, as it is actually a black version of Mutt's hair (from the Indy 4 line).

3	Personally, I think it actually looks better than the hairpiece used on the older version of Robin.

3	As the Batcave had before it, this set comes with some bricks to make two cute (but deadly) penguins.

3	They help add more charm to an already charming set.

3	When you're finished building, you'll end up with a nice little assortment of extra parts; 1 black "cheese slope," 3 1x1 tile (black, yellow and white), a revolver, a technic pin, and a 1x1 red round plate.

3	Here's Robin's Scuba Jet.

3	It's nice and sleek looking.

3	Notable parts of interest would probably be the green turbine engines.

3	My only complaint on this one would have to be the use of decals on the 2x2 round yellow tiles.

3	For that type of a part, printing seems as though it would have been the best way to go.

3	Now for, in my opinion, the best part of the set...the Penguin's sub.

3	This set has more decals than Robin's Scuba Jet, but they seem more necessary in this case.

3	I actually wanted to put the decal's on the sub, as I think the it looks great with them.

3	Obviously, it looks like a penguin, but wow, does it ever do it with style!

3	It has a lot of interactive features, the first of which I will mention, being the periscope which raises up and down.

3	And for the collectors of parts in new colors, it has a few parts in medium orange?, such as 2x2 tile.

3	Here's a shot of the bottom of the sub.

3	Another nifty little feature is how you can lift the top off and fit the penguin inside.

3	And there is enough room inside, so that you can firmly place top on again, and without interference to the movement of the periscope.

3	Another little feature is the rear spring-loaded missile.

3	You just tilt the small lever toward the front of the sub, and it fires.

3	And the last small feature are the flick-missiles on each side.

3	Overall, this is a great set with a lot to offer for a decent price.

3	A lot of fans might view the only drawback to it as being the use of decals, but if you plan on keeping the kit together they make it look really fantastic.

3	Buy it if you can.

3	Matt Edited by imperialshadows, 01 June 2008 - 11:42 AM.

3	Awesome!

3	I am totally getting this set.

3	Good review!

2	Good day, gentlemen! )

3	Set: 8635 - Agents - Mobile Command Center Pieces: 1154 Price: $US89.99 Those dedicated Agents.

3	They've fought chainsaw-armed villains, battled radio-controlled cyborg crocs, chased pallets of badly-stored golden loot and wrestled killer sharks with vicious, toothy grins.

3	Finally they've caught the notorious Dr Inferno and imprisoned him in their cavernous Mobile Command Center.

3	But Dr Inferno won't go down without a fight!

3	Can the Agents stop the evil Dr 'Disco' Inferno fleeing?

3	Will Spy Clops laser gun burn through the door in time, or will Dr Inferno simply use the lovely Agent Trace's enormous ponytail as an escape ladder to freedom?

3	More importantly, will there be a riot in the streets of Lego City as AFOLs go apopletic at the thought of a 12 wide truck roaring through their ordered town layouts?

3	Stay tuned!

3	Part 1: The Box, Instructions, Parts As the largest of the Agents sets (so far), the box is easily the biggest.

3	Trainee agents, examine the following three pics and see if you notice anything odd.

3	Box front: Box back: Box middle: Spot it?

3	That's right.

3	The printed cardboard which has supposed to be the bottom half of the fold out middle section is on the back, slicing the ultra-large set image which would form the foldout in half .

3	The way the cardboard is printed as one piece before it's folded I think this would be very hard to do 'accidentally' so suspect a major stuff-up somewhere along the production line.

3	I bought this set off bricklink so would be very interested if anyone in the States who has seen these boxes actually on the shelves can tell me if this is common or rare.

3	Basically I want to know if I should be annoyed that the bricklink seller didn't list this in the set description, or are they all like this?

3	The instructions come in 4 booklets.

3	The parts list comes in at 5 pages, which is a lot even at half-size pages !

3	Large images of the parts inventory are in this folderwhen moderated for anyone interested.

3	Here's also some cute Agents-type artwork at the end of one of the books.

3	Instructions show piece call-outs and are divided into sections according to numbered bags.

3	As you'd expect for a set with 1100+ parts, this baby comes with a lot of bags.

3	It's a treasure trove of dark blue.

3	As well as the obvious large slopes and wall panels which make up the body and the roof, there is a wealth of smaller navy blue pieces as well - small 1x1 bricks, 2x2 bricks, 1x1 plates, 2x2 tiles, heaps of 2x plates, some slopes, 22x cheese pieces... basically anyone wanting a lot of dark blue should think about this set.

3	The roof panels alone, for example, could provide a dark blue sea for a modernised Pirate MOC.

3	2 DSSs (Dreaded Sticker Sheets).

3	Quelle surprise - stickers!

3	The grey parts of the stickers here are metallic silver ink, which is a nice touch.

3	Actually, as sticker sheets go, they're not too bad.

3	Fairly subtle for the most part and the navy blue actually matches the bricks themselves.

3	However, after looking at the sticker sheets I thought I was missing something.

3	What about the pieces used for the projection screens showing Dr Inferno and the sharks - why weren't they on the sticker sheets?

3	There must be another one!

3	Frantically I checked and rechecked the box and flipped through all the instruction manuals to find the elusive 3rd sheet.

3	Where was it?

3	Ten minutes later I noticed something which had honestly never occured to me - THERE WERE ACTUAL PRINTED PIECES IN THIS SET!

3	So obvious and yet so unthinkable.

3	It's horrifying how years and years of Exoforce and Speed Racer set releases can mentally condition people's thought processes.

3	Tut tut, Lego.

3	What have you reduced us to?

3	Here they are, folks - ACTUAL PRINTED PIECES.

3	(Yes, I do believe this news deserves the caps.)

3	I also noticed this nifty modification of the usual 2x3 cupboard - you can now fit drawers in it!

3	Very clever.

3	This may have been around in Belville sets for years for all I know, but it's new to me.

3	The drawers slide in and out very well and the top one sits on slight indentations in the middle of the cupboard.

3	Part 2: The figs!

3	Our trusty agents - Charge, Chase, Trace and Fuse.

3	(High powered agents don't have time for names of more than one syllable - that's why the bad guys always lose ).

3	Chase and Fuse have the Mutt hair in black and dark orange.

3	The lovely Agent Trace has an exquisite new hairpiece in dark brown, perfect for 'Rapunzel' themed MOCs.

3	As you can see, her ponytail is loooong.

3	Makes it hard to sit down, the poor girl.

3	I feel sorry for all these female figs with such intricate hairstyles that they can never relax in an ordinary Lego chair.

3	However, at least she has two breasts unlike the recent Harley Quinn fig.

3	Compensation indeed.

3	Seriously though, it's great that there's a separate torso print for the female character and this attention to detail is typical of the set as a whole.

3	Three of the agents have reversable heads - nice touch with the headsets and I like the ID cards on their pants.

3	Obviously the agents security system is based on some kind of crotch measuring device.

3	This would make sense considering the conspicuous bulges in the pants of Dr Inferno's men (see the other Agents set reviews.)

3	The villains - Spy Clops, Dr Inferno, Gold Tooth.

3	Dr Inferno's hair in all it's glory.

3	This is a great piece, although the orange colouring is a little rough on the front.

3	It's so 3D, it deserves a back and side view (and indeed EB thread) all of its own.

3	As mentioned elsewhere, this is different plastic to the normal minifig hair, but it doesn't quite feel as soft as the Exo-force hair.

3	It doesn't fall off as much, anyway.

3	The figs get 10/10 from me.

3	Awesome hairpieces in great colours for the Agents and a sleek navy blue/ neon green uniform.

3	The villains' faces are great and they are all very distinctive.

3	The attention to detail is outstanding and it's great to see a Lego in-house theme with characters as memorable and cool as figs from the licensed themes .

3	Part 3: The build The build is divided into three stages - the small vehicles, the front of the truck, and the massive command center section.

3	(a) Small vehicles First up, all the small vehicles.

3	We have a small flyer, 2 buggies, jet ski, and a speed boat - all in glorious navy blue with little bits of silver detailing.

3	Top view.

3	These vehicles are all simple, small and well-designed.

3	Probably the weakest is the flyer, only because the cockpit looks a little large.

3	In fact, the small flyer is probably the weakest element of 8365 overall, which tells you how good the set itself is!

3	In various threads here, this set has been heavily criticised for being way out of proportion.

3	There's a reason for that, as we shall come to.

3	However, the existence of these small sets should appease some people.

3	With the new coast guard sets, for example, all of these save the flyer wouldn't look out of place on a City beach with a little modding.

3	Here's an example - agents beach party!

3	(Spongebob couldn't help but crash.)

3	The villains only have one small vehicle, but they've been well-served in the smaller sets, and this one is a unique and clever design.

3	I love the triangular shape and the simple but clever technique of making the arch slopes meet up around the propellers.

3	It's sort of insectile in black and orange, and looks very different from the usual assortment of helicopters etc.

3	(b) Truck front This thing is a beast!

3	Seriously, look at it.

3	It's chunky and mean looking.

3	You don't want to mess with this baby.

3	The build is really nice.

3	Like a lot of Star Wars vehicles, it's all based on technic beams pinned together.

3	Unlike a lot of Mars Mission sets, underneath isn't ALL technic beams with some plates slapped on like a facade.

3	The majority is a lot of plates and bricks which all fit together solidly.

3	You can see from the detailing of 'cheese grater' slopes and silver pieces on the front how effort has been made to give this vehicle a distinct feel different to other Lego sets.

3	Sure, the silver slope mirrors might be a bit too much for some, but this baby is all about attitude.

3	You can imagine it roaring down the road en route to Dr Inferno's diabolical lair!

3	After all, these sets are 'Agents' sets - nobody said they were *secret* Agents (c ) Command center - whole assembly Here's a view of the whole thing assembled - inside and cool details to follow at the end.

3	It's kind of hard to show here as it is extreeeeemely long.

3	This is indeed a big set.

3	The build for the trailer part of the command center is fun and very satisfying.

3	Yes, there are large pieces but there is also a huge amount of detail.

3	It is also solid as a rock.

3	I remember being annoyed building the big Ferrari truck a few years ago - everytime you looked at it, an 8 x 16 plate fell off.

3	The Mobile Command Center is solid - even with the hinged roof and special features, it is not delicate at all.

3	Kudos to the designers, again as it is mainly a brick build rather than a technic one.

3	I also like how the command center part connects to the cabin - it's not a special piece at all, just a technic axle going through two circle plates, but it works and it's solid.

3	(Please note I've been selective about which stickers I've applied during the build.)

3	Top view: The rear: Here's an example of why I like the build: (a) the designers have enough sense to put a ladder so a minifig can climb up to the interior when the command center is open (b) notice that although the ladder clips at the top, there is an *extra* clip there in the middle purely to hold it in place so it doesn't flap around and holds firm.

3	I don't know if most designers would even think to put a ladder there let alone go the extra mile and put a mechanism to hold it in place.

3	Pure class.

3	Oh, and notice the greebly detail stuff to the right there too.

3	The other side.

3	This is probably the other weak part of the build - the bricky gaps at the top where the hinge to open the roof sits.

3	It's a little gappy but the set is so big you don't really notice.

3	(d) And now for the fun stuff - inside and neat details!

3	OK, so we've built the thing.

3	It's big.

3	It's blue.

3	The top of the trailer itself would make a good warehouse MOC for a harbour layout.

3	But what about inside?

3	Is it any good?

3	What about all those small vehicles from the start of the review?

3	Where do they go?

3	Well, I'm glad you asked.

3	Because the solution is superb.

3	The small flyer folds slightly and slides into place here: Lift off the roof and you're away!

3	The large buggy and the speedboat go under here: The jetski slides out of the rear here, attached to its own little platform: And the small buggy goes inside the main cabin.

3	There's even a crane so you can lift it down.

3	So now we know why this set is so large!

3	To fit everything in!

3	It's amazing that this functionality doesn't affect the aesthetics of the set as a whole.

3	But we still haven't finished on the details.

3	The front section has a very easy-to-swing-open roof section and missiles: There's also a command section underneath the bit where the flyer lifts out: And now for the interior.

3	I have to say I really like this space.

3	Not only is it packed with great stuff, there's also enough room for minifigs to move around.

3	I hate bases where the figs only have about 2 studs to actually stand and walk.

3	Aquabase Invasion is a nice set, for example, but the actual functional space inside the base is teensy.

3	Claustrophobia!

3	You know within a week they'd be fighting to toss each other out of the airlock.

3	No such problems for these suave Agents, who have plenty of legroom *and* the ability to launch missiles from their ceiling.

3	The whole of the interior: Zooming in: Moving from left to right.

3	First off, the medicine cabinet.

3	Looks like someone's been leaving secret mission dossiers lying around.

3	The projector area for mission briefings.

3	Dr Inferno recently changed his hair colour from purple to orange, it seems.

3	Why are all these minifigs so obsessed with their hair?

3	The projector folds down when the trailer is open.

3	Push the button and the light glows on.

3	Now Dr Inferno's hair is orange again!

3	This is one of my favourite parts of the set.

3	It works a charm.

3	The batteries for these lightbricks can also be replaced - instructions are in the manual.

3	Agent Charge considers shark-fin soup for dinner.

3	Did I mention these projection panels are printed?

3	The detail is very fine too.

3	The tool section.

3	Laptops sit in the middle compartment.

3	You get some flippers, yellow scuba tank and various implements.

3	I'm so impressed that the helmet is pearl silver with a different coloured visor too - there's so much variation in the parts in this set, you don't get the sense the designers are using the same thing over and over to save money.

3	It all feels luxe and top-of-the-line, just like the Command Center itself.

3	Two laptops - yay!

3	The aforementioned rooftop missiles: The Dr Inferno cage.

3	Nasty electric shocks!

3	Bzzt!

3	(You can see my reviewing skills are burning out now - sentences.... truncated...) Another example of detail - nowhere else in the set is a 1x1 transgreen tile used - they could have used a 1x1 trans green cheese wedge piece as there are others in the set, but they didn't.

3	How does Dr I get out?

3	Flick that lever on the right hand exterior and the door pops open.

3	Spy Clops the loyal minion awaits his master on the other side.

3	And there we have it.

3	Take a bow, guys!

3	There's a lot of spare parts.

3	A suspicious amount of dark blue small slopes but I checked the instructions and didn't see anything missing.

3	I have to say, I do like the new policy (since Speed Racer I think) of including these small slopes as extras.

3	Part 4: Overall Rating If you've made it this far, you've got more stamina than Dr Inferno's army of cyborg animals themselves!

3	As I said earlier, this set has drawn criticism for the size of the truck.

3	However, large vehicles do exist - I grew up in a wheat farming area and as a kid the size of the lorries that thundered past carrying grain was probably intimidating to me as this monstrous espionage machine is to the good citizens of Lego City!

3	On top of that, it *does* contain a plethora of 4-wide vehicles inside !

3	Criticism of this set on the basis of size to me also seems misguided as this is basically a playset - and it is a very good one to boot.

3	As you can probably tell, I love it to pieces and wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to anyone, whether for parts or for play value.

3	Check out the parts list in this folderwhen moderated and you can see just how many excellent pieces it contains.

3	A light-up brick, a flood of navy blue, metallic silver bricks - we're spoiled.

3	8635 is also an enjoyable build, with fantastic figs and top-of-the-line detailing.

3	In a year when I've found City a bit disappointing after the run of great sets in 2006-2007, the Agents line has been one of the surprise hits for me and I can't wait to see what the designers come up with next.

3	Thanks for the amazing review!

3	7645 - MT-61 Crystal Reaper Piece count: 600 Price: $AUD79.95, 49.95 Euros (in most countries), 39.99 GBP, USD 49.99 It's happened in the wider world, and it had to happen to Lego - yes, the 80s are back.

3	Space invaders, holograms, compulsory seat-belt wearing legislation, and the return of classic Space.

3	Ok, we don't have a fully fledged classic space theme back yet, but if 7645 is the way of the future, I think Lego is ready to do it properly.

3	I wasn't a huge fan of last year's Mars Mission sets and only picked up a few on clearance, but this set is light years (excuse the pun) ahead of 2007's offerings.

3	This mining vehicle is solid, compact, and well-designed.

3	It looks impressive, and even better, it has fantastic Power Functions operability!

3	Behold 7645 - MT-61 Crystal Reaper!

3	(PS I wasn't joking about the holograms or seat belts.)

3	Part 1: Box, Instructions, DSSs (Dreaded Sticker Sheets), Parts Front of box: Back of box: 2 x instruction booklets: DSS numero uno - for the Reaper DSS number two - apologies for the blurry pic but I wanted to capture the sweet shimmy of the metallic holographic background on this sheet The way it catches the light really makes a difference to the small alien craft and makes it look much more interesting from the plain stickers of last year.

3	There's heaps of spare silvery stuff once the stickers are applied for those who use the leftover sticker material for customising.

3	Parts bags - 4 numbered with one extra with larger pieces Parts everywhere - woo!

3	I know the Lego instruction books scold me if I mix bags, but I'm a devil-may-care kind of guy.

3	In your face, TLC.

3	I love mixing all the parts together before I build, it reminds me of my youth when the days were long, anything was possible, and I didn't need strict instructions not to build on grass or poke my eye out with a technic shooter.

3	Interesting parts - these may or may not be new, my technic knowledge is not that detailed.

3	The little scoop parts are so cute and have a heap of potential uses.

3	I love 'em.

3	They're like Smurf hats at Miniland scale.

3	These technic wheel things in orange are also cute.

3	They kind of remind me of marigolds.

3	Giant Fabuland marigolds!

3	The track pieces - you get 70 of these - here's the section of track for one side - as you can see it's about 52 studs long.

3	These hold together better than the small ones on the Hailfire Droid/ Jungle Cutter.

3	Part 2: Minifigs, small mining transport, alien ship I have to confess - I forgot to take an individual snap of the astronauts .

3	It's the usual bunch though - Scaredy Face guy, Sunglasses in Space Man and a third one I can't remember.

3	You don't really care, though?

3	You're only interested in the alien commander and his matching arms/ legs combo deal.

3	As brickbitz noted in his review of the smaller set, the glowy eye is just a 1x1 cylinder.

3	The set also comes with 2 normal jellies - one pictured here for size.

3	You'll see what happened to the other one soon enough...

3	The alien craft is nothing exciting, apart from the gorgeous glinting stickers.

3	Here's the road safety angle.

3	The commander actually clips onto a 1x2 plate with handle so he can't fall out!

3	Then the lime tentacle thing descends on top of him to keep him firmly there, like a baby seat.

3	Not very brave for an alien commander, is he?

3	I mean, did Darth Vader ever use a seatbelt?

3	Tssk.

3	With cradle up: This part of the build also includes the small astronaut mining buggy - small and effective.

3	(Please note in this build I've applied stickers to everything bar cockpit pieces.)

3	This comes with radio and saw piece.

3	Part 3: The Reaper!

3	The first part of the build is the detachable shuttle.

3	I really like the retro aesthetic of this with the angled wings and the side hoverpod things.

3	It is much better than the comparable vehicle from 7699.

3	The new flickfire piece is a waste of space - it's fairly limp.

3	I prefer the simple flickfire technic pin to be honest.

3	There's also a very nice little side workshop as you can see.

3	I really like how the control unit is 'plugged' into the wall via 5 1x1 round plates (third pic, it's a bit dark).

3	Great detail.

3	[The technic pins on the back are there to connect the Power Functions battery box.

3	It's odd they're included at this stage of the instructions - maybe the intention was to release it originally with all the necessary motors etc but the price point was too high and they scaled it back] The base.

3	The shuttle sits on that bley technic axle in the middle when the Reaper is fully assembled.

3	The little vehicle scoots down the ramp at the rear, which folds up to hold it in place when the Reaper is in motion.

3	You can see there's a crystal container here as well - another nice small detail which I found the 2007 sets lacked.

3	There's also an alien here - thankfully not in those horrendous trans-orange tubes so prevalent last year.

3	The complete assembly.

3	Isn't it snug?

3	It's just the right size too - not massive but large enough to be a serious mining vehicle.

3	The ominous black treads contrast nicely with the white/ orange colour scheme of the vehicle itself.

3	The trans detailing - blue for weapons, neon green for energy - is carried nicely through the whole set.

3	The blades and the scoops whirl nicely as the machine trundles along.

3	Top down view: Tread detail: Whirling blades of death!

3	The buggy descends: Probably the most disturbing aspect of the whole set is this pic: The jelly has an orange pump plugged into its heart which is connected to an energy supply on the left hand side!

3	This vehicle runs on alien jelly juice!

3	Either that or it's milking the jelly in some equally disturbing fashion.

3	How amoral is that!

3	I know there's been debate about this - the jellys aren't innocent, they're evil energy crystal thieving maniacs etc - but I find it a bit odd that the humans respond by chaining the jelly up to the bowels of their mining vehcile and suck energy from its heart.

3	People debate about violence in Lego as represented by realistic minifig weapons, but I think the moral lesson here is even worse - it's OK to exploit foreign life forms for our own gain if they treat us badly first!

3	(Who-fans, I think the Ood should have a word with the jelly Commander ) That aside, this set is well-designed and fairly good value at $AUD79.95.

3	It's definitely a notch above last year's Mars Mission sets overall, with improved detailing and more useful functions.

3	The holo-stickers are fab and it's nice to have an alien commander, even if he is a bit bulky and his fingers are identical to his toes.

3	However, if all these reasons by themselves weren't reason to recomend this set, the following is.... Part 4: Power Functions The best part of this set - and the reason I bought it, really - is the integration of Power Functions.

3	Bizarrely this isn't mentioned at all on the box and I only found out about it from the instructions when they were posted on Eurobricks!

3	(Instructions for book 2 which has the Power function stuff available here.)

3	This is a great idea and hopefully we will see more new sets take this kind of approach (especially with the new Train sets).

3	Luckily I got Monster Dino 4958 on sale for half price earlier this year so already had most of the necessary motors etc - the only one needed was an extra small one.

3	What you need is listed in the instructions below with redirections to Shop @ Home to buy the motors.

3	Note there's actually a mistake on this page.

3	The 2 small motors you need are both 8883 not 8882 (which is the large XL motor).

3	Way to confuse the kids there, Lego!

3	Attaching them was a dream and only took a few minutes (In contrast to 4958 where it was almost impossible to remove motor elements without dismantling the model).

3	Basically the back platform and some plates and orange slopes come off, you attach the motors, and then the smaller plates go back on.

3	These parts are now left loose: Overall the look of the Reaper isn't badly effected as you're mainly viewing from the front anyway: Sadly I can't show you how it moves, you'll just have to trust me that it does !

3	The way it is steered is demonsrated in the instruction pages above.

3	Basically each motor is controlled by a corresponding switch on the remote.

3	Move them both forward to move forward, move one right to turn right, move both back to move back etc.

3	It zips along!

3	It's a speedy little thing!

3	Personally I wouldn't want to be in it's path as it comes roaring down the Martian canyon!

3	(My cat was scared as it was.)

3	It is oodles of fun and definitely worth trying if you have the motors or can get them cheaply, and adds a whole new dimension to the 'play' aspect of 'playset'.

3	It is also as I said very quick to switch between modded and non-modded Reaper in contrast to the more fiddly Dino creations.

3	The only problem I had is that if it moves too fast, the weight of the battery box at the back tends to pull the whole thing back and it rears up.

3	It does correct itself though.

3	I only trialled this on carpet last night so it may behave differently on other surfaces - I will need to experiment!

3	Part 5: Summation This is a great set made even better with the addition of Power Functions.

3	At $AUD79.95 it's well-priced.

3	Buy it!

3	Buy the motors as well (K-Mart still has stock of 4958 at $89, wait for a 15% off sale)!

3	You won't regret it.

3	Buy 2 and make competing battle machines!

3	The only thing is... just don't torture that poor jelly Edited by Sinner, 24 June 2008 - 03:25 AM.

2	The description, you'll understand later.

2	I ordered this off of S@H last tuesday, and oddly enough, it's listed on S@H as MX-81 Hypersonic Airplane...

2	I'd like to apologize for the random, horrible, faded pics.

2	I took the review outside, and the clouds kept shifting, changing the lighting, and then I had to go inside because it started raining.

2	It's been raining for a week.

2	It's raining now, as I type this.

2	So, I foolishly went outside to take pics.

2	The front of the box.

2	Not bad, as far as boxes go.

2	It features a lift-up tab... ...which shows the various functions.

2	Back of the box.

2	Still not much to say... Two manuals.

2	I think this is just right- Not too thick, but not too many manuals, either... Oddly enough, the box came with a little folded up piece of paper telling us not to mix the bags.

2	It comes sorted into 4 bags, by the way.

2	Minifigures The set features 3 normal MM figs, 1 normal jellie, and one of the new commanders.

2	I really like this guy.

2	He has a few issues, like his hands being stuck sideways, and still being hollow, but still a great improvement.

2	He'll make a lovely addition to any Halloween MOC.

2	Stickers The set comes with a fairly big DSS for the Spacecraft.

2	Pretty normal, but I do like the dragon sticker.

2	Then, suprises of suprises, a technicolor sticker sheet for the aliens!

2	How cool is this, huh?

2	The tops of the actual stickers are shiny, which is hard to see in the pic.

2	Even the bottom is shiny!

2	Who said stickers can't be cool?

2	The mining craft The little guy is pretty cute, and well built.

2	My only gripe is that there's nowhere to spin the drill!

2	It seems so lifeless without a feature...

2	The alien craft You'd think a Commander would be important enough to have a seatbelt, rather than be stabbed with a clip and stuck on the ship like those other grunt aliens...

2	I think this thing has some potential.

2	Shiny stickers, different body shape.

2	And when you look at those engines, this thing could be an alien Corvette!

2	But then you look at the back.

2	Pretty bare, no flares or anything.

2	It's a cool little craft, but it just...lacks.

2	The modules These things have some potential, as well.

2	With some modding, they could be pretty cool.

2	Unfortunetly, it's pretty boxy, there are no engines, and the wings are too small.

2	The top is pretty nice, though.

2	The greebles are all right.

2	The controls, as usual, are a sticker.

2	Pretty spacious, mind you.

2	The cockpit doesn't stay flush with the body, though.

2	The front plate underneath it can be easily replaced with a brick to fix that.

2	...I'm not gonna comment on this.

2	The main body Too bad.

2	The 'labratory' isn't much of a lab.

2	A trans-red panel and some tray thing are all that compose the 'lab'.

2	I was expecting more, but true to form, this Mars Mission set has no impressive interior to speak of.

2	There is a lot of space, though, so it shouldn't be hard to mod.

2	Phew!

2	The lab folds up like so.

2	Pretty simple, and would allow access to the lab, if there was one.

2	And then we have this thing.

2	What is it?

2	Defense laser?

2	Communications array?

2	Satellite T.V.?

2	The modules connect like so (sorry, out of place...): Too bad the pins stick out...

2	Various pics... As you can see, this thing has more of those bars than an AT&T commercial... (There, you understand the topic description now? )

2	The rear.

2	It uses a white City plane wing for the...wings.

2	When I first saw the prototype pics, I thought they slanted downwards... That would've been really cool.

2	Ah, now to the platform.

2	From the position of the drill, I think this could be a really cool turret location when I MOD it to more military space.

2	Back to the bars.

2	If we had space monkeys, they'd love this.

2	This set has more bars than a jungle gym.

2	( ) Here we see the button that drops the platform.

2	Pretty clever, and it's not in the way.

2	Best of all, it really works!

2	Really well, actually.

2	Good job, TLC.

2	2 more bars and a shooter mechanism.

2	Jeeze, this is really setting itself up for a joke.

2	A shooter mechanism walks into a bar... Never mind!

2	Here we have the handle that allows you to pick it up safely.

2	A good idea, but it's placed waaaay to far back, way off the center of balance.

2	You have to hold on to it pretty well to keep it angled up, though it does stop your hands from getting in the way of the platform.

2	Ah!

2	The platform in action.

2	This is really a neat little feature.

2	Not only can the ship land in a reduced footprint, but it also prevents the nice white paint job from getting red dust all over it...

2	It's centered pretty well, too, and you don't have to worry about knocking it over, just don't shove it back at all.

2	Here we have the latch.

2	When the button on top is pushed, this gets pulled inward...

2	...Which pulls out of this hole and allows it to swing neatly down.

2	Good luck, and happy mining!!

2	Again, sorry for the lack of in-progress review.

2	I would've liked to take pics of the mechanism and so on, but typical of the MM sets, you can't really take it apart.

2	Well, this is really a nice set, which can hopefully be upgraded with a better lab with little difficulty.

2	Some of my military mod plans include: -Strip the lab and install a command center -get rid of lots of bars.

2	The thing has more bars than Alcatraz.

2	-Install some turrets.

2	This is a big command ship, so why all the forward-facing weapons?

2	It'll need some AA defense... -mod the landing platform to be a troop dropper with installable AA turret.

2	-mod the cockpit pods to be more aerodymic.

2	So, that's all folks.

3	It seems even like it´s easy to attach them to some kind of Cloud City Twin-Pod Car thanks these hinged wings.

3	Looks like some solid fun to me.

3	Of course.... the cockpits aren´t airtight and even this reminds unfortunately of the post blue, grey and trans yellow era of CS.

3	Anyway, there´s no real fun without some MODing I guess.

3	One technic shooter, cool in grey and only one trans orange prison pod too.

3	The drill rover´s very charming, a little like a rebuilt Oldsmobile Convertibe stranded on Mars.

3	Sweet!

3	And that platform feature´s plain nifty and well done too, very playable and useable for a lot of things.

3	Hmm.... recently I complained a lot about the dense use of studless technic beams for the inner structure of vehicles like these ExoForce tanks par exemple which makes MODing (in an economical way) pretty frustrating.... but the beams here´re used in a very proper way.

3	It should be fairly easy to MOD, let´s say, the back of that lab section up to perhaps even the cockpits to create a larger airtight area that could be boarded from the platform.... just to fit this certain spacers need for, um, realism.... There´re many more nice details too like that 'satelite t.v.'

3	thingy and that cylinder with trans blue 2x2 dish for the knob or these cylinders with cones on that handle, and that Alien craft´s pretty nice and detailed as well.

2	Hello SheFOLS and AFOLS, as well as TFOLS, welcome to EB News Reviews, I am your host...For tonight anyway... Shadows will take over after this episode, if we make more... Today we are reviewing Mars Impulse sets 5616 and 5617.

2	Starting with 5617 Alien Jet, I must say it is a small and quick build, the jellie, is made of hard plastic, which surprised me, as I had expected Jellies to be a soft plastic.

2	The jet is mainly 2x4 plates, some swingy hinges, the "seatbelt" and a thing which I cannot seem to name My one gripe about it is that the Jelly cant see where he is flying, it looks better with a MF in it.

2	There was a red 1x1 as a spare part.

2	We move on to the 5616 Mini Robot, which is basically a "safe" brick, with binoculars, soem cheese slopes, little arms, and legs.

2	The best part i must say was the metal detector and "safe" brick, as these seem to be quite rare in sets (By my knowlage anyway).

2	The austronaut has a face, shown in Dr. Sinsters review.

2	The set also comes with a pick-axe and lime green gem.

2	Extra peices where a cheese slope, a green 1x1 and a white droid arm.

2	That concludes these mini-reviews.

2	I also will use this opportunity to show my photo setup.

2	Both sets are reccomended, if you either need a army, or are just trying to get a variaty of figs like myself.

2	Hello all Eurobricks members, I will be presenting my first review on one of the Harry Potter's set.

2	Firstly, I must emphasize that I am not a very big Harry Potter fan or owned many Harry Potter sets.

2	For this review, I will be highlighting what is the beauty of this small little set, and the reasons to own multiple sets of it.

2	Comments and critics are strongly welcomed.

2	This set is featured in the Harry Potter movie, Prisoner of Azkaban.

2	This set is orignally released in 2004, align with the Harry Potter's movie.

2	This was actually one of the movie scene where Buckbeak the griffin is appeared in the movie.

2	The group of students are supposed to be having up close and personal with him.

2	However, Draco decided to disturb our lovely Buckbeak.

2	Enough of this movie synopsis, I am sure fans of Harry Potter will know this better.

2	Box art Featured mini-fig/creature Background scene The scene is a simple garden, which had a very good mixture of spare parts for your MOCs building.

2	On its own, there is nothing outstanding about this set, except for the griffin.

2	You can buy multiple sets for the griffin alone and for Draco mini-fig.

2	Well, you don't need lots of Draco.

2	But for Castle lovers, black cap are exceptionally useful, at least from my view.

2	Now, I will point out the following why this sets is so great for other reasons.

2	Hidden cover Note that, this is the only mechanism which you can find in this set.

2	It looks rather simple but quite useful.

2	There are some little things hide in it too.

2	Greens, Foilage and Brown parts Needless to say much, it offer 3 foilage, a green plant, 3 brown slopes, 2 ideal bricks and 1x1 brown brick for building a tree.

2	Great for jungle building, forest building and etc.

2	I am sure there are many builders will look out for these.

2	Interesting parts It comes with a wizard book, owl, 2 printed tiles with a spider and stone prints on it.

2	The far right, seriously I don't find any good use for it.

2	Can any EB members enlighten me on that gray thing on the right?

2	Grey parts It comes with a good 10 x 4 green plate.

2	Useful for adding as a platform.

2	Some more grey slopes for your MOCs.

2	There you have it, Draco encounter with Buckbeak comparing with Deep Forest Ambush As you may remembered recently, there was an impulse set competition.

2	One of my entries, which is under the History theme.

2	The Deep Forest Ambush was firstly inspired by this set, and made an improvement out of it.

2	Look at the improved tree compared with the orignal.

2	Summary review Playability: 4/10 (Not much to play with, except swooshing around the Griffin) Design: 5/10 (Too simple and its defintely not related with the movie scene) Parts: 10/10 (Great for parts, explained by the review.

2	A great deal of green and brown parts) Price: 9/10 (An inexpensive set based on the 2004 pricing) Overall: 7/10 (A must have for all Harry Potter fans and collectors whom needs a great use of green and brown parts) Hope everyone of you enjoyed reading this simple review of mine.

2	More pictures can be found in My Brickshelf (When moderated) Let the Potter magic begans!

2	The far right, seriously I don't find any good use for it.

2	Can any EB members enlighten me on that gray thing on the right?

2	The gray thing is technically a plume, like any castle plume, except in this case it's a feather (presumably from the griffin), and made from the mold to the old Indian feathers in the Wild West sets.

2	It's a case of an old part coming back for a slightly new use, in a new colour.

2	Beyond that, the "stone print" tile is a bundle or rolled up blanket or package, depending on where it's used.

2	I don't think it's ever meant to be a stone.

2	It was used as a rolled up pack on the back of the Star Wars speederbikes, for example.

2	Nice pics, plenty of useful information.

2	I'd give this review an A+ Thanks for doing it!

3	I own about 6 copies of this set!

3	This is one of the few sets I've bought more than one (2!)

3	of.

3	It has a really good selection of pieces, and your review really does it justice, WhiteFang.

3	Multiple Hippogriff/Griffins On!

3	Hello EB!

3	Yes, I'm cranking out the reviews!

3	The other day I picked up this gem for an okay sales price at Devonport, Tas, while searching for the new Batsets.

3	I informed iamded of this as he is a Spidey-suckup ( ) and he informed me this was the only set he didn't have of the Wave 2 of this theme.

3	So I ask you great EB members to please remind him of this when commenting!

3	Here we go with the review of Doctopus' lair: Anyway, unlike other reviews, this stars more people, the Batbrick-iamded-dragonator-Daisy review!

3	(Daisy is the mouse that came in the set) First up re the figs, and I must say they are great.

3	I love fleshies and these are excellent to expand my Batman world, plus having a Spiderman to beat up is good too Doctopus is great, though his tentacles are annoying to keep in order.

3	Peter Parker is a nice addition, I love that torso.

3	Eve though Harry Osborn was totally absent from this scene, I welcome him as he is a good fig also.

3	Best of all is Mary Jane, fleshie females are hard to come by and I love that hair, my very first one!

3	Oh, and even better is bley Daisy on the far right: Another fantastic thing is that by mixing MJ with Doctopus you get a far more deadly and real villain than anyone could've forseen - The Hippy!

3	Oh c'mon, tell me that ain't cool?

3	Anyhoo, here is a pic of Doctopus showing his might: Random fact: Did you know I influence both dragonator and iamded in their sigfigs?

3	dragonator adapts his from my IA series while iamded added Mutt hair when I had him like that in a pic I posted.

3	Now onto the box, sorry about the lighting.

3	The art is good and the cartoon spidey in the corner may have beenthe inspiration for a similar style in the new Batsets: Back of the box.

3	Again, sorry about the lighting and blur, it was gtting late and these were the last pics: Finally we get to the first part of the set: The catapult.

3	Is that movie accurate or what?

3	I love the part in SM2 when he uses his homemade genetic spider powered catapult to launch himself to the scene!

3	Oh well, it does comes with a cool spider web an trans blue spider, so it gets some points: And it is really fun!

3	I launched spidey several metres once, I don't think he ever recovered.

3	Infact, he almost certainly webbed himself Slightly cooler extras are these two.

3	This awesome little boat is great for city, as is the simple but nice bouy, Daisy approves: Naturally dragonator ruins everything when he found out the "dragon" that would be riding with him was our nickname for Daisy Now finally, the main attraction - Coctopus' Dock.

3	iamded and I threw dragonator in the water to see if he could swim.

3	He er, couldn't One Sweeney todd later, we continue!

3	The overall construction of the building is very good.

3	I know a lot of people hated stickers and i hated applying these, but they do look spectacular and perfect for any City setting, like a bank, a Gotham Bank As iamded has already noted below me the black lifesavers a very cool as are the web piece and log pieces: The inside contains the neutron copperplate triple bypass humdrum holy hum 5000, which does does, see movie.

3	Anyhoo, it is very cool, and includes a little control thingy on the yellow brick next to it.

3	Unfortunately, the inside is plain but for that: The other side has no wall too which is a bit of a letdown really, but atleast it allows Daisy easy access.

3	one gripe is those yellow 1x1 bricks, they serve no purpose and break up the colour scheme: Better shot of the thingy thing.

3	I quite like it, the use of technic parts actually works, and the whole set is worth it for those purple flames and dishes alone It closes up pretty well too, unable to hit the dish which is a nice feature: Me and iamded liked it so much we threw a revived dragonator into it.

3	Unfortunately it disagreed with him, but it was fun: Another shot of the dock.

3	I like how they have gaps in the jetty, I know the movie version was pretty wack, and although the set isn't very faithful to it (looks more like a seaside library to be frank) it still is very nice.

3	This is my first large blue baseplate too which is wonderful, though funny how the set only uses about half of it: The roof is a well designed and fun feature, it uses some technic connections to render it flexible of any degree, as you can see here by my opening of it: Better shot of the roof design, it can lie flat or at any angle.

3	I might use the design myself in the future: As much as I love the building this feature bugs me, for in order for it to work this wall has to stick out, which not only looks ugly but makes you be able to see through the corners.

3	Still, easily modded, and log pieces are fantastic for mocing.

3	It also means that there are 7 windows all up for a good, sizeable building: By pulling out the piece in the center the walls both collapss sideways outwards, which is actually pretty fun and works everytime: Overall view of the set including characters: Now for the story that makes no sense....at all: Spiderman is dead after falling down the wall mechanism (see above): Only Daisy can save the day!

3	For dragonator is being held by the evil Doctopus!

3	And iamded and dragonator are too busy not caring!

3	And Brainbox is too busy complaining that this goes against all Marvel continuity!

3	Unfortunately Daisy is on a lunchbreak so tough luck dragonator: And Daisy goes on a search for fortune and glory: Okay, this is what I think of the set: Build: 3/5 - Fun, but those stickers ruin the experience somewhat, and if you don't apply them the instructions are a bit hard to follow.

3	Playability: 4/5 - Great little gizmos and bits, not the kind that keep you going like with the 2007 Aquabase, but good fun still.

3	Design: 4/5 - Not very movie faithful no, but still a great little building and a smart design for certain aspects.

3	Minifigs: 5/5 - Great figs with all different faces and very useful bits.

3	Price: 2/5 Far, FAR overpriced even on sale sadly Total: 18/25 - A good set that could've been better with a few minor changes.

3	Nothing wrong with it, but it doesn't really cross the line to greatness.

3	That said, it has a lot going for it and definitely worth buying or atleast a look!

3	Thanks for reading Batbrick Away!

3	Hi Everyone, Please note that this review was done back in 2006, so do forgive me if you happened to notice any dated comments.

3	Product: 6205 V-wing Theme: Star Wars No of pieces: 118 Release Date: Feburary 2006 RRP: SGD29.90/USD9.90 Availability: Lego Shop@Home, Target, Toys 'R' Us (US & Europe), Bricksworld (SG).

3	Lego.com said: Rule the spaceways!

3	The sleek V-wing fighter can adapt to any situation!

3	Position the wings and flaps in attack mode to protect Palpatine's shuttle from enemies.

3	Or position the wings in flight mode to survey the area for intruders!

3	Either way, the V-wing is ready to strike for the Republic.

3	Includes Clone pilot and R4 droid.

3	Position wings in attack or flight mode!

3	Sorry to all for the delay, since this was supposed to be done 3 days ago.

3	Anyway, to get on with it... Quite a minimal amount of baggies for this set, as noticed.

3	And the best thing is... no sticker sheet.

3	Yippee!!

3	:bounce: The completed v-wing.

3	Though not really a complaint, it would be nice if the entire astromech body was provided instead of only the head dome.

3	:p Of course, then it wouldn't be movie-accurate, since the Q7 series astro-mech is integrated with the starfighter.

3	:lol: He's definitely well-painted for a simple mini-fig.

3	Since even the back is painted too.

3	I have to assumed this is the same mini-fig provided for 7259 ARC-170 Starfighter too, since I don't have that set.

3	Anyway, this mini-fig is much more accurate for this v-wing since his suit is rated against vacuum, while those in the arc-170 aren't .

3	:p One thing that's lacking is the instruments panel in the cockpit... it's totally non-existent here.

3	I wonder what went wrong during the design stage.

3	Personally... this is the second most anticipated set for 2006, the first being the tie interceptor, for me.

3	One thing is that there's no known release of the V-wing starfighter by hasbro, nor the other well-known brands.

3	The other thing is that being a star wars vehicle collector, I would really loved to see a replica toy of the V-wing.

3	And the V-wing by the Lego Group does not disappoint... it's nearly movie-accurate, except for the cockpit transparisteel cover which could used some paint like the x-wing's.

3	Also, there's a permanent landing gear that quite neat, since it allows you to land the craft on uniform surfaces.

3	The s-foils on the other hand can be quite a pain to pose into flight position.

3	Very difficult for the s-foils to remain symmetrical during play.

3	The "swoosh-able" or play factor of this product is quite good... just check out the pics for yourself... :D *Crackle* General Skywalker, we have incoming!

3	To conclude, the v-wing starfighter would make a much better companion to the Eta-2 Actis Interceptor (Jedi Starfighter), than the arc-170.

3	Coz the arc-170 seems more like a long-range bomber to me, than a snub-fighter.

3	:p And a final pic to show it at rest...

3	Comments (For 2008) Just an updated pic to show my latest display on the clone wars Hmm... off the record, I do understand that sometimes, reviews by most tend to a certain set of guidelines like naming the set, and showing the boxed, and out of boxed pics, and of course, the grading portion.

3	Regarding my review, I prefer not to grade any of the lego sets at all as far as possible, because to each, his/her own.

3	My reasons to put up a review is not to belittle the efforts of TLG in coming out with these products nor to help them market them, but to show my appreciation and enjoyment of these products.

3	I hope noone is offended by this, and would like to apologise for any misunderstanding that this may caused.

3	For those who do not understand the above paragraph, care not for it and Play On!

3	Here's the 3rd of the whole batch of complete reviews done back in 2006.

3	Hope you guys enjoy them so far.

3	Product: 6206 Tie Interceptor Theme: Star Wars No of pieces: 212 Release Date: February 2006 RRP: SGD39.90/USD19.90 Availability: Lego Shop@Home, Target, Toys 'R' Us (US & Europe), Bricksworld (SG).

3	Lego.com said: Challenge the Rebels!

3	Blasting out of Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi, the TIE Interceptor is the fastest fighter in the Imperial fleet!

3	Open the cockpit canopy and fold down the instrument panel to put the TIE pilot inside and recreate your favorite classic Star Wars battles!

3	Includes TIE fighter pilot!

3	Cockpit opens and instrument panel folds down!

3	It does seem to have more pieces than the average tie fighter, but this is actually cheaper than the 7263 TIE Fighter.

3	Of course, there's no light-up feature in this set.

3	:sweat: YesH!!

3	Finally... A...

3	Tie Interceptor!!

3	This is probably the most anticipated for all set for all lego tie collectors worldwide, since the fighter, bomber, advanced, and even the Expanded Universe droid fighter had been released by the Lego Group.

3	This set is near movie-accurate, since the bottom part of it ain't.

3	:p The cockpit and pylons uses the same design as that of the tie advanced piloted by Darth Vader.

3	Except for one minor change, that is the aft interior of the cockpit is strengthen this time.

3	And this is indeed good news, since the older models had a problem of hard hinge and loose brick connection.

3	There's no landing gear for this set, but it doesn't require it anyway.

3	This tie interceptor balances perfectly on its wings.

3	Standard instruments panel and, of course, standard imperial pilot.

3	The "swoosh-able" or play factor of this set is definitely very high... Just take a look.

3	:D *Camera view from own craft* *Camera view from Tie-Advanced* *Combat simulation of Endor's Battle from the archives* No bomber, since I started late in re-collecting.

3	:p To conclude, for a typical lego fan, this set is a 60/40, 60 due to it's good design, and for a typical star wars fan, this is a must-get.

3	The only flaw for this set is the same flaw for any lego set in SG, the price.

3	:doh: Comment(Current in 2008) Being a starwars fan... no... being a typical toy collector, space is definitely a premium... so much so that I turned to lego starwars to sate my appetite for more starwars products when I already have no more display space.

3	For the next few non-lego pictures, they are the crown of my starfighter collection in 1/18 scale.

3	So just view them for fun, eh?

3	And no, I haven't had the chance nor the time to do up a scene of my lego starfighters blowing up spectacularly since the pieces would be very hard to put back... Hmm... then again, isn't that what lego is about.

3	"doH".

2	Haven't gotten this set yet but now I might Edited by Vaders_son, 18 June 2008 - 12:45 PM.

1	I picked up this set mainly because of the many (5+spare) glow in the dark parts and the promise of 2 racers and one helicopter for the price of a little more than two racers (90kr.

1	vs.

1	2x40kr.)

1	The box The back of the box shows the two alternate models you can build if the polybags rip.

1	There are 3 cheese slopes and two 1x2 tiles that glow in the dark, where the tiles are exclusive for this set.

1	The total parts count is high at 142, but there are no really big pieces among them.

1	Inside the box you will find the building instructions, a sheet with some odd sticky labels (thrown away) and 3 polybags marked by the bag building difficulty.

1	The models The lime colored car doesn't bring out anything new.

1	We have seen racers built like that before, but it does contain some nice bricks for the collection.

1	The police cruiser surprises with an interesting design along the sides as seen here.

1	It is harder to build because of the greater level of details: The helicopter is without doubt the hardest vehicle to build in a bag.

1	I can't finish it because it's larger than the bag.

1	You can't put on the top blades nor the tail of the thing, so it beats the forklift from 7733 where the top bar is the new kind that doesn't completely fit.

1	There is also instructions for the alternate models, but it requires the bags to be opened...

1	The vehicles are pretty standard for the racers theme with the police car being the highlight of the set Conclusion I like the difficulty curve between bag 1 and 2, but the last bag should be labeled 1000000 instead of 3.

1	It requires some inhuman skills to build that helicopter in the bag... ?

1	Lime colored car: 3 - We have seen it before, but it has some nice pieces... and lime.

1	Police Cruiser: 9 - It has a massive diffusers, rare parts and a high level of details.

1	It is a shame LEGO relies so much on stickers.

1	Helicopter: 6 - if you see it as a set for one fourth of the price of the cars, it is quite amazing, but you can't bag build it and I would personally prefer some more detail instead of the big size.

1	Overall it is a nice little set, but the police car is the main attraction.

1	I wouldn't get the other vehicles if they were sold separately.

1	Seeming as there were no reviews of this set in the index I have uploaded mine from Jabbas Hutt .

1	Here is my review for LEGO set 10178 Motorized walking AT-AT Because I live in the UK I got this set with 6 free duracell batteries which was great!

1	(It's just twice as expensive as the US) Heres the basic set that is from the instructions.

1	This is the cockpit but please note after I took this photo I realised it was slightly built wrong.

1	Heres one of the feet in proportion to a minifig to give you a general size.

1	This is Luke Skywalker swinging on a wire trying to destroy the AT-AT I really wish LEGO didn't make so many Luke's because I want differnt minifigs.

1	It would also be nice for a thermal detonator piece.

1	Underneath the AT-AT you can see the shaft that moves the back legs, the motor and squeezed in on the righ t the massive battery box.

1	A load of cogs that move the legs.

1	These are the included figures Snowtrooper, General Maximilian Veers, AT-AT Driver/Pilot or whatever you want to call him and Luke all whithout there wepons.

1	please note Veers should have a dark stone snowtroooper torso with 4 red and blue badge things not 3.

1	These are the figures with weapons I gave them and the included ones Snowtrooper has new style blaster, Veers has Standard light grey pistol like the ones from the old adventure sets, AT-AT driver has old style blaster which I call heavy Blaster and Luke has SHINY HANDLE blue Light Sabre .

1	The Shiny blue light sabre was included with the set which is a bonus because i really dont like the grey ones.

1	http://www.brickshel...sc00521.jpg.jpg This is the switch which is attached to the battery box on either side of the AT-AT underneath the lift up side panels.

1	you push the forward to walk forward and backward to walk backwards simple eh .

1	A front veiw with the the panels open.

1	Here are the Drivers controls which are simply a cotrol panel and 2 exo-force robot hands which are joystick things seen in the film if you look closley.

1	The almost useless carry handle.

1	This is the weird back piece.

1	Looking down the AT-AT from the back where you can see the the battery box and switch.

1	Troops decending from ropes and cables and Vader leading the assult for this I hadnt got any more imp's so I used Clones Pilots.

1	(I now have a whole load more snowtroopers) Solo and Chewie sabotaging.

1	More troops to squash rebel scum huzahh!

1	A very bad picture of everyone packed up inside.

1	The size incomparison to its predecessor Overall I would give this set 9/10 because it should come with more snowtroopers or it could be and Endor version with loads of strormies and scout troopers.

1	Aswell as this you can really sit any one down because of the battery box but I stilll find space to put all the shown figures on this review in the interior as you can see on the above image the chains and ropes are hanging down a bit.

1	Tjis set is now limited to 5 per customer in the UK and now no longer comes with free batteries.

1	The walking on this is a bit wonky and dosen't really walk like they do in the film as it moves two legs at a time.

1	I am currently attaching a motor to the head to make it move independently.

3	nooooooooooooooooooo..........." and on that note, let's start the reivew of the UCS DEATH STAR II.

3	Now this is an older set (2005) and I've only gotten around to buying it a short while ago.

3	It took me around 2 evenings to build it and I must say that I am fairly impressed by this set.

3	Time for a box pic: The Build: Since I started building this huge (small moon size) set at Morten's appartment, I wanted to keep as few polybags open at any given time as possible.

3	With this set it is actually possible to have a minimum of bricks scattered over a table or two while building.

3	Not sure why, but the division of bricks in the different polybags just work very well.

3	And that is great with a set this size - 3441 bricks.

3	The building of the set is divided into several "Build this times x".

3	For example the upper and lower part of the "unshielded" DS are completely alike.

3	This is difficult to see when looking at the model, but heaven when building it: And this is how they solved the problem of having the wings connected to the buttom of the Death Star - geniously done IMO: Note that in the first pic the "skeleton" is easily seen.

3	"The skeleton" holds the X to which both the upper and lower part is "clicked" on with technic pins.

3	Also there's a steering wheel (I'm sure there's a pirate name for that ) like the one in the bottom, in the top of the model to hold the upside "wings".

3	So after having build duplicate wings (upper and lower), the "belt" (all the way around the star) and the upper and lower part of the "unshielded" side, it was time to step back and watch the Death Star II in all it's glory: Such a great UCS set.

3	Now I did have a few "huh's" during the build: HUH!

3	#1 In the instruction the technic lesser-dragon-head should be dark grey, but I got it in light gray.

3	Go figure and thank you replacement parts.

3	I've experienced this before and apparently TLG uses different colours when "out-of-stock".

3	All one has to do is call them and ask for the right colour and it's on it's way Still a HUH!

3	experience.

3	HUH!

3	#2 Again it appears that TLG changed the design of the technic axleholed 1x2 bricks.

3	The bottom has changed and I got the set where it was mixed up between "old" and "new" version.

3	Not that annoying, but still got me perplexed as to: "Am I doing this right?"

3	Kinda stressing to consider taking most of the star apart to check the remaining 231 technic bricks 1x2 with axlehole.

3	Now for a verdict: : 1: looks great 2: even my "wife" likes it - female appeal 3: it's a great build 4: the polybags work for you 5: it's Star Wars 6: the design is awesome : 1: it wobbles if you touch it 2: very small parts come off, if you touch it 3: parts come off when you try to move it somewhere safe 4: zero swooshability So in short (yes even shorter]: The DSII is a well designed UCS set that has a great design.

3	Like most other UCS sets, it is not meant for play - hence don't play with it.

3	UCS verdict (the numbers) 5/10 (design++/instructions+-/bricks+-/sturdiness--/colourscheme+-) design: awesome look and great greeble set instructions: easy to follow steps with bricks mentioned hard to see wether it's black or dark grey bricks: loads of great bricks a zillion bricks of the same type sturdiness: DON'T TOUCH colouscheme: grey in grey with a little touch of black Need a missing instruction?

3	Then click the logo
